column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q4 2010 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

"
column6:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chief Executive Officer
column8:
Director and Member of Executive Committee

"
column9:
"

Charles Noski - Chief Financial Officer

"
column13:
"

David Hilder - Susquehanna Financial Group
column16:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets & Co.

"
column18:
"

Edward Najarian - ISI Group Inc.

"
column19:
"

Meredith Whitney - Meredith Whitney Advisory Group LLC

"
column20:
"

Christoph Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.

"
column21:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (NYSE:USA) Inc.

"
column22:
"

Matthew O'Connor - Deutsche Bank AG

"
column24:
"

And welcome to today's teleconference. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the program over to Kevin Stitt. Please begin
column27:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Chuck Noski begin their comments
column28: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column29:
and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations.

"
column31: among other things
column32: changes in economic conditions
column33: changes in interest rates
column34: competitive pressures within the financial services industry and legislative or regulatory requirements that may affect our businesses. For additional factors
column35:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column36:
"

Also joining us this morning will be Neil Cotty
column37: our Chief Accounting Officer. And with that
column38:
let me turn it over to Brian.

"
column40:
"

Thanks to all of you and good morning. We know this has been a busy week for all of you and thank you for joining us on a Friday. Before Chuck takes you through the quarter
column41: I was going to give you some perspectives and provide some thoughts about the economy and the priorities we have for 2011. I'll stay mostly with the key-takeaway slide on Slide 4 and touch on a couple of other slides
column42:
and then turn it over to Chuck to begin on Slide 9.

"
column43:
"

As we think about 2010
column44: we came in to the year with a focus on continuing to clean up the issues left over from the crisis
column45: while continue to driving the franchise forward. Finishing integration work in Merrill Lynch and Countrywide and continue to simplify our business model. During the year
column46: we made progress in many of these items. In the area of credit
column47: our improvement has been strong. Charge-offs have now improved for seven consecutive quarters and yet there's still room to improve here. We continue to see improvements in delinquencies at this quarter and of the last few quarters. The underwriting changes we made in 2008 across all the products with Credit Card
column48:
Home Equity and First Mortgage are performing better than we would've expected when we made those changes in those years. This ought to hold us in good stead as we move towards 2011 in terms of credit.

"
column49:
"

On the credit side
column50: we released reserves of $7 billion during 2010
column51: and while we know this is not core earnings
column52: it helped offset some of the cost of representation and warranties about $7 billion
column53: no litigation costs and other matters during the year. But even without release
column54: our reserve coverage ratio of 1.6x annualized charge-offs is the highest this company's had in many
column55:
many years.

"
column56:
"

We also identified the non-core loan portfolios and began to work those off out of the company. As we showed you
column57: that's about $130 billion at the start of the year
column58: now it's down around $100 billion. Now the good news on the loan side as the franchise is driven forward
column59: we are starting to see stability in the core loan balances that we want to carry-forward for this company. We've even seen some modest growth with some of the areas. Our utilization rates
column60: for example
column61:
and our commercial rate was stable in the fourth quarter from quarter three and that bodes well for 2011.

"
column62:
"

As we think about capital
column63: we ended the year with questions around it especially given the fact that the new Basel Rules are starting to emerge along with the other changes in adopting Basel II and the fed market risk rules
column64:
et cetera. We told you at the beginning of the year we need to hit targets of 5.5% to 6% tangible common equity ratios and 8.5% to 9% tier 1 common ratios under Basel I by year end in order to have the capital to run this company. This represents the view that we have that the risk capital we need to run the company. We achieved both of those goals this year.

"
column65:
"

We've also started early to make good progress to mitigating the changes that are going to come about in both capital and risk-weighted asset measures that will come with the new Basel Rules. This gives us strong confidence that we have a clear path meeting all these rules as are adapted in staying above regulatory minimums during the next couple of years as they come through. And even during that period
column66:
we have the ability to pay dividends and do stock buybacks over time as approved by our regulators.

"
column67:
"

During the year
column68: we also focused on our franchise. And what we mean by focused
column69: we sold non-core positions and businesses
column70: 20-some units overall
column71: netting $19 billion proceeds
column72: at the same time fulfilling the commitments to our TARP repayments and streamlining the franchise and focusing on the three core customer goods and the core products for them. In addition to that work
column73: we redesigned the consumer account strategy to deal with the new regulations that came in 2009 and 2010. As you read in the press
column74: we patterned our new account structure to mitigate the revenue loss from these regulations and still provide strong customer choice. By providing that choice and the changes we've made
column75:
we've seen dramatically lower attrition and complaints and account closures on our consumer businesses.

"
column76:
"

From the shareholders side
column77: our stock did underperform
column78: and our returns on equity returns and returns on assets are not where we want them and continue to be affected by one-time events. But during the year
column79:
we did successfully grow our tangible book value per share by 15% and we look forward to driving that forward in the future.

"
column80:
"

By far
column81: the biggest legacy issue we continue to deal is on the mortgage side. On Pages 7 and 8
column82: we highlight some of the changes that Chuck will talk about
column83: some the rep and warranty put-back issues later. But let me summarize on the key elements. As we entered the year 2010
column84: a lot of the operational work is around the modification area and building up the teams due to foreclosures. As we move through the year
column85:
discussions around representations and warranties started dominating the discussions.

"
column86:
"

This year we took a total of $7 billion of representation and warranty cost that offsets the revenue and significant portion of our mitigation expenses here was also due to mortgage issues. We are pleased to put the GSEs behind us this quarter as we announced on January 3. We'll continue to focus our efforts in protecting our shareholders regarding these matters as we deal with the other counterparties involved in representation and warranty and put-back issues. When we think about modifications
column87: our efforts continue to build. We did 285
column88: 000 modifications during 2010
column89: including 76
column90: 000 during the fourth quarter alone
column91:
the most in the industry. We completed our review of the foreclosure practices. The process is working. And we've restarted the efforts cautiously. We'll continue to face regulatory and other scrutiny here but the work is proceeding and we are very focused on doing this right for all the parties involved.

"
column92:
"

During 2010
column93: we also completed a milestone of $2 billion of merger integration work. The next quarter will actually complete the final touches on the Merrill Lynch integration. And for the first time in many years
column94: we'll have no integration work to do in this company. What that gives us the ability to do is turn that energy and focus to managing our efficiency in the company towards simplification
column95: including that
column96: we'll be taking our four deposit systems during 2011
column97: 2012 to one deposit system and many other like activities. Our expense levels are not where we want them right now. They are higher because of debt collection and other costs related to legacy issues. But if you think about what we've been doing in managing expenses
column98:
we continue to invest in the franchise while managing through the post-crisis issues.

"
column99:
"

To help you think about that
column100: think of the headcount in the company. During the year
column101: our headcount has up by about 3
column102: 000 people. We dedicate almost 13
column103: 000 additional people to the mortgage issues and foreclosure modifications and collection areas. We've invested 2
column104: 000 people in growth areas
column105: about half in the wealth management in other areas in the United States and about half outside the United States. That means the rest of the franchise is effectively down about 10
column107:
000 people. So we continue to manage cost while we deal with the legacy issues and invest for growth and that's how we'll continue to run the franchise during 2011.

"
column108:
"

While the work was going on and sort of repositioned the balance sheet capital in the franchise
column109: the core business has continued to progress. First
column110: our job is to drive the integration as franchise to bring the combination which can do better than anyone of our business as a standalone business could do. If you look at the Appendix
column111: Slides 33 and 34
column112:
you can see some of the evidence there.

"
column113:
"

Our Card business turned to an operating profit this year from a $5 billion loss last year. Our deposits performance was challenged by the lowest straight environment and the regularly changes as improving customer scores and our share deposits continue to grow on the retail side even giving effect to our disciplined pricing strategies. Our deposits now cost $1 trillion of Bank of America for the first time.

"
column114:
"

Our Wealth Management business has seen strong growth
column115: both in assets under management flows
column116: assets under management deposits and we see long stabilized net business. We've made good progress in hiring financial advisors
column117: wealth management bankers and other client base and teammates. The group has produced a solid profit
column118: including record revenue
column119:
in the fourth quarter of 2010 and still has lots of great opportunity ahead.

"
column120:
"

Our Global Commercial Banking business
column121:
our minimum market and small business banking business recovered strong earnings and returns this year as credit normalized and our market-leading position showed their strength.

"
column122:
"

In our global banking and markets area which with large corporate investment banking and the trading and capital market activity
column123: we maintain our number 2 position on Investment Banking business throughout the year. Our investment banking fees from third parties were the highest this quarter they've been since we merged with Merrill. Our sales and trading revenue team had a solid year but we have varied results by quarter
column124:
going from a high of $7 billion in revenue to a low of around $3 billion. We're satisfied with the year in total but we need to work at the ups and downs and Chuck will take you through some of the details on that later on.

"
column125:
"

But as we think about 2010
column126: we made progress. We stayed with the lines of balance sheet and capital and you can see that on Slide 6 and some statistics on the balance sheet statistics given there. We did loss $2 billion for the year 2010 and $1 billion in the fourth quarter
column127: both of those numbers we are disappointed with
column128: but with the year came large ins and outs and they're all new and driven by legacy issues which we continue to put behind us
column129: $12 billion in after-tax goodwill impairment
column130: $7 billion in representation and warranty and put-back costs as a counter to revenue
column131: $3 billion in litigation expense
column132:
nearly $2 billion in emerging restructuring charges and other charges like that and those of course were offset in part by the $7 billion in reserve releases and $3 billion in asset sales.

"
column133:
"

We clearly need to continue to reduce the ins and outs and what the core franchise performance comes through for you
column134: our investors. As we look to 2011
column135: the priorities are clear. We are going to make progress of putting the mortgage operational issues behind us
column136: meaning modifications
column137: foreclosures and related process improvements. On the representation and warranty and put back area
column138: we're going to continue to make progress only if we can do it on a basis consistent with our shareholder interest. But our best guess is this will take a longer period of time
column139: perhaps a few years. We're going to drive the core customer businesses
column140: integrating this powerful franchise we leave to each customer. We are going to drive our expense management during the year
column141: ensuring that we get the expenses out of here as we continue to recover in the mortgage and other credit-related costs. And importantly
column142: we're going to deliver on the growth opportunities on our franchise
column143: be it wealth management
column144: the asset customer base and the consumer area
column145: the investment banking and in the area
column146:
all 29 states and abroad and we'll continue to invest in those businesses as we did in 2010.

"
column147:
"

As we look to 2011
column148: we see the economy continuing to recover. All the key metrics we see in our customer base that we monitor externally like you do
column149: including the credit demand
column150: consumer spending especially spending among middle-class and affluent clients
column151: the debt burdens at households are caring
column152: the asset quality portfolios
column153: all of those are pushing ahead. We still face
column154: however
column155:
the realities of high sticky unemployment in this country and a slow and stagnant recovering in housing and modest overall U.S. growth.

"
column156:
"

In this context
column157: we'll continue to drive towards delivering shareholder returns by continuing to grow our tangible book value per share as we materialize in recovering the franchise. We continue to believe we're in a position to modest-increase our common dividend in the back half of 2011
column158:
but of course we need our regulators' approval to do so. So we still have a lot to do.

"
column159:
"

But at the same time we have the best franchising industry
column160: with number 1 and 2 positions in every product area
column161: largest customer client base in the industry. We can't and will not lose our focus on levering this franchise as the economy improves for you
column162: our shareholders. We have a clear strategy
column163: to serve three customer groups with our core financial needs in the best way that any provider can do. We have a well-defined operating principle which we've laid out for you that enables to meet that strategy and we continue to execute against them. 2010 was the year we repaired the balance sheet. We built some of the capital ratios and reserve ratios and also tough but necessary decisions as we focused on cleaning up our legacy issues. But as the economy continues to improve and we continue to execute
column164: I have every confidence the franchise will keep moving to the performance it's capable of. Finally
column165: I want to thank our 290
column166:
000 associates. The tireless efforts they made during 2010.

"
column167:
"

And I'll turn it over to Chuck starting on Slide 9.

"
column168:
"

Charles Noski

"
column169:
"

Thanks
column170: Brian
column171: and good morning
column172: everyone. As you can see on Slide 9
column173: we reported a net loss of $0.16 per share for the quarter. Our results reflected the non-cash and non-tax deductible write-down of $2 billion or $0.20 per share of goodwill associated with our Home Loans and Insurance business that we discussed on January 3. Excluding this goodwill impairment charge
column174:
earnings were approximately $750 million or $0.04 per share after preferred dividends. Results for the fourth quarter reflected the positive and negative impact of several items which makes for a difficult comparison this quarter.

"
column175:
"

If you turn to Slide 10
column176: we've listed some of the larger items. Representations and warranties expense from the fourth quarter was $4.1 billion
column177: of which $3 billion was associated with the GSE settlements we have previously described. The credit mark on structured liabilities under the fair value option resulted in a negative adjustment of $1.2 billion
column178:
reflecting the tightening of our credit spreads compared to a negative adjustment of $190 million in the third quarter and as reported in other income.

"
column179:
"

Asset sales during the quarter included our partial ownership in Blackrock
column180: reducing our ownership from 34% to 7%
column181: the sale of our rights to participate in CCB secondary offering and the sale of the majority of the Global Securities Solutions business. We had $872 million in security gains during the quarter. We already touched on the goodwill impairment charge. Excluding fees paid to external legal service providers
column182: litigation expense for the quarter was $1.5 billion
column183:
primarily related to our consumer businesses including the Mortgage business.

"
column184:
"

Merger-related and restructuring charges were $370 million
column185: loan loss reserves were reduced by $1.7 billion in the quarter versus $1.8 billion in the third quarter. And finally
column186: we had a tax benefit of $2.4 billion
column187: primarily reflecting the pre-tax loss before the goodwill impairment charges
column188: the release of a capital loss carryover valuation allowance of about $1.2 billion
column189:
and normal tax preference items.

"
column190:
"

Turning to Slide 11
column191: you can see that four of our business segments made money in the fourth quarter. Deposits lost money due to increased litigation costs this quarter and was also affected by the full impact of REG E and continued low interest rates. Global Card Services benefited from improving credit quality and reported $1.5 billion in net income. Global Wealth and Investment Management had a very good quarter
column192: earning $332 million
column193: due primarily to a near-record quarterly revenue levels driven by market activity
column194: strong long-term client flows and a shift to the mix of assets towards higher margin products. Home Loans and Insurance were significantly impacted by legacy costs
column195: including the goodwill impairment charge
column196: reps and warranties expense and litigation costs. Our first Mortgage Banking business however
column197: excluding these costs
column198: was profitable in the quarter. Global Commercial Banking earned more than $1 billion this quarter as credit quality continued to improve and has delivered stable revenue through the cycle
column199: reflecting strong client retention. Global Banking and Market showed continued solid results in investment and corporate banking
column200:
offset by a difficult trading environment in global markets.

"
column201:
"

Let's turn to net interest income on Slide 12. Net interest income on an FTE basis was $12.7 billion
column202: essentially flat with the third quarter. The impact of low rates and lower consumer balances
column203: excluding residential mortgages
column204: were offset by positive hedge income of $250 million
column205: increased balances in the discretionary portfolio and a reduction in long-term debt. Our average earning assets for the quarter were up $20 billion
column206: mainly due to growth in consumer loans and securities. Cash declined due to a shift in liquidity mix from cash to liquid securities in addition to a net reduction in our outstanding debt. Consumer loans increased due to retained mortgage originations. Commercial loan demand stabilized in the quarter. And as we said earlier
column207: average commercial loans
column208: excluding real estate
column209:
were up 1% from the prior quarter.

"
column210:
"

Although we were flat with the third quarter
column211: we expect net interest income to decline over the next couple of quarters. In the first quarter of 2011 in particular
column212: we expect net interest income to drop from fourth quarter levels due to fewer days in the quarter
column213:
continued declines from our loan run-off portfolios and an anticipated reduction in hedge results. We expect to see stabilization in net interest income sometime in the second half of the year. We're also on track to lower our long-term debt footprint by 15% to 20% by the end of 2011 relative to third quarter 2010 levels.

"
column214:
"

Slide 13 shows you that both average loans and deposits were up for the quarter. Deposits remains a good story of growth as wealth management clients continue to do more business with us and commercial customers continue to prefer to hold rather than invest cash.

"
column215:
"

On Slide 14
column216: you can see that period end loans from the end of September were up approximately $6.5 billion due to growth of almost $17 billion partially offset by net charge-offs and decreases in our run-off portfolios. We have a slide in the Appendix that details our run-off portfolios for you. The $17 billion increase in total loans was driven by residential mortgages
column217:
primarily FHA-insured originations as we use some excess liquidity and C&I loans offset by a slight decrease in commercial real estate.

"
column218:
"

Turning to Slide 15. Card revenue was up 7% from third quarter results due to 12% increase in interchange income. Increases in retail spending were 4% versus the prior quarter and 5% versus the prior year. These increases helped drive the increase in interchange income. And on the managed basis
column219:
Card revenue was relatively flat from a year ago despite the impact of the CARD Act.

"
column220:
"

On Slide 16
column221: we show service charges were down $176 million from third quarter levels to $2 billion which is the number we targeted for you two quarters ago. The decrease was due to the approximately $275 million impact of Reg E this quarter after becoming effective midway through the third quarter. So now that the full impact of Reg E is embedded in our results
column222:
you can use this quarter's results as a base going forward. Remember though that the full impact from both Reg E and the CARD Act wasn't reflected in the quarterly results and service charges in Card revenue for the first three quarters of 2010.

"
column223:
"

Other regulatory impacts that will affect service charges in 2011 are the Durbin amendment which is scheduled to occur in the last half of the year. We expect this would cost us approximately $1 billion in revenue. We won't know the expected impact on debit card at interchange though until late April
column224:
so we hope to update you on that during our first quarter earnings call.

"
column225:
"

While expect to mitigate some of the impact over time
column226:
we do expect the impact of mitigation efforts will be modest in 2011.

"
column227:
"

Mortgage Banking revenue on Slide 17 decreased from the third quarter
column228: as a result of higher reps and warranties expense which includes the impact of the GSE agreements and additional accrued liabilities. MSR performance net of hedges was $257 million this quarter
column229: an increase of $347 million compared to the loss last quarter. Although production volume in First Mortgage at $85 billion was up from the third quarter
column230: production revenue was down due to lower lock volumes and production margins. The capitalization rate for the consumer mortgage MSR asset ended the quarter at 92 basis points versus 73 basis points in the third quarter. Given the direction of interest rates since Thanksgiving and the redeployment of some of our salesforce to assist with our distressed customers
column231:
we forecast production levels will be lower over the near term.

"
column232:
"

Turning to Slide 18. You can see the total reps and warranties expense in the quarter was $4.1 billion
column233:
up $3.3 billion from the prior quarter. Much of the increase was the result of our recent agreements with the GSEs. The liability we have accrued on the balance sheet increased approximately $1 billion to $5.4 billion as the $4.1 billion representations of warranties expense was partially offset by approximately $3 billion in charge-offs and other activities.

"
column234:
"

As you can see
column235:
our unresolved repurchase requests totaled approximately $10.7 billion at year end. This amount includes $1.7 billion of demands contained in the communication from private label securitization investors. We believe these investors do not have the contractual right to demand the repurchase of loans directly or the right to access loan files. The inclusion of these claims and the amounts reflected in the chart does not mean that we believe these claims have satisfied the contractual requirements that would permit them to direct the securitization trustee to take action or that they are otherwise procedurally or substantively valid.

"
column236:
"

Outstanding claims were reduced by $2.3 billion driven by the resolution of $8 billion of claims during the quarter
column237:
including $4.9 billion as part of the GSE agreements. Monoline claims outstanding continue to grow as the monolines continue to submit claims and are generally unwilling to withdraw these claims even when they have given evidence refuting the claims. The increase in rescissions in approvals in the fourth quarter were substantially impacted by the agreements with the GSEs.

"
column238:
"

We've included slides in the Appendix that update the information we presented earlier this year on our GSE experience.

"
column239:
"

On Slide 19
column240: we provided additional information around our experience with non-GSE counterparties which would encompass whole loan sales and private label securitizations
column241:
including those where monolines have insured some or all of the debt.

"
column242:
"

On Slide 37 on the Appendix we break down our non-GSE experience
column243: much as we did for the GSEs. As you could see on Slide 19
column244: from 2004 to 2008
column245: $963 billion of loans were sold into private label securitizations or through whole loan sales where we believe we have originated reps and warranties exposure. We broke out the originations for you by both legacy entity
column246:
as well as product to give you a bit more clarity on the portfolio.

"
column247:
"

Through December 31
column248: repurchased claims received on the 2004 to 2008 vintages totaled $13.7 billion. $6 billion on those claims have been resolved and as you can see
column249: resolution success and rescission rates are much higher with private investors versus the monolines. The losses under result claims were approximately $1.7 billion. Of the remaining outstanding claims
column250:
$5.8 billion have been reviewed and declined for repurchase.

"
column251:
"

Moving to Slide 20. Of the $963 billion of original principal balance
column252: 22% have defaulted or are severely delinquent. 58% of defaulted or severely delinquent loans made at least 24 payments prior to default or delinquency. As we have indicated previously
column253: in those instances where we have had meaningful and consistent repurchase experience with counterparties such as the GSEs in certain monoline insurers
column254: a liability for reps and warranties has been established for asserted and unasserted requests to repurchase current and future defaulted loans. With the exception of certain monoline insurers
column255:
we have not had meaningful and consistent repurchase experience with other non-GSE counterparties. We do evaluate all of the certain claims received from all parties in establishing our liability.

"
column256:
"

However
column257: as we and others in our industry have noted
column258: analysts and other market participants have developed their own estimates of possible exposure for Bank of America and other institutions. Although the non-GSE claims experience remains limited
column259: we expect additional activity in this area going forward and it is possible that further losses may occur. We received a number of investor inquiries following our GSE announcement earlier this month regarding the extent of such possible non-GSE exposure. In addition
column260: in connection with our planning process
column261:
we evaluated various possible alternative scenarios. We've developed a preliminary estimate of a possible loss range using a variety of judgmental assumptions. That estimate suggests a possible upper range of loss that could be up to $7 billion to $10 billion over existing accruals.

"
column262:
"

As a reminder
column263:
there are significant legal and procedural hurdles that counterparties would need to overcome before we believe any of these amounts could become probable. We would expect resolution of these matters to be a protracted process which could take years to conclude.

"
column264:
"

As you could see on Slide 21
column265: for example
column266: there are substantial differences between the reps and warranties provided to GSEs and those provided in private label transactions. Until we have meaningful repurchase liability with these counterparties
column267: we do not believe it is possible to determine that the loss is probable and accordingly to accrue for any such loss. As we have previously described to you
column268: where we conclude that a valid breach of reps and warranties has occurred
column269: we will act in a responsible manner. On the other hand
column270: where we've concluded that the valid basis for repurchase does not exist
column271:
we will vigorously contest such claims and defend the interest of Bank of America and its shareholders.

"
column272:
"

Okay
column273: now back to earnings on Slide 22. As I said earlier
column274:
our activity with wealth management clients resulted in revenue approaching record quarterly levels which is where we generate the bulk of the investment in brokerage revenues. Investment in brokerage revenue was up $155 million or 6% from the third quarter due to both higher asset management fees and brokerage income. Asset management fees were a record $1.4 billion and brokerage revenue was approximately $1.5 billion. Total client balances grew $69 billion to more than $2.2 trillion during the quarter as a result of market activity and strong flows in the deposits and long-term asset management products.

"
column275:
"

Sales and trading revenue on Slide 23 of $2.6 billion
column276: which includes both net interest and noninterest income
column277: decreased approximately 43% from the third quarter although higher than last year by 17%. The decrease in sales and trading was partially from seasonal declines but a few other factors standout. We had a softer trading environment as rates backed up
column278: negatively impacting some of our risk positions. This also caused clients to exit bond funds with money flowing in the cash or equity funds putting pressure on prices. We've experienced this significant tightening of credit spreads during the year and to a lesser extent
column279:
during the fourth quarter.

"
column280:
"

Certain sectors such as European debt experienced spread widening. We've also been focused on the impact of the new Basel capital rule and the impact to the amount of capital retracted to our markets business. Over the last couple of quarters
column281:
we've been focused on reducing the higher capital intensive assets and as well our exposure to shorter-term funding agreements.

"
column282:
"

FICC was impacted the most from these items
column283: decreasing 49%to $1.8 billion with lower results in credit
column284: rates and commodities products. Equity revenue was down 19% to $789 million from the third quarter as an increase in cash business commission revenue from inflows was more than offset by a decline in market volatility and client flows impacting equity derivatives. We didn't have any major impact from legacy assets in the quarter while we continue to reduce our exposure to auction rate securities
column285:
CMBS and monolines.

"
column286:
"

In investment banking on Slide 24
column287: our overall fee ranking remain solid as we were ranked at a strong number two globally and number one in the U.S. Investment banking revenue increased 16% from the third quarter and was on par with the great fourth quarter from a year ago. Results were driven by increases in all areas namely M&A
column288:
debt and equity capital markets.

"
column289:
"

Let me say a couple of things about expense levels on Slide 25. Total expense
column290: excluding the goodwill impairment charges in the last two quarters
column291: increased $2 billion from the third quarter. Expenses this quarter included higher litigation expenses as I said earlier. Personnel expense compared to the third quarter is up approximately $400 million
column292: reflecting the build out of strategic hires in certain businesses including international
column293: as well as certain severance and benefit-related expenses. Higher levels of headcount and expense in home loans and insurance were related to default management staff and the other loss mitigation activities in that business. Reiterating what Brian said earlier
column294: our expense levels
column295: excluding goodwill charges
column296: are up from 2009 levels for several reasons
column297: including additional headcount to address legacy mortgage issues. For 2011
column298:
we expect our expense levels to remain elevated as we work through these issues and continue to invest in the franchise.

column299:
"

Moving to asset quality trends on Slide 26. As they did throughout most of the year
column301: excluding FHA loans
column302: net charge-offs and nonperforming assets
column303:
continued to improve.

"
column305: improving credit performance in almost all portfolios drove the decrease in net charge-offs. Net charge-offs of $6.8 billion decreased $414 million compared to the third quarter. Consumer net charge-offs were down $252 million
column306: even with a $330 million valuation adjustment on certain mortgage loans
column307: reflecting improvement in card and home equity. Commercial asset quality also improved as net charge-offs dropped 15% from the prior quarter with the biggest drivers being small business and commercial real estate. Reserve reductions included $1.1 billion on U.S. card
column308: along with releases in commercial real estate
column309: small business
column310: direct and indirect consumer and commercial. On our $36 billion purchased credit impaired consumer book
column311: which is comprised of discontinued real estate residential mortgages and home equity
column312:
we increased the reserve $828 million to reflect an adjusted outlook for home prices.

"
column313:
"

Even with the decline in reserve levels
column314: the ratio of allowance for loan losses to annualized net charge-offs was essentially flat compared to the third quarter at roughly 1.6x and is up from roughly 1.1x a year ago. And thinking about our credit costs in 2011
column315:
we think provision expense should continue to edge down through the year as charge-offs continue to move lower primarily in the consumer businesses. We expect loan loss reserve reductions will continue as long as portfolio performance and the economy continue to improve and our other credit metrics weren't lower reserves.

column603: we would have 8% or better in tier 01 common under the bank card rules. And so as you think about what we submit in these plans
column604: you're submitting the standards of the current Basel I and the levels you have are end of things and we exceed those and then as we implement
column605: we exceeded. So we have confidence what we've been done with the balance sheet now remains a balance sheet has reduced a lot of capital improvement for the year. And you can see on the slide earlier I mentioned in terms of Tier 1 improvement and things like that. So we put in plans. The regulators are looking at them as you know with everybody else. We did not contemplate something early this year
column606: it's in the back half of the year. So it'd be very modest
column607: but the idea is that it is consistent with the balance sheet to operating earnings
column608: the work we've done this year to build Tier 1 Common ratio from 8.5
column609: 8.6 this quarter
column610: we feel confident that we got it. Now we still got to get through the approval and this was a bigger issue for us
column611: three or four or five quarters ago but we cleaned up the balance sheet and restored the capital ratios to a point where it's pretty sizable and embedded in all of that is all the operating statistics and adverse scenarios and everything you've heard about. So we feel confident that we've asked for it
column612: we'll see what happens with the regulators but it's because we've done a lot of hard work in 2010 selling businesses
column613:
reposition the franchise to get us there.

column43: I want to spend a couple of minutes on announcements that occurred this morning other than earnings. Obviously
column44:
we will cover in this call the announcement with the FSA/Assured on the monoline.

"
column45:
"

But on the leadership side
column46: I just wanted to talk through what we've done there. Last year
column47: Chuck came to me and due to an illness of a close family member in California where he has lived
column48: it was going to be clear that he may not be able to move
column49: and we decided to continue to talk about the situation. He had made a commitment to move at the end of the school year obviously because he has a daughter who\u2019s at senior high school. But with that
column50: it became clear as we moved through this quarter that Chuck could not move. So I asked Chuck to take another leadership position that could help us work on some client matters
column51:
matters in the mortgage company and help them transition to new CFO.

"
column52:
"

So what we announced this morning was to have Bruce Thompson take over for Chuck as CFO effective -- and that transition will be completed by the end of the second quarter. And Chuck will continue as a great judge and perspective to help Bruce continue to learn the tasks. Chuck has served as a CFO at a time when we had a tremendous transformation on our financials. He's been a great partner
column53: and we're glad that we came up with something that worked for everybody. Bruce
column54: many of you know
column55: he's been a Chief Risk Officer. He's done a great job for us since last year doing that. He manned our Capital Markets business for Tom and ran Leveraged Finance and many other things for the company over his 15-year career here. As Chief Risk Officer
column56: he may assist through a difficult situation including
column57: as you'll see in some of the pages later
column58:
a great reposition of the balance sheet.

"
column59:
"

In addition to those two changes
column60: we also announced that Gary Lynch will join us as Global Head Of Legal
column61: Compliance and Regulatory Relations. My judgment was that we want to continue to add to the quality and capabilities of our management team. As Gary became available
column62: his reputation in the Street in legal circles and regulators is well known. He has also been the Head of Enforcement at the SEC. And the relationships he has around the world
column63: he spent the last couple of years in London
column64:
will help us outside the United States. He'll join us when his garden leave expires later this year.

"
column65:
"

So with the management changes behind us
column66: let's shift to the quarterly results. With that
column67: I'll start on Slide 4. Rather than get into some of the detail on the page
column68: let me just give you the themes for this quarter
column69:
which are similar to those relayed to you in early March.

"
column70:
"

The franchise that we've built over the last 230 years in this company continues to deliver
column71: and you can see that in the numbers and the statistics this morning. Obviously
column72: the Mortgage business is still in need of continued repositioning
column73: and we continue to work on that. But what you've seen is solid customer activity across the board. Our focus on changing the strategy in the Consumer Deposits business has led to the first quarter of net checking account growth
column74: a return to profit in that business
column75: improved customer satisfaction across the board
column76:
the best retention of customers in that business in many quarters.

"
column77:
"

In other areas
column78: we continue to grow our FA headcount. We've had strong referrals in the businesses across to each other. The deposit growth through the whole franchise has gone over $1 trillion in total deposits. And as the economy has improved a bit
column79: we're starting to see some loan growth on a core basis in the Middle Market business with David Darnell. And we'll touch on some of that later
column80:
but the key theme is the franchise continues to deliver.

"
column81:
"

As you back up to the second point
column82: revenue rose from last quarter. Expenses were flat on a gross basis to $20 billion
column83: including goodwill
column84: and I'll cover it a little later
column85: up $500 million more on the core business. But the absolute levels are elevated
column86:
and I'm just going to talk about what we're doing about that in a few minutes.

"
column87:
"

Overall
column88: earnings improved to $2 billion or $0.17
column89: but we're still impacted by charges as we continue to pull out through the financial crisis. We had $5 billion in charges this quarter we absorbed
column90:
and we also had $3 billion between reserve releases and higher private equity to the good side.

"
column91:
"

When we talked to you at Investor Day
column92: we said we were shooting for pretax
column93: pre-provision profits as we normalized to $45 billion to $50 billion. This quarter
column94: Chuck will walk you through the one-time items
column95: but if you adjust for those
column96: you'll get to a number of approximately $10 billion
column97: which is up from last quarter
column98: and I think puts us in a position that we can see clearly how we build a bridge to the $45 billion to $50 billion level as we normalize. That normalization requires the interest rate environment to change more fundamentally to more normalized environment. We've got to take the costs down across the board. As the economy continues to plug away
column99:
we'll continue to make progress in other revenue sources.

"
column100:
"

In addition
column101: one of the things we talked about at Investor Day was the need to continue to drive down the legacy assets and risk in the company. During this quarter
column102: we took care of one of the monoline exposures. We absorbed the home price fall-off
column103: and we also continued to have our loan portfolio run off across all categories of portfolio we identified for you a couple quarters go. This quarter
column104: that portfolio ran down by about $6 billion
column105: excluding the government-matured loans
column106: which we show you in the Appendix. The cost of that to the P&L was about $1.9 billion pretax this quarter. Again
column107:
Tom and his team did a good job reducing legacy trading assets and we continue to make progress in that area.

"
column108:
"

When you look at the balance sheet
column109: we continue to position the balance sheet
column110: our reserves even after the release remains strong
column111: 4.3% to loans
column112: 1.63x trailing to charge-offs. We made progress improving the capital ratios
column113: lowering our risk-weighted assets again
column114:
growing liquidity and reducing long-term debt. All those important metrics we identified for you a few months ago.

"
column115:
"

We also continue to move forward to take advantage of the opportunities we identified for you. We have a great opportunity in this company in the Affluent and Mass Affluent segments and between Joe Price and Sallie Krawcheck and the team
column116: they continue to see good growth there. We continue to have opportunities in our international capabilities
column117: and I'll describe the work we've done there over the last quarter. And we continue to have opportunities in the business
column118: that will rebound as the economy continues to move forward in the Investment Management and Capital Markets areas
column119:
and we had solid quarters there.

"
column120:
"

And again
column121: this quarter
column122: we continue to simplify the franchise. This quarter
column123: we made progress. We sold a European small business card portfolio. We have Balboa under contract. That will close late this quarter
column124: early next. In addition
column125: we continue to reduce our private equity positions across the board
column126:
and we continue to sell some other small pieces to continue to fine-tune this franchise.

"
column127:
"

When we get to the broader economy this quarter
column128: what we saw is that the customers' health continues to move forward. Delinquencies were down across all portfolios
column129: consumer spending continued to increase this quarter over last
column130: in 2011 over 2010. In March
column131: it increased 7% to give you an example
column132: about 1\u00bd% of that would have been gas price increases
column133:
the rest is sort of fundamental customer purchases moving forward.

"
column134:
"

We see loan demand in select areas and loan stability across the board
column135: absent the runoff. Our Affluent clients continue to take more risk in the market. And we've seen growth in the area there
column136:
and the capital markets remain robust.

"
column137:
"

So enough with that
column138: let's drop to Page 5 and get into some of the specific results for the quarter. On Slide 5
column139: you can see we can start with the capital ratios. We told you at the conference
column140: our share return model requires us to focus on building our balance sheet with a strong reserve position
column141: driving optimization of risk-weighted asset position and building capital through 2011
column142:
2012 as we move from Basel I to Basel II to Basel 2.5 to Basel III. This quarter reflects the continued progress.

"
column143:
"

The tangible common equity ratio increased to 6.1%
column144:
above the level we believe that -- of the risk inherent to run the company. The focus that we also shared with you is driving tangible book value per share. We moved that to $13.21 this quarter as you can see in the upper right-hand corner of the slide.

"
column145:
"

Our regulatory cap ratios continue to improve. We had a fairly sizable change in the DTA allowance period for regulatory capital treatment that caused a 27-basis points decline before we got the quarter started. But even with that
column146: we still made progress. The Tier 1 common ratio was up 4 basis points or 31 basis points
column147:
not taking into account the adjustment. And the Tier 1 was up 8 basis points gross.

"
column148:
"

On the lower right
column149: you can see we made progress by continuing to reduce RWA. And as we've talked to you
column150: we had significant mitigation coming later in the year in Basel calculations after planned implementation of technology
column151:
risk models and other risk management opportunities we've been working on for the last couple of years.

"
column152:
"

All this is critical in our ability to meet the Tier 1 Basel III common ratio goal of 8% at year end 2012 as if Basel III was fully implemented
column153:
and to move forward on capital management later this year and next year.

"
column154:
"

Now let me go to Page 6
column155: and then just step back and think about the progress first quarter of 2010 versus 2011 in the core balance sheet of this company. As you can see on this page
column156: overall assets down 3%
column157: our RWA is down 6%
column158: our deposits are up 4% or $44 billion
column159: our long-term debt has been reduced $77 billion
column160:
which is significant and has a significant benefit on our margin.

"
column161:
"

Importantly
column162: you can see our tangible common shareholders' equity is up $16 billion. Our Tier 1 common equity's up $8 billion. And you can see the rest of the statistics on this page. So in a year's time frame
column163: we've been able to significantly lower the risk
column164:
increase the capital and increase the statistics on reserve coverage while at the same time managing the customer franchise.

"
column165:
"

As we move to the businesses
column166: I just want to reflect quickly on those
column167: and then I'll let Chuck take you through the detail on the numbers. On Slide 7
column168: you can see the overall picture. It's a pretty simple picture. You can see all the businesses have moved back to profitably except our Mortgage business
column169:
and we'll talk in some detail about that later on.

"
column170:
"

As you go on each of the businesses
column171: let's first take our Deposit businesses starting on Page 8. The deposits team produced earnings this quarter of $355 million
column172:
and that was versus a loss in the fourth quarter. They had higher revenue and lower litigation expense compared to the fourth quarter.

"
column173:
"

Remember that in this business
column174: the fourth quarter was kind of the low point because the regulatory items affecting the Deposits business
column175: i.e.
column176:
the Reg E and overdraft are fully in this business. Our Durbin charges will go into our Card segment later this year if it becomes effective.

"
column177:
"

The return on tangible equity for our Deposits business this quarter was 25%
column178: which is above the rate of our early rates obviously
column179: but we expect to go higher as the business continues to recover. As deposit balances were up $5 billion or 4% annualized
column180: the cost of retail deposits
column181: both in this business and our Wealth Management business combined
column182:
were down 4 basis points to 33 basis points.

"
column183:
"

Importantly
column184: new accounts reflect continued focus on quality relationships and retention. As a matter of fact
column185: we're seeing the lowest attrition in accounts we've seen in three years or more. In this quarter
column186:
we saw the first net account growth based on the change in strategies that Joe Price and his team are accomplishing in five quarters.

"
column187:
"

Account closures are down
column188: and our customer focus continues to work. Early results in our pilots to reposition our franchise based on all the regulatory changes in a customer-driven analysis are still in early rollout
column189: but exceeding our expectations. In adding a preferred customer solutions group
column190: our Platinum Privileges offerings
column191: as we call it
column192:
has worked well.

"
column193:
"

On the expense side
column194: the team is working. Branches are down 200 over the last five quarters. Our cost to deposits ratio that we showed you in early March went down from 264 basis points. That\u2019s all the cost of operating a franchise over the deposits to 250
column195: which shows continued growth. Our active online accounts exceeded 30 million
column196:
a record for this company. Our mobile users are up 55% first quarter '10 to first quarter '11 to 6.8 million mobile users.

"
column197:
"

As we\u2019ve switched to Card Services
column198: that business earned $1.7 billion in the quarter on improved credit quality. Its revenue is down as the portfolio keeps repositioning as we continue to run down the book for the loans we don't want in that business
column199: and the lower yields did a seasonal decline in retail volume. The unit did benefit by reserve release
column200: but the earnings are normalizing
column201: and we\u2019ll see that happen over the next few quarters. The retail volumes are down from the fourth quarter
column202: but as I said earlier
column203: customer usage of cards has gone up year-over-year by in the 5%
column205: 7% range
column206:
depending on the month.

"
column207:
"

Our net loss rates broke another level here as we filed below 8% for the first time in a while
column208: from the peak of nearly 14% on card losses in U.S. credit card book. New accounts in our U.S. credit card book were up 26% in the fourth quarter in the highest level in six quarters. In credit quality
column209: there's no origination that's very strong. So as you think about our core Consumer businesses
column210: we returned to profit deposits
column211:
and we ought to expect to keep driving that forward. And our Card business continues to improve and both have upside as the interest rate environment and economy continues to stabilize.

"
column212:
"

We move to the next page
column213: Slide 9 in our Wealth Management businesses. The Global Wealth Management team turned in $531 million after-tax
column214: up 69% from solid fourth quarter results
column215:
but driven by an 8% increase in revenue and lower provision for credit cost.

"
column216:
"

Our pretax margin in this business
column217: showing the value of the innovative model across all the various products
column218:
is reaching nearly 19%. And the return on economic equity was 30%.

"
column219:
"

The growth in margin
column220: as I said
column221: is reflective of the loan deposits growth
column222: which grew 5% in the quarter. And it demonstrates the customers who want to integrate their finances with us
column223:
and that loan deposit growth led to NII growing 10% from the fourth quarter 2010.

"
column224:
"

Now many times people ask if that money is just money sitting on the sidelines. But during this quarter
column225: we've also seen the activity related to the investment side of the house grow nicely. Client balances grew 2%
column226: and that's on a $2 trillion base to give you a sense. So it's $45 billion in growth in clients and the new product flows of about $14 billion in long-term assets under management
column227:
were all good performance by this unit.

"
column228:
"

The growth in Financial Advisors continue to be steady
column229: 184 new Financial Advisors were added. We continue to have record low attrition in our advisor forums. And referrals by this unit
column230: which is sort of a Lynch Pandora referral strategy
column231:
continue to be strong and remain healthy with the other businesses.

"
column232:
"

On Slide 9
column233: we moved to one of the -- at the bottom of Slide 9
column234: we talk about one of the core businesses we had
column235: which is Middle Market
column236: Small Business Lending
column237:
which turned in another quarter of $923 million of earnings. They're down slightly as they went from a release of provision to actually having provision this quarter. The return on tangible equity in this business is 18% for this quarter.

"
column238:
"

Average C&I balances were up 2%
column239:
and that's concentrated in the middle market space. It offsets declines in the Commercial Real Estate business and Dealer Financial Services business. Average deposits also grew 2%. The Asset Qualities businesses was very strong through the cycle and continues to improve.

"
column240:
"

One of the things that you often ask about that we saw here
column241: was that we saw revolver utilization of our companies move from 32% in the fourth quarter to 35%
column242: which shows the companies are using credit ever so slightly. Remember that normalized to that level
column243: it\u2019s probably in the mid-40s
column244:
so we've got work to go ahead of us there still.

"
column245:
"

We move to Slide 10
column246: move to our large corporate and capital markets and sales and trading team in Global Banking and Markets. They earned $2.1 billion for the fourth quarter. Returns on tangible capital of business were 28%. The revenue was up 44% from the fourth quarter
column247: driven by increases in sales and trading
column248: a robust quarter investment banking and steady corporate banking revenue driven by treasury management growth of about 5%. Corporate loans were up $3 billion for the quarter
column249: about 12% annualized
column250:
driven by growth in our International Lending business.

"
column251:
"

Now one of the interesting things here is our international market share in some of our businesses is now stronger than our U.S. market share
column252: which shows the effort the team has made to grow across the world with its global client. In Equity Capital Markets advisory
column253: we actually had higher shares outside the U.S. this quarter than we did inside the U.S.
column254:
which shows good progress on our international strategy.

"
column255:
"

And now we move to the business that we continue to have to do a lot of work on
column256: and that's our Consumer Real Estate Services business. As you know
column257:
we split this business in two parts to focus the executives in the business to concentrate on two pieces: Barbara Desoer and her team to concentrate on the Front End business; and Terry Laughlin and the team to concentrate on the Legacy Asset business and running down.

"
column258:
"

In the business
column259: the Legacy Asset business obviously had a significant loss. And the go forward business had a slight profit
column260: and Chuck will talk you through that later. Our production levels in mortgage banking fell to $56 billion
column261: but we maintained our market share. To deal with the fall off
column262: we announced today and have been reducing headcount by approximately 3
column263: 500 people. About 2
column264: 000 of those are contractors in that business and about 1
column265:
500 are teammates. This is all in the good side of the house in Barbara's side of the business.

"
column266:
"

On the Legacy side
column267: we continue to plug resources to get through the backlog and modifications and foreclosures. During the quarter
column268: we modified 64
column269: 000 loans
column270: bringing us to over 840
column271: 000 loans modified in the last few years. On our Legacy side
column272: as you saw in our press release
column273: we settled the exposures
column274: one of them major monoline insurers
column275:
and Chuck will cover that later.

"
column276:
"

Again and after the review the regulators conducted late last fall and our self-assessment
column277: we have made significant progress in implementing the changes and solution on short sales
column278: deeds in lieu and foreclosures
column279: and we'll complete about 70
column280:
000 of those in this quarter. The cost of delay in foreclosures and assessments related to that is reflected in the P&L this quarter as is increased servicing cost in our MSR valuation.

"
column281:
"

As we move to the subject of cost
column282: which is something we focused on
column283: you can see on Slide 12 that you can see that we\u2019ve laid out for you sort of the fourth quarter and the first quarter in terms of the overall cost. There was about $20 billion in reported cost
column284: but on a core basis
column285:
we had about a $500 million increase from quarter-to-quarter.

"
column286:
"

We know that we need to do more on cost
column287: and we'll continue to work on those. If you look at the base run rate's approximately $17 billion
column288: and this is the run rate we've been facing consistent with what Chuck told you at the Investor Day about a $70 billion number. So we've been managing cost to try to run it flat as the incremental one-time costs continue to hit us on a given quarter. But the way we're managing that has been managing headcount. Overall headcount grew on a point-to-point basis from December 31 to March 31 about 0.3%. That's 0.3% or 2
column289: 700 people across the 285
column291:
000 people.

"
column292:
"

With the Mortgage business and the Legacy side adding 2
column293: 700 people and the rest of the company going down by 2
column294: 000. That 2
column295: 000 reduction is even with the investments we're making in small business bankers out in international capabilities
column296:
financial advisers and many other areas.

"
column297:
"

Our efficiency ratio\u2019s at 75%. It\u2019s down from 92% in the fourth quarter
column298: but that is not the progress we'd like to see. We expect that to continue to recover as the legacy assets and some of the charges go down in the high 50s
column299: low 60s
column300: which is where we were earlier in 2010. But we need to do more than show we can hold expenses flat or reduce them as revenue rises
column301: deliver the returns in this business in the company we need to do. To do that
column302: as we told you at Investor Day
column303: we continue to finish off with all the integrations
column304: and that will give us the time
column305:
the so-called peace dividend in the effort to continue to drive this company forward.

"
column306:
"

We told you we could get back to the 55% efficiency ratio. We have launched an effort this week using outside teammates who\u2019ve worked with other companies in a significant amount
column307: an internal team called New BAC
column308: which will continue to work to take all the work in this company
column309: examine it and see the work that doesn't add value to our customers or teammates and move it out of this company. We'll work on this effort for the next several months. It takes two phases and leads us all the way into 2012. The first phase completes late this fall
column310:
and we'll continue to implement immediately thereafter to get the expense savings and keep the run rate down as the revenue and the economy recovers.

"
column311:
"

With that general overview
column312:
let me turn it over to Chuck to take you through and detail the quarter. Chuck?

"
column313:
"

Charles Noski

"
column314:
"

Thanks
column315: Brian. I appreciate your kind words
column316: and I'm looking forward to continuing to work with you and the senior management team in my new role as Vice Chairman. I think Bruce will do a great job as the next Chief Financial Officer. And also Gary Lynch
column317: who will be joining us later in the year
column318: will be a terrific addition to Bank of America. As some of you may know
column319:
I worked with Gary during the five years I served on the board of directors of Morgan Stanley. And I found him to be a first-rate executive.

"
column320:
"

With that
column321: let's turn to the slides and begin on Slide 13. For the quarter
column322: as Brian said
column323: we reported $2 billion of net income or $0.17 a share after preferred dividends. There were several significant items during the quarter
column324: which are detailed on Slide 14. Representations and warranties provision in the first half was $1 billion
column325: of which slightly more than half was associated with the GSEs and the remainder was related primarily to a recent experience with a monoline. The provision related to the GSEs was driven by higher estimated repurchase rates
column326: along with the further deterioration in the home pricing index
column327:
what we call HPI in the quarter.

"
column328:
"

If you recall
column329: when we announced our agreement with the GSEs earlier this year and adjusted the liability for future losses
column330: I noted that there could be further refinements from a number of factors. A major factor in our estimate of the liability for future losses is the performance of HPI
column331:
which declined this quarter and impacts the severity of losses in our reps and warranties liability.

"
column332:
"

The credit market unstructured liabilities under deferred value option resulted in a negative adjustment of $586 million
column333:
reflecting a tightening of our credit spreads compared to a negative adjustment of $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter and is reported in other income.

"
column334:
"

Equity investment gains during the quarter included a $1.1 billion gain from an investment in connection with the related IPO in the first quarter and reflected both the sale of shares as well as the fair value mark on the remaining shares we still hold. We have $546 million in gains on the sale of securities during the quarter. Trading-related income included a negative DVA impact of $357 million due to wider debt spreads.

"
column335:
"

Excluding fees paid to external legal service providers
column336: litigation expense this quarter was $940 million
column337:
principally associated with mortgage-related matters.

"
column338:
"

During the quarter
column339: there were various mortgage assessments and waivers accrued for several areas of exposure driven by the foreclosure delays
column340: which totaled $874 million
column341:
including $548 million for compensatory fees that we expect to be assessed by the GSEs as well as costs incurred during the foreclosure process that we do not expect to recover.

"
column342:
"

Also included in the first quarter
column343: as Brian mentioned
column344: was approximately $1 billion of expense related to retirement eligible stock-based compensation awards
column345: so-called FAS 123R
column346:
that we have every year at this time. And merger related and restructuring charges were $202 million.

"
column347:
"

Credit loss reserves were reduced by $2.2 billion in the quarter versus $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter. The current period reserve number included $1.6 billion of reserve increases related to the purchase credit impaired portfolio. One item not on this slide
column348: but which I want to highlight for you is our effective tax rate that this quarter was 26.3%. At this time
column349: we would expect the rate for the rest of the year to be around 30%
column350:
plus or minus unusual items like a charge for the U.K. rate reductions expected later this year or more valuation allowance released benefits like we've seen during the last couple of years.

"
column351:
"

You may recall that we wrote down a portion of our deferred tax asset last year in the third quarter due to the 1% U.K. tax rate reduction
column352: resulting in a charge after tax of nearly $400 million. It looks like the U.K. is considering two more 1% tax rate reductions
column353: which could impact the third quarter of this year. So we are expecting a charge income tax expense of nearly $800 million upon enactment of those rate changes. Because we would just be reducing deferred tax assets that are disallowed at the margin
column354:
the $800 million charge would not affect our regulatory capital levels.

"
column355:
"

On Slide 15
column356: you can see that average loans were down $1.6 billion from the fourth quarter while average deposits increased more than $15 billion. Deposits remains a good story of growth as consumer balances grew
column357: Wealth Management clients continued to do more business with us and Commercial customers continued to prefer to hold rather than invest cash. In line with our comments over the past few months
column358: ending long-term debt dropped $14 billion
column359:
and we expect that decline to continue.

"
column360:
"

As you can see on Slide 16
column361: loans at the end of the quarter
column362: excluding net charge-offs and run-off activity
column363: were up $2.9 billion. Consumer loans were relatively flat. Commercial loans x real estate were up $3.5 billion or 1.4%
column364:
driven primarily by growth in Asia and EMEA. And commercial real estate loans declined $2 billion or 4.1% as reductions in higher risk assets continue to offset new originations.

"
column365:
"

Let's turn to net interest income on Slide 17. Net interest income on an FTE basis was $12.4 billion
column366: down $312 million from the fourth quarter. The impact of lower hedge income
column367:
lower consumer loan balances and yields and fewer days in the quarter were offset partially by a reduction in long-term debt and other items.

"
column368:
"

Our average earning assets for the quarter were down $14 billion
column369:
mainly due to reduced customer financing activity in the repo area. Average consumer loans were down as additional runoff in the Card and Home Equity portfolios more than offset retained mortgage originations.

"
column370:
"

Average commercial loans were relatively flat as decreases in real estate and U.S. Commercial were partially offset by increases in both core loan and trade finance activity in our non-U.S. Corporate Banking business
column372:
"

As we've said for the past few quarters
column373: we expect net interest income to be down again in the second quarter and anticipate stabilization in the second half of the year. We are also on track to lower our long-term debt footprint by 15% to 20% by the end of 2011
column374:
relative to third quarter 2010 levels.

"
column375:
"

Turning to Slide 18. Card revenue was down almost $300 million from the fourth quarter
column376: results due mainly to the seasonal decline in interchange. Decreases in retail spending were 6% versus the prior quarter
column377: and versus the prior year reflected an increase of 6%. Card revenue was down 7% from a year ago
column378:
due to the impact of the CARD Act as the provisions became effective throughout 2010.

"
column379:
"

On Slide 19
column380: we show service charges were flat with the fourth quarter
column381: but down 21% from a year ago due to overdraft policy changes
column383:
were fully embedded in our results as of the fourth quarter of last year.

"
column384:
"

Let me say a couple of things that you should note before we move away from retail banking driven revenue. Consumer spending is up
column385: account closures are down. Quality sales remained strong
column386: deposits grew and employment levels are higher
column387:
which all point to improving performance in our Retail businesses in future periods.

"
column388:
"

Mortgage banking income on Slide 20 improved by $2 billion from the fourth quarter as lower reps and warranties provision was partially offset by lower production volumes in margin as well as less favorable net MSR hedge results. Production volume in first mortgage of $57 billion

Much of the decrease was due to the impact of our agreements with the GSEs in the fourth quarter. The $1 billion provision in the first quarter dealt principally with the GSEs and recent experience with the monoline.

"
column394:
"

On that note as Brian made reference to this morning
column395:
we announced an agreement with Assured Guaranty to resolve all of the monolines outstanding and potential repurchase claims related to alleged reps and warranties breaches involving certain first- and second-lien residential mortgage-backed securitization trusts where Assured provided financial guaranty insurance. The agreement covers combined original collateral exposure of approximately $35.8 billion with the combined principal at risk of approximately $10.9 billion. The agreement includes a cash payment of approximately $1.1 billion to Assured as well as a loss sharing reinsurance arrangement that has a current estimated fair market value of approximately $500 million. Approximately $1.1 billion of that was reserved for these potential repurchase claims at the end of December with the remaining liability recognized in the first quarter.

"
column396:
"

This settlement gets behind us a sizable piece of home equity exposure along with some first-lien exposure. We currently estimate the upper end of the possible loss range related to non-GSEs to remain at around $7 billion to $10 billion over existing accruals. Any reduction in our previously disclosed estimated range resulting from reserve accruals in this quarter were largely offset by the impact of HPI deterioration during the first quarter.

"
column398:
this estimated range does not represent our estimate of a probable loss and is based on current assumptions that are necessarily subject to change. The liability for reps and warranties ended the quarter at $6.2 billion compared to $5.4 billion in the prior quarter.

column1199: that's the interesting part of the business. And I think we did about $1.5 billion
column1200: steady with the fourth quarter last year
column1201: which had some good activity up from $1.2 billion last year
column1202: first quarter. And we continue to have a strong and robust pipeline. And if you've seen some of the offerings going out on the IPOs and things like that
column1203: and we expect us to be continuing to improve those fees. But we got $1.5 billion in fees every quarter. For the last eight or nine
column1204:
we've been second based on fees received and expect that. And I guess that will continue.

"
column1205:
"

Vivek Juneja - JP Morgan Chase & Co

"
column1206:
"

And on the trading side
column1208: if you just break that down a little bit by products versus rates
column1211: can you give some color as to how you did on that year-on-year linked quarter and in terms of March
column1214:
"

We'll get Lee or Kevin to fill some of that in for you. But in broad stand
column1215: the place that we're -- still need to make improvement in the Commodities business. That's one of the difference between us and some of our peers and -- but on the other hand
column1216: we've done a good job in the rates and currencies and other areas. So it's really one of the big differences
column1217: just gross dollar amount between us and others is our Commodities business is just smaller and not performing so well. And so we'll \u2013 Lee can fill you in on some of the details
column1224:
and look forward to seeing you next quarter.

"
column1226:
"

This concludes today's conference call. You may disconnect at any time. Thank you

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q2 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

"
column6:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chief Executive Officer
column8:
Director and Member of Executive Committee

"
column10:
"

Bruce Thompson - Chief Risk Officer

"
column12:
"

Ed Najarian - ISI Group Inc.

"
column13:
"

John McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column15:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets & Co.

"
column17:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

"
column18:
"

Christoph Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.

"
column20:

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (NYSE:USA) Inc.
