"
column25: and welcome to today's program. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded [Operator Instructions]. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Kevin Stitt. Please go ahead
column27:
"

Kevin Stitt

"
column28:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column29: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column30: and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. And these factors include
column31: among other things
column32: changes in economic conditions
column33: changes in interest rates
column34: competitive pressures within the financial services industry and legislative or regulatory requirements that may affect our businesses. And for additional factors
column35:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column36:
"

And with that
column37:
let me turn it over to Brian.

"
column40: Kevin. Now before I turn it over to Bruce
column41: I just want to make a few comments about the quarter. As we discussed on the call on June 29
column42:
we announced the settlement on private-label securities litigation. We've been working hard to put large pieces of uncertain risks behind us as a company and where we can do that on the basis reasonable to you as our shareholders.

"
column43:
"

This quarter
column44: following the actions we took on last year's fourth quarter on the GSEs
column45: in the first quarter on the monolines
column46: we put another significant part of the rep and warrant exposure behind us and other mortgage-related matters. In all
column47: as you can see
column48: from the materials
column49: we took almost $20 billion in charges related to the Mortgage business. That is translated in a $0.90 per share loss in the range we gave you a few weeks ago. Adjusting for the mortgage charges
column50: our earnings were $0.33 a share
column51:
that's the high end of the range we gave you in June. Bruce is going to give you more details on those adjustments later on.

"
column52:
"

Switching to the important question of capital. The work we have done to improve our balance sheet over the last several quarters came through this quarter as
column53: even with the loss
column54: we reported capital ratios
column55: which are stronger than this quarter in 2010. Our Tier 1 common ratio
column56: which we -- was -- which we said at the end of June was coming around 8%
column57: actually came in at 8.23%
column58: higher than we expected
column59: a drop of 20 basis points since the first quarter 2011 but improving since last year. Our tangible common equity ratio
column60: which we estimated at the end of June to be about 5.7%
column61: came in at 5.87%
column62: again
column63:
an improvement of what we said.

"
column64:
"

We achieved the ratios through the continued balance sheet optimization and repair that we've been going through the company over the last several quarters. In all
column65: during the second quarter 2011
column66: our RWA came down over $30 billion. Bruce is going to take you through the actions we completed during the second quarter of 2011 and
column67: more importantly
column68: the actions that are still ahead of us in the quarters ahead
column69:
all of which gave us comfort and demonstrate we don't need to raise capital as we continue on our plans to comply with Basel III.

"
column70:
"

As we look at the business lines and you can see how they perform
column71: this quarter shows the power of the rest of our franchise
column72: which has been covered up by losses in Mortgage. As you can see on Slide 5
column73: you can see the results. Each business line
column74: other than Mortgage
column75: had solid earnings and returns
column76:
earning all -- in all over $5.7 billion after tax. The franchise and customer model continues to shine through.

"
column77:
"

In our Deposits business
column78: we grew deposits. We also grew accounts at 2x the rate we grew them last quarter on net new checking accounts. We paid less for our deposits this quarter on our deposits franchise
column79: and we lowered our cost to operate the franchise in this quarter. The transformation of this business unit continues to go well
column80: and we are growing our fees again
column81:
offsetting the overdraft regulations that came through last year.

"
column82:
"

In our Card business
column83: we had strong performance aided by the credit provision released. But we also increased our units in the United States this quarter to over 730
column84: 000 new cards. The Durbin will affect this business in subsequent quarters
column85:
and Bruce will lay that out later.

"
column86:
"

In our Global Wealth Investment Management business
column87: we had another solid quarter. We grew long-term assets
column88:
grew our advisory team and continue to see strong performance across the franchise.

"
column89:
"

As we move to the corporate commercial side of our house
column90: we had strong earnings in our Global Commercial Bank as you can see. That's our Middle Market business
column91: led by David Darnell. And we had a good quarter in our global corporate Investment Banking business
column92: which is part of the GBAM
column93:
led by Tom -- GBAM unit led by Tom Montag. That serves our larger corporate customers around the world. The deposit and treasury management revenues in these businesses were solid.

"
column94:
"

The loan growth outside the U.S. is strong
column95: and our investment Banking fees of $1.6 billion plus were one of the best quarters we had in this business
column96:
since we came together several quarters ago. Our efforts here also show that our international businesses investments are starting to bear fruit as the revenues outside the United States grew faster than revenues inside the United States.

"
column97:
"

As we switch our sales and trading portion of the GBAM
column98: Global Banking and Markets business
column99: we had a solid quarter
column100: down from the first quarter of 2011 but up from the second quarter of last year. We made money on 97% of the trading days
column101:
even on a choppy market.

"
column102:
"

Let me switch to 2 other areas of focus
column103: our credit and expenses. On credit
column104: we continue to see improvements in all portfolios
column105:
and we still have upside as charge-offs will continue to fall. Delinquencies in all portfolios continue to come down despite the recent backup on some economic and unemployment statistics.

"
column106:
"

Our -- on expenses
column107: we continue to manage to a flat core expense level that Bruce will show you in a few minutes
column108: if you eliminate the large mortgage onetime charges in the expense base. We've seen our headcount go down slightly this quarter. We continue to invest where we need and have to
column109: in this franchise. Examples are the LAS buildout
column110: the Legacy Asset Services buildout
column111: where we've had to invest to collect the delinquent mortgage loans
column112: but more importantly
column113: on the revenue side
column114: investing in more wealth managers in our Global Wealth and Investment Management business
column115: more FSAs or brokers in our branch and small business lenders in our Deposits business
column116: our international franchise and importantly
column117:
a technology investor throughout the franchise.

"
column118:
"

At the same time
column119: we continue to take out expenses in other areas to help fund these investments. For example
column120: this quarter
column121: our branch count is down 63 from last quarter. Our New BAC projects
column122: which is a company-wide initiative on expenses
column123: will be done this quarter
column124: in the third quarter 2011
column125: for one -- about 1/2 of the company
column126: and we'll give you the results of that in October and show you what we plan to do with the second half of the company during the latter part of this year. Suffice to say
column127:
that the work so far has gone well and shows a great opportunity to make our company better and more efficient in the future.

"
column128:
"

With that
column129:
I want to turn it over to Bruce to take you through the quarter.

"
column130:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column131:
"

Great. Thanks
column132: Brian
column133: and good morning. If I could ask you to start with Slide 6. As Brian referenced
column134: during the quarter
column135: on a reported basis
column136: we had a net loss of $8.8 billion or $0.90 a share
column137: and if we adjust that for mortgage-related and other items
column138:
we reported net income of $3.7 billion or $0.33 a share.

"
column139:
"

We've scheduled down at the bottom of the page
column140: the onetime items coming through the P&L. The $15.5 billion of mortgage-related revenue charges is comprised of $14 billion of reps and warrants and $1.5 billion negative valuation effect on our MSR. On the mortgage-related expense items of $2.6 billion
column141: $1.9 billion of that litigation expense and $700 million assessments and waivers. And then we've scheduled out back
column142: on Slide 30
column143:
the asset sale gains and other amounts that are comprised of a variety of items.

"
column144:
"

Before I leave this page
column145: I'd like to touch briefly on taxes. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 39.4%
column146: excluding our goodwill impairment. As you look out and think of the balance of the year
column147: think about the effective tax rate in the 30% area
column148: excluding any unusual adjustments. The other thing I'd call your attention to here is during the third quarter
column149: we will have an $800 million hit to our U.K. deferred tax asset
column150:
given the reduction in U.K. taxes that we would expect to be approved during the third quarter.

"
column151:
"

Turning to Page 7 and looking at the balance sheet. Assets during the quarter were down slightly
column152: while we continue to see growth in the deposits. I'd ask you to spend a minute and focus on risk-weighted assets. Risk-weighted assets were down $40.7 billion for the quarter or 2.8%
column153: which is consistent with our strategy of driving down risk-weighted assets as we look out to the new Basel capital rules. To give you a sense of the magnitude of this reduction
column154:
it led to a 23-basis-point benefit to Tier 1 common during the quarter.

"
column155:
"

As Brian alluded to
column156: Tier 1 common at the end of the quarter was solid at 8.23%
column157: and tangible book value ended the quarter at 12.65% (sic) [$12.65]. From an asset quality and a reserve perspective
column158:
ending loan loss reserves after the release were $37.3 billion or 4% of loans and leases in over 1.6x our annualized charge-offs that we saw for the quarter.

"
column159:
"

On Slide 8
column160: we walk through our net interest income for the quarter. On an FTE basis
column161: net interest income was down roughly $900 million for the quarter. Net interest margin was at 2.5%
column162:
which is consistent with our previous guidance where we expected net interest income margin to trough in the 2.5% area.

"
column163:
"

As you think about the decline in net interest income
column164: it was due to several factors. The first
column165: on the consumer side
column166: lower balances and lower yields. The second
column167: the drop in long-term interest rates had a negative impact on our hedge results
column168: and third
column169:
we had lower trading-related revenues.

"
column170:
"

As you think about our strategy with net interest income and managing OCI risks
column171: we continue to be very focused on keeping the duration in our discretionary portfolio short
column172: as our asset liability management strategy is focused on managing interest rate risk across the company and minimizing higher -- or excuse me
column173:
minimizing OCI exposure to the extent we were to have a higher interest rate environment as we move towards Basel.

"
column174:
"

If we flip to Slide 9 and look at the Deposits business. Net income in the Deposits business was $430 million during the quarter
column175: up $75 million or roughly 21% from the first quarter of 2011. Average deposits were up 2% for the quarter
column176: and net new accounts were positive for the second consecutive quarter. Brian referenced the rates paid on deposits and the cost per dollar of deposit. Rates paid on deposits came down 3 basis points from 32 basis points to 29
column177: and cost per deposit
column178: which we define as noninterest expense over average deposits
column179:
came down from 2.6% in the first quarter to 2.44% during the current quarter.

"
column180:
"

On Slide 10
column181: we walk through our Global Card business
column182: where net income was $2 billion
column183: a $300 million improvement or 17% over the first quarter
column184: as credit improvements more than offset lower net interest income from lower average loans and yields. As we think about volumes
column185:
total purchase volume for debit and credit transactions was up seasonally 9% from the first quarter and 6% when we compare it back to the second quarter of 2010. Credit continued to improve significantly as delinquencies improved and U.S. charge-offs declined for the seventh consecutive quarter.

"
column186:
"

From an average loan and lease perspective
column187: the $5.6 billion decline in average loans from the first quarter was due to higher payments
column188: charge-offs and continued runoff in our noncore credit portfolio. In addition to that reduction
column189: we exited approximately $2 billion in receivables at the end of the quarter
column190:
with virtually no income statement effect.

"
column191:
"

There's been a lot of questions about Durbin out there. If we look at our second quarter results and we look out to the fourth quarter
column192: which will be the quarter in which Durbin is implemented
column193:
we would expect a negative $475-million revenue impact from Durbin out in the fourth quarter relative to where we were in this quarter.

"
column194:
"

On Slide 11
column195: we walk through the Global Wealth and Investment Management business. Net income was $506 million
column196: down $27 million or 5% from the quarter
column197: based on higher expenses from increases in the investment in our Financial Advisors as well as higher credit costs. Revenue for the quarter was nearly flat to record first quarter levels that we saw during the first quarter of '11 as record asset management fees
column198: driven by market and long-term AUM loans
column199:
were offset by lower brokerage revenues reflecting lower market activity.

"
column200:
"

During the quarter
column201: more than 500 Financial Advisors joined the leading advisory force
column202: pushing the total number of FAs to over 16
column203:
000 for the first time since the Merrill Lynch merger. Ending loans within the business group for the fifth consecutive quarter and were up $1.6 billion.

"
column204:
"

Turning to Slide 12
column205: and looking at the Commercial Banking line of business. Net income of $1.4 billion was up $458 million from the first quarter and was at its highest level since the second quarter of 2009. Average deposits grew $6.3 billion or 4% during the quarter
column206: as customers in this line of business continue to remain highly liquid. As we look at average loans
column207: average loans declined $3.1 billion. On the negative
column208: we saw commercial real estate decline by roughly $2.2 billion
column209:
which masked the improvement and the increase in average loans that we saw in commercial industrial loans in our Middle Market business.

"
column210:
"

Once again
column211: very strong improvement in asset quality within the Commercial Bank. Charge-offs declined $193 million or 38% from the first quarter. Nonperformers declined 11%
column212:
and we continued to see very solid performance in credit.

"
column213:
"

If we move to Page 13 and look at the Global Banking and Markets business
column214:
net income for this business was $1.6 billion for the quarter and fell seasonally from -- seasonally by $576 million from the first quarter on lower sales and trading results that were partially offset during the quarter by higher Investment Banking fees.

"
column215:
"

If we start to look at sales and trading
column216: the revenues for the quarter were $3.8 billion dollars
column217: a $1.1 billion decline from the first quarter
column218: but up approximately $666 million from the second quarter. We've laid out the DVA gains that we saw during the 3 periods on this slide. And I think as you think about this business and think about the second quarter
column219: as far as how we ran the business
column220: its market certainty increased towards the end of the quarter
column221: based on what's going on in Europe
column222: global economic concerns
column223: and quite frankly
column224: the lack of opportunity to make money
column225: we reduced risk at the end of the quarter. From a risk-weighted assets perspective within sales and trading
column226: they declined $37 billion as we reduced legacy assets
column227:
exited our proprietary trading business in its entirety and continued to optimize the balance sheet as we look forward to Basel III.

"
column228:
"

If we move to Investment Banking
column229: Investment Banking revenues of $1.6 billion
column230: excluding any self-led transactions
column231: were a record since the closing of the Merrill Lynch merger
column232:
and we saw strong activity across all the Investment Banking products.

"
column233:
"

If we move to Corporate Banking
column234: average loans and leases increased $5.8 billion or approximately 6% from the first quarter
column235: as we saw strong growth in our international commercial loans and trade finance
column236:
which is consistent with what we've spoken about before as we made investments internationally in 2010 and they've started to bear fruit in 2011.

"
column237:
"

The next 3 slides
column238: we're going to touch on are Consumer Real Estate Services. On a consolidated basis
column239: you can see this segment reported a $14.5 billion loss. If we adjust out all of the onetime items that I talked about at the beginning of the call
column240: net loss for the quarter was $954 million versus the $399 million that we saw during the first quarter of '11. The adjusted loss of $555-million delta occurred as the revenue was impacted by the sale of Balboa
column241: which closed on June 1
column242:
as well as higher operating costs within the Legacy Asset Services area.

"
column243:
"

I would also highlight during the quarter
column244: the MSR decreased by $2.9 billion from $15.3 billion to $12.4 billion. And as we look at the cap rate on that MSR
column245:
it was at 78 basis points at the end of the second quarter versus 95 basis points at the end of the first quarter.

"
column246:
"

On Slide 15
column247: we look at the Home Loans business
column248: which is the ongoing mortgage operation within our bank. You can see that net income for the quarter was $531 million. If we back out the gain on Balboa
column249: it was $86 million
column250: up slightly from the $77 million in the first quarter. Revenue in the quarter was helped by higher lock revenue that resulted from deliberate pricing actions that we took
column251: as well as favorable channel mix
column252:
and was offset by lower production volumes.

"
column253:
"

On Page 16 we look at the Legacy Asset Servicing business
column254: which you'll recall is the business where we move a bucket of loans that are either significantly delinquent loans or products that we no longer are interested in participating in
column255: you can see
column256: once we adjust out the onetimers here
column257: the net loss for the quarter was $1.4 billion compared to roughly $800 million during the first quarter. The 2 principal reasons for the increased loss was the result of increased costs from staffing levels within the business
column258:
as well as an increase in provision.

"
column259:
"

As you monitor the progress in this business
column260: this is obviously a discrete portfolio
column261: where we're both trying to work down the number of loans in the portfolio
column262: as well as reduce the number of delinquent loans in the portfolio. And if you look in the bottom left-hand corner
column263: you can see we made very good progress during the quarter. Number of loans serviced was down about 3.3%
column264:
and the number of 60 days -- number of loans 60 days delinquent in the portfolio was down roughly 5%.

"
column265:
"

On Page 17
column266: we look at All Other
column267: which is a net loss of $216 million. That's the result of elevated credit cost related to valuation refreshes on our consumer loans
column268: as well as lower revenues. As you look at the revenue line item for the quarter
column269: 3 types of items that affected revenue for the quarter. We had roughly a $200 million FVO adjustment on our structured notes
column270: $831 million of gains on debt securities and about $1.1 billion of equity investment income that was comprised of the dividends from our CCB investment
column271: the gain on the disposition of the balance of our BlackRock interest
column272:
partially offset by $500 million impairment on a strategic equity investment.

"
column273:
"

During his opening remarks
column274: Brian touched on expenses. We've laid those out here. First
column275: I'd like to say a couple of things. If we exclude these selected items
column276: which we detailed elsewhere in this presentation
column277: the reported $22.9 billion of expenses was $17.7 billion in line with the first quarter and relatively flat with the fourth quarter. Expenses related to increased servicing cost in our Mortgage business
column278: as well as the additional client-facing professionals that we've talked about in this presentation
column279:
were offset by reduced personnel in various other areas of the company.

"
column280:
"

We referenced New BAC. In May
column281: we initiated New BAC
column282: which is an intensive effort on our part to create greater efficiency throughout the organization. We're currently identifying ideas and action plans
column283: and we intend to begin implementing those as we get closer to the end of the year. While I know you want us to identify some potential benefits to the bottom line
column284: all I can say at this time is we're very focused on expenses
column285:
and we'll update you on the progress as we meet certain milestones.

"
column286:
"

The next couple of slides
column287: I'm going to talk briefly about credit trends
column288: which continued to be quite strong. On Slide 19
column289: we look at consumer credit trends. You can see net charge-offs
column290: delinquencies and nonperformers continue to improve
column291: and the total provision expense for the quarter for our consumer loan portfolios was $3.8 billion
column292:
which is comprised of $5.2 billion of charge-offs and a reserve reduction of $1.4 billion.

"
column293:
"

On Slide 20
column294: we look at mortgage and home equity delinquencies. What I would highlight here
column295: as you can see
column296: delinquencies peaked in the second quarter of 2009
column297:
and we've seen 5 quarters of continued reductions in those delinquencies through the second quarter of 2011.

"
column298:
"

On Slide 21
column299: we look at nonperforming assets within our residential Mortgage and Home Equity books. You can see that during the second quarter of 2011
column301: as well as greater than 180-day delinquencies
column302:
improved in both residential mortgage and home equity.

"
column303:
"

With that being said
column304: I'd make 2 additional points. The first charge-offs do remain elevated due to refreshed valuation losses
column305: even though the frequency of loss continues to improve. The second thing I would note is that we've started to see the greater than 180-day backlog decline as foreclosure activity has started
column306:
particularly in most nonjudicial states.

"
column307:
"

On Slide 22
column308: we talked about home price impact on the call on June 29. We said we'd give you some greater color on that
column309: and what we've laid out here are those portfolios that are most subject to immediate changes in home prices. As you think about home prices in our assumptions
column310: once again
column311: we look at macro markets. Currently
column312: our assumptions are very much in line with those. We expect a little bit north of a 3% decline in home prices in 2011 and a 1% increase in 2012
column313:
largely during the second half.

"
column314:
"

As you think about the individual portfolios that are affected by home prices
column315: we have roughly $40 billion of portfolios that are directly affected
column316: $13 billion of nonperforming loans that are more than 180 days past due that have been written down to net realizable value. Given they're at net realizable value
column317:
every 1% decline in home prices will have a correspondingly immediate effect on this portfolio.

"
column318:
"

Within purchase credit impaired
column319: which is carried at $0.66
column320: we have $27 billion of carrying value. That portfolio
column321: on average
column322: is about 40% delinquent. So as you think about a 1% decline in home prices
column323:
it will be immediately affected but not to the entire magnitude of the decline in home prices.

"
column324:
"

Outside of that which is on our balance sheet
column325: we're affected by home prices in the GSEs. If you think about how we're affected by the GSEs
column326: to the extent home prices go down
column327:
it affects the collateral losses which they bear. We obviously share those collateral losses to the extent that we have defects. We currently estimate that about every 1% change in home prices is $125 million relative to the GSEs.

"
column328:
"

We've not touched on or talked to how changes in home prices can affect our core portfolio
column329: that obviously is something that happens over a period of time
column330: and we provide reserves over and above what our model reserves are
column331:
to try to reflect those types of risks that are out there.

"
column332:
"

On 23
column333: we look at commercial credit trends. Charge-offs declined $180 million in the second quarter of '11
column334: relative to the first quarter. Total provision was a benefit of $523 million and reflected a reserve reduction of $1 billion in the quarter. I would also note
column335: you can see that both nonperformers and reservable credit size declined 11% during the quarter
column336:
as corporate credit continued to improve.

"
column337:
"

Let's now shift from credit to capital. On 24
column338: we've laid out our Basel I Tier 1 common
column339: which Brian alluded to at 8.23%. And as I mentioned earlier
column340:
23 basis points of benefit based on the improvement in risk-weighted assets under Basel I.

"
column341:

column347: we will be well above all of the minimums that are required under Basel
column348: and once again
column349: as we told you at the end of June

column351:
as we enter into 2013.

"
column352:
"

On Slide 27. As we think about Basel mitigation
column353: we show you the different things that we've completed since we became very focused on this at the beginning of 2010. If you look at the bottom left
column354: we talked about the things that we've accomplished during the first half of '11. Risk-weighted assets under Basel I
column355: down by over $60 billion due
column356: in part
column357: to reducing our legacy capital markets
column358: risk exposures. Our MSR
column359: as I referenced
column360: is down $2.5 billion
column361: and we completed asset sale gains
column362:
generating $1.3 billion of Tier 1 common gains and reducing risk-weighted assets by $5 billion during the first half of the year.

"
column363:
"

As we look out at the activities that we're focused on to meet the guidance that we've given at year-end 2012
column364: on the numerator side
column365: under Basel III
column366: we see additional mitigation of $200 billion to $250 billion that will enable us to get to our targeted Basel III risk-weighted assets of $1.8 trillion. The way that we'll get there is to continue to reduce our capital-intensive assets
column367: rebalance our portfolios and optimize our models to be able to get to where we need to for Basel III. We'll also continue to very aggressively
column368: as I talked about in interest rate
column369:
to manage the OCI risk associated with our interest -- our net interest income.

"
column370:
"

The last point here
column371: future mitigation efforts. We've obviously heard the question that's out there: Your 6.75% to 7% at the end '12
column372: where do you go beyond that? As you look to get to the fully phased-in number of 9.5% by the end of '19
column373: even with all of the actions that we've talked about
column374: we have significant additional actions we can take in '13 and beyond. We've laid out 3 portfolios of assets here that we would expect to reduce aggressively. We have a loan run-off portfolio of $70 billion
column375: that we would expect at the end of '12
column376: that runs off by roughly 20% a year. We have a structured credit trading book
column377: that's roughly $30 billion at the end of '12
column378: that will run off over a 5-year period as well. And we have a private equity portfolio that's roughly $50 billion under Basel III
column379: that will be out there at the end of '12
column380: that we'd expect to run off over the several years beyond 2012. In addition to that
column381:
you can expect to see us continue to reduce assets in the way that we've done over the course of the last 6 quarters.

"
column382:
"

If we move now from the denominator to the numerator
column383: 2 things I want to touch on here. The first is the MSR. We referenced that the MSR is $12.5 billion at the end of the second quarter. You can expect to see us taking 2 types of actions with respect to the MSR
column384: going forward
column385: that will benefit the numbers beyond the 6.75% to 7% range I quoted. The first is we're taking a very close look at the types of activities we're originating in servicing. So on the front end
column386: you'll see actions where we look to scale back
column387: that which we put on our books to service. Secondly
column388: we're very focused on looking out and moving MSR assets through sale
column389:
in those instances where it makes sense. We had roughly $70 million of gains on MSR sales during the second quarter of this year.

"
column390:
"

The last thing I want to highlight on the numerator is the deferred tax asset and the multiplier effect with respect to that. As I think everyone knows
column391: the deferred tax asset flows through the Basel calculations in several different ways
column392: depending on whether or not it's an NOL DTA or a timing DTA. As you think about the leverage though and the benefits that we will have from the reductions in DTA through 2012 and significantly but -- beyond
column393: at the end of June
column394: we'll have roughly $30 billion of a net deferred tax asset
column395: roughly 2/3 of that is associated with NOLs and 1/3 is associated with timing. The net effect of that is that we would expect our Tier 1 common to grow at a rate that's above that
column396:
which is improved just by the generation of net income.

"
column397:
"

As we look to wrap up and close
column398: we continue to work very diligently in getting the legacy assets -- or excuse me
column399: the legacy issues
column400: as well as the legacy assets
column401: behind us while we reposition our business for future growth. If you think about the earnings this quarter
column402: they demonstrated that our businesses outside of mortgage are producing attractive returns
column403: even with the headwinds of low interest rates. Deposits continue to grow as we make progress on our customer-focused relationship strategy. Credit quality continues to improve. We have solid capital ratios. Our liquidity position is very strong
column404: and we expect to grow capital going forward. We look at the opportunity each day to make progress
column405:
and that's what we are all about.

column732: not at trend tomorrow. So it's a modest growth environment that the economy keeps grinding along and grinding along and -- but doesn't improve dramatically in the short term

several investors have asked about the idea of a potential capital raise. We've kind of gone full circle here. So just your level of conviction? Can you provide any more comfort -- do you have more confidential information than any of us to have on the call?

column840:

Brian Moynihan

"
column842: we've given you the improvements we've made in the capital. And even with the sizable $20 billion charge this quarter
column843: that impacted 20 basis points. So our economic scenario is posted -- is out there. The scenario that we used to plan against this is the one you see out in the domain
column845: and we don't see anything in that. The challenges we have reserved -- the difference between now and a couple of years ago when people worried about deterioration in the economy
column846: when employment obviously rose and think about the reserve levels we have
column847: think about the improvements in the portfolios that we have made across that. So when -- there's lot of discussion about future home risk
column848: there-- risk the charge-offs in -- our mortgage portfolios combined between home equity and first residential. $2.5 billion off that quarter is still an unacceptable level. But they're down from the peak even while housing prices actually have deteriorated from the time they peak
column849: because the quality of the portfolios and the quality of borrowers in the portfolios is different than it was. So that gives us good step between reserves
column850: the capital we built in the quality portfolios to hold us against economic times
column851: which are going to bounce around
column852: and that's what we've done. So you see this quarter
column854:
we took a 20 basis point hit to ratios and plowed through it.

A couple of things. As I'd say -- if you think about the quarter and what we absorbed
column865: it was obviously a fairly significant negative effect on hedge income
column866: and we clearly would not expect that to happen again
column867: given how flat the yield curve is as we look out there. The second thing that I would say is that we had some runoffs in the corporate book during the second quarter that we wouldn't expect to see again. So I think as we look at the number
column868: absent some meaningful change in the rate environment
column869: when we look at both the assets that we have
column870: as well as the rates that are applied against them
column871:
I think that the -- we feel pretty good that we're pretty close to the trough as it relates to net interest income.

column882: but I just want to reiterate that the reason it's there is because we're very sensitive to OCI risk and making sure that as we go out towards Basel III
column883:
that we don't have any negative effects from OCI.

column885:

But I think if you think about it more broadly
column886: the -- what's been going on in the last many quarters that we've been trying to make sure people saw is that as you\u2019ve ran off some high-yielding assets
column887: which don't have a net profit contribution because the charge-off exceeded yield and that keeps running down
column888: that was hurting us. And then what we -- and the offsets that were grinding down your debt cost and your deposit cost. The issue now is that the core loan growth is still -- is modest and even backing out the runoff portfolios
column889: just because the economic activity is not that strong. So that is -- that helps and that we're seeing that activity be a little stronger than it was several quarters ago
column890: but it's bumping along the deposits. So we continue to drive down deposit costs and OEM costs of debt by paying off the term debt
column891: as someone mentioned earlier. So we'll be grinding at this. So the assumption is as we trough out here
column892: it'll continue for a while. It's not going to leap right back up. So we want to make sure that you guys see it
column893: but it's in line with what we've been predicting for 6 quarters
column894: that this would be the place where we'd sort of see it bottom out. But long term
column895: it'll -- we'll have to grind from here
column896: on both the liability pricing side
column897: the debt cost side and also
column898:
you grind out loan growth slowly but surely.

column899:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

column900:
"

Yes. And a separate but somewhat related issue. As you mentioned
column901: $475 million a quarter of impact from Durbin. Obviously
column902:
that's less than you thought before potentially. But can you talk a little bit about your strategies to mitigate that from both from a product and pricing standpoint?

"
column905: Durbin gets caught with all the other changes that have gone on
column906: as opposed to any of them going back
column907: what seems like a long time ago
column908: to CARD Act and then Reg E and Durbin and all the pieces. So we're on the consumer business. So how do -- how are we mitigating the activity. If you look what we've been doing as the new account structure has now been rolled out in 3 states for new accounts and then now for all accounts and they're converting the account
column909: that is all going very well. So we'd expect that conversion to take place during 2012. And what that does is institute some monthly fees and other ways customers can pay us
column912: devalue the interchange in Durbin. And so the pricing structure that is set
column913: will be set -- is set and will be set to generate the activity. The good news is that -- reasonably good news is that where we ended up in Durbin is a place where we continue to drive debit usage. And as you can see from the statistics on the -- on the Card page
column914: you can see the payments made through plastic
column915: and our franchise continue to grow 5%
column916: 6% a year. You take out the gas prices
column917: it's 4% to 5% a year. Gas price contribute 1.5% to 2% of that. So we will continue to drive the usage of that
column918: which continue to drive the revenue up from a level after the Durbin takes it away. So it's the account structure. It's the pricing within that monthly accounts. It's the charges that you've seen some of us put in across the last several months to make up for some of the fee loss. But the real benefits that come -- really as we convert the entire account base to new structure in '12 and into '13
column919: and the benefits come in '13 after you're done with the conversions. And think about this
column920: this is all 30 million checking holders going through a conversion or franchise
column921: so it's a large conversion and will take place after we finished migrating the deposit platforms together. So it's going well. It's having intended outcome
column922: both from a dollars and cents basis but also from a customer behaviors basis
column923: and we'll continue to drive that. That all being said
column924: the other way that we'll get paid is to have to maintain discipline deposit pricing
column925: as short-term rates rise at some -- as the economy improves and that will be credit for us to do. You've seen our ability to continue to take down deposit pricing and grow deposits and the competitor for customer's deposit money won't be competitive until short-term rates rise quite a bit. And so if we maintain a deposit price
column926:
another way to make up for that cost.

column948: I think we can get back to you with the exact numbers. I believe

Two questions for you. First
column977: on the Commercial Bank. I think you said that CRE declined by about $2.2 billion
column978:
and then you had some loan growth in Middle Market C&I. Has the Middle Market C&I loan growth continued as we've gone into the third quarter here? And was the CRE runoff planned or unplanned?

"
column980:
"

Start with the Commercial Real Estate. I think the -- given both the capital markets as the -- as well as the refinancing markets
column981: I would say part of the real estate was planned and part of it
column983: were assets that were either criticized or nonperformers coming off the books. So as we look at that Commercial Real Estate number
column984: we obviously don't like to see loans going down at the same time that there was some stuff that you would have wanted to come off. And we feel very good about where the Commercial Real Estate portfolio is now and
column986: are trying to figure out places to do more commercial real estate where it makes sense. With respect to the C&I portfolio within the Middle Market
column987: that's about $37 billion of the overall Commercial Banking portfolio. And if you go back and look at that since the second quarter of last year
column989:
and that really is the core guts of the client base that we're very focused on within the Commercial Bank.

"
column991:
"

I guess the sort of the root of my question is the companies that we've seen report
column993: are sort of reporting the glimmers of commercial beginning
column994:
commercial loan growth. And I just wanted to see if that was your experience as well or if you can just give us sort of an overall view of where -- whether we're at a growth inflection point yet?

"
column998: as you came through the -- from the end of last year and the first part of this year
column999: you were seeing David Darnell would say the core Middle Market book
column1000: the customers were more -- were optimistic
column1001: and they were starting to grow a little bit. I think that sort of flattened out a little bit
column1002: so there's still some growth as we pointed out here. But if you look at the utilization rates and stuff
column1004: they were at a low probably 31% or 32%. They're sort of in the 34.5% to 30% range. They would be in a 43% range in normalized times. Now people have excess cash
column1005: but I'd say that as we've gone through the year this year
column1006: I think that people who are less aggressive -- our clients are less aggressive in the core broad middle market spectrum than they were earlier this year
column1007:
but the loan balances are holding in and growing slightly.

"
column1010: and I just have one final question for you. We've been getting several articles lately about what seems to be a prominent change in the attitude toward homeownership in the U.S.
column1011: want to get your opinion on that. And also
column1012: just when all is said and done here and whatever year that may happen
column1013:
how do you see the mortgage business as a contributor to the bottom line at BAC?

"
column1015:
"

Let me go to the second one first -- Nancy
column1016: because I think it kind of answers the first one in some respects. Leave aside the exact dollars and cents
column1017: but the way we see the Mortgage business and our company going forward is we have 50 million consumer households
column1018: 30 million have their core banking checking accounts with us
column1020: our job is to provide mortgage products to not only our general customers in our Retail and Preferred segment
column1022: Global Wealth Management customers in a very strong
column1023: very focused and very -- in a very fair way. And that's what we're going to drive to and that's what you expect to see in our Mortgage business going forward. I think the idea of being in a stand-alone context
column1024: where we had a wholesale business
column1026: a broker-driven business. We've gotten out of the -- reverse mortgage
column1027: we've gotten out of. We continue to shape our yield what the correspondent business looks like. But a -- the business that will be in
column1028: it will be a strong direct to consumer -- direct-to-retail
column1030: and that's where we're moving Barbara and the team and moving the business to. That actually fits into the capital demands of MSR and other things
column1031: as you could well figure out. So that's how we're going to run the business for the benefit of our customers
column1032: as if -- as the same way we're running all our business
column1033: making sure every ounce of our capital is used to support the core customer base and
column1035: to do the mortgage product very well for that customer base. When you back into the broader context
column1036: I think the homeownership discussion is a policy discussion I'd leave to policymakers. But as you look at our customers and listen to them and watch what they've gone through
column1037: I think that the people in the world
column1039: are going to think differently about homeownership
column1040: in terms of the value of it and how it factors into their thinking
column1041: because of what they've seen going on around them. And I think that that's just the reality where we're in. Doesn't mean it's good or bad
column1042: it's just the reality. And I think with the population growth dynamics and things like that in the United States
column1043: I think that that's going to be the reality of a more sober society on this. And I think our jobs are to buy products into that and help people become homeowners
column1044: because it's ultimately something they may aspire to
column1045:
but do it the right way.

"
column1047:
"

And due to the time
column1048:

column1049:
"

Christoph Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.

"
column1050:
"

Yes. When you look at the trading results on Page 26 of the supplement
column1051: it looks like your total trading profits this quarter were almost exactly in line with the trailing 4 quarter average. And so I'm curious -- what you're -- is this the new normal
column1052: or do you still view this as a depressed trading environment? And then what's the outlook for this business? And if the revenues remain at this level that they've been in
column1053:
is the expense side of that business properly structured then?

"
column1055:
"

I'd say that -- I'd still say we're probably below normal right now in the minds of Tom and the team running it. The -- and so I think that you won't see what you saw
column1057: in the first quarter of last year and things like that. That was above -- way above normal. We tried to talk about -- we've talked about sort of $4.5 billion range that -- in total revenue
column1059: plus the margin and other things. But -- so I think that that's -- I think we're still below the normal. The question is
column1060: unless you see the improvement back to normal
column1061: we will have to continue to work on the expense. And in fact
column1062: that's what Tom has been doing. If you look at our business
column1063: the headcount that he's had has been relatively flat. But -- we've done is deployed to -- in international space
column1064: for example -- obviously Asia being key component
column1066: we've got strong Asia-wide research ratings
column1068: things like that. So we deployed resources there to help our teams
column1069: sales people to cover the clients. At the same time
column1070: the total deployed resources headcount has been flattish
column1071: and we've been taking it out of places where the opportunities aren't as big. So you ought to expect us to continue to manage the business that way. In the aggregate
column1072: this is a little below normal. If it doesn't get above normal
column1073: then the cost structure come down but -- and the comp structure is one of the quick ways to adjust it
column1074:
but ultimately you got to keep factoring that in.

"
