Todd L. Hagerman - Sterne Agee & Leach Inc.
column37:
Research Division

"
column40: everyone and welcome to today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Kevin Stitt. Please go ahead
column41:
sir.

"
column42:
"

Kevin Stitt

"
column43:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column44: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column45: and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. These factors include
column46: among other things
column47: changes in economic conditions
column48: changes in interest rates
column49: competitive pressures within the financial services industry and legislative or regulatory requirements that may affect our businesses. For additional factors
column50:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column51:
"

And with that
column52:
let me turn it over to Brian

"
column53:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column54:
"

Hi. Good morning
column55: and thank you for joining us. Today
column56: we reported net income of $6.2 billion or $0.56 a share after preferred dividends. There were a lot of moving parts that impacted numbers
column57: and we'll get to those through the discussion here. In addition
column58: our earnings benefited from our own credit spreads widening. It related to fair -- positive fair value adjustments and DVA gains. Those items
column59:
Bruce will cover along with the other significant items in the rest of the presentation.

"
column60:
"

Our core revenues continued to be adversely impacted by a challenging environment
column61:
as low interest rates and the European debt crisis persist. It is especially evident in our fixed income trading results for the quarter.

"
column62:
"

As we think about the third quarter
column63: I think of 3 core areas. One of the areas is the continuation of the master strategic repositioning of our franchise. Another of the areas is the core operating platforms progress that we made in the quarter in each line of business. And the third area is the focus on the slow economy
column64: and its impact on how we're going to run the company going forward. So let's first talk about the first area
column65:
the strategic transformation of the company.

"
column66:
"

During the quarter
column67: we made steady progress repositioning our business to focus on our core customers and clients. We finalized the reconfiguration of our Credit Card business that we began in 2009 to focus solely on U.S. core credit card customers
column68:
exiting non-U.S. portfolios such as Spain and Canada and now exited the U.K. We also sold off some of the financial institutions platforms in the United States which enabled competitors to offer cards to compete against us.

"
column69:
"

In our mortgage area
column70: we've exited our correspondent
column71: previously exited our wholesale channels
column72: which when you put all together focuses solely on a direct-to-retail channel. This is a position which enables to serve our core customer base and do it on a basis consistent with driving our franchise. In addition to repositioning those businesses
column73: we've taken all our consumer businesses from our core consumer business through our Wealth Management businesses and put them under our new co -- one of our co-CEOs
column74: David Darnell
column75:
to drive those businesses on a customer and client-focus basis.

"
column76:
"

During the quarter
column77: we also sold half our interest in CCB
column78:
lowered our private equity investment substantially and made further progress on noncore assets dispositions.

"
column79:
"

As we move from a strategic transformation of the company to the line of the business
column80: we continue to see momentum in our core lines of businesses. We extended approximately $141 billion in credit for the third quarter. Our average deposits continue to grow. Our average commercial loans increased in all our regions
column81:
although our consumer loans are still declining mainly in the noncore areas. Our net checking accounts grew for the third consecutive quarter and attrition remains low.

"
column82:
"

We're seeing good progress with initiatives to grow through adding financial services advisers in our branches and Small Business Bankers in our broad consumer areas. We're seeing steady progress in our Wealth Management businesses
column83: U.S. Trust and Merrill Lynch
column84:
where we continue to add advisors and push forward in these market leading areas.

"
column85:
"

We continue to see solid performance on our commercial and corporate lending businesses
column86: including Global Commercial Banking and Global Corporate Investment Bank. In addition
column87:
we retained our second place position in investment banking and produced solid international customer growth in that area.

"
column88:
"

Our credit quality and delinquencies continue to improve
column89:
while reserve coverage remains at high levels.

"
column90:
"

As we think about the third area we're focused on
column91: how to manage in a slow or long-term recovery
column92: we're doing everything we can to continue repositioning the earnings of our company as we look forward. We continue to focus on driving growth in select areas
column93: very select areas
column94: but we're also focused on reducing expenses. Expenses remain elevated in large part due to nearly $2 billion in quarterly operating expenses at Legacy Asset Servicing. We hit our peak and headcount in July across the entire company
column95:
and are now managing down across all areas.

"
column96:
"

LAS is at its peak staffing level
column97: showed more of that overall staffing reduction should come through the bottom line. Our New BAC efficiency initiative is making progress. During the quarter
column98: we completed a Phase 1 evaluation and now we're implementing
column99: and you'll see the results as we come through the fourth quarter. The Phase 2 evaluation begins this month
column100:
and it will bear strong fruit.

"
column101:
"

With that
column102:
let me turn it over to Bruce to go through the financials.

"
column103:
"

Bruce R. Thompson

"
column104:
"

Thanks
column105: Brian. And good morning
column106: everyone. If I can ask you to flip to Page 5
column107: and we'll start on the income statement. As Brian referenced
column108: we made $6.2 billion for the quarter or $0.56 a share
column109: and these numbers were affected by several significant items that I'll walk you through and go through in more detail as we get into the presentation. The quarter did include a credit mark on structured liabilities under fair value option that resulted in a positive mark of $4.5 billion as a result of our credit spreads widening
column110:
and as you look at our financials you'll see that in other income.

"
column111:
"

Keep in mind that mark
column112: whether it be positive or negative
column113:
does not impact regulatory capital ratios such as Tier 1 common but does affect GAAP capital.

"
column114:
"

The widening of our credit spreads also generated a DVA gain of $1.7 billion related to our trading liabilities within our Global Banking and Markets business
column115:
and I'll get into more detail on that later in the presentation.

"
column116:
"

Our equity investments had a net $1.4 billion in gains
column117: driven primarily by 2 sale transactions and a write-down. As Brian referenced
column118: we did sell half of our investments in CCB for $8.3 billion in proceeds. That generated a pretax gain of $3.6 billion. X our sale of China Construction Bank
column119:
equity investments would have been a negative $2.2 billion.

"
column120:
"

As we move to net interest income
column121: we had 2 areas that negatively affected net interest income. The first was hedge ineffectiveness
column122:
a negative $600 million as well as a negative $400 million associated with the acceleration of amortization of premiums on securities during the quarter.

"
column123:
"

If we move down to the income tax expense line
column124: it reflects a charge of $782 million related to the revaluation of deferred tax assets in our U.K. business that we mentioned last quarter
column125: as a result of the July enactment of a 2% reduction in the U.K. corporate tax rate. If we take the other items on this page
column126: and add both the positives and the negatives
column127: the other adjustments totaled a loss of $800 million
column128:
and I'll touch on these different aspects as we get through the presentation.

"
column129:
"

If you flip to Page 6
column130: and look at the balance sheet
column131: you can see that assets are down Q2 to Q3 while deposits grew moderately during the quarter. Other items I would point to in the quarter
column132: you saw a $33 billion reduction in risk weighted assets that contributed to the improvement in our Tier 1 common ratio. We reduced long-term debt by approximately $28 billion and as we look at tangible book value per common share
column133:
that increased $0.57 to $13.22 at the end of the third quarter.

"
column134:
"

Asset quality continues to be very strong. Our allowance at the end of the quarter was approximately $35 billion
column135: which is roughly 3.8% of total loans
column136: 1.74x annualized charge-offs
column137:
and we saw $1 billion reduction in our nonperforming loans and leases.

"
column138:
"

If we flip to Page 7
column139: and look at funding and liquidity
column140: as we've talked about over the last couple of quarters
column141: we continue to proactively reduce both our short-term and our long-term debt. During the third quarter
column142: we reduced short-term unsecured borrowings by approximately $15 billion to immaterial amounts at both the parent and the broker-dealer
column143: as we repaid our commercial paper and eliminated the master notes program at the broker-dealer. In addition to the reductions in short-term debt
column144: long-term debt also came down by approximately $28 billion
column145:
as maturities continue to outpace issuances.

"
column146:
"

These reductions of $43 billion were the primary drivers of the $39 billion decline in our excess liquidity sources to $363 billion. When you think about that $363 billion
column147: unlike others
column148: realized debt does not include approximately $194 billion in additional liquidity that's available to our banking entities via pledging assets to the Home Loan Banks in the Fed discount window. As we think about time-to-required funding at the parent
column149: it increased to 27 months during the quarter from 22 months at the end of the second quarter
column150:
as we generated substantial parent-company liquidity and debt maturities after 2012 or lower.

"
column151:
"

As I think everyone is aware
column152: Moody's downgraded our credit ratings late in the third quarter based on their beliefs around potential government support. We obviously disagree with those actions in that we believe that their views of unsupported credit ratings do not sufficiently reflect the significant progress we've made
column153: improving our capital and liquidity positions
column154:
shedding legacy and noncore assets and managing our risk down.

"
column155:
"

That being said
column156: we had worked hard over the course of the last 9 months to be prepared to the extent that we did receive a downgrade and feel very good about the way that we minimized the potential impact. Most importantly
column157: since the downgrade
column158:
we have not seen any change in our global excess liquidity sources.

"
column159:
"

Moving to Slide 8 and looking at net interest income. As we've spoken about before and as we think about getting ready for Basel III
column160:
we're obviously very focused on managing interest rate risk across the company and minimizing OCI exposure in higher-rate environments and managing the duration of our securities given the low level of rates.

"
column161:
"

On an FTE basis
column162:
net interest income was down approximately $754 million for the quarter. That decrease was driven primarily by 2 factors. Asset hedge ineffectiveness of $400 million and the acceleration of amortization of premiums on securities of $500 million due to the faster prepayment expectations on mortgage securities.

"
column163:
"

Importantly
column164: if we back out these 2 adjustments
column165:
our net interest income was actually up as the positive contributions to net interest income from lower debt balances as well as reductions in our rates paid on deposits more than offset the reductions that we saw from consumer balances and yields.

"
column166:
"

As we look forward to the fourth quarter
column167: and we assume that rates stayed within that same range that they are today
column168:
we would not expect to see any meaningful impact on net interest income due to asset hedge ineffectiveness or premium adjustments.

"
column169:
"

I'm going to move through Slide 9 quickly
column170: which just reflects the divergence that we've seen within our commercial -- or excuse me
column171:
our Consumer Real Estate Services business from the balance of our businesses and get to the actual segments themselves on Slide 10.

"
column172:
"

If you look at Slide 10
column173: you can see that the Deposits business had net income of $276 million
column174: which was down $148 million from the prior quarter
column175: driven principally by lower net interest income
column176: which was partially offset by increases in our noninterest or fee income category. Average deposits are up significantly from the third quarter of 2010 and down very modestly at 1% due to seasonal reasons from the second quarter of 2011. As I mentioned before
column177: the rates paid on our consumer deposits declined from 29 basis points during the second quarter of this year to 25 basis points in the third quarter. Importantly
column178:
this was a third consecutive quarter where we saw positive net new checking accounts during the quarter.

"
column179:
"

We move to our Cards Services business. The Cards Services business generated net income of $1.3 billion during the quarter
column180: which was down about $675 million from the second quarter due primarily to higher provision expense and lower revenues which were partially offset by declines in noninterest expense. The decline quarter-over-quarter in net revenues was driven by the portfolio sales that we accomplished in the second quarter and realized gains from those
column181:
as well as the NII impact from lower yields and loan balances.

"
column182:
"

As we look at provision
column183: provision did increase by $735 million from the quarter. I think it's important to note that we actually saw charge-offs decline $403 million or 17%
column184: and that was more than offset by lower reserve releases of approximately $1.1 billion. Importantly
column185: despite some of what we've seen out in the economy
column186: we've continued to see very strong credit performance within our Cards Services business
column187:
and we show you here that the different delinquency categories continue to improve Q2 to Q3.

"
column188:
"

From a low-level balance perspective
column189: average loans did decline by about $3.8 million -- excuse me
column190: $3.8 billion quarter-over-quarter due principally to higher payments
column191: charge-offs
column192: portfolio divestitures and the run-off of the noncore portfolios that we've spoken about before. The actual core portfolio was up very modestly during the quarter. As you think about purchase volumes
column193: if we adjust for our portfolio divestitures
column194:
card purchase volume was up 5% from the third quarter of last year.

"
column195:
"

The last point I would make on this page is that we have continued to see growth within the new card area
column196:
with new card accounts growing 17%.

"
column197:
"

As we leave this page
column198: I do want to note though that the sale
column199: as you look at this data
column200: that the sale of the Canadian Card business and with the intention to market the European Card business
column201: that the results of those 2 areas have been removed from this data and moved to all other
column202:
and the prior period results were restated to reflect that.

"
column203:
"

Just to remind you with the sale of our Canadian Credit Card business
column204: which has about $8 billion in receivables
column205:
we would expect that sale to close during the fourth quarter of this year. The impact of that on Tier 1 common intangible common equity will be positive when the transaction closes.

"
column206:
"

If we move to the Global Wealth and Investment Management area
column207: net income of $347 million during the quarter was down $159 million from the second quarter of '11 as lower revenue and as we faced -- or had lower revenue and higher credit costs. On the revenue side
column208: the decline in revenues was due to lower interest rates and lower transactional revenue but
column209: importantly
column210:
was partially offset by Record Asset Management fees driven by continued inflows into long-term assets under management.

"
column211:
"

The decline in client balances during the quarter was driven almost entirely by lower market levels in the stock market. As we look at Deposits
column212: Deposits were
column213: basically
column214: flat during the quarter
column215:
despite the fact that we reduced the overall rates paid on our GWIM deposits by 7 basis points during the quarter.

"
column216:
"

Lastly
column217: this was the 9th consecutive quarter that we saw increases in client facing associates
column218:
and we added a net 475 financial advisers during the quarter.

"
column219:
"

Moving to Slide 13 in Commercial Banking. Net income for the quarter was down $331 million to $1.50 billion
column220: primarily due to lower loan loss reserves and some small revenue declines. The revenue declines were due to lower net interest income
column221: as well as the absence of a gain on the settlement of a portfolio that we saw during the second quarter. Importantly
column222: expenses were down quarter-over-quarter
column223: as the business continues to manage costs tightly. And also during the quarter
column224:
we saw a fairly significant increase in average deposits as they grew by $7.4 billion quarter-over-quarter.

"
column225:
"

Loans were generally flat during the quarter. We saw continued decreases in our Commercial Real Estate. Commercial and Industrial loans were generally flat
column226:
and we saw auto loans increase by about $1.2 billion.

"
column227:
"

The last point I would make within the commercial sector is that we do continue to see very strong credit quality. Our reservable credit size exposure declined from $27 billion at the end of the second quarter to $22.8 billion at the end of the third
column228: and our nonperformers declined from $7.6 billion -- or excuse me
column229:
$7.4 billion to $6.6 billion during the quarter.

"
column230:
"

If we flip to Slide 14 in our Global Banking and Markets area. You can see that the results reflected a loss of $302 million
column231: driven by decreased sales and trading activity
column232: lower Investment Banking fees and the U.K. tax rate change during the quarter that I referenced in my opening remarks
column233:
partially offset by our DVA gains.

"
column234:
"

As you look at the sales and trading revenues
column235: you can see that they declined to $2.8 billion
column236: a $1 billion decline from the second quarter
column237: primarily driven by our FICC business due to the adverse market conditions that we saw during the quarter. As I mentioned earlier
column238: our results included DVA gains of $1.7 billion in the quarter
column239:
as our credit spreads widened throughout the quarter versus gains of $121 million in the second quarter of the year.

"
column240:
"

As you look at the individual components within our FICC business and if we back out DVA
column241: what we saw was a relatively strong performance by our rates and currencies business that was down 14% quarter-over-quarter while we had small losses in our structured credit trading
column242: certain other credit trading and our fair value option loan book. Also keep in mind during the third quarter as a result of winding down our proprietary trading business
column243:
revenue in that business decreased from $434 million in the first half of this year to 0 in the third quarter.

"
column244:
"

If we move from FICC to the equities business and once again back out DVA
column245: cash equities performed relatively well
column246:
being down only 7% quarter-over-quarter while the primary declines in our equities business were due to equity derivatives.

"
column247:
"

If we move from the sales and trading to the banking side of the business
column248: Firmwide investment banking fees
column249: excluding self-led deals
column250: were $942 million
column251: down 44% from what was a very strong second quarter due to both market uncertainty as well as declined in global fee pools. That being said
column252:
I think it's important to note that we did maintain our #2 ranking globally in that investment banking fees.

"
column253:
"

If we move to loans and deposits
column254: loan balances did increase nicely by $10.7 billion during the quarter
column255: driven primarily by growth in domestic and international corporate loans and international trade finance. Average deposit balances were up 4% to $121 billion
column256: as corporate clients continue to increase liquidity in an uncertain market environment. We continue to chip away at our legacy positions
column257: those declined 3% to $16.6 billion
column258:
led by reductions in auction rate securities as well as CDOs.

"
column259:
"

We also saw a significant declines in our VaR during the quarter. Our daily average trading VaR once again 3 year at the 99% confidence interval was down $65 billion -- or excuse me
column260:
$65 million on a linked-quarter basis.

"
column261:
"

If we move to Slide 15
column262: I want to highlight here how our mortgage model is changing. As we all know
column263: Countrywide had a large scale platform that allowed for high volumes of origination but the mortgage market has declined
column264:
and we're obviously being required to hold much more capital against our MSR asset.

"
column265:
"

As many of you have seen
column266: we recently announced our plan to exit of the correspondent Mortgage business
column267:
which we would expect to complete by the end of the year. This business is clearly not consistent with the focus on our core customers and will require us to carry the MSR assets on an unleveraged basis under proposed Basel III capital requirements.

"
column268:
"

By exiting
column269: we will not add to the MSR and importantly over time
column270: the current MSR asset associated with the correspondent business will run off. Also during the quarter
column271:
we sold certain pieces of our MSR and we would expect to continue to do so going forward.

"
column272:
"

Within Legacy Asset Servicing
column273: our operating costs remain high. That being said
column274: we did see a 6% decline in the size of our portfolio within legacy asset during the -- from the second quarter to the third quarter
column275: and we're obviously working hard to continue to reduce that. Importantly
column276:
the focus within the Mortgage business will be to be the secured lender of choice with our customers while continuing to manage down expenses to deliver on this goal.

"
column277:
"

If we flip to Page 16
column278: and look at the Consumer Real Estate Services business. I'm going to ask you to focus on the right side of the results given the large number of adjustments that we saw during the second quarter of this year. On an adjusted basis
column279: you can see that from the 2 quarters
column280: that the net loss improved from $953 million in the second quarter to $601 million in the third quarter
column281: primarily due to lower credit loss provision as well as improved net interest income
column282: partially offset by less favorable MSR hedging results. Home Loans did produced a modest profit in the quarter
column283:
while the Legacy Asset Servicing side recorded a loss from elevated expenses.

"
column284:
"

As we look at production income
column285: first mortgage production was down 18% due to primarily to us shrinking and
column286: ultimately
column287: getting out of the correspondent and wholesale areas. Importantly
column288: our core production income was flat relative to the second quarter
column289:
as improved margins more than offset lower lock volumes.

"
column290:
"

You can see in the bottom left
column291: as far as the selected charges
column292: reps and warrants were $278 million for the quarter
column293:
litigation of $290 million and assessments and waivers of $350 million.

"
column294:
"

If we spend a minute on the MSR during the quarter
column295:
you can see the MSR asset decreased significantly from $12.4 billion to $7.9 billion due primarily to declines in interest rates. And you can see the cap rate on that asset went from 78 basis points at the end of the second quarter to 52 basis points at the end of the third quarter.

"
column296:
"

A couple of pieces of sequential data on Page 17
column297: as we look at the Legacy Asset Servicing area. You can see that our 60-plus delinquent first mortgages declined 4% from roughly $1.211 million to $1.158 million. Our pretax loss
column298: x notable items
column299:
improved from a loss of $2.2 billion to $1.4 billion due primarily to the higher net interest income as well as lower provisions. The other point here is that we have had to add several thousand people to satisfy our obligations to do the mortgaging and with some of the regulations that we're seeing in that area.

"
column301: all other total revenue of $6.3 billion
column302: you can see in the middle of the page that revenue was primarily driven by the fair value adjustment on our structured liabilities
column303: the gains on our sales of debt securities
column304: as well as equity investment income. One of the things that I do want to highlight during the quarter that we accomplished
column305: you can see that our Global Principal Investments area
column306: which was primarily the legacy private equity portfolio
column307: was reduced from $10.8 billion to $6.9 billion. And as you look at our total equity investment exposure
column308: it came down by roughly 40% during the quarter from $44 billion to just under $27 billion
column309: which
column310: clearly
column311: should look to minimize some of the volatility going forward. And once again
column312:
just want to highlight that the Canadian Card and the U.K. Card business had been moved to this segment during the quarter.

"
column313:
"

From an expense perspective
column314: on Slide 19
column315: you can see noninterest expense decreased from $22.9 billion to $17.6 billion during the quarter. And if you look to back out our mortgage-related items during the quarter
column316: we still saw a nice decline in our expense base
column317: Q2 to Q3. If we look at headcount
column318: while headcount was up very modestly from Q2 to Q3
column319: it does not pick up 2
column320: 000 people that we've notified that will be leaving the company and are still in that number. And obviously
column321: as we go into the fourth quarter and we look to execute on New BAC
column322:
we look to make continued progress on that front.

"
column323:
"

As we think about New BAC
column324: on Slide 20
column325: let me just spend a minute on this. Obviously
column326: as we've gone through the low rate environment
column327: unemployment where it is
column328: an economy that's not growing at the like -- at the pace that we would like
column329: it does provide some headwinds from a revenue perspective. The one lever that we obviously have to offset that is the expense side. And as Brian referenced in his opening remarks
column330: we're in the process of completing our initial planning related to Phase 1 of New BAC
column331:
and we'll move into the second phase of New BAC later this month.

"
column332:
"

As we talked about in the presentation a few weeks ago
column333: we completed 6 mergers over the last 5 years. That added approximately 150
column334:
000 new associates. This growth in our expense base obviously provides a lot of opportunities to streamline and reduce costs going forward. That why New BAC makes sense and why it's attainable.

"
column335:
"

To summarize what we detailed for New BAC in September
column336: we divided our expenses into 2 categories
column337: controllable costs and other direct costs. In Phase 1
column338: we're focusing on our consumer businesses
column339: along with small business banking
column340: tech and ops and support areas. Based on our analysis
column341: we have a goal to achieve $5 billion in cost savings or about 18% of the expenses associated with these areas. As I said
column342:
our Phase 2 evaluations began this month and we expect to complete them in April of next year.

"
column343:
"

As you look at Phase 2
column344:
be careful to extrapolate what we believe will accomplish in Phase 1 to Phase 2 because the headcount in Phase 2 is about 50% of Phase 1 and some of the businesses in Phase 2 already have low efficiency ratios such as the commercial banks. We'll obviously update you on Phase 2 during the first part of next year.

"
column345:
"

If we move down to page of the expenses that relate to sold our liquidating businesses
column346: our goal is to obviously wind those down over time. And finally
column347: in other expenses
column348: most of these are fixed
column349:
although we expect to bring down merger charges and expect to work towards goals of reducing litigation settlement-related costs and waivers and assessments over the next few years.

"
column350:
"

If we move from the businesses to credit and the trends that we've seen in credit. As we look at consumer credit trends on Slide 21
column351: we continue to be very pleased with the progress that we're making. If you look at consumer credit trends quarter-over-quarter
column352: you can see continued declines in net charge-offs
column353: 30-plus performing delinquencies
column354: as well as our nonperforming loans and foreclosed properties. You can also see that provision expense was roughly $3.5 billion for the quarter and included roughly $1 billion of loan loss reserves. Our allowance for the consumer businesses was over $30 billion at the end of the third quarter
column355:
4.9% of total loans and 1.7x our annualized charge-offs.

"
column356:
"

The last point on consumer credit that I would make is that this is the first time in several quarters where we've not had evaluation reserves for our purchase credit impaired portfolios.

"
column357:
"

Flipping quickly to Slide 22
column358: you can see that our 30-plus performing past dues in residential mortgages continue to decline during the third quarter
column359:
and our Home Equity was roughly flat.

"
column360:
"

On Slide 23
column361: we highlight our nonperformers in both residential mortgage
column362:
and Home Equity improved modestly during the quarter.

"
column363:
"

On Slide 24
column364: as we get to our commercial credit trends
column365: credit continue to perform very well within the commercial books. We had nice declines in our nonperformers
column366: as well as our reservable criticized. Our total provision
column367: which was a benefit of $59 million
column368: included a reserve reduction of $670 million during the quarter. And once again
column369: on the commercial side
column370: roughly $4.8 billion of an allowance
column371:
1.6% of coverage of assets and just under 2x annualized charge-offs.

"
column372:
"

Moving from credit to capital. You can see here
column373: we show our Tier 1 common equity and Tier 1 capital ratios and the progression and progress that we've made. Importantly
column374: we increased each of these measures by between 45 and 50 basis points during the quarter. And as you think about these numbers
column375: realize that they are now higher than where we were at the end of the first quarter before we took the roughly $20 billion in charges that we took during the second quarter. In addition to building our common equity
column376:
these ratios also benefited from reductions in risk weighted assets of about 2.4% or $33 billion during the quarter.

"
column377:
"

Flipping to Slide 26
column378: we show both tangible common equity and tangible book. They were both up nicely during the quarter
column379: in part due to the positive fair value marks
column380: which I do want to remind people
column381: can reverse themselves when spreads tighten. The tangible common equity ratio did close the quarter at 6.25%
column383:
and tangible book of $13.22 was up $0.57 or 5%. The tangible book value also reflects the impact of the drop in the market value of the CCB shares that we hold as of the end of the third quarter of this year.

"
column384:
"

The last comment I would make is the progress that we continue to make as we look to move and meet our objectives on Basel III. You'll recall during the last quarter
column385: we gave guidance that we had a target of reduction of risk weighted assets on Basel III of $200 billion to $250 billion. As we looked and got through the quarter
column386: we've now identified all of the assets that we need to move or mitigate to accomplish that. And during the quarter
column387: we worked through more than half of those reductions during the third quarter. And as a result of that
column388: we continue to be very comfortable with our phased-in -- our fully phased-in guidance of 6.75% to 7% at the end of 2012 -- yes
column389: excuse me
column390:
at the end of 2012.

column766: if a person carries their sort of nest egg
column767: what they're saving on the run rate

column774: that is tough for us to afford to provide
column775:
and we need to provide to all our customers to be competitive. And so the fees are to get people to bring more relationships that we're comfortable with that we'll end up in a good dynamic there.

column911: if you look at the adjustments and I think the things that are out there

column962: with what we've seen in the GIPS because a couple of pieces of information you can see this through some of our different disclosures

column965: and that was down roughly $1.5 billion quarter-over-quarter. As you think about that number
column967: that number has been offset or reduced by roughly $2 billion through different CDS and short positions that we have. But when you start at that $14.6 billion
column968: realize that there are certain things that we've hedged that don't show up there. The first is
column969: and you can see in our supplement
column970: we've got $1.7 billion of CVA hedges
column971: largely against our Italian exposure. So as we think about sovereign exposure in Europe
column972: we feel very good. In addition to that
column973: we are not able to count our FVO hedges that we have on our fair option value book with the way we report for FICC. That reduces the exposure by about $2.2 billion. If you take those two adjustments and think about where we are
column974: that gets that $14.6 billion number down by several billion dollars. And I think as we've said before
column975: we got after this at the beginning of 2010
column976: so there's nothing material from a P&L perspective that you would have seen going through the income statement. If we move to France
column977: what I would say there that we obviously do a lot -- not a lot in France
column978: but we have a presence in France. I would say if you look at our exposure
column979: we obviously have exposure to the clearinghouse there
column980: which is pretty good exposure. The corporate lending that we do there
column982: is to multinationals that are not dependent within France. And then I would say
column983: if you move to the counterparties and look at what we do with the different financial institutions there
column984: it's a couple of billion dollars that we have out to the banks in the aggregate. And we manage that exposure very tightly
column985: and manage it in a way where we don't have any real tall trees to any one institution. So I would say
column986: as we look across not only to GIPS but also France and other countries that pop up
column987: we feel very good about where we're positioned. And I think that the
column988: as it relates to our book
column989:
we're more focused on -- is there a second derivative effect that comes out of what's going on in Europe as opposed to any concern with any of the exposures that we have.

Todd L. Hagerman - Sterne Agee & Leach Inc.

Good day
column48: and welcome to today's program. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Kevin Stitt. Please go ahead
column49:
sir.

"
column50:
"

Kevin Stitt

"
column51:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column52: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column53: and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. These factors include
column54: among other things
column55: changes in economic conditions
column56: changes in interest rates
column57: competitive pressures within the financial services industry and legislative or regulatory requirements that may affect our businesses. And for additional factors
column58:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column59:
"

And with that
column60:
let me turn it over to Brian.

"
column61:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column62:
"

Thanks
column63: Kevin. Before Bruce begins
column64: and good morning to everybody. Before Bruce begins his portion of the presentation on the slide
column65: I thought I'd make a few comments about 2011 and what we are focused on for 2012. The last 2 years
column66: we've been executing on a huge transformation here at Bank of America. After 6 large acquisitions in 6 years during the mid-2000s
column67: then the economic crisis and its aftermath
column68: we set on a course to simplify the company
column69: to streamline the company
column70: to reduce the size of the company
column71: to lower our risk and build a fortress balance sheet. During that
column72:
we set goals to have 9% Basel I Tier 1 common and 6% tangible common at year-end 2011.

"
column73:
"

We set goals to reduce our non-core assets. We set goals to bring our credit risk down and to address the mortgage risk related to the Countrywide acquisition. At the same time
column74: we also set goals to continue to invest in areas where our company can grow and has its competitive advantage. Areas like our Wealth Management area
column75: areas like our Preferred Small Business areas
column76: where we've added Preferred Bankers and Small Business Bankers
column77: areas like our Commercial Corporate and Investment Banking areas
column78:
especially in large corporate investment banking outside the United States.

"
column79:
"

Along the way
column80: we had to address the issues that came up in mortgage; the slow recovering economy
column81: which isn't moving -- which is moving forward but not as fast as we all like; the European crisis
column82: a muted interest rate outlook and the revenue loss to the new regulations that have been passed. These then result in our focus on cost
column83:
and we announced late -- early last fall our New BAC program and the goals that we had for it.

"
column84:
"

So as we think about 2011
column85: we saw the following. First
column86: on capital and liquidity. This quarter
column87: our Tier 1 common equity ratio ended at 9.86%. Our tangible common equity ratio ended at 6.64%. In the case of each of these ratios
column88:
they are dramatic improvement from the beginning of the year. And we made these improvements while absorbing significant mortgage-related costs during the year.

"
column89:
"

We have ratios that are in line with our peers
column90: and we expect further improvement due to continued work on our balance sheet we'll make during 2012. In addition
column91:
our liquidity is and remains at record levels even after the downgrades we experienced in the fall.

"
column92:
"

Moving from capital and liquidity to our core businesses. On Slide 3
column93: you can see
column94:
we continue to do what we're here for. We simply serve our clients and customers and we do it very well.

"
column95:
"

Our core business activity continues to move forward. During 2011
column96: we continue to grow our deposits and our investment assets for our corporate and personal customers. We originated 20% more in small business loans this year
column98: than we did in 2010. This met our internal goals we had for that unit
column99: but importantly
column100:
also met our $1 billion incremental goal we committed to the White House and the Small Business Administration a few months back.

"
column101:
"

For our commercial clients and our corporate clients
column102: we did what we're here to do. We provided more loans
column103: more capital and more market access here in the U.S. and around the world. For example
column104: in the fourth quarter
column105:
you can see strong growth in our loan balances in our corporate area.

"
column106:
"

And for our investor clients
column107: we achieved the #1 Institutional Investor Overall Research ranking. Evidenced in the quality of ideas to match our capital to help them make their investments. In our Mortgage business
column108:
we continue to reshape our operations to focus solely on origination of mortgages for our customers and to do it well.

"
column109:
"

And importantly
column110: we continue to help those who have difficulty making their payments in mortgages. We've now crossed over $1 million modified loans in our servicing portfolios. The third area we focus on
column111: after capital liquidity and the core businesses
column112: was costs. It's clear that we're going to grind forward with the recovery in this country. Our clients continue to push forward and we're seeing the activity continue to move forward
column113: but a full recovery to what we would call normal may take some time. So with that in mind
column114:
we begin to focus on bringing our cost down across the company.

"
column115:
"

Our cost structure for Bank of America has 2 broad elements today. First
column116: the cost we incur to deal with the mortgage issues. And second
column117: the remaining cost to run the rest of the company for the benefit of our customers. Overall
column118: cost were down from 2010 to 2011
column119: and we expect substantial cost savings in 2012. This quarter
column120: you can see that starting to take hold. We made significant progress towards our overall FTE reduction goals. Our period-end FTE is down about 7
column121: 000 people in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. This is over and above the 2
column122: 500 people we added in this quarter for our Legacy Asset Services. There's 2 things about this. One
column123: this shows that our New BAC  implementation has begun in earnest. And second
column124: the good news is
column125:
that we expect that LAS is at and near its peak staffing.

"
column126:
"

The fourth area we've been concentrating on in 2011 was trading. Trading was strong in the first part of the year
column127: but with the issues in Europe
column128: the down -- U.S. downgrades
column129: the downgrades of our company and changes in client risk appetite
column130: results were weak in the second half
column131: especially in the third quarter. However
column132: during the fourth quarter
column133: we partially recovered as Bruce will talk about later. Yet
column134: we still reduced risk during the quarter to ensure we were well positioned to handle what might have come up. We still have work to do in trading
column135: but the team got active this quarter as the quarter unfolded
column136:
and we saw a stronger results.

"
column137:
"

From a credit risk perspective
column138: you can see that our charge-offs and cover ratios continued to improve. We ended the year with strong ratios. And we'll also end the year with $15.9 billion in rep and warranty liability reserves. We built significant litigation and other reserves in this area also. So the 4 areas of 2011 was all about raising capital and liquidity
column139: driving the core businesses
column140:
managing the cost and risk management.

"
column141:
"

As we look at 2012
column142: these seems the same. First on capital and liquidity. Bruce will talk to you later about our targets as we look forward
column143: but the focus in this company is to continue to move through the 10% level in Basel I Tier 1 common and drive towards a Basel III implementation. Liquidity will remain high

"
column1376:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column1379: part of what I was going to ask
column1381: was about the mitigation results post 2012 because that's something you have spoken about before. But
column1383: in terms of -- on the mortgage side
column1384: just going back to that for a second there
column1386: you mentioned that no significant change or no unexpected change from the GSEs
column1387: but you did note a little bit of a build in the amount of kind of unprocessed claims
column1388: and yet you brought the reserve down. So what is it actually that you saw that allowed you to bring the reserve down? Was it kind of passage through more of the book? I mean
column1389:
how should we think about that?

"
column1393: if you think about the reserve
column1394: the reason that the reserve comes down is that because to the extent that you saddle up and pay things that you believe that you've owed
column1395: it comes out of the reserve
column1396: and the reserve comes down. And I think the other thing I'd say is that
column1399: $275 million of rep and warrant expense
column1400: so the reserve coming down was reflective of paying those things that were expected and accrued for. And then obviously
column1401:
we had a couple of hundred million of expense over and above that.

"
column1404: remember this is a little different than other things you can think about in the P&L in a financial service company in that there's really a sealed book of 2004
column1409: originations that you're working against. And so the expectations as you -- we provided for all the activity you expect to see out of that whole pool
column1410: and then -- so you're going to work this reserve down every quarter because you're using it to pay for stuff that you calculate in your expectations. So it's different than credit or other stuff in that that's the expected outcome because it's a sealed book. When you look at originations from '09 forward to '10
column1413: are much better than you would have expected when you're originating in '09. So at the end of the day
column1414: if the loan doesn't ever become delinquent
column1415: we don't talk it. This isn't a problem. The quality of the origination practice and stuff
column1422: sealed bid. And on the private label side
column1423: we didn't -- private label market stopped in '08. So you really are looking at a sealed group of loans
column1424: and that's why I'd expect the reserves to come down. And agreed
column1426: we are consistently applying the standards of resolving. If people are more aggressive on what they put to us
column1428:
and we'll deal with it over time.

"
column1429:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column1431:
"

Okay. And just a follow-up on the AG settlement. Obviously
column1432: one of the things you talked about was on principal reduction. How do you think about that as it relates to kind of current rate of charge-offs
column1433:
the amount that's sitting in your reserve and the prospective charge-offs? How do you think a change there is going to impact those items?

"
column1435:
"

We've been doing principal reductions for a number of years now. And the thing is it has -- it's always based on a situation that the assessment is a net present value from the [indiscernible] is better than the alternative
column1436: which will be foreclosed and taken through for the investors. And so I think that is a clear determiner of what better value is. So if -- and that's the basis of how you make determination. So I think overall
column1438: I think reaching a solution here
column1439: it would be positive. And as Nancy talked about earlier
column1440:
it is a rational set of criteria to get to these issues.

"
column1442:
"

And I just want to be clear and I referenced it earlier
column1443:
the reserves and where we are at year end with respect to the credit reserves within the mortgage business are reflective of our expectations from what we know now what comes out of the DOJ-AG settlement.

"
column1445:
"

This concludes today's conference. You may disconnect at this time. Thank you

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q1 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

Brian T. Moynihan - Chief Executive Officer
column8: President
column9:
Director and Member of Executive Committee

"

Good day
column41: everyone
column42: and welcome to today's program. [Operator Instructions] Please note
column43:
today's call is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Kevin Stitt. Please go ahead.

"
column44:
"

Kevin Stitt

"
column45:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column46: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column47: and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. These factors include
column48: among other things
column49: changes in economic conditions
column50: changes in interest rates
column51: competitive pressures within the financial services industry and legislative or regulatory requirements that may affect our businesses. And for additional factors
column52:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column53:
"

And with that
column54:
let me turn it over to Brian.

"
column55:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column56:
"

Thank you
column57: Kevin. Before Bruce discusses the results in detail
column58: I just want to take a minute and provide some additional thoughts on the quarter. On our last call
column59: I listed the following areas of focus for our company during 2012: We want to focus on our capital levels
column60: we want to focus on our risk
column61: we want to focus on the cost base in the company
column62:
and we also need to drive the core business improvement.

"
column63:
"

In the first quarter of 2012
column64: we have made progress in each of these areas. As you can see
column65: our capital and liquidity are at record levels in our company. Our credit costs continue to decline
column66: and our cost structure is coming down
column67: and many of the business
column68:
customer and profit metrics have improved.

"
column69:
"

So first from a capital perspective. We entered 2012 with increasing strength in our balance sheet position. We managed through the CCAR test and made significant progress on our regulatory capital ratios again in this quarter. Our Tier 1 common ratio reached 10.78% at the end of -- at March 31
column71:
"

We continue to make progress on capital at a faster pace than we expected. When we turn to risk
column72:
our credit costs fell to the lowest level in nearly 5 years. Reserve levels cover 3.6% of our loans and leases and 2x our current level of annualized credit losses.

"
column73:
"

The improvement in delinquent and nonperforming assets bodes well for further improvement in net losses as we go forward. As you know
column74: we continue to take opportunities to reduce the remaining legacy assets in the capital markets business
column75:
and we believe we have the strong litigation and rep and warranty reserves in the mortgage area.

"
column76:
"

On a day-to-day basis
column77: the average value at risk or VaR is lower in our trading business than has been some time. Yet
column78: we managed to make similar levels of sales and trading revenue
column79: excluding DVA as we did last year. The continued cost reduction remains at the forefront of our thinking at Bank of America. We continue to streamline our company. Our priority is to make our company work better for our customers
column80:
our teammates and our clients and in the process reduce costs.

"
column81:
"

As Bruce will show you later
column82: we are achieving those results. We're achieving good results in bringing down expense across our various business lines showing good progress on trends over the past year. One area we continue to work is our Legacy Assets and Servicing area. Personnel costs there are beginning to peak
column83:
and after adding significant resources over the past several months to implement a single point of contact in other mortgage programs.

"
column84:
"

We expect these Legacy Assets and Servicing costs to come down in the second half of 2012. Just for your reference in the first quarter of 2012
column85:
the expense in Legacy Asset Servicing was $3.3 billion.

"
column86:
"

As this cost increased
column87: we passed a milestone. We have now modified more than 1 million mortgages. In addition to the modifications
column88: the pace of the short sales
column89:
deeds-in-lieu and other alternative resolutions continues to make progress and continues to quick helping us reduce our delinquent loans overall.

"
column90:
"

For the rest of our company
column91: we saw a continued improvement in our costs. We expect to continue to achieve significant cost savings over the next 18 months consistent with our New BAC goals. We're finalizing New BAC 2
column92:
Phase 2 as we have told you and would discuss those expected outcomes soon.

"
column93:
"

As you are well aware
column94: headcount drives our operating cost in the end
column95: and we expect to see continued progress in this area going forward. This quarter
column96: we added more than 2
column97: 500 associates in LAS as I spoke about earlier. But overall
column98: as we work throughout the company in cost management and every other area
column99: we reduced our overall headcount
column100: including those additions in LAS by over 3
column101: 000 FTEs. That's on top of reductions 7
column102:
000 FTEs-plus last quarter.

"
column103:
"

At the same time
column104: as we're reducing our cost
column105: we continue to invest in our franchise and support the economy. During the quarter
column106: to help move the economy along
column107:
we extended more than $100 billion in loans to individuals and companies of all sizes. Showing the fifth consecutive quarter of average commercial loan growth to corporate and commercial clients.

"
column108:
"

We've added client facing teammates in selected growth areas in our company. We've hired 100 small business bankers in this quarter to further support our small business customers
column109:
bringing the total of small business bankers since the program began to over 700.

"
column110:
"

In small business lending
column111: we continue to exceed all the goals we set for small business lending
column112: including the goals we announced last fall in cooperation with the administration and Small Business Administration. In fact
column113:
we're up 17% this quarter versus last quarter -- first quarter last year.

"
column114:
"

We've added 200 Financial Advisors to our team in the first quarter. As the quarter progressed
column115: we added mortgage loan officers to focus on our direct to consumer mortgage business. As we think about the consumer business as an area we'll continue to work and we spoke about
column116: we continue to respond to changing preferences to optimize our distribution network
column117:
while investing where appropriate.

"
column118:
"

This quarter
column119: we added 0.5 million mobile banking customers during the quarter. That's about 40
column120: 000 a week of pace and continues. We now have more than 9.7 mobile banking-enabled customers. In our industry-leading online banking area
column121: we added another 0.5 million accounts this quarter
column122:
active accounts this quarter bringing us to over 30 million active accounts.

"
column123:
"

In addition
column124: through our ATM capabilities
column125: we passed a milestone. With half the deposits at Bank of America going through our ATMs that used to go through our branch platform. So overall
column126: our customers continue to do more with us through all the channels
column127: including traditional branches
column128: mobile
column129: online and ATM. But they're using the branches less
column130:
and that's why we are fine-tuning our delivery network.

"
column131:
"

We continue to align our banking center network with our customer needs. And this includes reduction and consolidations
column132: which there was a net reduction of 51 this quarter. That's part of the reduction we've spoken to you about of 750 branches over the next couple of years. In select instances
column133: we'll consider branch sales in markets where growth potential and size don't meet our goals. And at the same time
column134: we continue to expand in markets with high density
column135: where new locations can generate good results
column136:
and we continue to renovate centers in all the places we do business.

"
column137:
"

We continue to use our leadership position to deepen our relationship with our customers and clients across all our franchise. In the consumer business
column138: we opened 800
column139: 000 new credit card accounts this quarter
column140: half of which
column141: even with our focus on credit quality were opened in our branches. Our innovative Bank of America card
column142: Cash 123 card
column143:
introduced only 8 months ago now has more than 1 million cards outstanding and has achieved great customer acceptance.

"
column144:
"

In our brokerage and wealth management area
column145: we continue to make progress. Brokers accounts and assets are growing nicely. In our Merrill Edge self-serve area
column146: they've grown nicely year-over-year. But most importantly
column147: our industry-leading capabilities in Merrill Lynch Wealth Management and U.S. Trust
column148: we've seen solid long term assets under management flows this quarter
column149:
some of the best we've seen in a while.

"
column150:
"

Our affluent and wealthy consumers of Bank of America is served by the best team in the business. For the fourth consecutive year
column151: we have more Financial Advisors on Baron's Top 1000 list than any other firm. When we turn to our commercial clients
column152:
we saw higher utilization of lines of credit as our commercial customers continue to take advantage of opportunities as the economy continues to grow slowly.

"
column153:
"

Our business is serving clients on our Global Banking segment
column154: and our ability to offer innovative solutions from lending
column155: investment banking
column156: treasury services. All the areas these clients need services
column157: just continuing to produce strong and steady profits
column158:
and we have maintained our #2 investment banking position on fees.

"
column159:
"

For institutional investor clients
column160: we are encouraged to see a rebound on capital markets activity. We had more than $5 billion in sales and trading revenues this quarter
column161: excluding DVA
column162:
and that's a strong quarter. Recorded positive trading-related revenue every single day in the quarter. And this quarter represents the highest ever fixed income results in our company's history. This team did a good job of continuing to build customer depth even in the uncertainty of the world's economic events over the past couple of quarters.

"
column163:
"

Let me close with this before I turn it over to Bruce. The momentum around our strategy continues to accelerate. We still have lots of work to do
column164: but the team is focused and encouraged by these results. We're going to stay focused as we said in the first quarter call
column165: we're going to stay focused on the fundamentals this year and continue to drive forward the results for our clients
column166:
customers and you our shareholders.

"
column167:
"

With that
column168:
let me turn it over to Bruce.

"
column169:
"

Bruce R. Thompson

"
column170:
"

Great. Thanks
column171: Brian
column172: and good morning
column173: everyone. I would just echo Brian's comments about the progress that we feel that we made throughout the quarter
column174: and would look to kickoff the presentation starting on Slide 4 of the investor presentation. As we look at that and think about the quarter
column175: we'd note several key takeaways
column176: some of which Brian referenced. We obviously reported $0.03 a share in earnings
column177: but when you look at and consider that number
column178: realize that includes negative valuation adjustments of $4.8 billion pretax or $0.28 a share after-tax
column179:
which is the result of our credit spreads tightening significantly throughout the quarter.

"
column180:
"

In addition to those results
column181: we accreted significant levels of both capital and liquidity throughout the quarter
column182: and each of those metrics are at record levels as we ended the first quarter of 2012. As we look at the operating results
column183: Brian referenced capital market activities
column184: and the capital markets generally improved throughout the quarter
column185: driving sales and trading results that were significantly above the fourth quarter of 2011 and in line with what we saw during the first quarter of 2011
column186: once again
column187:
excluding DVA.

"
column188:
"

Outside of the sales and trading business
column189: all of our business segments reflected improved profitability during the first quarter of this year relative to the fourth quarter of last year. Credit quality continued to improve significantly
column190:
provision expense at $2.4 billion for the quarter was the lowest that we've seen since the third quarter of 2007.

"
column191:
"

We've talked a lot about expenses. Expenses did decline from the fourth quarter of 2011
column192: despite the fact that we had higher revenue-related incentives
column193: as well as the annual retirement eligible compensation cost that occur during the first quarter of every year. Excuse me
column194: and lastly
column195: I'd highlight
column196: we capitalized during the quarter on the ability to capture significant gains on some of our subordinated debt and preferred securities
column197:
$1.2 billion pretax during the quarter.

"
column198:
"

If we turn to Slide 5
column199: where we give a little bit more income statement information. You can see the buildout of the net income of $700 million or $0.03 a share. The one thing I would highlight when you look at the income statement
column200: that the pretax pre-provision number of $3.3 billion does not add back the $4.8 billion of FVO or DVA that we had during the quarter or for that matter any of the other selected items
column201:
which I'll go through now.

"
column202:
"

As we look at things during the quarter that benefited net income
column203: I referenced the debt and trust preferred repurchases
column204: in addition to that $1.2 billion during the quarter
column205: we had $800 million of gains both within our private equity portfolio
column206:
as well as on the gain on sale of fixed income debt securities.

"
column207:
"

On the negative side
column208: I referenced the $4.8 billion of FVO and DVA. In addition to that we had $900 million of annual retirement eligible compensation cost that once again as you recall
column209: we incur each year during the first quarter of the year
column210: and roughly $800 million of litigation expense
column211:
the majority of which was not mortgage-related.

"
column212:
"

If we turn to Slide 6
column213: and look at capital. We obviously built significant levels of capital from the third quarter to the fourth quarter of last year when we took our Basel I Tier 1 ratio from 8.65% to 9.86%. We had another very strong quarter from a capital accretion perspective
column214: growing capital from 9.86% to 10.78%. If you look at the components of that increase
column215: 4 buckets that we've laid out here. The first roughly 7 basis points in capital by virtue of the fact that employees were paid a portion of their 2011 compensation in stock. The gains on repurchases of sub debt and trust preferred exchanges and repurchases I referenced were 13 basis points of capital. And most significantly
column216: during the quarter
column217: risk-weighted assets declined by $64 billion during the quarter
column218:
which contributed 52 basis points to our benefit in our common ratio.

"
column219:
"

As you think about that 52 basis points of improvement
column220: think about that in the context
column221: 2/3 of that represented pure exposure reduction
column222: and roughly 1/3 of that represented declines as we continue to analyze
column223: refine and optimize our capital calculations. And then lastly
column224:
about 20 basis points of capital from earnings.

"
column225:
"

As you look at that earnings
column226: realize that the FVO piece of the charge that I referenced does not negatively impact or positively
column227: if it goes the other way
column228: regulatory capital. As a result of this capital accretion that we've seen during the quarter
column229: we've previously given you guidance that we would expect to be at 7.25% to 7.5% of Tier 1 common under Basel III on a fully phased-in basis at the end of 2012. Based on the improvement we saw this quarter
column230:
we're very comfortable increasing that guidance to above 7.5% at the end of 2012.

"
column231:
"

If we move from capital to liquidity on Slide 7
column232: you can see that during the quarter
column233: our excess liquidity sources across the company grew by $28 billion to an all-time record of $406 billion at the end of the first quarter. As we look at parent company liquidity
column234: it increased to $129 billion during the quarter
column235: which is up $4 billion. While at the same time
column236:
on a net basis our parent company debt was reduced by $5 billion.

"
column237:
"

Importantly
column238: as we talk about liquidity
column239: we quote a time-to-funding metric. That time-to-funding metric increased to 31 months during the first quarter and with $129 billion of parent company liquidity
column240: we're in a great shape to address the $34 billion of parent company maturities we have during the second quarter
column241:
which includes the remaining $24 billion of debt associated with the Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program or TLGP.

"
column242:
"

As you recall
column243: we worked hard. We no longer -- or have very little parent company or broker-dealer short-term unsecured funding
column244: and as we look out at the balance of the year
column245: we issued just over $5 billion of debt during the first quarter. Based on what we're seeing now
column246:
we clearly expect that to be less during the entirety of the remainder of the year.

"
column247:
"

Moving to Slide 8
column248: to look at certain balance sheet items. I referenced the reductions in risk-weighted assets. You can see that we had about an $8 billion increase in deposits during the quarter. Our tangible common equity ratio remained very strong at 6.58%. Tier 1 common grew by just under $5 billion to $131.6 billion
column249:
which contributes to the 10.78% Tier 1 common ratio I just referenced.

"
column250:
"

Tangible book remained relatively flat at $12.87. And you can see below
column251: our allowance continues to cover our annualized charge-offs by about 2x
column252:
and our liability for reps and warrants remained relatively flat at $15.7 billion.

"
column253:
"

If we move away from capital and liquidity
column254: net interest income on Slide 9. Net interest income increased sequentially from the fourth quarter to the first quarter by about $100 million. As you look at and think about that change
column255: we benefited from about $500 million of less premium amortization and hedge ineffectiveness. In addition
column256: $100 million improvement by virtue of lowering our rates paid on deposits
column257:
as well as the contraction of our debt footprint. And offsetting those benefits were reductions from declines in consumer balances and yields of about $400 million.

"
column258:
"

We turn to Slide 10
column259: we've laid out here the changes that we've made from a business segment reporting changes. I'm not going to go through these. We've laid it out there. We filed an 8-K last week. That gave you a lot of information as to what those numbers look like with those changes. And while we apologize for the additional work that it creates
column260: I would note that it very much aligns our business segments with the way that we manage both our customer relationships
column261:
as well as the way that we manage the overall company.

"
column262:
"

On Slide 11
column263: we highlight the results of our Consumer & Business Banking segment. Earnings for the quarter were $1.5 billion
column264: which is an increase of 17% from the fourth quarter and was driven by both lower expenses
column265: as well as lower provision. From a deposit perspective
column266:
average deposits were up 1.4% or more than $6 billion during the quarter.

"
column267:
"

The rates that we paid on those deposits declined during the quarter to 20 basis points. As we look at credit and debit card purchase volume
column268: volume had a seasonal decline of 6% from the fourth quarter
column269:
but increased 4% from a year ago.

"
column270:
"

In U.S. credit card
column271: new accounts grew by 19% from the first quarter a year ago. I would note that as we look at the U.S. credit cards
column272: there's been a significant change in the way that we open new accounts. We're very focused on leveraging our franchise and online networks
column273:
while scaling back what we do from a direct mail perspective.

"
column274:
"

Average loans during the quarter declined $5.6 billion from the fourth quarter due to seasonality
column275: divestitures that occurred at the end of the fourth quarter
column276:
as well as the continued runoff of our non-core portfolio.

"
column277:
"

Lastly
column278: within the card space
column279: credit quality continued to improve. U.S. credit card losses improved for the tenth consecutive quarter
column280:
and the 30-plus day delinquency rate declined for the 12th consecutive quarter.

"
column281:
"

Turning to Slide 12 and looking at our Consumer Real Estate Services area. It reported a loss of $1.1 billion during the quarter. That loss was driven by the cost of managing delinquent and defaulted loans in the servicing portfolio combined with costs associated with managing other legacy mortgage exposures.

"
column282:
"

The Home Loans business
column283: which is reported within the Consumer Real Estate Services segment
column284: did record a profit of $115 million for the quarter. First mortgage originations of $15 billion were down from the fourth quarter due to our exit from the correspondent mortgaging business. Importantly though
column285: while our production volume was the lowest that we've seen in 5 quarters
column286:
production income before the negative impact of reps and warrants was the highest that we've seen in 5 quarters.

"
column287:
"

Our results for the quarter include $282 million in cost for reps and warrants
column288: primarily related to the GSEs. $313 million of litigation expenses
column289: $410 million for expected assessments and waivers cost associated with our servicing operations
column290:
as well as overall increased cost related to our servicing operations.

"
column291:
"

As you look at the MSR
column292: our MSR asset increased by $211 million during the quarter
column293:
driven by higher rates and partially offset by borrower payments and model changes and ended the quarter at $7.6 billion.

"
column294:
"

MSR results
column295: net of hedge
column296: were positive by approximately $200 million in the first quarter and as you look at our capitalized MSR rate at the end of the quarter
column297:
it was at 58 basis points versus 54 basis points in the fourth quarter and 95 basis points a year ago.

"
column298:
"

If you turn to Slide 13
column299: some data that we want to talk about within our Legacy Assets and Servicing area that's within the CRES segment. You can see on a linked quarter basis as well as compared to the first quarter of a year ago
column300:
we continue to work hard to reduce the number of delinquent loans and find homeowner solutions.

"
column301:
"

Keep in mind
column302: Legacy Assets and Servicing now reflects all of our servicing operations and the results of our MSR activities. During the quarter
column303: we added more than 6
column305: both employees as well as third-party staffing in this area in the quarter alone. As we look at the results and as we look to drive down both the number of loans serviced
column306: as well as the number of delinquent loans
column307: the number of first-lien loans serviced dropped 3% in the quarter and more importantly
column308: the number of 60-day plus delinquent loans dropped 6%. Once again
column309: we're very focused on driving the number of 60-plus day delinquent loans down because as we drive those down
column310:
it will give us the ability to start reducing cost within the segment.

"
column311:
"

In Global Wealth and Investment Management on Slide 14

column665: at the end of the day

column667: the person who either doesn't pay or pays on their first

column918:
Global Banking loans are flat. GWIM loans are flat. Consumer is down. And it's looks like some sort of deceleration. So are you seeing a swap from at least the large loans to the capital markets? Or how do you describe what's taking place? Is there a slowdown in the U.S. economy? Are you deliberately backing away from some credits? Any color you can give would be great.

column920:

Sure. I think what I'd say is a couple of things on that
column922: we have a very strong both commercial and corporate franchise. And obviously
column923: we're very focused and especially given where we've built capital levels now
column924: as we go forward to look to build off and to grow traditional C&I loans
column926: as well as the overall corporate bank. I think when you look at in 2 of the things or 3 of the things as I referenced that were slight offsets that we made a decision on during the quarter is that we've continued to work through
column927: and we've got our commercial real estate lending down to an area that we feel good about. So going forward
column928: you wouldn't expect to see the reductions in commercial real estate that you've seen over the last couple of quarters. The second thing I would say is that we did during the quarter
column929: given what the market opportunity was and where pricing and securitization pricing was
column930: to securitize some of our DFS assets out in the market
column931: which led to some of the reductions. That's something that was opportunistic and quite frankly gives us a base to be able to go out and grow and do more with our customers on. And then the third thing that was a little bit lighter relative to year end was on the trade finance side. That
column932: that it will ebb and flow
column933: but as we've talked about before
column934: we're very focused on growing the international footprint as well. So I think
column935: while on the overall -- from an average balance sheet perspective
column936: it looked kind of flattish. We did see some growth within the areas that we're focused
column937: and those areas that there were reductions
column938: we feel like we're generally down to and have done the things that we want to do to the point where we can start growing off that base. I think if you move to the consumer space
column939: I would just note a couple of things as people look at loans in the consumer space. Obviously
column940: as we look at the home equity business
column941: that the balances were down about $3.5 billion in home equity. We clearly are not doing a lot of new home equity lending now
column942: and the fact that those balances are going down
column943: we view as a very good thing. The second thing is
column944: if you look at our supplement
column945: you'll see that the residential mortgage area is coming down. Keep in mind
column946: that's not due to residential mortgages that were originating as we look to manage the overall risk profile and interest rate profile
column948: do we want to own whole loans or do we want to own securities? And at the end of the quarter
column950:
we were a little bit more into securities than whole loans. And then the last thing I would say on loan balances is just within the Card business that seasonally your card balances obviously tend to peak in the fourth quarter. So the declines you saw in the Card business in the first quarter were largely seasonal.

"

column954:
is this a deliberate move? Are you underperforming what you'd like to achieve? Or is this simply prudent given what you're seeing in the market?
