column957: if you look at -- let's take mortgage first. If you look in the fourth quarter
column958: we did about $15 billion of direct to consumer originations
column960: we did about the same. So the real steep drop in \"our market share\" out there has been on the correspondent side just going to 0. So if you look year-over-year
column961: it dropped $20-odd billion in production. That is an absolute deliberate move. We will move -- we will be in a direct to retail channel for both our general customers and then also our affluent and wealthy customers. It's a business we think we have an advantage in
column962: and we'll continue to drive that. That being said
column964: we underperformed on a direct to retail. And we expect that and as we moved through each quarter
column966: we saw improved results in just straight volumes
column967: and we've added more loan officers. We've focused the people to getting several thousand in the quarter of referrals from the branches and working with their teammates there. We've staffed up on the fulfillment side to increase our throughput. You'd remember there's some noise about a reservation system earlier on. So we underperformed
column968: but we're doing exactly what we wanted
column969: which is to focus on direct to retail. The team's working hard. David Darnell and the team and you'll see us improve there. But the correspondent is behind us
column971: if you want that business back and go out and buy in the market is not actually a customer-driven business in the way we look at businesses here in the company. When you go into the Card business
column972: I think we have been continuing to fine-tune and have sold off some portfolios. We're providing the card as a backbone to other companies. Meaning
column974: and then we sold those portfolios back to them as part of fine-tuning the business. I'd say that we have performed as anticipated in card. We brought the direct mail down. This quarter
column978: half through the branch system with the credit quality you can see in our numbers
column979: which is outperforming what we had expected as we put the cards on over the last couple of years. So we should expect to hold our share there and start to drive it. But we still are in the straight raw market competitiveness of 15% versus 16% or something like that in the fourth quarter. It really is based on us continuing to shape the affinity groups and some of the vestiges in the U.S. business of the past. But you should expect that to stabilize now and start to grow. That's been the strategy we told you we would start in 2009 honestly
column980: and it's behaving the way we said. That being said
column981: there's plenty of opportunity for us drive the Card business in our franchise. So we have the 800
column983: the 1 million Bank of America Cash 123 cards. We will drive that business back up
column984:
but again it'll be focused on the customers.

Just a follow-up on the GSE activity. 2 separate points. First of all
column1066: with all the -- despite all the rhetoric about the GSEs kind of expanding what they're looking at
column1067: it looks like this quarter actually had a smaller kind of new claims from the GSEs than the last -- at least the previous 4. But at the same time
column1068: you're kind of activity either approving repurchases or rescinding them were both kind of much
column1069:
much lower. Could you talk about what's actually going on there and what it's going to take to get some more of this resolved as we go forward?

"
column1071:
"

What I would say is generally -- and any one quarter can bounce around a little bit. But just to reiterate
column1072: I would say that the activity that we saw during the first quarter was not significantly inconsistent with what we saw during the fourth quarter. But you're right
column1073: and the data you just quoted
column1074:
you would expect to see the number of repurchases as a percentage to decline to the extent that you disagree with what's coming in.

"
column1077: you're assuming that a loan in every quarter for the last 10 quarters is exactly what they send in is the same
column1078:
what's happened is it's different. And so the result of the activity is different because what is sent after being sent is different. It's not that the volume is different.

"
column1079:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column1081:
"

Got it. A couple of other quick things. First actually
column1082: you mentioned before the correspondent business and the Mortgage business kind of being focused on the core Bank of America customer. Is there any thought about thinking about that in the credit card business as well and kind of doing something with some of the affinity business
column1083:
the national credit card business that doesn't kind of overlap with your customer base?

"
column1085:
"

Just to be clear. The correspondent business is out of the Mortgage business. So it's a direct to retail business. In the Card business
column1087: and we've narrowed that group of affinities over the last 3 years to be consistent with where we think it adds value to the customer and to the company. And so we have major affinity programs which are very valuable to us that we continue to drive growth in. What we've done is pared off several thousand of programs
column1088: which the economics just didn't make sense. So we have achieved that. I think those are affinities with big brands that we benefit by as a company as opposed to affinities
column1089:
frankly where we are providing a credit card for another financial institution that provides a core product to their customers. That's what we really gotten out of and then smaller groups that just didn't have the volumes to make sense.

"
column1090:
"

Moshe Orenbuch - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column1092:
"

Great. And just one quick last thing and that is
column1094: some terrific progress on the capital front. I didn't catch
column1095: if you had said this before
column1096:
but do you -- have you changed your expectation of kind of year end risk-weighted assets under Basel III or has been the improvement -- has the improvement been kind of more from the numerator or is it denominator-driven also?

"
column1098:
"

If you look at it
column1099: it's going to be a little bit of both because as I referenced
column1100: as you think about what we got through and once again
column1103: we are in a disallowance under Basel I of DTA and in Basel III
column1104: we're over the 15% sin bucket. So as we generate net income and as you think about the piece that's FVO not being in it
column1105: the numerator is benefiting. And then secondarily
column1106: the denominator as we continue to work through and optimize
column1107:
it will improve. We obviously have taken the guidance on Basel III at year end fully phased-in up above 7.5%. We will look to give you greater detail on both numerator and denominator when we look at Basel III at the end of the second quarter.

"
column1109:
"

We'll take our next question from Jefferson Harralson with KBW.

"
column1115:
"

As a question on LIBOR
column1116: there's been some ruckus overseas on how it's set and regulators being concerned about potential
column1118:
issues with how it's set. Can you comment on how BAC participates in the setting of LIBOR. And if you have reserves or any concerns over this process as it plays out?

"
column1120:
"

This had been going on a while. We wouldn't comment. I'd leave it to our lawyers to talk to you about it. But that's been going on for a couple of years.

"
column1122:
"

Our next question comes from Andrew Marquardt with Evercore Partners.

"
column1123:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1125:
"

Just wanted to circle back on the margin NII commentary. In terms of -- I think you're basically saying that we should think about NII
column1126: basically holding. But I want to go back this quarter
column1127: you had the benefit that's not going to repeat. But then what were the drags? Again
column1129: maybe I missed it in terms of some consumer yield pressure
column1130:
but then is there also a core asset yield pressure because of the low rate environment?

"
column1135: if you think about it was that the -- and keep in mind we're thinking about NII now
column1136: not pretax income. The biggest difference in the quarter that was a drag was the fact that we had over $8 billion of card receivables from the Canadian card business
column1137: but that sale closed at the beginning of December. So as you think sequentially
column1138: and you think about those consumer balances and consumer yields
column1139: that was the biggest piece of it and obviously
column1140:
the number that we've put out there was that it was to the tune of about $400 million.

"
column1141:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1143:
"

Got it. And then in terms of outside of that commercial pricing competition
column1146:
is that manageable it seems like?

"
column1148:
"

I think it's manageable. I think the only other thing that I'd say is that as you look out at NII and when you run the size of the investment portfolio that we run from a rate management perspective as rates bounce around and as some of those mortgage and other type securities yields either go up or down will fluctuate with that. But there was nothing really notable for the quarter from that perspective.

"
column1149:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1151:
"

Okay. And then in terms of looking at the pre pre
column1152: this quarter came in just under on a core basis
column1155: which was just under $4 billion. But then this quarter obviously helped by FICC in mortgage banking
column1156: that may not repeat. I mean
column1157:
how should we think about that kind on a core run-rate basis? And will that improve largely now due to expenses continuing to improve based on Phase 1 and then Phase 2 next year?

"
column1159:
"

I think there's a couple of things. Obviously
column1162: you've got on the revenue side
column1163: the one variable piece that we have in revenues is going to be what you see from a sales and trading perspective. That there is a level of variability in that
column1164: either up or down. I think from a revenue perspective
column1165: given that you've backed out the different security gains and private equity gains
column1167: that's going to be the one number from a revenue line that does have the variability to it. And then I think your point is exactly right
column1168:
that what we can do to look to drive that number up is largely going to be on the expense side.

"
column1169:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1171:
"

And do you still have confidence in
column1172: maybe it's an outdated range now of 45 to 50 on an annual basis? Is that still valid or have things changed enough that
column1175:
"

I think on the prior calls
column1176: we brought -- that range has been a lower range just because we sold off a lot of the credit card and stuff when that number was originally published
column1177: but I think as we said last quarter
column1178: we're continuing -- confident that we can push the number
column1179: given the time and the interest rate environment and over $10 billion a quarter
column1180: but it's going to take that normalized interest rate environment and economy growing at 3%. As opposed to the economy growing at 1.5% or 2%
column1181:
which is what we've been consistently seeing.

"
column1182:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1185:
just on capital. Any updated thoughts on potential deployment? May be still too early but may be more confidence now that bumping up your goal and target for Tier 1 common Basel III of 7.5% by the end of the year. Any updated thoughts on when or how or maybe some thoughts also kind of lessons learned from what happened with Citigroup?

"
column1187:
"

I think we were clear in the CCAR. We said
column1188: and we came through that test
column1189: and we were clear before that we didn't apply for anything in 2012. I don't think we changed our thinking that as we work to make sure that we drive towards being Basel III compliant over the next couple of quarters. So I think we're -- we have a high confidence in our capital
column1190: a high confidence that we have the right capital and high confidence that we're building at a good pace that we knew before
column1191:
but now you all see. And so I think we'll just keep playing it through the end of this year in this way.

"
column1192:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1194:
"

Got it. And too soon to call until maybe towards the end of the year where capital stands ultimately in the outlook macro-wise
column1198:
I didn't hear the very end of that.

"
column1199:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners Inc.
column1201:
"

Is that fair to assume kind of too soon to call in terms of is 2013 the year? In terms of maybe starting at least you think about it or at this point?

"
column1203:
"

We'll let you know when we -- we've said consistently
column1204: we'll apply when we know we'll get approved
column1205: and we can work closely with our regulators to get that through
column1206:
and we'll see how we proceed through this year and the next.

"
column1208:
"

That was our last question. I'd like to thank you for participating.

"
column1215:
"

This concludes today's program. You may disconnect at any time. Thank you

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q2 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Bruce R. Thompson \u2013 Chief Financial Officer

"
column9:
"

Brian T. Moynihan \u2013 Chief Executive Officer

"
column11:
"

John E. McDonald \u2013 Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column13:
"

Paul J. Miller \u2013 FBR Capital Markets & Co

"
column14:
"

Glenn Schorr \u2013 Nomura Securities International Inc.

"
column15:
"

Matthew D. O'Connor \u2013 Deutsche Bank

"
column25:
"

Matthew H. Burnell \u2013 Wells Fargo Securities
column27:
"

Operator

"
column28:
"

And welcome to today\u2019s program. At this time all participants are in listen-only mode. (Operator Instructions) Please note that today\u2019s call is being recorded.

"
column29:
"

It\u2019s now my pleasure to turn the program over to Kevin Stitt. Please begin
column31:
"

Kevin Stitt

"
column32:
"

Good morning. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column33: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements
column34: and please review slides two and three with information around forward-looking statements. And for additional factors
column35:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column36:
"

And with that
column37:
let me turn it over to Bruce.

"
column40: Kevin
column41: and good morning
column42: everyone. I\u2019m going to start on slide four. And as you all saw this morning
column43: we reported net income of $2.5 billion for the second quarter
column44:
or $0.19 a share on a diluted basis.

"
column45:
"

You will notice at the bottom of the page
column46: we do not have any selected items that we brought forward during this quarter. And given that the list is relatively short
column47:
we\u2019ll just hit those as we go throughout the presentation within the lines of business.

"
column48:
"

We go ahead and move forward to slide five. We clearly believe that the results in the second quarter demonstrated our ongoing momentum on several fronts. Capital continued to strengthen and is at record levels by most metrics.

"
column49:
"

Tier 1 common capital increased $2.5 billion to $134 billion and ended the quarter at 11.24% under Basel 1. We estimate the Basel 3 Tier 1 common equity with 8.1% at the end of June
column50: on a fully phased-in basis
column51:
based on our current understanding of both U.S. market risk rules and international Basel 3 guidelines.

"
column52:
"

If you recall
column53: we had estimated we would be in excess of 7.5% under Basel 3 at the end of the year. So based on where we came out at the end of quarter
column54:
we\u2019re quite pleased with the progress we've made so far.

"
column55:
"

While we increased capital
column56: we also continue to bring down our long-term debt
column57:
reducing it by $53 billion in the second quarter through both maturities as well as liability management actions that we\u2019ll get into throughout the presentation.

"
column58:
"

Likewise
column59: we made progress on expenses
column60: which declined $2.1 billion from the first quarter
column61:
of which approximately $900 million was due to the absence of an annual retirement eligible stock-based compensation awards that impacted the first quarter.

"
column62:
"

As we said last quarter
column63: while revenue growth correlates in large part with the health of the overall economy
column64: the two areas that we clearly have the ability to control are our expenses as well as our debt cost
column65:
and we aggressively addressed those during the second quarter.

"
column66:
"

Asset quality also continued to improve in almost all categories. This improvement combined with decreased levels of distressed loans drove provision expense to be its lowest level going all the way back to the first quarter of 2007.

"
column67:
"

Interest rates did continue to be a headwind. And as you can see
column68: the decrease in loans and rates during the quarter did negatively affect net interest income. The European crisis and seasonality are impacting the markets related businesses
column69: driving those revenues lower compared to the first quarter of 2012. However
column70: non-interest income did reflect improved results in some of our consumer businesses
column71:
which we\u2019ll get into as we go through the presentation.

"
column72:
"

If you turn to slide six
column73: as we look at regulatory capital under Basel 1
column74: you can see that $2.5 billion of earnings along with a $27 billion decline in risk-weighted assets or about 2.3% of risk-weighted assets drove the capital improvement from 10.78% at the end of the first quarter to 11.24% at the end of the second quarter. If you look at the left hand chart since June of 2011
column75: one year ago
column76:
our Basel 1 Tier 1 common ratio has increased by approximately 300 basis points.

"
column77:
"

Turning to slide seven and providing a Basel 3 update
column78: as we near the 2013 implementation period for Basel 3
column79: we\u2019ve estimated our Tier 1 common equity ratio and its components to provide a better understanding of where we are relative to the Basel 3 guidelines that will be fully implemented at the beginning of 2019. The estimate we provide here is for BIS Basel 3 guidelines in the final U.S. market risk rules. If we reported Basel 3 as of June 30<sup> </sup>on a fully phased-in basis
column80: we estimate that Tier 1 common equity ratio would be 8.1%
column81: we estimate that our Tier1 common equity would be approximately a $127 billion
column82:
while our risk-weighted assets would be $1.566 trillion.

"
column83:
"

As we think about the important differences between Basel 1 and Basel 3 capital or the numerator
column84: the differences include capital deductions related to the MSR
column85: our deferred tax assets and the inclusion of unrealized gains and losses on debt and equity securities recognized in other comprehensive income. As you are well aware
column86:
these items will be impacted by future changes in both interest rates as well as overall earnings performance.

"
column87:
"

We turn to slide eight on funding and liquidity
column88: you can see that long-term debt during the quarter was down $53 billion
column89: while our overall Global Excess Liquidity Sources only declined by $28 billion to $378 billion at the end of the quarter. At the parent company
column90: long-term debt during the quarter came down by approximately $40 billion. That $40 billion reduction was approximately $34 billion of parent company maturities
column91: of which we call out $24 billion of that related to TLGP debt. At the end of June
column92:
all of our TLGP related debt has been repaid.

"
column93:
"

In addition to the maturities
column94: we brought in about $5.5 billion through liability management actions on our TRUPs and subordinated debt that are outstanding. The benefit in the quarter from that was a little over $500 million. As we look forward
column95:
those liability management actions will result in net interest income savings of approximately $100 million in 2012 and $180 million in 2013.

"
column96:
"

As we look at parent company liquidity
column97: it remained very strong at $111 billion at the end of the quarter. And as we look at time to required funding
column98:
we finished the quarter at 37 months; the highest in the company\u2019s history.

"
column99:
"

During the quarter
column100: we didn\u2019t issue any long-term unsecured parent company debt and I doubt that we will do so during the balance of 2012. What we will continue to do is to bring down long-term debt both by paying off debt at maturity as well as active liability management
column101:
consistent with our overall goals of continuing to optimize net interest income.

"
column102:
"

In fact
column103: we\u2019ve already announced calls of another $5.2 billion in both TRUPs and sub debt
column104: which we expect to complete during the third quarter of this year. In addition to these calls
column105: maturities of $23 billion
column106: of which approximately $15 billion at the parent
column107: will come due during the second half of the year
column108:
which will also help reduce both long-term debt balances as well as associated interest expenses.

"
column109:
"

I\u2019ll spend a minute on page nine
column110: on a couple balance sheet highlights. You can see
column111:
total assets were down about 1% to $2.16 trillion while total risk-weighted assets were down over 2% to about $1.19 trillion.

"
column112:
"

Our tangible common equity ratio improved 25 basis points in the quarter from 6.58% to 6.83%. Intangible book value improved by $0.35 during the quarter to $13.22 from $12.87.

"
column113:
"

We turn to slide 10 and look at net interest income on an FTE basis. It was $9.8 billion during the quarter
column114: down $1.3 billion from the first quarter. The decrease in the quarter was primarily due to higher premium amortization expense associated with FAS 91 as well as market related hedge ineffectiveness. If you recall
column115:
rates rose in the first quarter of this year and that led to lower premium amortization and favorable hedge ineffectiveness that benefited NII by about $400 million in the first quarter of this year.

"
column116:
"

However
column117: lower rates in the second quarter had a negative impact of approximately $500 million
column118: which resulted in a combined negative impact of approximately $900 million to NII from the first quarter to the second quarter. If we back out those market related swings
column119: net interest income decreased by approximately $400 million during the quarter due to lower loan balances and yields and lower trading net interest income
column120:
which was partially offset by the benefit of the lower long-term debt that I just mentioned.

"
column121:
"

In the near term given long and rate levels at the end of June
column122:
we estimate that quarterly net interest income will start at a base of approximately $10.25 billion before the impact from liability management actions.

"
column123:
"

Second quarter parent debt maturities and liability actions plus third quarter announced redemptions and calls will benefit quarterly interest income by approximately $300 million
column124: of which $60 million was captured in the second quarter of this year. To state the obvious
column125: if rates increase from the end of June
column126:
it will have a positive impact and obviously lower rates would have a negative impact.

"
column127:
"

We turn to page 11 and look at overall loan activity
column128: total loans for the quarter declined by approximately $10 billion from the first quarter or about 1%. If you look at the composition of the loan balances
column129: you can see ending commercial loans actually grew by about $4.1 billion or 1.3% from the first quarter of 2012. That growth was attributed to increases in our commercial and industrial loans and was partially offset by about a $1.4 billion reduction in commercial real estate. If you go to the bottom of slide 11
column130:
you can see ending consumer loans declined approximately $14 billion from the first quarter of 2012.

"
column131:
"

I\u2019d like to spend a minute on that. If you go and look at the bar chart
column132: we\u2019ve talked throughout the last couple of quarters about run-off portfolios that we\u2019re looking to run-off that do not produce any meaningful level of pretax income
column133:
you can see we had about $4.4 billion of that during the quarter.

"
column134:
"

In addition
column135: residential mortgages were down about $4.4 billion. Keep in mind
column136: as we look at those mortgage portfolios
column137: we can either invest in mortgages or securities
column138: and during the quarter we came up in securities
column139:
a little bit down in loans. Over and above that about $3.4 billion of loan sales that had been targeted that wrapped up at the beginning of the second quarter.

"
column140:
"

If you back those three items out and look at consumer loans on a net basis
column141:
that leaves us with about a $2 billion reduction during the quarter or well below 1%.

"
column142:
"

On slide 12
column143: we highlight the results of the Consumer and Business Banking segment. Earnings were $1.2 billion
column144: a decrease from the first quarter
column145: driven by lower net interest income
column146: lower reserve releases and higher litigation expense
column147: partially offset by higher non-interest income. Non-interest income did increase from the first quarter due to a couple of factors; our consumer spending including higher interchange
column148:
the gain on certain card portfolios and the impact of our consumer protection products.

"
column149:
"

On slide 13
column150: we list some key indicators for our Consumer and Business Banking for the quarter. average deposit balance growth was strong
column151: increasing by over 2% or $10 billion compared to the first quarter of 2012. As we continue to focus on cost and look to optimize our delivery network
column152:
our branch count came down by 57 branches during the quarter.

"
column153:
"

As far as card purchase activity
column154: combined credit and debit card purchase volumes increased 6% from the first quarter of 2012. In addition
column155: credit quality continued to improve as the U.S. credit loss rate is the lowest since the fourth quarter of 2007
column156:
while the 30-plus day delinquency rate is at historic lows.

"
column157:
"

As we look at activity levels within the segment
column158: we\u2019ve also continued to increase our mobile banking customer base to more than 10 million customers
column159:
which is a 6% increase from the prior quarter and up 34% from the year-ago period.

"
column160:
"

We turn to slide 14
column161: Consumer Real Estate Services reported a loss of $768 million
column162:
which was an improvement of $377 million versus the first quarter of this year. Lower revenue was more than offset by lower expenses and a lower provision for credit losses.

"
column163:
"

The Home Loans business within our Consumer Real Estate Services segment recorded a profit of $241 million for the quarter. First mortgage retail originations of $18 billion were up 18% over the first quarter due to lower rates and HARP Refis and in line with our retail originations a year ago.

"
column164:
"

However
column165: as you all know
column166: we exited the corresponded business late last year
column167: so current correspondent originations during the quarter are virtually non-existent versus volumes of approximately $22 billion a year ago. Even with the exit from this correspondent channel
column168:
core production income is higher than a year ago.

"
column169:
"

Results for the quarter include $395 million in costs for representations and warranties provision and $109 million of litigation expenses and expected assessments
column170:
waivers and other cost related to foreclosure delays.

"
column171:
"

During the quarter
column172:
our MSR asset decreased by approximately $1.9 billion due to lower mortgage rates and ended the quarter at $5.7 billion. MSR hedge results for the quarter largely offset market valuation declines and the capitalized MSR rate at the end of the quarter was 47 basis points versus 58 basis points in the first quarter and 78 basis points a year ago.

"
column173:
"

If we move forward to slide 15
column174: as we've done before
column175: we show some comparisons of certain metrics in our Legacy Assets and Servicing basis on a linked quarter basis
column176: and compared to second quarter a year ago is we continue to focus and work very hard on reducing delinquent loans
column177:
and looking to find homeowner solutions.

"
column178:
"

As you recall
column179: Legacy Assets and Servicing reflects all of our servicing operations
column180: and the results of our MSR activities. We added almost 1700 people in the quarter
column181:
including contractors versus 3000 people in this area in the first quarter alone.

"
column182:
"

The number of first-liens serviced did decline by 5% in the quarter
column183: while the number of 60-day plus delinquent loans dropped 2%. As we think about that drop in 60-day plus delinquent loans of 27
column184: 000 loans from the first quarter
column185: it was lower than we would have expected for two reasons. The first is a result of the DOJ/AG Settlement
column186: we have holds on loans that were attempting to modify
column187: and in addition to that we had approximately 15
column188: 000 loans were servicing is being sold
column189: but we won't complete until this month. Even with these delays
column190: we continue to believe
column191: we can reduce our 60-day plus delinquencies by a net of approximately 300
column192:
000 over the next 12 months.

"
column193:
"

And as we've talked about before
column194:
we remain very focused on decreasing these loans because on a lag basis it gives us the ability to further reduce costs within this segment.

"
column195:
"

On slide 16
column196: you can see that outstanding claims have increased from the end of March from a rep and warranty perspective. Claims from the GSEs increased as a result of ongoing disagreements with Fannie Mae about what constitutes a valid repurchase request. Through June
column197: there\u2019s been minimal monoline activity consistent with the past six quarters. However
column198: as I\u2019m sure many of you saw
column199:
last night we did sign a settlement with Syncora that would have reduced our outstanding monoline claims at the end of June by approximately 20%.

"
column200:
"

On the private-label side
column201: we did have an increase in outstanding claims from $4.9 billion to $8.6 billion during the quarter. The increase in claims is primarily due to claims received from trustees that we fully anticipated at the time of the Bank of New York settlement a year-ago
column202: and were largely reflected in the increase in our reserves at that time. As we look forward
column203:
we expect these outstanding claims to continue to grow as the process for ultimate resolution continues to evolve and does remain unclear.

"
column204:
"

As you look at this table
column205: I think it\u2019s important to keep in mind that the table reflects unpaid principal amounts as opposed to actual losses that are projected on the loans. Our reserves for rep and warrants ended the quarter at $15.9 billion
column206: up slightly from the prior quarter. And as you look out
column207:
our non-GSE range of possible loss over and above existing levels is up to $5 billion.

"
column208:
"

{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q3 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan - CEO

"
column17:
"

Nancy Bush - NAB Research LLC

"
column26:
"

And welcome to today\u2019s third quarter earnings review program. At this time
column27: all participants are in listen-only mode. (Operator Instructions) We\u2019ll take questions in turn during our Q&A session. And please note
column29:
"

It's now my pleasure to turn the program over to Kevin Stitt. Please begin sir.

"
column31:
"

Good morning. Before Brian and Bruce begin their comments
column32: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column33: and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. For additional factors
column34:
please see our press release and SEC documents.

"
column35:
"

And with that
column36:
let me turn it over to Bruce.

"
column37:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column40: everyone. I am going to start the presentation on slide four. And as I am sure you\u2019ve all seen for the third quarter of 2012 we reported net revenue of $20.6 billion. Importantly
column41:
that number was reduced by about $1.9 billion for FVO and DVA and if we adjust for that you get to a revenue net of interest expense of $22.5 billion for the quarter. Net income was $340 million or $0.00 a share after preferred dividends.

"
column42:
"

The results reflect the previously announced charges in late September that relate to $1.9 billion for the combination of FVO adjustments as well as DVA resulting from the significant tightening that we saw in our credit spreads during the quarter.

"
column43:
"

In addition
column44: we had $1.6 billion of pre-tax of total litigation expense including the charge for the Merrill Lynch Class Action Settlement. Lastly
column45: we had about $800 million of tax expense related to the reduction in the UK tax rate. In the aggregate
column46:
these items negatively impacted EPS by approximately $0.28.

"
column47:
"

We turn to slide five
column48: the results in the third quarter demonstrated ongoing momentum on several fronts. Period-end deposits across the company grew $28 billion
column49: or 2.7% versus the second quarter which is an 11% annualized rate
column50:
and we accomplished that as the rates on the deposits declined slightly from 20 basis points to 18 basis points. The net interest yield increased by 11 basis points as our liability management actions continue to benefit net interest income.

"
column51:
"

Our Mortgage business home loans had its most profitable quarter excluding asset sales since we started reporting its results separately with first-lien production up by 13%. Wealth and Investment Management showed growth in long-term assets under management
column52:
deposits and record loan levels while maintaining solid margins.

"
column53:
"

Ending loans in our Global Banking segment increased 2.5% from the second quarter or 10% on an annualized basis. Results in the capital markets area reflected strong performances both on a quarter-over-quarter as well as a year ago basis.

"
column54:
"

We continue to invest in growth areas of our company such as mortgage lending
column55: small business banking and financial advisors. Our 60 plus day delinquent loans serviced out in a Legacy Servicing business declined 12% from second quarter levels
column56: and we\u2019ll spend sometime later in the presentation talking about what that means going forward. And our number of full time equivalent employees declined approximately 3
column57:
000 from the end of the second quarter related to a different New BAC initiatives.

"
column58:
"

If you turn to slide six
column59: a lot of information on the balance sheet highlight area
column60: I just want to draw your attention to three of the line items. The first
column61: our tangible common equity ratio improved by 12 basis points to 6.95%. If you move down the tangible book-value
column62: it grew by $0.26 in the quarter
column63: up to $13.48 and if you look at our adjusted loan coverage where we look at the allowance for loans over annualized charge-offs
column64:
it improved during the quarter to 2.2 times.

"
column65:
"

If you turn to slide seven; as we\u2019ve seen all year
column66: regulatory capital continued to strengthen. Our Basel 1 Tier 1 common capital ratio was up 17 basis points to 11.41%. Remember
column67:
FVO in the tax charge do not impact regulatory capital.

"
column68:
"

As we near the 2013 implementation period for Basel 3
column69:
we\u2019ve estimated our Tier 1 common equity ratio and it's components to provide a better understanding of where we are relative to the expected 2019 Basel 3 requirements. Our estimate as per the final U.S. market risk rules in the U.S. Basel 3 NPRs.

"

As a result

Non-performing loans increased by $1.1 billion as a result of this change and $954 million or 91% of these borrowers are current on their contractual payments. Of these contractually performing loans more than 70% were discharged from bankruptcy more than 12 months ago and nearly 40% were discharged 24 months or more ago.

column244:

column216:
"

000 from a year ago. An important driver behind the reduction of $1.4 billion in expenses from fourth quarter a year ago is new BAC which we have discussed with you several times.

column218:

column228:

column230:

column238:
reservable criticized levels showed a decline of 8% from the third quarter and 42% from a year ago.

not all of it comes out that because of combined pools and stuff but a significant amount.

And so once we get this out -- these are products that we just aren\u2019t going to continue with and we\u2019ve been focusing on rebuilding the business into the core business as I spoke about earlier.

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q1 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan - President and CEO

"
column8:
"

Bruce Thompson - Chief Financial Officer

"
column13:
"

Meredith Whitney - Meredith Whitney Advisory Group

"
column16:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column17:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column21:
"

Welcome to today\u2019s program. [Operator instructions.] It\u2019s now my pleasure to introduce Kevin Stitt. Please begin
column25:
"

Good morning. Before Bruce Thompson and Brian Moynihan begin their comments
column26: let me remind you that this presentation does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column27:
and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. And please see our press release and SEC documents for more reference.

"
column29:
let me turn it over to Bruce.

"
column31:
"

Thanks
column32: Kevin
column33: and good morning everyone.  I\u2019m going to start on slide four
column34: as we work through the presentation.  We earned $0.20 per fully diluted share during the first quarter or $2.6 billion
column35:
up significantly from both the first and fourth quarter of last year.

"
column36:
"

The one item we want to highlight up front
column37: since it only happens once a year
column38:
is approximately $900 million of expense related to retirement eligible stock based compensation awards that we have had in the first quarter for the past several years.

"
column39:
"

We believe first quarter results demonstrate significant progress towards the goals we have discussed over the past several quarters. Global markets client activity drove improved sales and trading results versus the fourth quarter of 2012
column40:
while investment banking performance remained strong.

"
column41:
"

Global wealth and investment management reported record earnings post the Merrill Lynch merger. Expenses in most of our businesses continued to decline
column42:
although they are partially offset by higher revenue related incentive compensation and the impact of expense related to annual retirement eligible stock based compensation awards.

"
column43:
"

Capital and liquidity both continued to strengthen and are at record levels by most metrics. The interest rate environment continues to be challenging
column44:
but moderate loan growth and reduced average long term debt helped stabilize net interest income versus the fourth quarter.

"
column45:
"

Credit quality improved in almost all products
column46:
and both consumer and commercial loss rates were the lowest in several years. And we continue to make strides in resolving legacy issues as we just recently reached an agreement to settle three class action lawsuits involving Countrywide-issued RMBS.

"
column47:
"

On slide
column48: if we look at the balance sheet
column49: you can see the total balance sheet was down from both the fourth quarter of last year as well as the year ago period
column50:
although total loans are up slightly.

"
column51:
"

If we look at commercial loans and leases
column52: they\u2019re up 3% relative to the fourth quarter of 2012
column53:
and up 17% compared to the year ago period.

"
column54:
"

If we move down to deposits
column55: deposits were down slightly from the fourth quarter of \u201912 to the first quarter of \u201913
column56: although up approximately $54 billion
column57: or 5%
column58:
from the first quarter of 2012.

"
column59:
"

column1:
{"Bank of America Corp (BAC) CEO Discusses Q2 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan - President and CEO

"
column8:
"

Bruce Thompson - Chief Financial Officer

"
column14:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets

"
column21:
"

Welcome to today\u2019s program. [Operator instructions.] It\u2019s now my pleasure to turn the program over to Lee McEntire. Please begin
column24:
"

Good morning to those on the phone or joining us by webcast. Before Bruce Thompson and Brian Moynihan begin their comments
column25: let me remind you that this presentation
column26: available at bankofamerica.com does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column27:
and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. And please see our press release and SEC documents for further information.

"
column29: let me turn it over to our CEO
column31:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column32:
"

Thank you
column33: Lee. Good morning everyone
column34: and just to start off
column35: let me remind you of what our focus is and has been for some time: on capital generation
column36: on managing our risk
column37: on continuing to reduce our costs
column38:
and on addressing the legacy issues so that we can drive our growth strategy by simply doing more with our customers and clients.

"
column39:
"

This quarter shows very clearly how the focus is paying off
column40: as we earned $4 billion. We built our company over the last several quarters to maintain stability
column41:
and we\u2019ll continue to make progress to withstand the volatility that we saw in part again this quarter while delivering for our customers and shareholders.

"
column42:
"

And that came true
column43: even as mortgage demand has decreased
column44: we still had a 40% increase in retail production over last year
column45: and an increase over the last quarter. Even as interest rates rose
column46: we were able to add to our capital ratios. And keep in mind
column47: with our trillion-dollar deposit book
column48:
rising rates will continue to increase the value of those over time.

"
column49:
"

We have leading capabilities in the areas where our customers want us to be. We do more business with them and we\u2019re gaining momentum across every customer group. And while we\u2019re doing that
column50: our balance sheet continues to strengthen
column51: our capital ratio has again moved higher
column52: and just as importantly
column53:
we\u2019ve begun the process of returning capital to our shareholders.

"
column54:
"

Our credit quality continues to improve. Expenses are down by $1 billion from a year ago. LAS
column55: or Legacy Asset Servicing
column56: expenses
column57: excluding our litigation
column58: are down by nearly $800 million on a quarterly basis
column59: from the peak only a couple of quarters ago
column60:
and are ahead of our projections.

"
column61:
"

Our loans and our deposits continue to grow. All the businesses produced solid
column62:
stable revenues in the focus areas where we are growing that grew their revenues. And we\u2019re seeing growing activity levels across all our customer and client groups.

"
column63:
"

So as we look forward
column64: we\u2019re closely following recent regulatory proposals around capital and leverage
column65: just as you are. Obviously we have already taken significant steps in our company to build our current strong levels of capital and liquidity
column66:
and we maintain a comfort level here that Bruce will take you through the numbers later.

"
column67:
"

The good news in all this is that we\u2019re seeing in our business as reflected in our improved economy. The economy continues to improve across all areas. That benefits our company across multiple fronts
column68: but most importantly
column69: with an improving economy
column70: it strengthens and creates opportunity for the people
column71: companies
column72: and investors that we serve
column73:
and that opportunity will continue to provide opportunity for us to capture and to connect all our capabilities to help those that we serve realize their financial goals.

"
column74:
"

With that
column75:
let me turn it over to Bruce.

"
column76:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column77:
"

Thanks
column78: Brian
column79: and good morning everyone. I\u2019m going to start on slide five of our presentation materials. Total revenues for the quarter were very solid at $22.9 billion
column80: and we earned $4 billion
column81: or $0.32 per diluted share
column82:
which is up significantly both from the first quarter of this year as well as the comparable period in 2012.

"
column83:
"

column101: led by our commercial loans

up $10 billion.

That\u2019s significant in the context of our $4 billion of earnings largely offset the negative after-tax impact from accumulated other comprehensive income
column106:
driven by the increase in rates that we saw during the quarter.

Also helping our tangible book value per share in the quarter was the return of roughly $1 billion of capital through the repurchase of 80 million common shares at a price below tangible book value. And as we look forward

If we look at our primary bank subsidiaries

On page eight

we will look to move that time to funding towards the 24 months as we repay the upcoming debt maturities in 2013 and 2014.

On net interest income

As a result of those different factors

column178: excluding any market related impacts
column179:
to build off of the second quarter of 2013\u2019s $10.4 billion adjusted level as we move forward during the balance of 2013 and into 2014.

And keep in mind that as we work through these

the $600 million improvement in all other cost was driven primarily by lowering incentive compensation costs during the quarter as well as our new BAC efforts. We remain on track to achieve $1.5 billion of new BAC quarterly savings by the fourth quarter of 2013.

So a little bit of apples to oranges relative to our peers as to how we report it.

column857:
"

I\u2019m sorry
column858:
the servicing revenues are in the LAS?

"

Bruce Thompson

column860:

And this is just origination?

Bruce Thompson

Chris Kotowski - Oppenheimer

Brian Moynihan

column886:
"

Operator

column887:

Could you talk a little bit about whether you either have - it doesn\u2019t look like it - or are planning to kind of retain mortgage loans in the second half of the year?

column890:

Bruce Thompson

column891:
"

I\u2019m not sure I understood.

column893:

Well

column896:

column897:
"

Bruce Thompson

Okay. So we would expect

column905:
and the balance through our CPB segment. So there is an origination of activity.

column907: the investment portfolio is there to invest the residual of what\u2019s used. There will be some incremental investments during the year

but I don\u2019t think in the aggregate you should expect to see the overall level of securities balances change dramatically between now and the end of the year.

column910:
"

And given that you\u2019ve been kind of ahead of or meeting

You\u2019ve seen two different levels of activities amongst our peers

column918: given the capital and liquidity that we\u2019ve built
column919:
in using that capital and liquidity within our core customer segments.

column920:
"

And so when you look at that liquidity

column923:
because of what we\u2019re doing from a securities lending perspective and a mortgage lending perspective. You look at the commercial loan balances. And so they were up $10 billion. That\u2019s not from buying loans or doing anything else.

"
column927: some of that comes from being able to lend where other people are pulling back. So you\u2019re not going to see anything inorganic that we\u2019re doing. What you will see

column929: is to continue driving that growth in those customers areas where because of the dynamics that you mentioned
column930:
other people may be doing less.

column932:
"

If you link this question to the last question about the efficiency of the mortgage business
column933: year over year we deploy about 5
column936:
to make sure that we can close mortgages on time and meet the demand of the customers.

column937:
"

So at the same time the headcount of the overall company is down significantly
column938: we\u2019ve had that kind of investment go on. We have more commercial bankers today than we had a year ago. We have more small business bankers
column939:
financial services advisor branches. So we continue to make the investment.

column940:
"

It\u2019s not really about capital
column942: because we still have so many loan portfolios that are running off

column944: and so this [a returning of] cost of capital on the allocated capital
column945: which is regulatory minimums or above. But it\u2019s really a question of where to put the expense dollars
column946: and that\u2019s what we\u2019re focused on in the core business
column947:
and we have the best opportunity.

column949:
"

Do you have a number in mind as to how much you would look to reinvest of the expense savings that you\u2019re generating?

column952: so we don\u2019t give you a number that doesn\u2019t take account. But for this year

column954: we\u2019ll spend $1.1 billion in connection with the new BAC ideas
column955: which are expense revenue and improving our company basis

that is on top of the $2.5 billion we spend otherwise in pure systems development initiatives to help drive this company. So there\u2019s investment going in.

column957:
"

But all the numbers we give you are net of all the investments we\u2019re making. So we\u2019re giving a net number
column958: but we are investing significantly at the same time. And that was what Bruce and the management team set out a few years ago
column959:
was we had to make sure we progressed the core franchise at the same time we brought the expense base and headcount down.

column961:
"

We\u2019ll go next to the site of Nancy Bush with NAB Research. Your line is open.

column963:
"

You\u2019ve made gains in market share and mortgage
column964:
and you said that you have stabilized the credit card. Are you going to be able to gain share in credit card? And how do you look to do that?

column966:
"

I think we\u2019re in a position for the first time in a long while\u2026 We\u2019ve been stabilizing credit card for a couple of quarters
column967: because we\u2019ve seen it sort of settle in. We divested some portfolios
column968:
as you know. We sized out of some of the business that we didn\u2019t find attractive.

"
column970: we saw the increase for the first time I think in almost five years. And so the team produced about 975
column972: up from 950-ish last quarter. That is a multiyear high in production
column973:
I think goes back to 2008. So we should see this go on.

"
column975: you have activity levels. You\u2019ve got to be careful in the summer and things like that. But overall
column977: that restructured portfolio which we\u2019ve shown you guys
column978: I think started at $15 billion to $20 billion several years ago
column979: and it\u2019s now down to a few billion. So the underlying demand is there
column980:
that we should be able to grow the business and hold our share.

column981:
"

And if you look over the last couple of quarters
column983: and card balance is a little bit down
column984:
but in line with the peers. And so we feel good that we finally have reached this point after five years of hard work of restructuring that business.

"
column986:
"

Is it a business where you want to gain share? If you could just sort of give your overall philosophy on the credit card business right now?

column988:
"

We will continue to drive share among our customers. We have low penetration in certain segments and low usage of our cards in other segments
column989: and so we\u2019re driving it through three or four core products
column990: the Cash 123 product for people who feel that\u2019s what they want in a card
column991: through the travel rewards and other awards products
column992: and we\u2019re seeing the cards come in through those core products and we\u2019re driving them. And yes
column993:
we want to grow share in the context of our customers in the select affinity teams that we work with across the country.

"
column995:
"

The second question I have is somewhat imprecise
column996: and I apologize in advance. But I think what everybody is waiting for with your stock
column998: is for this massive deposit gathering network to get profitable. And we understand that that is a function of short rates going up. Can you kind of walk us through this? Is there an ideal yield curve? Is there an absolute level of short rates? I mean
column999:
what do we have to see to begin to see the branches get massively profitable?

"
column1003: if you go to the supplement
column1004: during the second quarter the deposit segment within CPV did make $500 million during the quarter. As we look forward
column1007: to the extent that the overall yield curve shifts up
column1008: and this is once again in our first quarter Q
column1009: that the benefit from a net interest income perspective on a 100 basis point parallel shift
column1010: as of the end of the first quarter
column1012:
the lion\u2019s share of which is going to flow through the consumer segment.

"
column1013:
"

So as it relates to where we are now
column1014: it is profitable. We\u2019ve made almost $500 million. We continue to optimize and reduce the expenses to make it more profitable. And you\u2019re correct
column1016:
it will become much more so.

"
column1018:
"

If I could just finally ask a corollary to that question
column1019: because of all the issues that you\u2019ve had in the past few years
column1022: several different sort of programs to change the retail footprint of the company
column1023: is there going to be a need as rates go up to give more of that benefit to your customers? In other words
column1024:
are you going to have to act differently in deposit pricing this time around than you have in previous rate cycles?

"
column1026:
"

I think a lot of the adjustments we made on the fee side for the general consumer have already been made
column1027: and I think the customers have benefited dramatically from our position
column1028: and how we do overdrafts and other types of fees. So I think that is the payback to the customers. As rates rise
column1029:
we will meet the market and grow the market as we\u2019ve been doing.

"
column1031: remember the constitution of our deposits across the last three years
column1032: we have run off a lot of CDs and other things which are not advantage products. And it\u2019s really become more and more core every single quarter. And that will play to our benefit
column1034: checking accounts are noninterest at this point
column1038:
"

And we\u2019ll take our final question from the site of Mike Mayo with CLSA. Your line is open.

"
column1040:
"

I have three real small questions and one bigger question. What tax rate should we assume to be normal?

"
column1043: 30% is a reasonable effective tax rate for the last two quarters of the year
column1044: realizing you need to add about 1.1 billion to that for the U.K. tax. And as we go into 2014 and 2015
column1045: that 30% migrates into more of a 32%
column1046:
33% effective tax rate based on what we think we will be earning as we go into \u201914 and \u201915.

"
column1050: I\u2019m just trying to compare that to the old Merrill Lynch wealth management margin
column1051:
and you have the asset management and U.S. Trust in there. Can you just give us some estimate where that 28% margin would be? Would it be 26%? Or 25%?

"
column1055:
"

Excluding U.S. Trust and excluding asset management
column1058: what kind of margin did that have? I\u2019m trying to see if this is the highest brokerage margin ever
column1060:
if you can go back to the old Merrill Lynch.

"
column1062:
"

We don\u2019t disclose the difference. I think what you\u2019re asking is is the margin in U.S. Trust materially different than what it is in the traditional Merrill Lynch wealth management model. And you should not assume that the margin improvement and the 28% is driven by a mix. Virtually all of that margin is driven by overall what we\u2019re seeing in what you\u2019ve characterized as the traditional wealth management business of Merrill Lynch.

"
column1064:
"

And then as far as net interest income
column1065: you said you had a $300 million benefit this quarter from the increase in the 10-year. So am I just doing the math right? You had $10.5 billion of net interest income
column1066:
so it added 3% just this last quarter? Or really in the last month. It just seems like a lot. That\u2019s a nice benefit.

"
column1068:
"

If you flip to slide nine
column1069: we show both the reported as well as the actual number. And the reason why that increase in interest rates led to the improvement in NII is because you need to adjust the way you look at premium securities when rates go up to reflect the slowdown in the rate at which you\u2019d expect to be paid back. So that is more of a life of loan type adjustment
column1070:
and that\u2019s why it\u2019s $300 million. It\u2019s the reason why we show you the number both ways.

"
column1073: the legal expense came way down. You expect to stay around $500 million. But I\u2019m still focused on the $8.5 billion settlement
column1074: and I go down to the courthouse in lower Manhattan
column1075: and what I think I hear - and again
column1076: correct my thinking - some lawyer say
column1077: that Bank of New York rubber stamped the $8.5 billion agreement
column1078: therefore throw the $8.5 billion deal out. And what I think the Kathy Patrick side say is
column1079:
accept the $8.5 billion deal. It\u2019s the best economic alternative out there.

"
column1081: you have $8.5 billion of reserves to the $8.5 billion settlement. Your disclosures say if the judge does not approve the deal
column1082: your reserves would go higher. So my question is
column1083: how much higher would your reserves go if the judge does not approve the deal
column1084:
and what part of my logic would you like to perhaps correct?

"
column1086:
"

The first is we\u2019re not going to comment on the ins and the outs of the $8.5 billion
column1088: technically we\u2019re not a part of that. The second thing as it relates to that that I would say is
column1089: and I think if you go back and look at one of the comments that was made
column1090: we accrued the $8.5 billion assuming that all 424 trusts were at the point where they got to the 25%
column1091:
to where there was a negotiation.

"
column1093: to comment whether or not we think the reserves would be higher or they could be lower is really not appropriate
column1094: because right now there\u2019s an $8.5 billion settlement that\u2019s going through the process. We\u2019ve accrued based on what 22 of the largest investors said was a fair deal
column1096: when we set up the reserves
column1097: we applied that same methodology to a variety of our other exposures. And to speculate or to comment before then
column1098: given where we are in this
column1099:
I just don\u2019t think is appropriate.

"
column1101:
"

Sure. I think last quarter you thought it would all be wrapped up by now. Any sense of when this might be wrapped up
column1102:
when you might have this behind you?

"
column1104:
"

I\u2019m not sure that we ever said that we thought it would be wrapped up in the second quarter. What we do know is what you know now given how you\u2019ve followed the case. I believe there\u2019s a court schedule set up through the 26th of July. It\u2019s not clear whether or not it will be wrapped up by the 26th or it will go beyond that. And we\u2019ll just have to see how the process unfolds.

"
column1105:
"

I believe at this point we\u2019re through all the questions
column1106: so thank you very much for joining us this morning
column1107:
and we\u2019ll look forward to talking to you next quarter.

"
