column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q3 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan - President and CEO

"
column8:
"

Bruce Thompson - CFO

"
column17:
"

Matthew O'Connor - Deutsche Bank North America

"
column22:
"

Good day and welcome to the Bank of America Third Quarter Earnings announcement. Currently all lines are in a listen-only mode. Later there will be an opportunity to ask questions during a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) please be advised
column24:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Lee McEntire. You may begin.

"
column26:
"

Good morning to those on the phone or joining us by webcast. Before Brian Moynihan and Bruce Thompson begin their comments
column27: let me remind you that this presentation
column28: which is available at bankofamerica.com does contain some forward-looking statements regarding both our financial condition and financial results
column29:
and that these statements involve certain risks that may cause actual results in the future to be different from our current expectations. Please see our press release and SEC documents for further information.

"
column31: let me turn it over to our CEO
column32:
Brian Moynihan.

"
column33:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column34:
"

Thanks
column35: Lee. Good morning
column36:
everyone. I will cover a few points and then I will turn it over to Bruce to go through the details of the quarter as we\u2019ve done in other quarters.

"
column37:
"

Consistent with prior quarters
column38: our Company continued to show progress on those areas we\u2019ve been focused upon. Capital generation
column40: achieving cost savings
column41:
addressing legacy issues and driving our core growth strategies in our core lines of business.

"
column42:
"

On the capital front this quarter
column43: we generated $3 billion plus of Basel 1 Tier 1 common capital. Our Basel 3 ratio has now approached 10% on a fully phased-in basis. That capital and liquidity in the balance sheet optimization has been going on for the last several quarters
column44:
holds us in good shape with regards to the regulatory suggested or proposed requirements that we see on the horizon.

"
column45:
"

The strength in capital is allowing us to return capital to shareholders. In the past six months we repurchased 140 million shares equaling about $2 billion of our $5 billion authorization.

"
column46:
"

Turning to the revenue side
column47:
we experienced relative stability this quarter. But of course we felt the impact of the industry wide headwinds on a slower refi business and mortgage and slowdown in the capital markets from a typical summer slowdown as well as the investor concerns of a political and monetary uncertainty.

"
column48:
"

On expenses
column49: this quarter we incurred additional litigation costs. Outside of that we continue to make progress on our expense initiatives
column50:
remaining on track to deliver the cost savings that we told you about two years ago in New BAC and also reducing the costs in our legacy assets and servicing area.

"
column51:
"

In the credit area we continue to see asset quality improve and our net loss rates are at levels not seen since 2005. As the macro environment slowly improve
column52: we experienced the 20% drop in net charge-offs and declining delinquencies from the second quarter. Our 248
column53: 000 teammates have been fully engaged with our customer clients to drive activity. We are pleased to see another quarter of solid loan growth in our commercial businesses while we continue to see the consumer lending activity stabilize in our card balances and modest growth elsewhere
column54:
which has offset the run off in a non-core portfolios.

"
column55:
"

As a company
column56: we reached record deposit levels this quarter
column57:
more than $1.1 trillion in deposit. Our client balance flows and our wealth management clients helped us maintain our industry leading positions. And you\u2019ve seen that Bank of America Merrill Lynch has assumed prominent roles in the marquee investment banking deals that have gone on this quarter.

"
column58:
"

We\u2019ve also seen a nice trend of progress
column59: absent some seasonality
column60: that results in our equity trading business. It\u2019s been gaining market share and continue to improve. So to sum it up
column61:
it\u2019s another solid quarter of progress in our core businesses and I\u2019m going to turn it over to Bruce to cover the -- in detail the presentation. Bruce?

"
column62:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column63:
"

Thanks
column64: Brian
column65: and good morning everyone. I\u2019m going to start my presentation on slide 5. During the quarter we earned $2.5 billion or $0.20 per diluted share. Before I address the core business trends
column66:
let me mention a few noteworthy items from our results that we\u2019ve disclosed to you previously.

"
column67:
"

First
column68: we sold our remaining stake in CCB
column69: recording a pre-tax gain of $753 million
column70: which was partially offset by $443 million negative impact of FVO and DVA as our credit spreads continue to tighten during the quarter. The net of these items benefited EPS by $0.02 in the quarter. We also recorded a $1.1 billion charge to re-measure our U.K. deferred tax assets
column71: given the 3% decline in the tax rate
column72:
which reduced EPS by $0.10 a share. The net of these is obviously a reduction of $0.08.

"
column73:
"

Moving to the core business
column74: total revenues in the quarter on an FTE basis were solid at $21.7 billion or $22.2 billion if we exclude the FVO and DVA charges. If we compare this to the second quarter
column75:
revenues declined on lower mortgage banking revenue as well as mostly seasonal declines within our sales and trading area.

"
column76:
"

Total non-interest expense of $16.4 billion included 1.1 billion in litigation costs
column77: $600 million increase in litigation costs from second quarter levels. The increase in these costs was partially offset by the improvement in both our legacy assets and servicing costs as well as the benefits of our New BAC initiatives. Asset quality improved significantly with net charge-offs improving 20% from the second quarter of 2013 to $1.7 billion and with the reserve reductions we took in the quarter
column78:
we recorded provision expense of just under $300 million in the quarter.

"
column79:
"

On slide 6
column80: you can see that our period end balance sheet remained relatively stable versus the prior quarter at about $2.13 billion. Customer activity remained solid with loans
column81:
largely led by commercial loans up $12.8 billion. Consumer lending activity in the quarter improved as we saw increased loan generation in our dealer financial services area and our continued stabilization of card balances which was partially offset by the run off within our home equity portfolio.

"
column82:
"

Period end deposits were up over $29 billion or 2.7%
column83: led by commercial client activity and solid flows from our wealth management clients. If we move down the page
column84:
tangible book value per share improved to $13.62 and our tangible common equity ratio increased above 7%.

"
column85:
"

Couple of other things that I like to mention
column86:
during the quarter we repurchased 60 million shares for roughly $900 million during the quarter. OCI increased by about $900 million during the quarter and our preferred stock includes the completion of our previously announced preferred stock redemption for just under $1 billion.

"
column87:
"

On slide 7
column88: you can see our Basel 1 Tier 1 common ratio of 11.08%
column89: increased 25 basis points from the second quarter of 2013. Under Basel 3 on a fully phased-in basis under the advanced approach
column90:
Tier 1 common capital increased by approximately $6 billion to an estimated $131.8 billion. Our Tier 1 common ratio is 9.94% showing a 34 basis point improvement from the second quarter of 2013.

"
column91:
"

In our estimate of the Basel 3 Tier 1 common ratio on a fully phased-in basis under the standardized approach would be just over 9% above our proposed 8.5% 2019 minimum requirement.

"
column92:
"

If we move to the supplemental leverage ratio
column93: based on the proposed U.S. requirements that don't take effect until 2018
column94:
at the end of the third quarter our bank holding company leverage ratio improved to above the proposed minimum of 5% and our two primary banking subsidiaries BANA and FIA continued to be in excess of the 6% proposed minimum.

"
column95:
"

So to reiterate what Brian mentioned there are a lot of new capital regulations proposed or finalized and we already exceed the requirements for the various known rules on Basel 3 capital and the supplementary leverage ratio.

"
column96:
"

On Slide 8
column97: funding and liquidity
column98: you can see our long-term debt end of the quarter $7 billion lower as maturities and the completion of our $5 billion tender offer outpaced issuances. We have $40 billion of parent company maturities through 2014 and as we look forward
column99:
we expect issuances to be materially below that number as we continue to reduce and smooth the maturity profile of our debt footprint.

"
column100:
"

Global excess liquidity sources of $359 billion increased from $342 billion at the end of the second quarter of 2013 and parent company liquidity remained strong at $95 billion. That translates into a time to required funding of 35 months well above our two-year coverage that we target.

"
column101:
"

I would also like to highlight that on October 1 of this year
column102:
we completed the legal entity merger of the Merrill Lynch holding company into Bank of America Corporation as part of our continued efforts to both simplify the company and reduce costs.

"
column103:
"

We turn to Slide 9
column104: net interest income. Net interest income on a reported basis was $10.5 billion down from the second quarter of '13 as the improvement in our core net interest income was more than offset by negative impact from market-related impacts. If we exclude those market-related impacts
column105:
net interest income built off of Q2 '13's $10.4 billion to be just north of $10.5 billion.

"
column106:
"

During the quarter we benefited from higher rates in our discretionary book
column107: lower long-term debt levels
column108:
higher commercial loans and lower rates paid on deposits. These positives were partially mitigated by lower loan yields and lower trading-related NII.

"
column109:
"

As you'll note on this slide
column110: the net interest yield excluding market-related impacts improved from 2.36% to 2.44% driven by the lower balance sheet levels as well as our lower funding costs. And consistent with what we mentioned last quarter
column111:
we expect to realize the benefit of higher long-term rates as we reinvest but note that some of those benefits will occur through time.

"
column112:
"

On Slide 10
column113: we'd spend a few minutes on expenses. Total expenses for the quarter were $16.4 billion
column114: a $1.1 billion improvement from the year ago quarter but up $371 million from the second quarter of this year. I want to be clear as you look at expenses and see that the uptick in the linked quarter expense
column115:
we continue to deliver on our non-litigation expense reductions in our legacy assets and servicing area as well as the ongoing benefits from our New BAC initiatives in the balance of the company.

"
column116:
"

Compared with second quarter '13
column117:
progress on LAS and New BAC in addition to lower revenue-related incentive compensation was more than offset by increased costs of litigation as well as some marketing initiatives that were accelerated from the fourth quarter 2013.

"
column118:
"

Our litigation expenses did increase as they continued the valuation of legacy exposures led to an addition to reserves. Our LAS expenses ex-litigation which are shown on the grey bar on Slide 10 of $2.2 billion declined $110 million from the second quarter of '13 and we continue to expect our fourth quarter LAS expenses ex-litigation to be below $2 billion as we continue to make very good progress on reducing the number of 60 plus days delinquent that we have in that business.

"
column119:
"

Our New BAC savings in the third quarter were approximately $100 million and are included in All Other
column120:
the red bar. We also remain on track to achieve the expected $1.5 billion of New BAC quarterly cost benefits by the end of 2013 and ultimately the $2 billion quarterly benefit upon completion of the project.

"
column121:
"

From an employee staffing perspective
column122: our number of FTEs ended the quarter at 248
column124: a decline of more than 9000 or 3.6% from the second quarter of '13 and that was driven by staff reductions within our legacy assets and servicing area
column125:
declines in home loans given the slowdown in mortgage productions as well as the continued optimization of our branch network.

"
column126:
"

And while we were down by 3.6% from the end of the second quarter to the end of the third quarter
column127:
the average LTEs only declined 2.3% so we'll get some additional benefits during the fourth quarter relative to the third from those reductions.

"
column128:
"

We touched on asset quality
column129: Slide 11. You can see that credit quality once again improved significantly. Net charge-offs declined to $1.7 billion
column130:
a 20% improvement on a linked-quarter basis.

"
column131:
"

As Brian referenced our third quarter of 2013 loss rate of 73 basis points declined 21 basis points from the second quarter and is now at 2005 levels. Delinquencies
column132: a leading indicator of charge-offs
column133:
again declined nicely.

"
column134:
"

During the quarter we did reduce reserves by $1.4 billion on the back of steadily improving consumer data which resulted in a provision expense of just under $300 million. Given what we see from the improving delinquencies as well as the current HPI trends absent any unexpected changes in the economy
column135:
we expect net charge-offs to decline again in the fourth quarter and stabilize sometime in 2014 at approximately $1.5 billion per quarter.

"
column136:
"

Let's move into the individual lines of business on Slide 12. Our consumer and business banking segment we were very pleased with the results during the third quarter as we delivered improved earnings with revenues growing modestly and expenses declining from both the previous quarter as well as the year-ago quarter. This coupled with lower credit costs within the segment resulted in net income of approximately $1.8 billion during the quarter
column137:
a 28% improvement over the previous quarter and a 32% improvement over last year.

"
column138:
"

That was achieved as we continued to do more business with our core customers. Our average deposits were stable as our organic customer growth was offset by some small branch divestitures as well as migrations to our Global Wealth and Investment Management area. Our brokerage assets are at record levels within this business
column139:
up 6% from the second quarter and up 18% over the prior-year\u2019s quarter. Average loans as I mentioned reflect stability in card balances as well as growth within our dealer financial services area. Card issuance during the quarter remained strong.

"
column140:
"

We issued more than one million new cards in the third quarter which is at the highest level going back to 2008. Consistent with our relationship strategy
column141: 63% of this issuance was to people that we have existing relationships with
column142:
and credit quality continues to be strong as delinquencies and net losses continued to improve during the quarter. Reduced expense levels in the segment reflects the benefits of our network optimization partially offset by investments we continue to make as we build out our specialist sales force in this area.

"
column143:
"

On Slide 13
column144: commercial real estate services where we operate the production
column145: origination and servicing of consumer real estate loans. In our supplemental information we report the two separate components of this segment
column146: one focused on loan origination and the other focused on servicing and legacy issues. On originations this quarter
column147:
first mortgage retail originations were $22.6 billion which was down 11% from the prior quarter and up 11% compared with originations in the year ago period. We believe that the current period decline in production is less than our industry peers as we have been working through our existing pipeline.

"
column148:
"

Our current pipeline at the end of the third quarter is however down approximately 60% compared to the end of the second quarter of \u201913 which reflects the significant reduction in market demand particularly in the refinancing space. Since our production revenue is booked at the point in which you lock alone is opposed to funding
column149: I should point out that our lock volume was down 23% from the second quarter of 2013. In addition to those lower lock volumes
column150:
we saw a gain on sale margins decline compared to the second quarter of 2013; our reduction was about 60 basis points during the quarter.

"
column151:
"

As a result of all these factors
column152:
core production revenue was down 46% to $465 million from the second quarter of 2013. From a staffing point of view just on the origination side as we saw demand slow we reduced headcounts by more than 1000 employees towards the end of the quarter. We will continue to reduce these staffing levels to be consistent with the lower volumes that we\u2019ve seen. The other primary component in this segment servicing revenue declined approximately $100 million versus the second quarter as our servicing portfolio declined as we continued to complete certain servicing transfers.

"
column153:
"

The other item that I want to highlight on this slide that\u2019s particularly important is the servicing cost that we see within the legacy assets and servicing area. We\u2019ve spoken a lot about reducing the number of 60 plus day delinquencies in this portfolio and we had a lot of success during the quarter as the number of 60 plus day delinquent loans dropped below 400
column154: 000 units at the end of September nearly a 100
column155: 000 lower than what we had at the end of June. Roughly half of the decline was driven by the transfers of servicing that I referenced in conjunction with the MSR sales agreements that we announced in the first quarter of 2013. And once again
column156:
as a result of this work we continue to believe that our LAS expenses ex-litigation will be below $2 billion during the fourth quarter of 2013.

"
column157:
"

On slide 14
column158:
our global wealth and investment management area had another strong quarter generating solid earnings and solid returns. Within this segment both Merrill Lynch and U.S. Trust maintained their leadership positions with a total of $2.3 trillion of client balances. Revenue remains near record high at $4.4 billion up 8% over the third quarter of 2012. Relative to the third quarter of 2012 net income improved 26% and with the third consecutive quarter in which our pre-tax margin was above 25%.

"
column159:
"

Asset management fees achieved the new record during the quarter while our brokerage income did decline from the second quarter due to reduced market activity. Client engagement remains quite strong
column160: long-term AUM flows were $10.3 billion near doubling last year\u2019s production. Ending deposits were up $6.5 billion or roughly 3% from the prior quarter
column161:
and our ending client loan balances of $117.2 billion reached record levels and are up 2% from the second quarter of \u201913 and 11% over the third quarter of a year ago as we continue to provide more banking products to both our Merrill Lynch and U.S. Trust clients.

"
column162:
"

On Slide 15
column163:
you can see global banking earnings were stable relative to the year ago period. Revenue compared to a year ago includes the benefit of strong loan growth and stable investment banking fees. Expenses this quarter include very good cost controls offset slightly by elevated litigation expense. Global fee pools did decline but we maintained our strong second place ranking of global net investment banking fees recording $1.3 billion of fees in improving our market share to 7.7%. In addition if you look at fees within the Americas we ranked number one within 11% market share.

"
column164:
"

During 2013 we have advised on 7 of the top 15 announced M&A deals. As we head into the last quarter of the year
column165: the pipeline looks quite strong but I do want to highlight that during the fourth quarter of last year we did see record levels of debt issuance during that period. If you look at the balance sheet
column166:
average loans increased $4.4 billion from the second quarter with more than half of that growth driven by commercial real estate lending with the balance by C&I lending particularly with our large corporate clients. Average deposits increased $12.2 billion from the second quarter of \u201913 above our expectations given certain timing consideration as well as customer liquidity that\u2019s been built around the fiscal cliff concerns.

"
column167:
"

If we move to Slide 16
column168:
global markets; we earned $531 million during the quarter after excluding the $1.1 billion U.K. tax charge as well as DVA losses of $291 million. On a comparable basis this is a decrease of $341 million compared to the third quarter of 2012 and down $403 million from the second quarter of \u201913 due to lower sales and trading revenue as well as higher expense from litigation. Sales and trading revenue ex-DVA was $3 billion during the quarter an 8% decline from the comparable year ago period. Fixed sales and trading revenue was down 20% versus the year ago period once again impacted by concerns regarding the present decision out of stimulus program as well as political uncertainty both domestically in abroad.

"
column169:
"

Our equity sales and trading area had another very strong quarter with revenues ex-DVA up 36% over the year ago period as we experienced higher market volumes and continued to benefit from the repositioning of this business that\u2019s happened over the last 18 months. We are gaining market share and we\u2019re improving our performance in each of the product lines. Expenses in the quarter compared to the third quarter of \u201912 included higher litigation costs that were partially offset by a reduction in operating expenses. Average trading related assets were down 4% from the year ago period while our VaR was effectively flat.

"
column170:
"

On Slide 17
column171: we show you the results of all other. Gains on the sale of debt securities were $347 million in the third quarter down $105 million from the second quarter of '13. You can also see the breakout of $1.1 billion of equity investment income which reflects the CCB gains
column172: as I mentioned earlier
column173:
as well as an additional $368 million of gains. The FPO that I mentioned earlier is also recorded in this segment.

"
column174:
"

Expenses include roughly $350 million during this quarter for litigation. That compares to $100 million in the second quarter of '13 and $950 million in the third quarter of 2012. As we close on All Other
column175: I would note that the effective tax rate for the quarter ex the impact of the U.K. tax reduction charge was 25% and as we look forward to the fourth quarter of 2013
column176:
we expect the effective rate to be in the high 20s.

"
column177:
"

Before we take questions
column178:
I'd like to leave you with several thoughts about our results. Capital and liquidity both strengthened during the quarter. We had encouraging business results as we saw improvement in both activity and profitability within Consumer and Business Banking. We saw continued strength in Global Wealth Management. We maintained our top position in investment banking and had another quarter of strong growth in our equity sales and trading business.

"
column179:
"

Credit continued to improve. Our cost initiative work remains on track and to the extent of the steepened yield curve environment stays with us
column180:
it should allow us to move NII upward as we move forward. We'll continue to execute on our strategy and continue to deliver on the earnings power of the company.

And then the very final question is you had meaningful improvement in your Basel 3 capital above and beyond the earnings and it looks like it's a pretty meaningful reduction in the threshold and other deductions. I was wondering if you could just give us a little bit more granularity on what was going on there.

"
column635:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column636:
"

It's a great question. And really two things going on. Keep in mind as we've said because we have a decent chunk disallowed DTA from a Basel perspective that ballpark we will accrete capital on a pretax basis generally speaking as opposed to a post tax basis for a decent number of quarters going forward. So when you look at that
column637:
I think pretax not so much post tax. And then the second benefit that you had which was an earlier question was the benefit of OCI during the quarter of roughly $1 billion after-tax or $1.5 billion pretax and that was the combination of the pension to the positive and then to the negative CCP coming out as well as some of the debt securities gains.

"
column639:
"

Got it. Okay
column640:
that's great. Thanks so much for taking my questions.

"
column641:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column642:
"

Thank you. Okay
column643:
I think that's all the questions that we have. So thanks for joining us this morning.

"
column644:
"

Operator

"
column645:
"

This does conclude today's program. You may disconnect at any time.

"

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q4 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan - President and CEO

"
column9:
"

Bruce Thompson - Chief Financial Officer

"
column19:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets

"
column22:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column24:
"

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

"
column27:
"

Andrew Marquardt - Evercore Partners

"
column29:
"

Good day
column31:
and welcome to today\u2019s program. [Operator instructions.] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Lee McEntire.

"
column32:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column33:
"

Good morning
column34: everybody on the phone as well as the webcast. Thanks for joining us this morning. Before I turn the call over to Brian and Bruce
column35: let me remind you we make forward-looking statements today. For further information on those
column36:
please refer to the website and our SEC filings about our forward looking statement information.

"
column37:
"

So without further ado
column38: let me turn it over to Brian
column40:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column41:
"

Thanks
column42: Lee
column43: and good morning to all of you
column44: and thank you for joining us to review our fourth quarter results. As we talked about over the last several quarters
column45: we\u2019ve been on a journey to simplify our company
column46: and we\u2019ve talked to you about our some consistent areas of focus: capital generation
column47: reducing our costs
column48: managing the risk down
column49: addressing the legacy issues
column50:
and driving business growth overall.

"
column51:
"

Each quarter
column52: you have seen the progress our teammates have made and the momentum is becoming more evident. On the first page
column53: slide two of the deck
column54:
you can see the annual comparisons that will show you the progress over the last couple of years.

"
column55:
"

First
column56: we\u2019ve improved the balance sheet. Our tier one common capital has grown 16% this year
column57:
liquidity and time to required funding have further strengthened. The strength in capital and liquidity allowed us to begin returning capital through share buybacks to shareholders in 2013.

"
column58:
"

Another area of our early focus has been rightsizing our expense base. We have been meeting the goals of our cost programs each year. While we\u2019ve made progress on those each quarter
column59:
there is still significant progress when you look over the last couple of years.

"
column60:
"

After reporting expenses and excluding a goodwill impairment of $77 billion in 2011
column61: we\u2019ve worked that number down to $69 billion in 2013. As we\u2019ve been clear with you
column62:
we expect additional cost savings in 2014 as we continue to execute on both our new BAC and our legacy assets and servicing initiatives.

"
column63:
"

We\u2019ve also focused on addressing our legacy mortgage issues
column64: and although we still have work to do
column65: we have made progress. On our credit costs and our provision costs
column66:
we\u2019ve seen tremendous results as net loss rates in our portfolios are at levels not seen in nearly a decade.

"
column67:
"

As a result of all this work
column68: earnings have improved significantly
column69: but we still have not approached the true earnings potential of Bank of America. So as we move to slide two
column70:
let\u2019s talk about recent results in the business on a business by business basis.

"
column71:
"

We\u2019ve been delivering solid growth in activity and relationships across all the groups of our customers and clients we serve. Let me highlight a few of those for you. Deposit levels continue to reach records each quarter. While this growth has been occurring in balances
column72: the rate paid has been declining to what we believe is low against our peers
column73:
at 8 basis points in our consumer businesses.

"
column74:
"

Our operating costs
column75: which we focus on heavily
column76:
of our deposit business has declined to just 200 basis points now. Driving this improvement is the work we\u2019ve done to optimize our delivery network in our stores in response to customer behavior changes across time.

"
column77:
"

Banking center over the counter transactions continue to go down
column78: but ATM
column79: online
column80: and mobile transactions continue to grow. We understand this
column81: and we observe this in our customers
column82:
and we\u2019re working with them to capitalize on arguably the largest and best-positioned branch network in banking.

"
column83:
"

However
column84: branches to remain a critical component of everything we do. We have about 8 million customer visits a week
column85: the kind of traffic we really appreciate
column86:
and most retailers would give their right arm for.

"
column87:
"

Meanwhile
column88: as that traffic comes in
column89: the customer behavior continues to shift to ATMs
column90: online
column91: and mobile
column92:
and that\u2019s given us the opportunity to be more efficient and at the same time continue to deliver innovative products to our customers.

"
column93:
"

When you move to our mass affluent customer base
column94: we\u2019ve seen deepening across the customer relationships. Merrill Lynch Brokers assets continued their strong growth. We\u2019ve invested heavily in a sales force for what we call our specialist sales force
column95: and that\u2019s grown to 6
column96:
700 people in 2013.

"
column97:
"

Looking at what that sales force has been able to do
column98: this year we opened 350
column99: 000 new Merrill Lynch accounts
column101:
000 new small business deposit and card accounts as well during 2013.

"
column102:
"

As we move to our industry leading global wealth investment management business
column103: we continue to break records on top line profitability. We just recorded the best year in the company\u2019s history for wealth management results. We have more customers and clients doing more business with us
column104:
and now we manage client assets of over $2.4 trillion.

"
column105:
"

In our global banking business
column106: loan flows have been very strong
column107: now growing for six consecutive quarters. Investment banking is coming off a very strong year
column108: and a very strong fourth quarter. We once again maintained our number two position in fees overall
column109:
and grew market share year over year.

"
column110:
"

As we look at our trading business
column111: our global markets business
column112: we\u2019ve been really pleased with the success we\u2019ve had in equities over the past year
column113:
and that\u2019s helped offset some of the industry challenges facing the larger FICC business that we have.

"
column114:
"

Now
column115: both remain very important customer facing businesses for us. They face some tough regulatory changes as the rules have changed about what the scope of activities is over the past couple of years
column116: but the team
column117: under Tom Montag
column118:
has been managing those changes well.

"
column119:
"

Importantly
column120: we ranked for the third year as a top global research firm. All in all
column121: we believe
column122: if you think back
column123: 2013 was a significant year for the progress this company has made against all the focus areas I mentioned earlier. As we look to 2014
column124: we are well-positioned as a company to meet our customers\u2019 needs by delivering the whole company to every client
column125: and every customer
column126:
and winning in the marketplace.

"
column127:
"

With that brief introduction
column128:
I\u2019d like to turn it over to Bruce to cover the numbers in the quarter. Bruce?

"
column129:
"

"
column130:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column131:
"

Thanks
column132: Brian
column133: and good morning everyone. I\u2019m going to start and go through the fourth quarter results
column134:
starting on slide number four.

"
column135:
"

We earned $3.4 billion
column136: or $0.29 per diluted share
column137: this quarter. Total revenues in the quarter on an FTE basis
column138:
were in line with the third quarter of 2013 at $21.7 billion and were $22.3 billion if we exclude the negative impact of FVO and DVA as a result of the significant credit spread tightening we saw in our credit spreads during the quarter.

"
column139:
"

Our revenues benefitted from increased net interest income
column140: strong investment banking and wealth management fees during the quarter
column141: and were partially offset by lower equity investment gains. Total net interest income of $17.3 billion increased from the third quarter of \u201913 as a result of increased litigation costs
column142:
which were $2.3 billion during the quarter.

"
column143:
"

If we back those litigation costs out
column144: and back out $1.4 of the foreclosure lookback expense that we saw in the fourth quarter of 2012
column145:
our expenses during the quarter declined $300 million from the third quarter of \u201913 and $1.4 billion from the fourth quarter of 2012. Asset quality continued its improvement and resulted in provision expense of only $336 million.

"
column146:
"

I would also mention two additional items that impacted results during the quarter. As I mentioned
column147: FVO and DVA were $618 million
column148: and we also recorded discrete tax benefits of approximately $500 million during the quarter that were driven by tax items that were related to non-U.S. operations
column149:
as well as the resolution of certain global tax matters.

"
column150:
"

On slide five
column151: you can see that our period-end balance sheet came in at $2.1 trillion
column152: below the prior quarter
column153:
on lower trading assets versus that third quarter of 2013.

"
column154:
"

Ending loans declined $6 billion due to the decline in residential loans in our discretionary portfolio. Outside of residential mortgages
column155:
client and customer lending reflected good commercial and seasonal credit card growth that was offset by expected declines that we have within our runoff portfolios.

"
column156:
"

Period-end deposits grew $9 billion from the record levels that we saw during the third quarter of \u201913.

"
column157:
"

Moving down the page
column158: tangible book value improved to $13.79
column159:
as the full benefit of earnings was partially offset by a negative move in AOCI as a result of higher rates. Tangible common equity increased to 7.2% during the quarter and during the quarter we repurchased 92 million common shares for roughly $1.4 billion.

"
column160:
"

The last thing that I would mention on this slide is
column161: despite the earnings of $3.4 billion
column162: our return on tangible common equity
column164: remains lower than we would like it to be
column165:
but we continue to make very good progress on this front.

"
column166:
"

On slide six
column167: you can see our Basel I tier one common ratio of 11.19% increased from the third quarter of 2013. If we look at Basel III
column168: on a fully phased-in basis
column169:
we remain above our 8.5% 2019 minimum requirement under both the standardized as well as the advanced approaches.

"
column170:
"

Let\u2019s first look at the advanced approach. Under that approach
column171: tier one common capital increased from the third quarter of \u201913 to more than $132 billion. Our Basel III risk-weighted assets remained steady at $1.3 trillion
column172: and our common ratio improved slightly from the third quarter of 2013 to 9.96%. Under the standardized approach
column173: our estimate of Basel III tier one common ratio improved a touch from the third quarter of \u201913
column174:
and remained slightly above 9%.

"
column175:
"

If we turn to the supplementary leverage ratios
column176: based on the proposed U.S. requirements that are expected to take effect in 2018
column177: as of the end of 2013 our bank holding company leverage ratio improved from the third quarter of \u201913 and continues to exceed the proposed minimum of 5%. Looking at our primary bank subsidiaries
column178: BANA and FIA
column179:
they also continue to both be in excess of the 6% proposed minimums.

"
column180:
"

The last point I would make on this topic
column181: the BCBS published final supplementary leverage rules over the weekend
column182: and while we do note some improvements from the original proposal
column183:
we\u2019re still evaluating the exact impact to us.

"
column184:
"

If we turn to slide seven
column185: funding and liquidity
column186: our long term debt ended the quarter $6 billion lower
column187: which further improved our funding costs. Global excess liquidity sources during the quarter increased $17 billion to $376 billion
column188:
and was driven by our strong deposit flows.

"
column189:
"

The time to required funding at the parent company increased to 38 months
column190: and as we look at 2014
column191: we have $31 billion of parent company maturities during the year. And once again
column192:
we would expect the issuances to be below that number as we both reduce as well as smooth the maturity profile of that debt footprint.

"
column193:
"

The other thing I would mention is that we do expect to see some additional issuance within our banks this year
column194:
given the applicability of the new liquidity rules and how they apply to the bank\u2019s subsidiaries.

"
column195:
"

If we turn to slide eight
column196: net interest income
column197: our net interest income on an FTE basis was $11 billion
column198:
which was $520 million over the third quarter of 2013. The fourth quarter of 2013 did include $210 million of positive benefits in market related adjustments driven by lower premium amortization from slower prepay assumptions on mortgage-backed securities as long term rates rose 30 basis points from the end of \u201913 to the end of \u201914.

"
column199:
"

Our net interest income
column200: excluding those adjustments
column201: was $10.8 billion
column202: representing a $241 million increase from the third quarter of \u201913. Roughly two-thirds of that improvement was driven by trading-related net income and the balance
column203: once again excluding market-related adjustments
column204: was driven by lower long term debt levels and
column205: to a lesser degree
column206:
higher deposit levels and lower rates paid.

"
column207:
"

Net interest income in those benefits were partially offset by lower consumer loan balances and lower yields. As a result of these different factors
column208: our net interest yield
column209: excluding market-related adjustments
column210:
improved from 2.4% in the third quarter of 2013 to 2.51% in the fourth quarter of \u201913.

"
column211:
"

As we move into 2014
column212: I do want to remind you that the first quarter includes two less interest accrual days
column213: so the Q4 \u201913 base of just below $10.8 billion
column214: excluding the market-related adjustments
column215: all else being equal
column216:
would start at roughly $10.6 billion for the first quarter of 2014.

"
column217:
"

Our asset sensitivity position remains positioned to benefit from higher rates
column218:
particularly from the short end of the curve.

"
column219:
"

If we move to expenses
column220: as I mentioned earlier
column221: noninterest expense was $17.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 2013 and included a $2.3 billion charge for litigation expense. Litigation expenses increased $1.2 billion from the third quarter of \u201913
column222: as we continued to evaluate our legacy exposures
column223: largely RMBS litigation
column224:
which led to additional reserves.

"
column225:
"

Excluding litigation
column226: total expenses were $15 billion during the quarter
column227:
which compares favorably to the $15.3 billion in the prior quarter and $16.4 billion in the fourth quarter of 2012.

"
column228:
"

Our legacy assets and servicing costs
column229: once again excluding litigation
column230: declined nearly $400 million from the third quarter of \u201913 and were below $2 billion this quarter
column231:
as we previously guided. This drove the $300 million improvement in expenses adjusted for litigation in the quarter.

"
column232:
"

As we continue to reduce the delinquent loans serviced over the course of 2014
column233: and reduce operating costs
column234: we expect the fourth quarter of 2014 LAS cost
column235: excluding litigation
column236:
to be roughly $1.1 billion.

"
column237:
"

Move for a moment to new BAC
column238: the benefits from new BAC in the most recent quarter were offset by a small seasonal uptick in costs when comparing to the third quarter of \u201913
column239: and when comparing to the fourth quarter of 2012
column240:
our new BAC savings are partially offset by roughly $300 million of increases from revenue related costs on higher global banking and markets and GWIM revenues. We remain on track to achieve the expected $2 billion of new BAC cost savings in mid-\u201915 as these initiatives wind down near the end of 2014.

"
column241:
"

If we move to the number of full time equivalent employees
column242: we ended the quarter at 242
column243: 000 employees
column244: a decline of more than 5
column247: from the third quarter of \u201913
column248: and that was split pretty evenly between staff reductions in LAS and the production side of the mortgage business
column249: as volumes declined
column250:
and to a lesser extent we reduced staff associated with our branch optimization.

"
column251:
"

Before I leave expenses
column252: I do want to remind you all that the first quarter typically includes the annual cost of incentives for retirement-eligible associates
column253: and once again we expect
column254: in the first quarter of 2014
column255: that number to be approximately $900 million
column256:
which is consistent with what we saw in each of the first quarters of 2012 and 2013.

"
column257:
"

If we move to slide 10
column258: on asset quality
column259:
you can see that credit quality once again improved nicely. Net chargeoffs declined to a reported $1.6 billion or a net loss ratio of 68 basis points.

"
column260:
"

The quarter did include $144 million of chargeoffs related to clarification of regulatory guidance on accounting for TDRs in the home loans portfolios. If we exclude that change
column261: net chargeoffs were approximately $1.4 billion or a 62 basis point net loss ratio and improved $250 million
column262: or 15%
column263:
from the third quarter of 2013.

"
column264:
"

Delinquencies
column265: which are obviously a leading indicator of net chargeoffs
column266: declined again as well. Our fourth quarter provision expense was $336 million on the back of this steadily improving consumer data
column267: resulting in a reserve release of $1.1 billion
column268:
excluding the regulatory guidance change.

"
column269:
"

As we move into 2014
column270:
we continue to see credit quality improve.

"
column271:
"

Let\u2019s now move into a discussion of the businesses
column272: and I\u2019m going to start on slide 11
column273: with consumer and business banking. Within this segment
column274:
we delivered improved earnings for both the previous quarter as well as the prior year\u2019s quarter.

"
column275:
"

Net income of nearly $2 billion in the fourth quarter of \u201913 is up 11% from the prior quarter and 36% from the fourth quarter of 2012. Stability in revenues
column276: lower credit cost
column277:
as well as expense reductions driven by network optimization drove the improvement in both periods.

"
column278:
"

If we take a step back and review customer activity during the quarter
column279: we saw our average deposits grow steadily and rates paid down to 8 basis points. Our brokerage assets increased 7% from the third quarter of \u201913
column280:
and are up 26% year over year on both improved market valuation as well as account flows.

"
column281:
"

Our consumer card loans showed seasonal growth this quarter
column282: as well as continued strong issuance
column283:
with 1 million cards issued during the quarter.

"
column284:
"

I would note that our fourth quarter of \u201913 balances reflect the reclassification of roughly $1 billion of an affinity portfolio that was moved to loans held for sale
column285:
and we would expect seasonality to move these balances lower in the first quarter of 2014.

"
column286:
"

Our risk-adjusted margin on credit cards is now back above 9%
column287:
driven by seasonal spending and improved credit quality as net chargeoffs and delinquencies continue to improve.

"
column288:
"

Our expense levels during the quarter do include approximately $112 million of litigation costs and that masked the benefit of our delivery network optimization as mobile banking usage continues to increase and we continue to consolidate banking centers.

"
column289:
"

Let\u2019s move to slide 12
column290: consumer real estate services
column291: which as you all know represents only 8% of the company\u2019s revenues. In our supplemental information
column292: we report two separate components of this segment
column293:
one focused on loan origination and the other focused on servicing and legacy issues.

"
column294:
"

As we signaled last quarter
column295: our first mortgage retail originations of $11.6 billion were down 49% from the third quarter as the amount and level of refinancing opportunities slowed given the rising rate environment. Lock volumes declined 37%
column296:
leading to lower core production revenue. We continue to reduce our production staffing levels to be consistent with these lower volumes that we\u2019re experiencing.

"
column297:
"

Our rep and warrant expense was $70 million during the quarter and declined by roughly $250 million from the third quarter of \u201913
column298:
which benefited mortgage banking income.

"
column299:
"

One item I do want to mention from the appendix of our slide deck is on page 20
column300: regarding represent and warrant exposure. We did receive increased levels of private label claims
column301: but it\u2019s important to note that the vast majority showed no evidence that the claimant reviewed the individual loan file ahead of the submission
column302:
and that obviously impacts the overall claim quality and therefore the process for claims resolution.

"
column303:
"

The other primary revenue component in this segment
column305: declined $54 million from the third quarter of \u201913 as a result of our smaller servicing portfolio. From a cost of servicing perspective
column306: our number of 60-plus day delinquent loans dropped 73
column308: 000 units at the end of 2013
column309: and as a result of this
column310:
once again our LAS expense ex-litigation declined nearly $400 million during the quarter to $1.8 billion.

"
column311:
"

Global wealth and investment management
column312: on slide 13. This represents 21% of our company\u2019s revenue and our wealth management business achieved records for net income in both the quarter as well as for full year 2013. Within this segment
column313: both Merrill Lynch as well as U.S. Trust maintained their strong leadership positions
column314:
managing a total of $2.4 trillion in client balances.

"
column315:
"

Revenue approached $4.5 billion in the quarter
column316:
increasing 7% year over year and 2% on a linked quarter basis. And I would also note it\u2019s the fourth consecutive quarter in which the pretax margin was above 25%.

"
column317:
"

Our asset management fees once again achieved a new record during the quarter
column318: driving the revenue improvement from the third quarter of 2013. Our client engagement remains strong
column319:
and market levels are providing an additional tailwind.

"
column320:
"

Our long term AUM flows for the quarter were $9.4 billion and $48 billion for the year
column321: nearly doubling the 2012 production level. Ending deposits also grew nicely again
column322:
and our ending client loan balances of almost $119 billion reached record levels as we continue to see very good activity in both consumer real estate as well as our security based lending.

"
column323:
"

Turning to slide 14
column324: global banking
column325: our fourth quarter earnings of $1.3 billion showed good growth over the third quarter of \u201913
column326: with strong investment banking results
column327:
but are down from the fourth quarter of 2012 due to higher provision expense.

"
column328:
"

Provision in the year ago quarter included reserve releases while we built reserves in the fourth quarter of \u201913 associated with the commercial loan growth that we\u2019ve seen. While we\u2019re on credit quality
column329:
I would note that our net chargeoffs within the banking segment for the quarter were only $7 million versus $132 million in the fourth quarter of \u201912 and $35 million in the third quarter of \u201913.

"
column330:
"

Our expenses reflect effective cost control
column331: but also reflect increased related to revenue related compensation for investment banking. Our investment banking fees this quarter across the company were a record $1.74 billion
column332:
up 9% from the fourth quarter of 2012 and 34% from the third quarter of 2013.

"
column333:
"

Based on [Dealogic]
column334: we did maintain our number two position and fees with an 8% market share
column335: and in addition
column336:
during the quarter we ranked number one in Americas investment banking fees with a 10.7% market share.

"
column337:
"

During 2013
column338: we advised on 10 of the top 20 announced M&A deals
column339: and as we move into 2014
column340:
the pipeline remains strong.

"
column341:
"

If we move to the balance sheet
column342: average loans increased $8.8 billion from the third quarter
column343: with solid C&I growth
column344: particularly in large corporate and healthcare
column345: along with growth in commercial real estate. Our average growth did outstrip our $2.3 billion end of period growth as we funded several deals near the end of the third quarter of \u201913
column346:
which benefited the overall average balances.

"
column347:
"

We see solid customer demand for loans as we head into 2014
column348:
but would note that competition is particularly aggressive for middle market loans.

"
column349:
"

Lastly
column350: on banking
column351:
our average deposits increased almost $20 billion from the third quarter of \u201913 as our customers continue to show strong liquidity.

"
column352:
"

If we switch to global markets
column353: on slide 15
column354: ex-DVA
column355: we earned $341 million in the fourth quarter of \u201913
column356: consistent with the fourth quarter of \u201912
column357: but down $190 million compared to the third quarter of \u201913 after we exclude the U.K. tax charge. Higher revenue in both comparisons was offset by litigation costs
column358:
mostly associated with RMBS securities litigation.

"
column359:
"

Sales and trading revenue
column360: once again ex-DVA
column362:
19% above the fourth quarter of \u201912 and in line with what we saw in the third quarter of \u201913.

"
column363:
"

Our fixed sales and trading revenue were up roughly $300 million or 16% compared to the fourth quarter of 2012
column364:
as the strength we saw in our credit and mortgage businesses more than offset slowness in both rates and commodities. Our fourth quarter of \u201913 did include roughly a $200 million benefit from recoveries on certain legacy positions within the FICC business.

"
column365:
"

column372:
"

column373: or 11%
column374:
from the year ago period and are generally flat with the third quarter of 2013.

column375:

On slide 16
column376: we show you the results of all other. Profitability this quarter
column377: compared to the third quarter of 2013
column378:
declined as the tax benefits this quarter that I described earlier were more than offset by lower revenue and less reserve release.

column379:
"

The revenue decline from the third quarter of \u201913 was driven by lower equity investment gains. If you recall
column380:
we sold CTB shares during the third quarter of \u201913 as well as more negative FVO valuations. The expense within all other includes $250 million of litigation in the fourth quarter of \u201913.

"
column381:
"

And lastly I would note we expect an effective tax rate of approximately 30% in 2014
column383:
"

Before we open it up for questions
column384: let me make a few comments on the quarter. Capital and liquidity have never been stronger. On the revenue side
column385:
customer activity drove stronger core business results. Our consumer banking saw modest improvement on card income and service charges after troughing in early 2013.

"
column386:
"

Our global wealth and investment management business had a record year. Our global banking had a record year as well
column387:
with higher investment banking fees and stronger lending activity. And our global markets business is performing well against the market opportunities that they\u2019re seeing.

"
column388:
"

We kept our cost initiative work on track
column389: and credit improvement continues its track towards historic lows. We also made significant progress in 2013 in continuing to resolve legacy mortgage matters with the more significant ones being settlements with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on GSE rep and warranty issues
column390: MBIA in the monoline space
column391:
and the Luther Maine State class action suit in the private label area of RMBS litigation.

And with that

yes. Because we\u2019re rebuilding a system. But that\u2019s all built into the dialog that we had about new BAC.

column1:
{"Bank of America's CEO Discusses Q1 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corp. (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan - President and CEO

"
column22:
"

Nancy Bush - NAB Research LLC

"
column27:
"

Good day
column29:
and welcome to today\u2019s program. (Operator instructions) It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead.

"
column31:
"

Good morning
column32: thanks for joining us on the web as well as the phone this morning. Before I turn the call over to CEO
column33: Brian Moynihan and CFO Bruce Thompson
column34: let me just say that we may make some forward-looking statements. For details on those I will refer you to our Page 24 and 25 in our earnings deck material
column35:
either the website or our SEC filings.

"
column36:
"

With that I\u2019ll turn it over to Brian.

"
column37:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column40: and thank you for joining us to review the first quarter results. As you can see from our numbers
column41: we report a loss this quarter. That loss reflects the cost of resolving more of our legacy mortgage issues
column42:
as well as adding reserves primarily for previously disclosed legacy mortgage related matters. As disappointed as we are in the bottom-line results; we\u2019re pleased to report that the businesses reported earnings at a level that will allow us to substantially offset these losses. And also at the same time we were able to sell grow and improve our Basel III standardized regulatory capital ratio during the quarter.

"
column43:
"

Bruce will take you through the particulars of our results. But first I want to spend a couple of minutes looking at the progress we continue to make across the customer groups that we serve. In particular
column44: we added some slides to the appendix on pages 17 and 18
column45:
which highlight multi-year trends across our customer groups. Let me just touch on a few of those and connect them to our results.

"
column46:
"

When you think about broad consumer franchise for mass-market consumers
column47: affluent and wealthy consumers
column48: as we think about the mass-market group
column49: the strategy in our retail segment has been to lower the cost of service
column50: so we could improve our customer experience. We do that by continuing to optimize our delivery networks of all types in response to customer behavior changes. Banking centers and basic teller transactions continue to decline as customers move their business to mobile and online transactions. Yet we still have many millions of visits each week to our branches. But in the aggregate
column51: our self-service channels of ATM
column52:
online and mobile transactions continue to grow.

"
column53:
"

This quarter
column54: more than 10%
column55: of all of the deposit transactions that consumers make in our Company are now done through mobile devices
column56: as people effectively carry a branch in their pocket. This
column57: coupled with other measures allowed us to reduce our cost in our consumer banking business
column58:
4% from last year\u2019s first quarter. It allows us to continue to invest in other areas to further improve customer satisfaction and grow sales.

"
column59:
"

On the preferred side of our consumer business
column60: where we serve mass-affluent clients we continue investing in this group by adding sales specialists. We now have more than 6500 sales specialists concentrated in the top banking centers. We have also increased service associates to drive satisfaction of these clients as well. The end result
column61: when you put all consumer business together is a segment -- is organic deposit growth of $23 billion from last year to a total of $535 billion in deposits. On investment side of this general consumer client base
column62: our Merrill Edge assets grew 21% from last year. When we put the segment together
column63:
the earnings in our consumer and business banking business improved 50% year-over-year to nearly $1.7 billion this quarter.

"
column64:
"

As we move to the wealthy part of our consumer client base
column65: in our wealth management business with U.S. Trust of Merrill Lynch
column66:
client balances again grew this quarter and now total over $2.4 trillion. column633: the first is on a year-over-year basis you had average loans up about $30 billion. So there were more loan balances against which you need to allocate capital. The second thing that I would say is as you look at that segment and you consider Basel III standardized ratios
column634:
they tend to risk weight almost all commercial loans at 100% regardless of what the models would suggest they should be risk weighted at.

"
column635:
"

So I think the combination of the loan growth
column636: along with some of the impacts from regulatory capital led us to increase what we did with respect to global banking. Within global wealth management
column637: as you go back and refine operational loss models and assign operational risk capital
column638: that was topped up as well as reflecting the fact within wealth management business that we\u2019ve seen loan growth within that segment. So there was additional money allocated there and then as we look at and just continue to refine and look at both comparables as well as asset mix
column639: we thought it was prudent to increase modestly what we saw with a global market and as I said in my comments
column640: when you consider the aggregate and we look at where we are relative to peers
column641:
we\u2019ve got virtually all of our capital at this point pushed out to the different businesses which is the way it should be.

column643:
"

Mike Mayo - CLSA

column645:
"

I agree. So it sounds like it\u2019s partly business growth and partly regulatory related and partly a desire simply to have less unallocated capital.

column649:

000 I think.

"
column922: you have to consider as that. As we went through with the different regulatory metrics we needed to get to that that the last metric that we needed to solve for and we wanted to get behind us was the satisfaction of where we needed to be from the LCR perspective in 2017 at both the bank level
column923:
as well as the parent and work to the point where we\u2019ve gotten to that point. So from an overall liquidity HQLA perspective we feel very good about that progress.

"
column924:
"

As you look at on a go-forward bases
column926:
the big focus and the reason as a company that we are looking to drive the loan growth that we have is to basically take the access deposits today that are within the investment portfolio and release them from the investment portfolio into two core loan activity to do more with our clients.

"
column927:
"

So as you look at the changes and mix in the balance sheet as far as the built that you\u2019ve seen with cash. I think we are at the point where from an overall balance and where we need to be with the different metrics that we\u2019ve satisfied that at this point and it will be more of a normal course on a go-forward basis.

"
column929:
"

Yeah. I think generally thematically if you think about as we see rules come up
column930: we try to get in full compliances as fast as possible even though there is delay dates. And then you can then work back on how to continuously improve the way you get there but first thing you guys do is get over the humps because it affects every other aspect of the franchise. And so I think the LCR and case set we got over the hump 17 is two years away still and we are in compliance and then the idea is that you keep to figure out how that work to dies to make it more and more shareholder friendly overtime
column931:
but the first we want to make sure we can do.

"
column935:
"

I think that\u2019s a -- I think that was the last question. Thanks for joining today and we\u2019ll talk to you in the next quarter.

"
column937:
"

This concludes the program for today. Thanks for your participation. You may now disconnect and have a nice day.

"
column938:
"
