column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q2 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian T. Moynihan - Chairman and CEO

"
column9:
"

Bruce R. Thompson - Chief Financial Officer

"
column12:
"

Matthew D. O'Connor - Deutsche Bank

"
column14:
"

John E. McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column22:
"

Michael L. Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities

"
column27:
and welcome to today's program. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later you will have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]. Please note this call may be recorded. I'll be standing by should you need any assistance.

"
column28:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. You may begin sir.

"
column29:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column30:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone
column31: as well as the webcast for joining us this morning for the second quarter results. Hopefully
column32:
everybody has had a chance to review the earnings release documents that are available on the website.

"
column33:
"

So before I turn the call over to Brian and Bruce
column34: let me just remind you we may make some forward-looking statements and for further information on those please refer to either our earnings release documents
column35:
our website or our SEC filings.

"
column36:
"

So with that I'm pleased to turn it over to Brian Moynihan
column37: our CEO for some opening comments
column39:
the CFO goes through the details. Brian?

"
column40:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column41:
"

Thank you
column42: Lee
column43: and good morning
column44:
everyone and thank you for joining us for our second quarter results.

"
column45:
"

As you can see from our release we reported $5.3 billion in after tax earnings this quarter
column46: which is up from last quarter as well as more than double what we made last year. Not only were we pleased with the bottom line
column47:
but revenue was up and expenses were down comparably against both periods.

"
column48:
"

Lots of things came together to achieve these results and we continue to work on all these also. On the expense side we told you that we achieved this new BAC cost savings back in the third quarter of last year. However
column49:
we didn't give up on our focus on expenses and you can see those in the results. It's the lowest non-litigation expense base since 2008.

"
column50:
"

At the same time we continue to invest in the future of this company. Just to mention a few of these investments
column51: we added sales specialists in our financial centers
column52: up 3% versus last year. We added 3% to our financial advisers since last year
column53:
4% to our commercial and business bankers. We've opened new financial centers in new markets that we previously didn't have coverage and we continue to upgrade those in other markets.

"
column54:
"

In addition
column55: we continue to invest in young new talent in our company. We hired a record number of teammates from college
column56: over 1
column57: 200 and we have our intern program to over 1
column58: 800 this summer. And we continue to invest as we have said in technology
column59:
so that was $3 billion we spent this year to continue to improve and drive our products and our capabilities in the company.

"
column60:
"

As we are doing that we continue to focus on our process improvement
column61: our simplified and improved effort continues to take hold and you saw that to have some affect that this quarter. The goal of that program is to hold the costs
column62:
manage them well as the economy continues to recover and our revenues continue to recover.

"
column63:
"

Away from expenses
column64:
a few other highlights for the quarter. We saw overall loan growth and balances from the first quarter. We saw continued improvement in our net charge-offs and credit quality; our deposits in our consumer continue to grow even faster this quarter than prior quarters.

"
column65:
"

We also built capital and tangible book value despite the OCI impact of higher rates. We\u2019ve returned over $1.3 billion to our shareholders through share repurchases and common dividends and looking at the results this quarter you can also see that we're making progress on our path to our long-term targets of return on assets and return on tangible common equity.

"
column66:
"

Bruce will take you through the business activity in the various pages in the slides with some highlights. This quarter again we averaged about 5
column67: 000 new customers a day to our mobile banking platform
column68: but importantly the team continues to make progress in bringing that platform into the company in multiple ways. Example of that is this quarter our digital channel sales were up 30% from last year in the second quarter. In addition to that we continue to focus on our mortgage area
column69: our direct to consumer mortgage and home equity originations improved 40% from a year ago. In the mass affluent space our Merrill Lynch product
column70:
it continues to have record assets and they were up 15% to over $122 billion and that\u2019s on top of our investment brokerage services revenue teammates in U.S. Trusts and Merrill Lynch that continues to grow.

"
column71:
"

We also continue to drive our 401(k) business and this year we\u2019ve added some of the industry\u2019s largest companies to our platform. So this is the trends in the business and Bruce will cover more later.

"
column72:
"

From a broad economic standpoint what do we see out there
column73: notwithstanding uncertain economies outside United States we see the U.S. economy continues to steadily improve. In our middle market business
column74: our commercial businesses
column75: our company\u2019s balance sheets are strong and they continue to drive loans at a higher rate than they did last quarter. Our consumers continue to spend on our debit and credit cards
column76: this quarter spending about $127 billion this quarter
column77:
up 3% from last year even with the down draft in gas prices in the year-over-year comparison.

"
column78:
"

Our industry leading research team under Candace's leadership and Bank of America research expects U.S. GDP growth for the second half of the year to be 3% for each of those quarters and we see that in our statistics. Our company is well-positioned to benefit from that continued health in the economy and we continue to manage this company to deliver for our customers and clients and for you our shareholders.

"
column79:
"

With that
column80:
I'll turn it over to Bruce.

"
column81:
"

Bruce R. Thompson

"
column82:
"

Thanks Brian and good morning everyone. I am going to start on slide three
column83:
and let\u2019s go through the results.

"
column84:
"

We recorded $5.3 billion of earnings in the second quarter or $0.45 per diluted share. This compares to $0.27 a share in the first quarter of 2015 and $0.19 in the second quarter of last year. A few items to note as you review the results. In the second quarter
column85: we had $669 million of positive market related adjustments in net interest income
column86:
primarily driven by premium amortization on our debt securities from higher long-term rates. This provided a $0.04 benefit to EPS. The quarter also included $373 million in benefits from consumer real estate loans which added $0.02 a share.

"
column87:
"

One other item worth noting is the rep and warrant provision which is a net $205 million benefit this period. This was mostly associated with positive developments in legacy mortgage related matters
column88:
which I'll discuss later in the presentation. This added a $0.01 to EPS.

"
column89:
"

Revenue on an FTE basis was $22.3 billion in the second quarter and included the items that I just mentioned. Total non-interest expense in the quarter was $13.8 billion and reflects lower litigation costs
column90:
lower LAS costs and good core expense controls compared to both the first quarter of \u201815 and the second quarter of 2014.

"
column91:
"

Provision for credit losses this quarter was $780 million and included improved net charge-offs on an adjusted basis as well as less reserve release compared to the first quarter of 2015. Return on tangible common equity this quarter was 12.8%
column92: return on assets was 99 basis points and the efficiency ratio was 62%. If we adjust for those metrics for the few items I mentioned earlier
column93: return on tangible common equity was 10.9%
column94:
return on assets was 85 basis points and the efficiency ratio was 65%.

"
column95:
"

On slide four
column96: the balance sheet was up less than 1% versus the first quarter of '15 as loan growth and higher securities balances were offset by a decline in the ending balances within our global markets business. Loans on a period end basis were up reflecting good core loan activity. All of our loan categories showed growth from the first quarter of '15 with the exception of consumer real estate
column97: which declined from both discretionary activity as well as other one-offs. Common shareholders\u2019 equity improved
column98:
the solid earnings growth was partially offset by a $2.2 billion decline in OCI and $1.3 billion in capital return to common shareholders. We repurchased 49 million shares for $775 million and paid approximately $500 million in common dividends this quarter. Tangible book value increased to $15.02 and tangible common equity improved to 7.6%.

"
column99:
"

If we look at lending activity on slide five
column100: our reported loans on an end of period basis increased for the first time since the third quarter of 2013 growing $8.5 billion from the first quarter or 4% on an annualized basis. Activity in our discretionary portfolio which is reflected in the LAS and all other box
column101:
where we used consumer real estate loans to manage interest rate risk in the LAS unit where we have home equity run-off portfolio together showed a decline from the first quarter of '15 of $15 billion.

"
column102:
"

The loan sales I mentioned earlier accounted for roughly half that amount and included certain loans with long-term standby arrangements that were converted into securities. After we exclude this activity
column103: our core loans increased $23.5 billion or 4% from the first quarter of '15. Commercial lending was strong. Among other initiatives
column104: the management team challenged our corporate and commercial lenders for the past several quarters to more fully utilize the credit limits
column105:
to drive responsible growth.

"
column106:
"

In that light
column107: global banking showed a continuation of loan growth from the end of the first quarter of '15
column108:
growing $11.4 billion or 4% during the quarter from a mix of C&I across large corporate and middle market as well as growth in commercial real estate.

"
column109:
"

Our wealth management business continues to experience strong demand in both securities based lending as well as consumer real estate. And our consumer banking area grew both card and auto loans.

"
column110:
"

We move to regulatory capital on slide six. Under the transition rules our CET1 ratio improved to 11.2% in the second quarter. If we look at our Basel III regulatory capital on a fully phased-in basis
column111: CET1 capital improved $1.1 billion driven by earnings partially offset by the OCI decline
column112: share repurchases and dividends. Under the standardized approach
column113:
our CET1 ratio was steady at 10.3% as RWA was stable with the first quarter of '15.

"
column114:
"

Under the advanced approaches
column115: CET1 ratio increased from 10.1% to 10.4% as RWA improved by approximately $34 billion. Lower counterparty RWA drove this decline and was equally split between three factors. The first
column116: lower derivative exposures
column117: mainly driven by movements in both rates as well as FX. Second
column118: optimization through better collateral management and reductions in certain positions. And third
column119:
an increase in the population of trades eligible for model treatment. The balance of the improvement was driven by lower levels of market risk.

"
column120:
"

In regards to the Fed's requested modifications to models in order to exit the parallel run that we have previously communicated to you
column121:
at the end of the quarter we estimate if we made the requested modifications that our advanced approaches CET1 ratio would be approximately 9.3% at June 30th.

"
column122:
"

Moving to our supplementary leverage ratios we estimate that at the end of the second quarter we continue to exceed the U.S. rules that are applicable in 2018. Our bank holding company SLR ratio was approximately 6.3%
column123:
while the primary bank subsidiary BANA was approximately 7%.

"
column124:
"

If we turn to slide seven
column125: on funding and liquidity
column126:
long-term debt of $243 billion was up $6 billion from the first quarter as issuances outpaced maturities. As you can see from the maturity profile we have $10 billion of parent company debt scheduled to mature in the rest of 2015 and we'll continue to be opportunistic in regards to issuance.

"
column127:
"

Our global excess liquidity sources reached a record level during the quarter at $484 billion and now represents 23% of the overall balance sheet. The increase from the first quarter of GELS reflects a continued shift from discretionary loans into HQLA securities as well as the increased debt balances.

"
column128:
"

Our parent company liquidity increased to $96 billion and our time to required funding improved to 40 months. And at the end of the second quarter we estimate that the consolidated company was well above the 100% fully phased-in 2017 requirement for the liquidity ratio.

"
column129:
"

If we turn to slide eight
column130: our net interest income on a reported FTE basis was $10.7 billion
column131: an increase of $1 billion from the first quarter of \u201915. Volatility of long end rates over the past few quarters has clearly caused some variability in our reported NII. The market related adjustment from our bond premium amortization this quarter was a benefit of $669 million
column132: as rates rose 40 basis points in the quarter
column133: while in the first quarter of \u201915 we reported a negative $484 million adjustment from a decline in rates in the period. If we adjust for those items our NII declined approximately a $100 million from the first quarter of \u201915 to just over $10 billion
column134:
as the impact of lower discretionary balances in consumer loan yields more than offset the impact of one more day of interest.

"
column135:
"

At the end of the second quarter an instantaneous 100 basis point parallel shift and increase in rates would be expected to contribute roughly $3.9 billion in NII benefits over the following 12 months and that split roughly 60% to short-end rates and 40% to long-end rates. Given the movement higher in long-end rates
column136:
our balance sheet did become less sensitive to long-end rates compared to March 31st as we realized some of that sensitivity through FAS 91 in the second quarter.

"
column137:
"

As you can see on slide nine
column138: non-interest expense was $13.8 billion in the second quarter and included a $175 million in litigation expense. Litigation expense did decline significantly from the second quarter of \u201914 levels. If we exclude litigation expenses were $13.6 billion in the quarter
column139:
a decline of $900 million or 6% from the second quarter of 2014. On balance we\u2019re quite pleased with our year-over-year expense improvement even while we continue to invest in the franchise.

"
column140:
"

In the third quarter of \u201914 we wrapped up the new BAC cost savings initiatives and several quarters later we continue to see good progress on operating cost reductions in LAS
column141:
as well as in other areas. Our headcount is down 7% compared to the second quarter of \u201914 and as a reminder we do expect to incur some cost associated with our CCAR resubmission through the balance of the year.

"
column142:
"

If we go ahead and switch to asset quality on slide 10
column143:
reported net charge-offs were $1.1 billion versus $1.2 billion in the first quarter of \u201915. Both periods include charge-offs associated with the August 2014 DOJ settlement which we had previously reserved for. If we exclude these impacts and a small impact from recoveries on NPL sales our core net charge-offs declined $75 million from the first quarter of \u201915 to $929 million.

"
column144:
"

Loss rates on the same adjusted basis improved to 43 basis points in the second quarter of \u201915. U.S. consumer credit card delinquencies improved as well and on the commercial front we saw an uptick in NPLs and reservable criticized exposure from the first quarter driven by downgrades in oil and gas exposures. Despite these downgrades we feel good about our exposure in this area as they are well collateralized and most of these credits only had a one level migration on a risk rating scale.

"
column145:
"

The second quarter provision expense was $780 million and we released a net $288 million in reserves which includes the utilization of previously accrued DOJ reserves. Releases in consumer card and consumer real estate were partially offset by reserve bills within the commercial loan growth area.

"
column146:
"

Let\u2019s go ahead and move to the businesses on slide 11
column147: Consumer banking had earnings of $1.7 billion which was 4% greater than the second quarter of 2014 and 16% above the first quarter of \u201915 level. This in turn generated a strong 24% return on allocated capital. Within revenue fees were up 2% from last year driven by higher card and higher mortgage banking revenue
column148:
but this growth was more than offset by a decline in net interest income. The decline in net interest income is a result of the allocated impact of our ALM activities as well as some compression in card loan yields. Provision decreased $44 million from the second quarter of '14 driven by the continued improvement that we saw in both the credit card as well as the auto portfolios.

"
column149:
"

Our non-interest expense was down 4% from the second quarter of '14 as we reduced the number of financial centers and associated costs and personnel. The cost of average deposits ratio is now less than a 175 basis points and we have a 57% efficiency ratio within this segment. This business is a good representation of how the company is doing more business while we continue to reduce expenses.

"
column150:
"

We also continue to experience a shift in consumer behavior patterns away from branches and towards more self-service. For example
column151:
the number of mobile banking customers continues to grow and increased to more than $17.6 million customers this quarter and these customers look to mobile devices for approximately 13% of all transactions -- all deposit transactions.

"
column152:
"

If we look at some of the key drivers and trends within the consumer area on slide 12
column153: we remain a leader in many aspects of consumer banking
column154:
doing business with roughly half of all U.S. households.

"
column155:
"

Let's look at card activity. Card income increased 5% from the second quarter of '14 on strong sales and solid spend levels. Card issuance reached almost $1.3 million units in the quarter on increased sales efforts while the average book FICO score was also strong. Average loan balances were down slightly from the second quarter of '14 as we do see customers paying down more of the balances. Net charge-offs declined from very low levels and were 2.7% in the second quarter and risk adjusted margins remained high at roughly 9%. Mortgage banking income in this segment was up 8% from last year as originations had nice follow through from the elevated pipeline at the end of the first quarter as well as the higher productions margins.

"
column156:
"

First mortgage originations for the total company were $16 billion
column157:
up 44% year-over-year and up 16% from the first quarter of '15. Home equity line and loan originations increased 23% to $3.2 billion from the year ago quarter and were stable with the first quarter. Revenue improvement versus the second quarter of '14 was driven by improved margins. Although the mortgage pipeline remained solid it is down 15% from the end of the first quarter driven in part by higher rates. Service charges were down modestly versus the second quarter of '14. This fee line item does continue to be somewhat muted as we continue to open higher quality accounts and those accounts are carrying higher balances. Compared to the second quarter of '14 our average deposits of $545 billion are up $31 billion or 6% even as we lowered the rates paid which now stands at five basis points.

"
column158:
"

Lastly
column159: while we are bringing down our overall headcount in this business
column160:
we continue to invest in the growth opportunity of our preferred client base and we've been increasing sales specialists in the financial centers and that's resulted in increased activity.

"
column161:
"

If we turn to slide 13
column162: Global wealth and investment management produced earnings of $690 million
column163: which was up 6% from the first quarter of '15 level but down 5% from the second quarter of '14. Compared to the second quarter of '14 solid fee growth was offset by lower net interest income
column164: higher credit cost and modestly higher expenses
column165:
which resulted in a decline in year-over-year results. The allocation of the impact of our company's ALM activities more than offset the NII benefits that we had from solid loan growth within the space.

"
column166:
"

Year-over-year non-interest income was up 4% on strong asset management results. Non-interest expense was modestly higher in the second quarter on the strength of our asset management fees as well as the continuing investment in client facing professionals. The year-over-year increase in provision reflects larger reserve release in the prior periods. Pretax margin was 24% and the return on allocated capital remained strong at 23%.

"
column167:
"

If we look at activity and drivers on slide 14
column168:
asset management fees continue to grow and are up 9% from the second quarter of '14. This was partially offset by sluggishness of transactional revenue in the brokerage business. We did increase our financial advisers by 6% over the last 12 months and we feel good about the number of advisers that are joining us from competitors.

"
column169:
"

Client balances are above $2.5 trillion
column170:
up almost $12 billion from the first quarter of '15 driven by solid client balance inflows as well as improved market valuations. Long-term AUM flows were $9 billion for the quarter and that's the 24th consecutive quarter where we've seem positive flows. As I mentioned earlier we continue to experience strong demand in both our securities based and residential mortgage lending areas and we reached a new record for loans within the space during the quarter.

"
column171:
"

We turn to slide 15; global banking earnings were $1.3 billion
column172: which is 14% on allocated capital. Earnings did decline 13% from the second quarter of '14 as lower non-interest expense was more than offset by lower net interest income
column173:
lower investment banking revenues and higher provision expense that was associated with the strong loan growth that we saw during the quarter. The year-over-year decline in net interest income reflects the allocation of our ALM activity and liquidity costs as well as some compression in loan spreads. Non-interest expense did decline 3% from the second quarter of '14 as lower litigation and other technology initiative costs were partially offset by investment in client-facing personnel.

"
column174:
"

If we look at the trends on slide 16
column175: we chart the components of revenue. Investment banking fees for the company were $1.5 billion
column176: down 6% from the near record levels that we experienced during the second quarter of '14. Advisory fees were up 5% during the quarter
column177:
debt underwriting was relatively stable as increased activity in the investment grade and other products offset the declines that we saw within our leverage finance area.

"
column178:
"

Equity underwriting was down 19% from what was a record level for our company in the second quarter of 2014. Outside of investment banking fees other banking revenue declined from leasing gains partially offset by modestly higher treasury fees and card income.

"
column179:
"

If we look at the balance sheet
column180: loans on average were $301 billion
column181:
up 4% from both the year-over-year and linked-quarter periods. The growth was broad-based across both corporate and commercial borrowers. Although average deposits were relatively stable versus the second quarter of '14 we did see a favorable shift in mix with our non-interest bearing deposits up over $20 billion and our interest bearing deposits down $17 billion versus the second quarter of '14. This growth in non-interest bearing balances was driven by a continuing focus on the growth within operating balances. The decline in interest bearing balances was driven by targeted reductions in these low liquidity value deposits.

"
column182:
"

Switching to global markets on slide 17
column183: in the second quarter earnings were $1 billion on revenues of $4.3 billion. We generated 11% return on capital in this business during the quarter. Earnings were up modestly from the first quarter of '15 levels
column184: which included higher litigation
column185: but down from the second quarter of '14 as revenue declined. Total revenue
column186: excluding net DVA declined from the second quarter driven by lower equity investment gains
column187: lower sales and trading results and lower investment banking fees. If we exclude a $188 million difference between periods on the sale of an equity investment
column188: revenue was down 4% in the second quarter. Non-interest expense was reduced 5% from that same period
column189:
in line with the revenue reductions.

"
column190:
"

We focused on the sales and trading performance components on slide 18. Sales and trading revenue of $3.3 billion ex-net DVA is down 2% from the second quarter of '14 levels. Compared with the same period a year ago
column191: fixed sales and trading was down 9% and not unlike what we saw in the first quarter of '15 strength within the macro-related products like FX
column192:
rates and commodities was offset by lower levels of activity within the credit product space. And to remind you our mix does remain more heavily weighted to credit products based on the size of our new issue business.

"
column193:
"

Equity's trading was up 13% year-over-year driven largely by increased client activity within the Asia Pacific region as well as a strong performance within the derivative area.

"
column194:
"

Slide 19 shows our legacy assets and servicing business
column195: where we were profitable during the quarter given the net benefit in our rep and warrant provision. Revenue excluding this benefit did decline from the first quarter of '15 on less favorable MSR hedge performance as well as lower servicing revenue. Litigation expense declined significantly from the second quarter of '14. Non-interest expense ex-litigation was roughly $900 million this quarter improving $122 million from the first quarter of \u201815 and $526 million going back to the second quarter of '14. We remain on track to hit our fourth quarter goal of approximately $800 million in LAS cost ex-litigation. We were also pleased that during the quarter our number of 60 plus day delinquent loans decreased to 132
column196:
000 units. That's down 14% from the first quarter and almost 50% from the prior period of last year.

"
column197:
"

Before I move away from the mortgage space let me mention an important development in our legacy mortgage exposures. This quarter there was a closely watched case in New York's highest court which confirmed that the New York's six year statute of limitation on filing rep and warrant claims begins to run at the time the reps and warranties are made and not at some later point in time. Based on our review of the relevant documents we believe the vast majority of the bank's remaining PRs representation on warranty obligations are governed by New York law.

"
column198:
"

As a result of the case ruling you can see on slide 20
column199: a significant $7.6 billion reduction in our gross outstanding private label claims as a result of certain claims now being time barred. This ruling also had positive implications on our rep and warrant provision
column200: as I mentioned
column201:
as well as the range of possible loss above those reserves. You\u2019ll recall the RPL had been a range of up to $4 billion for several years and so that the top end of that range has now been reduced to up to $2 billion.

"
column202:
"

On slide 21 we show all other. The $637 million of earnings this quarter resulted in a swing in profitability is a result of the improvement in the NII market related adjustment from quarter-to-quarter as well as the prior period inclusion of the annual retirement eligible incentive cost. The loan sales
column203: I mentioned earlier are also included in revenue. Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 29% and I would expect the tax rate to be roughly 30% for the rest of 2015
column204: absent unusual items like the recent UK tax reform proposals. Among the UK proposals where a reduction in the corporate tax rate
column205:
a surcharge tax on bank earnings and a reduction in the bank levy rate.

"
column206:
"

Our preliminary read is that we could have a one-time charge of several hundred million dollars later in this year to re-price our UK deferred tax assets upon enactment. At this time on an ongoing basis we expect the recurring tax impact to be modest. Before wrapping up on this slide
column207:
let me remind you that our preferred dividends in the third quarter should be $440 million and $330 million in the fourth quarter of this year.

"
column208:
"

So to wrap up
column209: as Brian started the presentation with
column210: many things that our teams have been focused on for some time came together nicely this quarter and that enabled us to report more than $5 billion in earnings and move closer to our long-term targets. Revenue reflected relative stability. We lowered cost
column211: we grew loans nicely
column212:
credit quality remains very good and we're focused on operating leverage within the business. The foundation of the company's balance sheet has never been stronger with record capital and record liquidity levels and we remain well-positioned to benefit from a rising rate environment.

"
column213:
"

With that

let's go ahead and open it up for Q&A.

column854: and we\u2019re very
column855:
very focused on continuing to keep that balance as we go forward.

"
column857:
"

Okay. Just to understand because I am looking at your slides
column858: slide 17 and the other slides in your presentation deck
column859: looked at the four slides
column860: related to GWIM
column861: Global Banking
column862: Global Markets
column863: Consumer Banking
column864: I took second quarter of 2015 versus second quarter of 2014 and looked at the delta in revenues and that\u2019s how I got the $800 million decline
column865:
so you would say which adjustment should we make from that?

"
column866:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column867:
"

Let\u2019s just take -- we will take GWIM because I have got that number on the top of my head
column868: Mike. I think year-over-year the difference in GWIM NII allocation through this sort of [indiscernible] and those things is
column869:
Bruce how much\u2026?

"
column870:
"

Bruce R. Thompson

"
column871:
"

Yes
column872: let\u2019s just go through relative to the second quarter of \u201814 you have got consumer from an overall NII impact was more than $200 million
column873: GWIM was as Brian said roughly $130 million
column874: overall investment bank
column875:
our global banking was a couple of hundred million and then you have the minimus amounts within markets in LAS.

"
column877:
"

So that is nothing more than us changing the allocation method. It\u2019s because of LTR things becoming important
column878: so we push down the business to get the behavior of the businesses aligned with the parent. So this is why you have to be a little careful about micro assessing these movements because things change and the methodology year-over-year and we don\u2019t go back and restate this
column879:
we didn\u2019t do it last year.

"
column880:
"

Michael L. Mayo

"
column881:
"

Okay. I will follow up on that. So just are you comfortable
column882: are you satisfied with the revenue progression that you have had
column883:
no matter how you take a look at it?

"
column885:
"

We are satisfied that we are starting to see the hard work of all our teammates come through but we are not satisfied in the sense that we expect better performance on both the revenue expense line in the future. We said that we\u2019ll keep working at it
column886: but if you look at it over the last several quarters we\u2019ll see the stability in revenues but continued work on expenses both in the dollars but also the headcount
column887: you have \u201815 straight quarters
column889:
000 or more personnel reductions per quarter is a pretty strong record that shows that we are disciplined [in cutting costs].

"
column890:
"

Michael L. Mayo

"
column891:
"

And then a separate question
column892: I think it\u2019s first time you have listed ROA and ROE on the first page of your press release and should we read anything into that
column893:
that you are more focused on achieving these targets with a specific time frame or kind of what changed?

"
column894:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column895:
"

It maybe the pagination. It\u2019s been listed
column896:
in our documents consistently Mike so... We are all focused on those goals and we\u2019ve told you that last time you asked the question.

"
column897:
"

Michael L. Mayo

"
column898:
"

And then lastly
column899: just I know I have asked this question before
column900: is there a specific timeframe that you commit to
column901:
to achieve your ROA and ROE goals?

"
column903:
"

Mike as I told you
column904: Dan and me [ph] will be there with a few other people
column905: and asked me questions on this question
column906:
we have the building blocks in place to get us to where we are and we consider building blocks are in a place to get us to our goals and there are external factors with the rate increase and stuff that are -- you see the market curve that\u2019s changed just in the last 15 days this quarter and has moved around dramatically. So we are going ahead with our control elements we continue to drive and see the progression towards next several quarters as we told you.

"
column908:
"

And I think if I could -- just to be clear
column909: we talked about a 100 basis points and 12% to 14% return on tangible common equity
column910: obviously at 99 basis points we are bumping right up against that. And I think what\u2019s important is as you look to the past
column911: to what we have talked we are basically there in the second quarter you can say you have the $700 million in FAS 91 the 400 of loan sale gains and a couple of hundred million from rep and warrant provision but what I think is interesting and as you look at the past Eric
column912:
if you look at and assume the 100 basis point parallel shift in the yield curve what that would mean in the quarter as well as if we ultimately get to where our LAS expense goals are you basically back to all other things being equal where we were this quarter.

"
column913:
"

So what was articulated is something where you couldn\u2019t see a path or a way to get there. I think it was a step forward this quarter as far as seeing how we can get there.

"
column917:
"

And we will take our final question from Christopher Wheeler from Atlantic Equities. Your line is open.

"
column920: good morning gentlemen and I am sorry to raise the subject of cost again. But I just want to square away what you said I think to Betsy\u2019s question at the very beginning. So what you said at the conference back in May when you actually said that if the trading revenues didn\u2019t pick up you would have to adjust costs further. I just wondered where you were on that
column921: because obviously trading revenues were down about 2% year-on-year
column922:
I think in the quarter and I am having to assume that the start of the quarter has been pretty bumpy with Greece and China.

"
column923:
"

So could you just talk a little bit about how you see that
column924:
perhaps also talk a little bit about how you might address that situation in global markets and global banking in respect of the U.S. business and the international businesses because it is very clear that the U.S. business seems to be offering more opportunities not just because they are more buoyant but also because you\u2019re seeing European bank play a lesser role than obviously seeing three of the big banks getting new CEOs in the last few weeks. I hardly imagine they are going to be allocating more capital to investment banking? Thank you.

"
column926:
"

Let me take a stab at a couple of parts of that question. The first is and I think you referenced that what would you do if global market expenses were lower at a go-forward basis. I think this quarter was reflective of the way you\u2019d expect us to manage it which is the pure sales and trading number was down 2% and total expenses within the segment were down 5%. So I think some of what Brian communicated in May you saw evidence of that happening during the quarter.

"
column927:
"

The second thing that I would say is that it\u2019s obviously early in the quarter but I wouldn\u2019t draw any conclusions as to overall performance based on the volatility that we\u2019ve seen during the first couple of weeks to the negative. And then third
column928: I think your question was and is just that with what\u2019s going on within some of the European banks as well as changes in management and questions around capital
column929:
how does that translate and what are you seeing in the U.S. business. I think I\u2019d say is that we obviously have significant share in the U.S. business. We\u2019re looking to do a better job of that and I think that as you look at some of the loan growth that we\u2019ve seen that it\u2019s reflective of the fact that we\u2019re deepening in the U.S. but just as importantly that loan growth is not only in the U.S. its\u2019 throughout Europe. There\u2019s been a little bit in Latin America and there\u2019s been growth in Asia Pac.

"
column930:
"

So we are looking to use some of these market opportunities as a basis to deepen and look to grow the overall global banking segment.

"
column935:
"

Thank you everyone. That\u2019s the last question and we look forward to talk to you next quarter.

"
column937:
"

This does conclude today\u2019s program. You may now disconnect at any time.

"

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q3 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian T. Moynihan - Chairman and CEO

"
column12:
"

John McDonald - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column20:
"

Thomas LeTrent - FBR Capital Markets

"
column21:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities

"
column23:
"

Good day everyone and welcome to today's program. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later you will have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]. Please note this call is being recorded.

"
column24:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead sir.

"
column26:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone
column27: thanks on the webcast for joining us as well. Welcome to the third quarter results. Hopefully
column28:
everybody has had a chance to review the earnings release. It is only available on the Bank of America Investor Relations website.

"
column29:
"

So before I turn over the call to Brian
column30: let me just remind you we have a new CFO that will be going through the results this morning
column31: Mr. Paul Donofrio. And so
column32: we will -- we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those
column33:
please refer to either our earnings release documents on our website or our SEC filings.

"
column34:
"

So with that I will turn it over to Brian.

"
column35:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column36:
"

Thank you Lee
column37: and good morning everyone
column38: and thank you for joining us to review our third quarter results. Today
column39: we reported $4.5 billion in after tax earnings or $0.37 per diluted share. When we think about the quarter
column40: the key message is we continued to make good progress in a tough revenue environment due to low interest rates and a sluggish economic recovery. In addition with the late summer's volatility
column41:
especially the fixed income trading markets are remaining challenging. So with that we produced another good quarter of progress in all the businesses.

"
column42:
"

Before Paul takes you through the details of the quarter
column43: I want to provide a little context from my vantage point. We continued to make progress towards our full earnings capacity here at Bank of America
column44: and this quarter represents the fourth consecutive quarter of solid results following the resolution of our large legacy exposures in the third quarter of last year. When you think about it
column45: over the last four quarters we have reported over $16 billion in after-tax income. That compares to the previous four quarters leading us to the third quarter of 2014 of about 5.2 billion
column46:
including the significant litigation cost.

"
column47:
"

Returns over the last four quarters in aggregate generated an ROA of about 76 basis points and a 10% return on tangible common equity. This quarter
column48: we were able to keep the absolute level of our balance sheet flat to the second quarter. But by doing that
column49: we continued to replace discretionary assets with good core customer loans
column50: and we believe that is a very good trend. We continue to build record liquidity
column51:
and we believe we are well positioned against 2017 LCR requirements.

"
column52:
"

Our capital is again at record levels
column53: and we returned over $3 billion back to shareholders so far this year through common share repurchases and dividends. Our tangible book value per share improved this quarter to $15.50. It is the highest level in many
column54: many years. So
column55: I am going to spend a couple more minutes focusing on a few drivers in our business. Our teams here at Bank of America are focused on the everyday engagement with our customers
column56: deepening relationships by growing the core things we do with them
column57: deposits
column58: loans
column59: managing their risks
column60: helping them invest their assets
column61: all while keeping our cost down
column62: and you can see that in our results. When you think about our deposit franchise
column63: we grew $50 billion in deposits over the last year
column64:
on an all-organic basis. That in and of itself is a large bank.

"
column65:
"

As a reminder
column66: our consumer franchise is the largest retail bank in the United States. In our consumer banking business
column67: as you can see
column68: we grew revenue and earnings year-over-year despite the low interest rate environment. We have been restructuring our branch structure
column69: selling some branches
column70: closing some branches
column71: and changing account structures
column72: and with that this quarter our core consumer checking accounts continued to grow. We grew those accounts and improved the percentage of those customers who use us as a primary bank
column73:
and importantly the average balance per account continues to grow.

"
column74:
"

On cards
column75: on credit cards
column76: we issued another 1.3 million credit cards this quarter
column77: and active accounts continued to grow. The good news is we are doing it through the lowest cost possible through our core franchise much lower than other means of growth. When you go to the change in our financial services business for mobile and digital banking
column78: we now have 18.4 million active mobile customers and 31 million active online customers. Digital sales this quarter were up 30% over the last year. More customers are using mobile device to deposit checks and access their accounts
column79: and now are starting to buy products as well as book appointments. To get a sense of that
column80: we are now booking 15
column81:
000 appointments a week off of our mobile devices.

"
column82:
"

Our Merrill Lynch teammates who work within our consumer business helped push us through a new standard of 2 million accounts this quarter. When we go to our wealth management business
column83: this business is showing the effects of lower market valuations pressuring revenue
column84: but actively here has reflected good long term flows
column85: good deposit flows
column86: and good loan growth. In addition
column87: we continued to invest in long-term growth in this business. More advisors
column88: better products
column89: and better advice in building and preserving wealth for our clients
column90:
and these clients continue to use the full range of our products including banking products.

"
column91:
"

As we switch to our commercial banking business
column92: the business we call global banking
column93: loans to commercial and corporate clients around the globe grew nicely from last quarter and the year-ago quarter. And although investment banking fees were down year-over-year
column94:
the industry fee pools appeared to be down as much or more. We maintained our leadership across many of the products.

"
column95:
"

In our global markets business
column96: despite the challenging market conditions in the late August and September timeframe
column97: we reported $1 billion in after-tax earnings in that business. Excluding DDA impacts
column98:
this is the best third quarter in earnings for this business we have seen in recent memory.

"
column99:
"

Our net interest income in the company is benefiting from loan and deposit growth showing momentum this quarter after you exclude the impact of FAS 91. Focusing on expenses
column100: which we have talked to you much about
column101: we continue to hold our costs in check. Expense less litigation LAS costs remain well below the $13 billion threshold at $12.7 billion
column102:
and that was in line with our second quarter despite the additional costs of CCAR and additional investments in the business.

"
column103:
"

We are taking the benefits of our simplify and improve program
column104: which keeps our costs flat
column105: while we continue to invest in customer-facing client people to grow our businesses. This ability to invest in growth is key to driving our franchise forward. When you go to the risk side of the house
column106: credit risk remains very strong
column107: market risk remains subdued
column108:
and we get a great return on that VAR as you look at it across the competitors.

"
column109:
"

We continue to feel good about our legacy exposure risk
column110: and LAS business continues to work itself down. So
column111: in the context of the environment we faced
column112: we are operating what we feel is a solid quarter
column113: and as evidenced
column114: the continuing progress on our strategy
column115:
our strategy of responsible growth with our customs. With that let me hand it over to Paul.

"
column116:
"

Paul Donofrio

"
column117:
"

Thanks Brian
column118: good morning everybody. Starting on slide 3
column119: we present the summary of our income statement and returns for this quarter as well as Q2 and Q3 last year. As Brian said
column120: we earned $4.5 billion in the quarter compared to a loss of a couple hundred million dollars last year and earnings of $5.3 billion in Q2. Earnings per share this quarter were $0.37. Let me mention a few larger items that in aggregate benefited diluted EPS this quarter by a penny. First
column121: a negative $597 million market related NII adjustments
column122: primarily FAS 91
column123:
cost us about $0.03.

"
column124:
"

More than offsetting this was a $0.02 benefit from DVA of $313 million and a $0.02 benefit from a collective impact of three other items; gains from selling some consumer real estate loans
column125: tax benefits from restructuring some of the non-U.S. subsidiaries
column126: and a provision for payment protection insurance in the UK. Revenues were 20.9 billion this quarter
column127: expenses were 13.8 billion
column128: significantly lower than a year ago because of litigation costs and compared to Q2
column129: expenses were flat as we managed costs well
column130:
while investing in our franchise. Return on assets was 82 basis points this quarter and return on tangible common equity was 10%.

"
column131:
"

Turning to slide 4
column132: the balance sheet ended basically flat relative to Q2 with assets of 2.15 trillion. However
column133: we grew deposits 12 billion from Q2 while long-term debt declined by approximately 6 billion. Liquidity rose to nearly $500 billion
column134:
a record level and the time required for funding is now three and half years. Tangible common equity of 162 billion improved because of earnings supplemented by 1.5 billion in OTI. This was partially offset by 1.3 billion in capital return to common shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.

"
column135:
"

Tangible book value increased 10% from Q3 last year
column136: and our tangible common equity ratio grew to 7.8% as equity improvements outpaced asset growth. With regard to regulatory capital I want to start by pointing out that our transition ratios under Basel III increased with CET1 ending the quarter at 11.6%. However
column137: I will focus my comments on Basel III fully phased in regulatory capital ratios. CET1 capital improved 4.8 billion to 153 billion driven by net income
column138: positive OTI
column139:
and DTA utilization. This was partially offset by capital returned to shareholders.

"
column140:
"

Under the standardized approach
column141: our CET1 ratio improved to 10.8% as risk-weighted assets decreased modestly even as loans grew. Under the standardized approaches
column142: the CET1 ratio increased from 10.4% to 11% as RWA improved by roughly 30 billion
column143: largely due to reductions in risk. During the quarter
column144: we announced that we exited parallel loans
column145: and we will begin reporting under the advanced approaches beginning in 4Q. So
column146: we have also presented our CET1 ratio for 9/30 on a pro forma basis
column147: which includes the addition of approximately 170 billion in RWA primarily for wholesale credit under the advanced approaches. The pro forma CET1 ratio at 9/30 was 9.7%
column148: an increase of approximately 40 basis points from Q2 on the same pro forma basis. In terms of the supplementary leverage ratio
column149:
we estimate that as of 9/30 we continue to exceed U.S. rules applicable at the beginning of 2018 at both bank and parent.

"
column150:
"

Turning to slide 5
column151: we grew loans and deposits both of which are key drivers to our financial performance. We reported loans on an end of period basis increased 1.2 billion from Q2. However
column152: underneath the consolidated number there was significant activity I want to take a moment to point out. With that in mind
column153: let\u2019s review why loans in all other and LAS are declining. First
column154:
the portion of our mortgages that we report in all other continue to run off due to pay downs. This run off is being replaced by new loans which are now reported in business segments like GWIM and consumer where they are originated.

"
column155:
"

Second
column156: also in all other
column157: we converted 6.2 billion of mortgages with long-term standby agreements into securities thereby improving HQLA. These types of conversions are largely complete. Third
column158: we sold roughly 3.6 billion of other mortgages and NPLs as we continue to clean up and optimize the balance sheet. Lastly
column159: in LAS
column160: where we report our legacy home equity portfolio
column161: second lien loans continue to run off. Now
column162: if one excludes the above activities in LAS and all other
column163:
ending loans in our primary lending segments increased $19 billion or 3% from Q2.

"
column164:
"

Turning to deposits
column165: on an ending basis
column166: they reached 1.16 trillion this quarter
column167: growing 50 billion or 4% over Q3 last year. We produced solid growth across the franchise. Global banking grew deposits 6% year-over-year. GWIM grew 3%
column168: and consumer grew 7%. However
column169: as you can see at the bottom right
column170: if one includes CD run off
column171:
consumer deposits grew 10%. We have also included two other tables to give you a sense of the composition of our deposits.

"
column172:
"

Turning to quality on slide 6
column173: I won't spend a lot of time here as asset quality continued to be strong and mostly consistent with Q2. Net charge offs were flat around 930 million versus adjusted Q2
column174: Q3 provision expense of 806 million
column175:
and we released a net 126 million in reserves.

"
column176:
"

Releases in consumer real estate and credit cards were partially offset by reserve builds in commercial. In commercial
column177: we saw small increases in reserve over criticized exposure from Q2 driven by a downgrades in oil and gas that were partially offset by some improvements in the rest of the commercial portfolio. Also noteworthy
column178:
the increase in oil and gas reserve over criticized in Q3 was less than half the size of the increase from Q1 to Q2.

"
column179:
"

Turning to slide 7
column180: net interest income on a reported FTE basis was 9.7 billion
column181: declining 1 billion from Q2. The decline in long end rates in the quarter caused adjustments in our bond premium amortization
column182:
which resulted in a linked quarter decline in NII of 1.3 billion partially offset by good growth in NII otherwise. The Q2 adjustment increased NII by 669 million while the Q3 adjustment decreased NII by 597 million.

"
column183:
"

NII excluding these adjustments improved 292 million from Q2
column184: to 10.3 billion. Three factors drove this increase. First
column185: we grew core commercial loans. Second
column186: we improved the composition of the balance sheet and our global markets business which improved trading related NII. And third
column187: we benefited from one extra day in the quarter. With regard to asset sensitivity
column188: at the end of the third quarter our overall asset sensitivity increased as a result of the decline in long end rates
column189: which drove the FAS 91 adjustment. As of 9/30
column190:
an instantaneous 100 basis point parallel increase in rates is estimated to increase NII by approximately 4.5 billion over the subsequent year with a little more than half of that improvement caused by increases in short end rates.

"
column191:
"

Turning to slide 8
column192: non-interest expense was 13.8 billion in Q3
column193: matching the level of expense reported in Q2. The 20.1 billion expense in Q3 last year included 6 billion in litigation costs. Litigation this quarter and in Q2 was less than 250 million. Excluding litigation
column194: expenses were 13.6 billion in the quarter
column195:
a decline of 600 million or 4% from last year and consistent with Q2 despite additional costs related to our CCAR submission.

"
column196:
"

Headcount continues to trend lower
column197: down 6% compared to Q3 last year. LAS costs
column198: excluding litigation
column199: were relatively stable compared to Q2. However
column200: we still expect to lower that number to roughly 800 million in Q4 and move lower in 2016. As a reminder
column201: in the fourth quarter
column202:
we tend to experience some seasonal increase in expenses as we close out the year.

"
column203:
"

Let\u2019s walk through the business segments starting on slide 9 with consumer banking. Consumer earned 1.8 billion
column204: 5% greater than Q3 last year. The business segment generated strong 24% return on allocated capital. Revenue increased over last year as increases in non-interest income outpaced the decline in NII. With respect to NII compared to last year
column205:
the benefit of higher deposit levels was more than offset by the allocation of ALM activity and lower card yields [ph].

"
column206:
"

Non-interest income benefited from divestiture gains as well as higher card income driven by increased customer activity while service charges declined. Expenses declined from Q3 last year despite a 5% increase in sales specialist and higher fraud costs in advance of ruling changes regarding EMV chip implementation. Those increases were offset by savings from the continued optimization of our delivery network. The cost of operating our deposit franchise remains low at 180 basis points
column207:
and the consumer bank reported an efficiency ratio of 57%.

"
column208:
"

We continue to experience shifts in consumer activity away from branches towards self-service options. Self-service trends are driven by mobile banking
column209: online banking
column210:
and ATM usage. Mobile banking customers increased to 18.4 million and deposits via mobile devices now represent 14% of consumer deposit transactions. Mobile processing is better for us and it is better for our customers. It is one-tenth the cost relative to processing of financial centers and more convenient for customers.

"
column211:
"

On slide 10
column212: we present key drivers and trends. Average loans grew across mortgages
column213: card
column214: and vehicle lending. Deposits
column215: as Brian mentioned
column216: continued to increase particularly if one excludes the impact of CD declining. On this basis
column217: deposits were up 10% from the year ago. Regarding brokerage assets
column218: Merrill Lynch accounts crossed the 2 million mark and are up 2%
column219: while asset levels are up 8% from last year even with declines in equity markets this year. Mortgage production
column220: although up from 3Q last year
column221:
was down from 2Q as refinances declined.

"
column222:
"

In the future
column223: mortgage banking income in the consumer segment will be lower by approximately $30 million per quarter given the Q3 sale of a small appraisal business. A similar amount of expense should reduce quarterly as well. Looking at our card activity
column224: card issuance was strong at 1.3 million. Combined credit and debit spending volumes were up 3% from last year despite the decline in fuel prices. Average outstandings were down slightly from Q3 last year as customers paid off more of their balances. However
column225:
average balances showed modest growth over Q2.

"
column226:
"

U.S. card credit volume was strong as net charge offs declined this quarter to a decade low of 2.5% driving risk-adjusted margins higher to 9.3% excluding divestitures. Turning to service charges
column227:
they were down moderately versus Q2 last year -- Q3 last year as we continued to open higher quality accounts that carry higher balances. These higher quality accounts tend to have fewer account fees.

"
column228:
"

Turning to slide 11
column229: global wealth and investment management produced earnings of $656 million. Results were down from Q3 last year driven by lower market values and lower [indiscernible] client activity. Compared to Q3 last year
column230: asset management fees were up 2% but more than offset by declines in transactional revenues. The trend of lower transactional revenues continued this quarter as clients migrated from brokerage to managed relationships which was compounded by lower markets and muted new issuance. On NII
column231:
the benefits of higher loan and deposit flows was more than offset by the company's ALM activities driving NII down from Q3 last year.

"
column232:
"

Non-interest expense was modestly higher than the year ago period as litigation costs were higher and wealth advisors grew 6%. Pre-tax margin was 23%
column233: down from a strong Q3 last year. Margins were pressured this quarter by a few factors. First
column234: markets declined pressuring revenue across many products especially those in which we record transactional revenues. Second
column235:
operating leverage was challenged as areas of revenue where incentives are high like asset management grew while NII where incentives are much lower declined.

"
column236:
"

Moving to slide 12

column248: generating a 14% return on allocated capital. Earnings declined from Q3 last year but were up modestly versus Q2. The comparison to Q3 last year reflects higher provision expense and lower NII driven by the company\u2019s ALM activities as well as increased liquidity costs. Additionally
column249: we saw year-over-year compression in loans spread; however
column250: loan growth was a positive contributor to NII. Growth from Q2 reflects improved NII from loan and deposit growth. Regarding provision expense while flat to Q2
column251:
it is up 243 million from last year. We added 125 million to reserves in Q3 compared to a release of 116 million in the year ago quarter.

column252:

column254: we maintained our number three global fee position and believe we increased our market share as industry fees pools declined. Investment banking fees for the company this quarter were 1.3 billion
column255: down 5% from Q3 last year. Advisory fees were up 24%. Debt underwriting was down modestly
column256: equity underwriting was down from Q3 last year
column257:
in line with industry volume declines.

"
column258:
"

Outside of IB

column261:
the decline in spreads year-over-year flattened as the decline from Q2 was relatively small.

column262:

column263:
"

Switching to global markets on slide 15
column264: earnings were $1 billion on revenue of $4.1 billion despite challenging markets. We generated 11% return this quarter. Earnings were up from Q3 last year which included litigation cost of roughly $600 million most of which was non-deductible for tax purposes. As you can see
column265: we had a net DVA gain this quarter which was higher than last year. Total revenues excluding net DVA declined from Q3 last year driven by lower fixed sales and trading and to a lesser extent IBCs
column266: offset partially by improved equity sales and trading. Non-interest expense excluding litigation improved a $102 million versus Q3 last year
column267:
up 4% improvement.

"
column268:
"

column269: fixed sales and trading revenue declined 11%. Similar to the first half of this year the year-over-year comparisons reflect good activity and macro related products like rates and after tax. Conversely
column270:
market activity remained muted in credit products driving lower client activity this quarter than Q3 last year.

"
column271:
"

As a reminder
column272:
our mix remains more heavily weighted towards credit products driven by the strength of our new issues capability and market share. Equity rose 12% driven by strong performance in equity derivatives reflecting favorable market conditions. Asset levels were down modestly from Q3 last year.

column273:

Turning to legacy asset servicing on slide 17

column275: mortgage banking income
column276: and expenses and compare each to Q2. First
column277:
the number of delinquency for mortgage loans continued to decline down 14% this quarter as the teams continued to work through solutions for customers.

"
column278:
"

Second
column279: mortgage banking income declined by more than $400 million. This decline was driven primarily by three factors
column280:
servicing fees declined about $50 million as the units we serviced declined. Net MSR and hedge performance declined a $100 million driven by gains on MSR sales in Q2. Reps and warranty provisions swung nearly $300 million from a benefit of $204 million in Q2 to a provision of $77 million this quarter.

"
column281:
"

Lastly
column282:
I want to focus on expenses which excluding litigation were flat compared to Q2 as increased professional fees offset improved operating cost from the decline in delinquent loans. We believe we were on-track to achieve our goal of reducing expenses excluding litigation to approximately $800 million in Q4.

"
column283:
"

On slide 18
column284: we show all other which primarily includes our ALM actions and the operations of our UK card business and other smaller activities. While other reported a $503 million pretax loss
column285:
more than offset by certain tax benefits. The pretax loss was a result of a negative NII market related adjustments and an increase in provisioning for UK credit card payment protection insurance. This was partially offset by gains from securities and loan sales.

"
column286:
"

Regarding the change in PPI liability
column287:
we increased it because of a notice of future regulatory guidance regarding treatments of claims and a case ruling.

"
column288:
"

A comment or two on taxes before we wrap up. The Company's effective tax rate for the quarter was 26%. It was lower than Q2 due to the tax benefits I mentioned earlier. I will expect the tax rate to be roughly 30% next quarter excluding unusual items and specifically the UK
column289:
the recent UK tax proposals.

"
column290:
"

In terms of 2016
column291:
I would expect it to be in the low 30s. As a reminder from last quarter's announcement we expect that the UK tax proposal announced in July will result in a one-time tax charge of approximately $300 million upon enactment from revaluing our UK DTAs.

"
column292:
"

Let me conclude our prepared comments by offering these takeaways. Although the U.S. economy is improving slowly
column293: revenue growth remains challenging in this interest rate environment. We are focused on those things we can control and drive
column294:
these includes delivering for our clients and customers within our risk framework and driving those things we know will result in sustainable profits and returns.

"
column295:
"

Our results reflect this focus. We grew both loans and deposits across our business. We delivered to our corporate institutional clients in a challenging market environment. We stayed focused on managing risk and we kept cost in check while investing in the business. We are getting better positioned each quarter for the current business environment and we remain well positioned to benefit when rates rise. With that let's open it up to Q&A.

column520:
"

Okay

Brian T. Moynihan

I\u2019ll let Paul hit that but in terms of the \u2013 but just want to make sure you are talking about trading or investment banking fees or both?

Both?

Brian T. Moynihan

Paul.

On the other hand we do have a strong FICC business that\u2019s tied into issuance and the new issuance market in the third quarter wasn\u2019t as strong so some of the flows just weren\u2019t there.

column592: where are the lending officers now in terms of like using the excess capacity to continue to grow the balance sheet
column593:
is there still room from the BofA supply side to extend that growth on top of what the economy and the marketplace is giving you broadly?

column594:
"

Brian T. Moynihan

column596: I think
column597: so if you look at the different segments
column598: if you think about on the consumer side using \u2013 it\u2019s more sales force growth and effectiveness in building that team. And then also the digital sales coming up whether it is auto
column599: whether its credit cards are up dramatically. So think of that engine as being both people and a machine for lack of better term. But don\u2019t think of it as changing credit quality or taking any kind of more risk
column600:
so Tom and Dean that run that business for us has done a good job and so I\u2019d say the supply has been more from a delivery capacity than it is from an expanding the box or anything like that. We really kept it to where we want it and we think that holds us in good stead as you think through all the different dynamics on company.

"
column601:
"

When you go to the commercial side it is simply couple of things and a very small business which is reported in consumer we have actually seen that business stabilize and start to make its way out of runoff position and that\u2019s again more automated scored approach
column602: we sped up approval times and done a lot of work to make ourselves more competitive
column603: more on delivery than credit. But if you go on business banking
column604: commercial banking
column605: and global corporate investment banking segment
column607: [Indiscernible] the team they\u2019ve actually hired over a 100 people
column608: loan officers this year. So they could add 10% to 15% growth on loan officers. Got them hired and they are working
column609: it takes time for them to get up to speed. [Alistair] [ph] looking at our middle market business. I think there\u2019s about 60 this year something like that
column610:
70 people delivering and running products and things behind that also is treasury services people.

"
column611:
"

So again capacity expansion in the global corp investment bank work differently. As we look at middle market I think that is scenario where we are
column612: we used to think if we are going to take 10 let\u2019s only take 8
column613: that\u2019s better. We are now telling our teams
column614: we need to understand why you are not taking 10 if that\u2019s our whole limit and our capacity in a given transactions as example and they are doing that. So I think we are probably creating a little more not risk rating type of supply but just take a little bit more loans because we are twice the equity we used to be. And therefore we can absorb it and the team does a great job in credit quality there. So I\u2019d say if you look at across the board
column615:
consumer is more delivery capacity and commercial it\u2019s more both delivery capacity and then as you cite take a little more risk in terms of dollar denomination but not in terms of [Indiscernible] credit quality.

column616:
"

Ken Usdin

"

Okay

column641: this as just putting it all - you put the loans on in the commercial side especially be changed. So
column642:
we\u2019ll get to that when we get to that but it hasn\u2019t been clarified what the rule is; lots of people commented on it and it would be a one-time thing and as you say somewhere out in 18 is what people currently think.

column643:
"

Nancy Bush

column644:
"

Okay

Can you just comment on this inflection point issue and when you think we will get there?

column647:

Paul Donofrio

We\u2019re still seeing reserve releases on the consumer side of the bank that is certainly starting to moderate. that is some place in 2016.

column653:
"

We expect that to probably mitigate and then if you get loan reserve you\u2019ll build reserves at some point but I think that is still a bit out there.

column654:
"

Nancy Bush

"
column655:
"

So sometime in 2016
column656:
probably?

column657:

Brian T. Moynihan

"
column658:
"

It depends on what the loan growth is
column659: it depends on the economic scenario. But I think it\u2019s -- we\u2019re still repositioning reserves on the consumer side that are excess
column660:
as we can see in the credit statistics. We\u2019re carrying a healthy reserve for areas that have continued to come down in terms of risk.

column661:
"

Nancy Bush

column662:
"

Okay

thank you.

Thomas LeTrent

Okay

Thomas LeTrent

"

Okay

thank you.

Michael Mayo

Paul Donofrio

400 million.

should we assume that repeats or this is kind of a one off?

Brian T. Moynihan

Mike

it\u2019s in the puts and takes we put on the first slide there.

column716: that is fine. Higher rates

The FAS91 is really the major difference.

Michael Mayo

And then lastly

column731: as you are new on the job as CFO what changes might you want to make and Paul or Brian if rates don\u2019t go up for a lot longer than you expected

what is your Plan B to deal with the tougher environment?

column734:

So

And so we announced that and Paul became CFO. There is nothing new to add. In terms of what we do in the environment
column736: as we have said a lot of times to earlier questions

column738: severance and everything and we will continue to work at it. If the environment changed and we didn\u2019t think we\u2019re getting returns from that

we would reduce the investment rate.

"
column741:
"

Michael Mayo

"

"

And Paul philosophy on being CFO

any changes with your predecessor?

Paul Donofrio

I think it is a little early for me to have developed a plan in terms of radical change. We have -- Bruce did a tremendous job of cleaning up the balance sheet and positioning our company for growth. He -- we have got a great team that he built and I am getting to know all that and we will see how it goes.

"
column746:
"

Michael Mayo

Alright
