column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q4 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column2:
"

Q4 2015 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

"
column9:
"

Paul Donofrio - Chief Financial Officer

"
column14:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets & Co.

"
column26:
and welcome to today's Bank of America earnings announcement. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later you will have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this call may be recorded. I'll be standing by if you should need any assistance.

"
column27:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire.

"
column29:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone
column30: thanks for those that are joining us on the webcast as well. Welcome to the fourth quarter earnings results presentation. Hopefully
column31:
everyone has had a chance to review the earnings that we released. It is available on the Bank of America Investor Relations website.

"
column32:
"

And so before I turn over the call over to Brian and Paul
column33: let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information of those
column34:
please refer to either our earnings release documents on our website or our SEC filings.

"
column35:
"

So with that
column36: I will turn it over to our CEO
column37:
Brian Moynihan.

"
column40: Lee
column41: and good morning. Thanks to all of you for joining us this morning to discuss our fourth quarter results. Before Paul Donofrio takes you through the details of the quarter
column42:
I just want to provide some overall context on our progress in 2015 and the opportunities and challenges ahead.

"
column43:
"

As you know
column44: for the fourth quarter
column45: we reported $3.3 billion in earnings or $0.28 per diluted share. For 2015 we had net income of $15.9 billion
column46:
that's the highest net income we've had in a long time. Full year return metrics were 74 basis points for ROA and 9% for return on tangible common equity.

"
column47:
"

During 2015 we continued to drive our 8 lines of business forward. We've focused on driving responsible growth across all our businesses and as you look at the annual earnings of the company and see how they fell
column48:
you can see how they came through.

"
column49:
"

Our consumer and wealth management businesses serving mass market customers all the way to the wealthiest Americans delivered $9.3 billion in net income this year. Our Global Banking business which provides services to small
column50: medium and large companies around the world
column51:
produced $5.3 billion in net income this year.

"
column52:
"

Within our institutional investor clients our markets business with its market leading research capabilities and the top tier platform across the globe delivered $3 billion in earnings after adjusting for DVA in a very challenging market.

"
column53:
"

What's clear in these earnings despite the gyrations of markets especially at the end of the year last year is annuity nature that we get from our franchise by driving customer and client flows. That's the power of our company
column54:
it\u2019s balancing the scope and a strong customer base and we aim to continue to improve it every day for our clients and customers and our shareholders. These results reflect the work we've done over the past several years to develop a more straightforward and simplified operating model and focus on responsible growth.

"
column55:
"

As you see on slide 2
column56: across the variety of measures
column57: loan growth business activity
column58: capital liquidity
column59: credit losses and cost management
column60:
we've made meaningful progress and believe we are positioned for a variety of economic cycles. At the foundation of all this is a strong capital and liquidity base. We added to our record liquidity levels in 2015 and we believe we are well positioned against the 2017 LCR requirements with total global excess liquidity sources now at over $500 billion. This amount represents nearly a quarter of our balance sheet and we now have enough [indiscernible] liquidity to last more than three years before we need to tap the market for funding.

"
column61:
"

Now our liquidity levels were driven by strong growth in deposits this year and we were able to put that funding to work to grow loans on an absolute basis for the first time in several years. Loan growth was all driven by organic activity and is consistent with our risk posture.

"
column62:
"

Our tangible common equity of $162 billion is at record levels as well. We returned $4.5 billion to shareholders this year in common dividends and share repurchases. Our tangible book value per share improved 8% in the past 12 months to a new high of $15.62. Our responsible lending focus also shows in our underwriting results. Our net charge-offs were down just $4.3 billion this year
column63:
consistent with 2014 but much lower than previous years.

"
column64:
"

Commercial charge-offs increased off a very low base mostly from oil related charge-offs while consumer losses as a core continued to improve. This reflects further responsible underwriting as continued improvement in our legacy portfolios.

"
column65:
"

And finally we get to the cost management side. At the heart of our work has been improving expenses which you can see are down sequentially from last year mostly on lower litigation costs
column66:
but also on improved LAS and other operating costs and these have improved steadily across the last several years.

"
column67:
"

We began new a BAC in 2011 and completed it in 2014. Since then we have been using our Simplify and Improve initiatives to find savings that more than offset increased compliance
column68:
merit and other inflationary costs. But most importantly those savings fund investments in our business whether it is in technology or sales force growth or other infrastructure costs.

"
column69:
"

As we move to slide 3
column70: we included a few examples of trends
column71: business activity in our consumer side of the house and wealth management side of the house. As you can see
column72:
we grew average deposits in consumer banking and wealth management business is $52 billion or 7% comparing year-over-year fourth quarter periods. These deposits were up over $105 billion in core deposits at the end of 2012.

"
column73:
"

This strong organic growth is the result of hard work in improving the customer satisfaction in our franchise by making it easier for customers to do business with [indiscernible] and strong product management simplifying the product set. All this has been done
column74: where we've optimized our delivery networks
column75: reducing our financial standards
column76:
divesting certain markets and also expanding our award winning mobile capabilities in the customer base that uses that.

column77:
"

As you can see this work also extends to our wealth management business. We had long-term net flows every quarter for six and a half years in wealth management. We have record loan levels and significant higher deposit levels
column78: good products and [advisers] [ph]
column79:
a growing sales force and two of the leading brands in business positions us well here..

"
column80:
"

Let me move to our global banking markets area. You can see on the institutional side of the [house] [ph] that\u2019s set out forth on slide 4
column81:
we saw solid activity in 2015. Loans to commercial and corporate clients around the globe are growing nicely. Client demand has been good and our bankers have met our challenge to capture market share responsibly. This focus allows us to demonstrate a strong 12% growth in loans through global banking in the past 12 months and you can see the deposit growth has been strong here in the last year as well.

"
column82:
"

If you look at the markets business Tom Montag and team have done a good job of reducing assets and lowered the risk and still are generating relatively stable revenues. Despite the recent market challenges we remained quite profitable in this business and well positioned around the globe with both a strong [FICC] [ph] and equity platform.

"
column83:
"

As we step back we remain focused on our core customer strategy. We will continue to invest in the future and even as we continue to address the legacy issues of the past. We've been able to grow even as operating and economic environment remains in a low growth mode. Our model is solid but there is still plenty of work to do
column84:
but also there is plenty of opportunity ahead for us.

"
column85:
"

Overall I am pleased with the progress made in 2015 and we have more to do in 2016. In 2016 you should expect us to continue to focus on responsible growth. We will continue to drive the investments made in our franchise to deliver the value to you the shareholders. We will continue our sharp focus on risk management and we will continue our cost discipline as we look to continue to improve return on capital \u2013 capital metrics of our company.

up 12% versus a year ago.

column97:
"

column98:

We also provide returns and a few other metrics on this page

Lastly

column103:
"

Turning to slide 6 and focusing on the balance sheet
column104:
we grew deposits by $35 billion from Q3 and we used these increased deposits to fund responsible loan growth. In total assets climbed $9 million as increases in loans and security balances of $30 billion were more than offset by reductions in trading related assets and cash.

Liquidity rose to just over $500 billion
column106: a record level

column108:
another new record high.

column111:
CET1 capital improved modestly to $154.1 billion under the advanced approaches compared to Q3 2015 pro forma estimates the CET1 ratio increased slightly to 9.8%. RWA was essentially flat as growth from commercial exposures was mostly offset by lower activity and balance sheet levels in our global markets segment.

"
column112:
"

We also provide our capital metrics under the standardized approach. Here our CET1 ratio was flat at 10.8% with modest improvements in capital offset by modest increase in RWA. In terms of the supplementary leverage ratios we estimate that as of 12/31 we continue to exceed U.S. rules applicable beginning in 2018 at both the parent and bank.

column113:
"

Turning to slide 7
column114:
we had strong loan and deposit growth this quarter. Reported loans on an end of period basis increased $15 billion from Q3. This is the third consecutive quarter of recorded increases in total loan balances. We continue to see solid loan demand in our primary lending businesses partially offset by runoff in LAS and all other.

"
column115:
"

Excluding declines in LAS and all other
column116:
ending loans in our primary lending segments increased $22 billion from Q3. $8 billion of this increase was in consumer loans as GWIM increased mortgages and security based lending. Consumer banking also saw good loan growth in mortgages as well as vehicle loans.

"
column117:
"

We also had some seasonal growth in credit card partially offset by selling $1.7 billion of card receivables at the end of the quarter. Commercial loans grew $15 billion spread across multiple industry groups.

column118:
"

Turning to deposits
column119:
on many basis they reached nearly $1.2 trillion this quarter growing $78 billion or 7% in Q4 2014. Growth was solid across the franchise. Consumer led the way growing 9% year-over-year while global banking and GWIM each grew at 6% pace.

"
column120:
"

Turning to asset quality on slide 8
column121: while still strong we did see net charge-offs increase modestly from recent levels. Total net charge-offs increased $212 million versus Q3
column122: $144 million was from consumer items previously reserved for and lower recoveries on the sale of NPL in the fourth quarter versus Q3. We also saw a $73 million increase in net charge-offs from our energy portfolio. Outside of these two areas
column123:
net charge-offs were stable compared to Q3.

"
column124:
"

Provision of $110 million in Q4 was relatively flat with Q3. Reserve releases in consumer real estate and credit card were partially offset by reserve builds in commercial which was driven by increase in criticized exposures as well as loan growth. Reserve releases excluding the previously reserved items I mentioned earlier were roughly $200 million.

"
column125:
"

On slide 9 we provide credit quality data on our consumer portfolio. Net charge-offs increased $137 million. The two items of note that make up this increase were reserved for in prior periods and did not impact the provision expense in the quarter. $119 million was the result of collateral valuation adjustments. In addition
column126:
we had some small charge-offs associated with our 2014 DOJ settlement. We expect to complete our commitments under this settlement in the first half of 2016.

"
column127:
"

Adjusting for these two items
column128:
consumer net charge-offs were relatively flat versus Q3. Delinquency levels and NPLs continue to decline and reserve coverage remained strong.

"
column129:
"

Moving to our commercial side
column130: on slide 10
column131: net charge-offs increased $75 million primarily from losses in our energy portfolio. Outside of the energy portfolio
column132: commercial losses remained very low. Given the focus on the impacts of low oil prices on companies in the energy sector
column133:
we want to spend a minute to describe our energy portfolio and provide some perspectives.

"
column134:
"

The pie chart break down our $21 billion utilized exposure to the energy sector. This represents a little more than 2% of our total loan balances. Within that $21 billion $8.3 billion or less than 1% of the total loans is loans to borrowers in two subsectors
column135:
Exploration and Production as well as Oil Field Services. We consider these two subsectors to have significantly higher risk than the rest of the energy portfolio.

"
column136:
"

Of our $8.3 billion utilized exposure to these two higher risk subsectors $2.9 billion has already been downgraded to criticized. So 35% of the higher risk subsectors has already been downgraded to reservable criticized exposure thereby driving a portion of the reserves. And allowances for loan losses for the entire energy portfolio is approximately $500 million or 6% of the funded exposure of these two subsectors.

"
column137:
"

The company in the vertically integrated subsector represents $5.8 billion of the energy portfolio. We believe this subsector has a better ability to withstand lower oil prices. Nearly 100% of the companies have a market capital of $10 billion or more or they are sovereign owned and the average company has a market cap greater than $60 billion. We believe the remaining exposure in Refining and Marketing as well as other is also less dependent on oil prices.

"
column138:
"

As part of our standard risk management process
column139: we stress test our credit portfolios including our energy portfolio. Our stress analysis of the energy portfolio includes various sustained low oil prices over extended periods. As an example
column140:
if we held oil prices at $30 per barrel for nine quarters we estimate our potential losses on the energy portfolio would be roughly $700 million.

"
column141:
"

In energy and across our commercial sector
column142:
we continue to support clients while managing lending limits and actively engaging with stressed borrowers. Before moving from asset quality I want to refocus on total provision expense and how one should think about it over the next couple of quarters. As we continue to assess and react to future changes in the energy sector we could see lumpiness that could potentially drive provision expense over $900 million.

"
column143:
"

Turning to net interest income on slide 11
column144: on an FTE basis NII was $10 billion increasing roughly $300 million from Q3. NII included a negative $612 million charge associated with three trust preferred securities. These securities were scheduled to be completely phased out of tier 2 capital as of January 01
column145:
and with 7% to 8% coupons became expensive debt. NII also included a $150 million of positive market related adjustments to the amortization of bond premiums under FAS 91.

"
column146:
"

NII excluding market related adjustments and the charge on the trust preferred improved $188 million from Q3 to $10.5 billion. This improvement was driven by increased deposit balances which we used to fund growth in loans and securities.

"
column147:
"

As we move into the first quarter
column148: please note the following: first
column149: we will have one less day of interest. Second
column150: recent changes by Congress will lower the amount of dividends we receive from the FRB by approximately $50 million a quarter. Having said that
column151:
if the forward curve is realized and if we have some modest deposit and loan growth we still expect to show some growth in NII in Q1 2016 relative to our adjusted NII of $10.5 billion.

"
column152:
"

With regards to asset sensitivity
column153:
at the end of the fourth quarter our overall asset sensitivity decreased slightly as a result of increases in long-end rates as well as security balances. As of 12/31 an instantaneous 100 basis points parallel increase in rates is estimated to increase NII by approximately $4.3 billion over the subsequent year. Although more than half of that improvement comes from the increases in short-end rates and a little less than one quarter of the benefit comes from market related adjustments.

"

"

column156: $300 million lower than Q4 2014. This was driven by good expense discipline across the company. Litigation expense was a little higher this quarter at $428 million exhibiting some lumpiness as we work to resolve legacy issues. Keep in mind that annual litigation expense decreased from $16.4 billion in 2014 to $1.2 billion in 2015. Legacy asset servicing cost excluding litigation finished Q4 a little better than our targets of $800 million. As we have said
column157:
our net goal is $500 million per quarter.

column158:
"

Expenses excluding litigation and LAS were $12.6 billion and represents the fifth quarter out of the past six below $12.8 billion. We continue to look for ways to streamline and simplify how we do business. This is important because it allows us to invest in growth while maintaining relatively flat core expenses and a sluggish revenue environment. And importantly this relevant flatness continued even as we invested in additional sales professionals and improved technologies.

column159:
"

this would also increase incentives and other associated costs.

column165:
9% greater than Q4 last year. These results reflect good operating leverage on increased customer activities. The segment generated a strong 25% return on allocated capital. Revenue of $7.8 billion was up modestly from Q4 2014.

The cost of operating deposit franchise remains low at 177 basis points. Operating leverage drove improvements in the efficiency ratio of 56% as we continue to experience shifts in customer activity away from branches towards self-serve options.

column168:
"

column172:
"

column179:

column181:
000 recently. We expect these adoption trends to play an increasing role in future performance in customer satisfaction as we continue to advance online and mobile capabilities.

"

Turning to slide 15

global wealth and investment management produced earnings of $614 million. Results were down from Q4 last year driven by lower transactional revenue and the impact of the market decline on asset management fees.

column187:
2014. Beginning in the first quarter of 2016 we will benefit from lower expense resulting from the completion of amortizations related to advisor retention awards given at the time of the Merrill Lynch merger.

column196: 2014 while expense declined modestly. Driven by higher loan balances NII improved despite spread compression and the allocation of the company\u2019s ALM activities including higher liquidity costs. Non-interest income benefited from higher treasury services revenue

partially offset by lower IB fees.

column205:

column208:
2014 on a similarly adjusted basis. Note that our net DVA loss this quarter was $198 million and compared to a loss of $626 million in Q4 2014 which included an initial FVA adjustment.

sales and trading revenue are up $2.6 billion excluding net DVA was up 11.5% in Q4 of 2014. Compared to Q4 last year FICC sales and trading of $1.8 billion improved 20% reflecting improvements across most products notably in rates and credit related products. Equity trading of $822 million declined 3% reflecting lower client activity. Average trading related asset levels were down 9% in Q4 2014 while VAR was down 14%.

Turning to legacy assets and servicing on slide 21

column216:
revenue warranty provisioning improved $237 million to provision of $9 million this quarter. That favorability was offset by a decline in servicing fees of $108 million as the units service declined as well as a decline in net MSR hedge performance of $152 million.

column217:
"

Next the number of first mortgage loans that we serviced that are 60 day delinquent continued to decline and are now at 103
column218: 000 units. And last
column219:
the team did an excellent job lowering expenses. Excluding litigation we achieved our goal of $800 million moving costs down $309 million or 28%.

column220:

On slide 22

we show all other which reported a loss of $289 million. This was an improvement of $86 million from Q4 2014. This loss was driven by $612 million pretax charge associated with our trust preferred as well as the impact on the UK tax law changes. This was partially offset by gains on debt security sales as well as reserved leases on consumer real estate loans booked in all other.

column222:
"

[Audit Start]A comment or two on taxes before wrapping up. The Company\u2019s effective tax rate for the quarter excluding the UK tax charge was 25% reflecting reoccurring tax benefits plus a few small one-off benefits. We would expect the tax rate to be in the low 30s for 2016 excluding unusual items.

"
column223:
"

Before closing
column224:
I want to cover our early adoption of DVA accounting in more detail. In January of this year the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued an update to allow early adoption of a new rule regarding recognition of DVA on financial liabilities from changes in our own credit spreads.

"
column225:
"

The update means that these types of debit valuation adjustments will now flow through OCI instead of the income statement. We believe this change makes our earnings comparison more meaningful and easier to understand
column226:
therefore we adopted early. We restated all periods this year per FASB rules and those numbers are contained in the supplemental package.

"
column227:
"

This had no impact on capital as it moved on between retained earnings in the OCI but it did impact revenue
column228: earnings
column229: taxes and EPS in the first three quarters of 2015. The changes reduced previously reported EPS by approximately $0.02 each in Q1
column230:
Q2 and Q3. This accounting standard adoption did not impact DVA on derivatives which continued to flow through trading account profits .

"
column231:
"

Okay let me conclude by offering a few takeaways. Although the U.S. economy is improving slowly
column232:
revenue growth remains challenging. This quarter we continued our progress on those things we can control and drive. These include delivering for clients and customers within our risk framework and driving client and customer activity that will result in sustainable profits and returns. Our results reflect this focus.

"
column233:
"

We maintained a strong foundation of capital and liquidity. We grew loans
column234: deposits and investment flows. We continue to invest in our franchise by adding sales professionals and improved technology. Our strength
column235: global capability and experience allowed us to deliver for clients in a challenging market environment and we did all of this while closely managing expenses. With that
column236:
we\u2019ll open it up for Q&A.

column636: I feel like we got the time to do that. We're certainly not going to need to take all that time. We would expect to get there soon
column637: but it is impacted changes in rates
column639: we are returning
column640: we are hopefully returning capital
column641:
but we\u2019re not - we feel like we\u2019re on track to get to 10% plus an appropriate buffer there.

"
column642:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column643:
"

And the only other thing I would add is
column644: we still have some opportunities to optimize RWA from an advanced perspective
column645: that\u2019s in two fundamental areas. It\u2019s always tough. You can do in markets and other areas
column646: but in two fundamental areas
column647: one is the extra RWA we got on the wholesale side when we exited parallel run
column648:
that is not a permanent thing. We need to work on \u2013 work with our regulators and hopefully over time we can make some improvements there.

"
column649:
"

The other one is operational risk
column650: we have $500 billion of RWA operations with some of the advanced approach. That is 25% more net higher to bank and that operational risk is for businesses that we are no longer in it with products we no longer sell
column651: it\u2019s for a risk profile that we no longer tolerate. So again that will take time
column652:
but that is another opportunity for us to lower RWA through an advanced perspective.

"
column653:
"

Eric Wasserstrom

"
column654:
"

Thanks and if I can just sneak in one more
column655:
and when you talk about an appropriate buffer are you thinking in method one or method two as a baseline?

column656:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column657:
"

I think a buffer to the capital
column658: we\u2019re thinking we\u2019re basically thinking we need to be above the 10%
column659:
we would say 25 to 50 basis points would be where --

column660:
"

Eric Wasserstrom

column661:

Got it. Okay
column662:
thanks very much.

Ken Usdin

Brian Moynihan

column679:

column682:

Ken Usdin

column683:

Yep

Brian Moynihan

Well

column695:
but it is going to come through [indiscernible] on a more annualized basis.

column696:

Ken Usdin

column698:

Paul Donofrio

column699:
"

From a broader -- leave aside the fees because of the geography and how the accounting works and when you put 60%

column702: we continue to have lots of opportunities with our core customers setting out and still that are creditworthy in our customer base
column703: we are still getting to move it elsewhere and that is what the team is chipping away. And it is never going to be the hugest business of Bank of America compared to things like the Merrill Lynch business consumer
column704: the credit card business in consumer

but we expect to get broader market share from each of the segments.

column706:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column708: I think it is interesting

column711: and we see progress
column712:
we see the prime loans growing.

column713:
"

Ken Usdin

Brian Foran

is there any update you can give us on how the first wave of HELOC recasts or switches to amortization schedules have performed versus what you had modeled?

column746:
and this portfolio continues to improve as home prices improve. The risk is an ongoing part of our reserve process and we think we\u2019re all reserved.

column747:

Brian Foran

"

Brian Moynihan

we just have a little more clean up because of the legacy portfolio in there.

"

Operator

column759:
"

column760:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column761:
"

Brennan?

Operator

column763:
"

column765:
"

Hi
column766: I have one question for Paul
column768: lower energy prices you said can help certain segments such as consumers. Can you give any examples of that and also on the energy topic

column770:
I didn\u2019t understand the answer from before?

Paul Donofrio

column772:
"

Well
column773: let me take the last one first
column774: so we\u2019ve got a reserve on our energy portfolio of $500 million. That is 6% of those two filled factors that we can call high risk and we have done modeling
column775: stress test modeling at various oil prices. The one we have been talking about on this call has been at $30
column777: and so if oil stays at $30 for nine quarters
column778: we would think that our losses over those nine quarters would be $700 million. Again that will go against the $500 we already have reserved
column779:
and one would presume we're building reserves during that time period to make up the difference.

"
column780:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column781:
"

So Mike when you look at consumer benefits from the oil and gas

column783: if you look at our card base in the fourth quarter of '15
column784: the spending on debit
column785: credit cards rose 4% from the fourth quarter of '14
column786: and if gas prices would have been stable
column787: they would have grown at 5.7%. And so what that means is consumers had effectively on that base of 1.7% to-date received the benefit of year-over-year. If you translate that to dollars
column788:
round numbers as $20 million a day is less spending on gasoline by our consumers in our portfolios per day.

"
column789:
"

And from like $90 million down to $70-ish million or something like that
column790: that is the benefit they get
column791: and so for a large number of consumers median income
column792:
the cash flow increases and that gives them more money to spend.

"
column793:
"

Mike Mayo

"
column794:
"

Okay
column795: do you think people are being too negative on the decline in oil prices
column796: you\u2019re implying it has a nice simulative effect
column797:
but people sure aren\u2019t taking that these days.

"
column798:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column800: it comes down to a question whether you think this is a - the oil price is a reflection of a broader issue of growth in economies
column801: we\u2019re going to get slow growth 2.5% in the U.S. and IMF [ph] said I guess 3.5% in the world. If you\u2019re going to get that in '16
column802: it is going to be isolated. This negatives could be isolated
column803: the oil companies and related commodity producers just because of slow growth environment. If you are saying this is going to be a much different economic scenario than most [indiscernible] so called consensus predicts. It\u2019s a broader based problem
column804: but right now it's really an oversupply of oil driving prices down
column805: and that\u2019s impacting the people in the industry and rest of the consumers
column806:
that means corporate customer and consumers that use oil and energy are getting a good benefit.

"
column807:
"

Paul Donofrio

"
column808:
"

And again Mike
column809: the only thing I would say is
column810: I mean Brian is spot on
column811: but the demand issue is kind of we are going to see it in other parts of the economy
column812: however
column813: we have not seen that yet
column814:
we have not seen change in our asset quality outside of energy.

"
column816:
"

And then if I can shift gears Brian
column817: I know I have asked this question in other years
column818: but I know you are not satisfied with the mid 60s core efficiency ratio
column819:
and I know you\u2019re not satisfied with a single-digit ROE. So what is your specific financial target for efficiency and ROE and what is your timeframe to get there?

"
column820:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column821:
"

As we said
column822: we ran about 9%
column823: it has just been travelling about 9.5% for the year and return to annual common equity. We believe we have a path to get that to 12. Rates get us part of it and hard work on expenses and core revenue growth and driving gets us the rest of it
column824: and so LAS expense drop-in
column825: and we're chipping away that
column827: we made substantial steps
column828: and we will continue to drive away. We haven\u2019t put a specific timeframe on it. It\u2019s just a goal to keep driving
column829:
and we will drive beyond that.

"
column830:
"

On efficiency
column831: it follows that - as an efficiency
column832: it follows that sort of math. Right now
column833: we are operating 66%
column835: probably normalized for 2015 and between LAS we can drop that down to 65%
column836: and that is just hard work and we\u2019re grinding away every day. You're seeing loans grow
column838:
and so you should see improvement in 2016.

"
column839:
"

Mike Mayo

"
column840:
"

Any expense initiative plan Paul since you've had a couple of quarters now to take a look at that? Are we looking for like an extra billion or kind of like a new BAC program or what are you thinking about there?

"
column842:
"

Expenses are on our mind every day at Bank of America. We have - everybody focuses on expense discipline that\u2019s translating to our culture under our simplified and improved program where the teams are always coming up with ideas to make it simpler for our customers
column843: to make it simple for our employees
column844: and improve the expenses of the company
column845:
that is how we\u2019re going to achieve our objectives around core expenses that we talked about on this call. We\u2019re all very focused on expenses.

"
column848:
"

Operator

"
column849:
"

And it appears that we have no further questions at this time. I'd like to return the program back to our host for any concluding remarks.

"
column850:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column851:

Thank you everyone. We look forward to talking to you next quarter.

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q1 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column6:
"

Lee McEntire \u2013 Senior Vice President-Investor Relations

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan \u2013 Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

Paul Donofrio \u2013 Chief Financial Officer

"
column24:
"

Good day and welcome to today\u2019s program. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead
column27:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everyone on the phone
column29: for joining us this morning for the First Quarter 2016 Results. Hopefully everybody has had a chance to review the earnings release. The documents are available on our website. Before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul
column30: let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those
column31:
please refer to either our earnings release docs or our website or the SEC filings.

"
column32:
"

Let me just remind you
column33: please limit the number of questions so that we can get to everyone\u2019s \u2013 so we can get through all the questions that everyone has. And with that
column34: I\u2019m pleased to now turn it over to Brian Moynihan
column35: our Chairman
column36: CEO
column37: for some opening comments before Paul Donofrio
column40:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column41:
"

Thank you
column42: Lee
column43: and good morning to everyone. We want to thank you for joining us to review our first quarter results. Today we reported $2.7 billion in earnings this quarter
column44: or $0.21 per diluted share. As you can see in the results
column45:
two large items impacted this quarter\u2019s results. We recorded negative market related NII adjustments for bond premium amortization. That adjustment alone cost us $0.07 per diluted share. And we also recorded a $0.05 per share diluted share cost of seasonal retirement eligible incentives.

"
column46:
"

When you think about revenue
column47: net interest income
column48: excluding that bond premium adjustment
column49: was $10.6 billion this quarter. This is improvement linked quarter and year-over-year. Our loans are growing across the franchise and
column50: compared to the prior year
column51: are up 11% in our business segments. In addition
column52:
deposit growth remains very strong. Our deposits were up $64 billion from last year or 6% to over $1.2 trillion.

"
column53:
"

This growth reflects our progress to grow responsibly and deepen relationships with all of our core customers. Moving to non-interest income
column54: it declined year-over-year. Of note
column55: the downdraft in that was driven by Capital Markets and related activities and
column56: to a lesser degree
column57:
mortgage servicing and other fees as we continue to wind down our third-party servicing book.

"
column58:
"

However
column59: the other banking sources of non-interest income were relatively stable. Switching to costs we continue to drive costs down in this Company. Costs year-over-year in the first quarter were down 6%. FTEs were down 3%. That is $1 billion per quarter
column60: $4 billion on an annualized basis. And if you focus just on the core costs excluding our LAS and litigation
column61:
those were down $600 million quarter \u2013 from first quarter of last year or $2.4 billion annualized. We\u2019re going to keep driving those costs own as we continue to move forward through 2016.

"
column62:
"

Turning to Slide 3 and looking at the business segment earnings
column63: you can see the good year-over-year results because of the operating leverage in those businesses. The only exception is the results in Global Banking
column64:
which were negatively impacted by the increased energy related reserves. The combination of business segments outside the All Other group earned $4.5 billion in quarter one this year compared to $3.9 billion in quarter one of 2015.

"
column65:
"

Offsetting those earnings were the $1.9 billion loss in All Other. That loss primarily reflects the two large adjustments I mentioned earlier and some legacy litigation costs. You can also see the returns and efficiency ratios for each of our segments and note
column66: with the exception of LAS
column67: which came close to breaking even this quarter
column68:
they earned above their cost of capital.

"
column69:
"

Moving to Slide 4
column70: during the period of \u2013 during the first quarter
column71: there was a lot of talk with the market volatility
column72: the Company buying surrounding the question about global growth and the forward-looking economic picture. However
column73:
we don\u2019t see any evidence of our customer base changing. Spending by consumers remains strong and is up year-over-year over 4%.

"
column74:
"

Loan demand remains solid throughout the franchise. And we continue to position our Company to face any potential economic outcome. When you think about this
column75: it\u2019s important to remember the work we\u2019ve done over the past years to simplify and strengthen our foundation. We remain a different Company today than that which had entered the last downturn. We start with a clear strategy to serve the core financial needs of the customers. We\u2019ve gotten out of businesses
column76: portfolios
column77:
products and client relationships that don\u2019t meet those strategic goals.

"
column78:
"

We simplified the Company in every area. We cut the number of legal entities in half and we also reduced costs through programs like New BAC that produced a loan more than $8 billion in annual savings and our SIM program which continues to operate today. At the same time we\u2019ve continued to invest in the areas we can grow. $3 billion in technology-related growth initiatives
column79: especially in areas of digital practice
column80: whether it\u2019s in Consumer Banking
column81: Commercial Banking
column82:
where we lead the industry with mobile and online platforms.

"
column83:
"

We\u2019ve also invested more in client facing teammates
column84: funding that investment through elimination of bureaucracy and simplification and elimination of management jobs. We believe that we have to continue to drive the productivity and will continue to do so in 2016. In the end
column85: when you think about all this
column86: it makes our Company more resolvable. As you all know
column87:
we received the latest input from our regulators on our resolution plans yesterday. Those plans were filed nine months ago and we\u2019ve been busy at work since the day they were filed to continue to remedy the deficiencies and shortcomings stated in those plans and we will do so by the October submission date.

"
column88:
"

As you move to Slide 5 you can also see the financial foundation that we\u2019ve built in this Company. Liquidity and capital at record levels. Tangible book value per share
column89:
the marker of what we as shareholders own in our Company now stands at $16.17 and has improved over $5 a share over the last few years even as we\u2019ve taken the hits that are now largely behind us. Our funding structure continues to improve. Long-term debt has been cut dramatically; deposits have increased over 20% and most of that growth is coming through our Consumer Banking and Wealth Management segments.

"
column90:
"

Our loan book is now well balanced
column91: half consumer
column92: half commercial. And importantly
column93: the consumer piece is much more secured lending than it was before the last crisis. As we look in Global Markets
column94: whether it\u2019s our Level 3 assets which are more risky
column95: the total trading assets or VaR
column96: they are all down significantly over the last few years. So as you can see we\u2019ve simplified our Company and our operating structure. As we look ahead to 2016
column97:
we remain focused on what we can control.

"
column98:
"

We intend to keep driving the core customer activity you see on the loan and deposit and customer flow growth in each and every business
column99:
focusing intently on the Wealth Management and Global Markets businesses to take advantage as markets have stabilized. We\u2019ll continue to drive on focusing on costs and drive those costs down and we\u2019ll continue to drive to deliver more capital to you as we did in the first quarter as investors.

"
column100:
"

With that
column101:
let me hand it over to Paul.

"
column102:
"

Paul Donofrio

"
column103:
"

Thanks
column104: Brian. Good morning
column105: everybody
column106: and thanks for joining us. Starting on Slide 6
column107: we present a summary of the income statement returns for this quarter
column108: highlighting comparisons to Q4 2015 as well as Q1 2015. Earnings this quarter were $2.7 billion or $0.21 per share. These earnings include the negative impact of the FAS 91 market-related adjustment
column109: which reduced EPS by $0.07. They also include $850 million of FAS 123 retirement eligible incentive expense
column110:
which reduced EPS by $0.05.

"
column111:
"

For comparative purposes
column112: the aggregate impact of these two same items in Q1 2015 reduced EPS by $0.08. Revenue on an FTE basis was $19.7 billion this quarter. Adjusted for FAS 91
column113: revenue was $20.9 billion
column114: a decline of $700 million from Q1 2015 on a similarly adjusted basis. This decline was driven by the reduction in sales and trading revenue and IB fees
column115:
as well as mortgage banking income offset by improvement in adjusted NII.

"
column116:
"

Expenses were $14.8 billion
column117: approximately $1 billion or 6% lower than a year ago
column118: driven by good discipline across the entire Company. Before moving to the balance sheet I want to note an adjustment to the financial statements this quarter
column119:
reclassifying some operating leases. We moved $6 billion of leases to other assets and we made conforming reclassifications to prior periods to improve comparability. This reclassification had no effect on net income.

"
column120:
"

However
column121: as a result of this reclassification
column122: quarterly NII is lower by approximately $50 million
column123: other income is higher by approximately $180 billion and depreciation expense is higher by about $130 million. While these changes are small and don\u2019t affect profits
column124:
I wanted to note them so that you can more easily adjust your models.

"
column125:
"

Turning to Slide 7 and the balance sheet in the balance sheet. Total assets increased $41 billion from Q4 driven by higher Global Markets repo activity as well as increased cash. Deposits rose $20 billion from Q4 while loans increased $4 billion. Driven by deposit inflows
column126: liquidity rose to $525 billion. Time to required funding
column127: while down
column128: remains strong at three years. And note that the first quarter included the $8.5 billion settlement payment to Bank of New York Mellon as trustee in the article 77 suit
column129:
which was reserved for over four years ago.

"
column130:
"

Tangible common equity of $167 billion improved $4.7 billion from Q4. On a per share basis
column131: tangible book value increased to $16.17
column132: up 9% from Q1 2015. Turning to regulatory metrics: as a reminder
column133:
we report regulatory capital under the advanced approaches. Our CET1 transition ratio under Basel III ended the quarter at 10.3% and really is only comparable to Q4 as prior periods were reported under the standardized approach prior to our exit from parallel run.

"
column134:
"

On a fully phased-in basis
column135: CET1 capital improved $3.4 billion to $158 billion as improvements from earnings and OCI were partially offset by dividends and repurchases. Under the advanced approaches
column136: compared to Q4 2015
column137:
the CET1 ratio increased 30 basis points to 10.1% and is now above our fully phased-in 2019 requirement. RWA decreased roughly $18 billion driven by reductions related to retail exposures as credit quality improved.

"
column138:
"

One is the markets area.

column971:

the ability to use it to inform our corporate customers.

column980: we look at how we pare away things and look at it \u2013 so in the international business we\u2019ve pared back \u2013 there was 1

It just takes more time because 130 million square feet of real estate down to 80 million go into 70 million. There\u2019s a lot of work to get out of that real estate.

column996:

column1004: I think if you think of branches and think about it as offices as opposed to the historical notion of a place where you transact
column1005: the question of how many you have is going to be how many relationship managers you need and how many places they have to sit. And so

"

I wanted to focus on mortgage banking and the retention of those loans
column1052: more on the balance sheet than continuing to push them to the GSIBs. Is that regulatory driven or are you really looking for that higher retention rate because you\u2019re looking for some assets that have duration
column1053:
so is that one of the better maybe option adjusted yields that you can get at this point?

column1056: you can come at this a fairly straightforward way which is we have $1.2 trillion in deposits and we have $900 billion in loans. And if we put our own mortgages on the balance sheet we know the quality
column1057:
we know the customer and we know that the servicing cost ultimately will be a lot less of how we\u2019re doing it. If we buy third-party loans \u2013 so to extract the value of those deposits we\u2019ve got to invest in something. We invested substantially in treasuries. We have to \u2013 back to mortgages and mortgage-backed securities. And so the question is why by someone else\u2019s when you are producing your own?

column1058:
"

So it\u2019s really a very pragmatic view of \u2013 we want to control our destiny in mortgage going forward so that the customer we look in the eye and originate the mortgage with is the customers we service for
column1059: is the customer we have the asset quality with and there is no third-party involved. So it\u2019s more driven by us just getting to our own
column1062:
"

column1063: which is showing that retention. However
column1064: if you look at all other

column1077: the \u2013 we used to \u2013 there is an element that\u2019s just as \u2013 we used to book that retained piece in the central area. We stopped doing that. That\u2019s showing the changeover

column1080:

column1089: look \u2013 the facts are we\u2019ve been growing overall

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q2 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan \u2013 Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

"
column9:
"

Paul Donofrio \u2013 Chief Financial Officer

"
column21:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column27:
and welcome to today\u2019s program. At this time all participants are in listen-only mode. Later you will have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded.

"
column28:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead.

"
column29:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column30:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone as well as the webcast for joining us this morning for the second quarter 2016 results. Hopefully everybody\u2019s had a chance to review the earnings release documents that were available on our website.

"
column31:
"

Before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul
column32: let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those
column33: please refer to either our earnings release documents
column34:
our website or our SEC filings.

"
column35:
"

So before Brian and Paul get into the results
column36: just let me mention one housekeeping item. Please limit your questions to one per caller so that we can get to everyone
column37:
and you can circle back.

"
column39: I\u2019ll turn the call over to Brian Moynihan
column40: our Chairman and CEO
column41: for some opening comments; before Paul Donofrio
column42: our CFO
column43:
goes through the details. Brian?

"
column44:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column45:
"

Thank you
column46: Lee
column47: and good morning
column48: everyone
column49:
and thank you for joining us to review our second quarter results. I\u2019m beginning on slide two of the materials we sent to you.

"
column50:
"

We reported solid earnings of $4.2 billion after tax
column51: or $0.36 per diluted share
column52:
in what was certainly an eventful quarter for the markets from an overall macro perspective. This compares to $5.1 billion or $0.43 per share in the year-ago quarter. This quarter included negative market related NII adjustments that cost $0.05 per share and negative DVA that cost us another penny for a total of $0.06. That compares to a $0.03 benefit for EPS for both those items in the second quarter of 2015.

"
column53:
"

Earnings neutralizing for the past 91 DVA for both periods improved from $0.40 per share to $0.42 per share on a year-over-year basis. Our results represent another quarter of solid progress in the strategies we have been executing. Those strategies are delivering more of the company\u2019s capabilities to each and every client we serve. At BAC
column54: we focus on what we can control
column55: and despite low rates and other macro events
column56: we continue to focus on managing our risk
column57:
our costs and our delivery of quality products and customer service.

"
column58:
"

In Q2
column59: we grew loans $22 billion or approximately 2.5% versus last year
column60: even as we sold a few portfolios during the year. All this growth was organic and consistent with our risk appetite. We also grew deposits more than $66 billion or 6% over that same time period
column61:
and we did so while maintaining disciplined deposit pricing.

"
column62:
"

We also continued to transform our company in a digital way at all things and all businesses. For example
column63: this quarter we crossed over 20 million active mobile users and continued to increase their use of digital channels for both transactions and buying more bank products. Active mobile banking customers logged into their accounts over 900 million times this quarter
column64: depositing more than 25 million checks

we had $6.7 billion in P2P payments this quarter. That is more than $13 billion year to date and is up 20% from last year. This channel is a valued channel for all our customers and made possible by the [indiscernible] investment we make.

column71:
"

As we move to slide three
column72:
we have talked to you \u2013 a lot of you over the last several months including many of you on the phone today. I thought I\u2019d try to address some of the more common questions we get from those conversations by looking at our results \u2013 by looking at the income statement and the items therein.

"
column73:
"

First
column74: one of the core questions is what if rates stay lower for longer? Well
column75: for bank management and for you as investors it would be easier if rates were to rise but that hasn\u2019t happened. So the question is can we grow earnings without rates improving? We believe we surely can. We can do that by continued success on things like expense management
column76: by keeping NII stable to growing
column77: stable and growing fees
column78: and continue to manage risk well and hold down our credit costs. As you can see
column79: revenue this quarter was $20.6 billion on an FTE basis. Adjusted for the negative impacts of market-related NII adjustments and DVA
column80: that number is $21.8 billion. Adjusted for the same items in the year-ago quarter
column81:
the total was comparable.

"
column82:
"

Now as we focus in on NII
column83: Paul will take you through some of the changes this quarter later in the presentation. However
column84: in summary
column85: adjusted for market-related changes in both last year\u2019s second quarter and this year\u2019s second quarter
column86: we grew NII by 400 million or 4% year-over-year. And that took place while the 10-year Treasury yield fell 86 basis points from last year on a spot basis. Going forward in a stable interest rate environment
column87: we believe we can maintain NII around the second quarter 2016 level based on the current loan and deposit growth we see. And if rates rise
column88:
we would expect NII to grow.

"
column89:
"

Another question relates to Global Markets business. That question is often asked how we need to change this business
column90: especially the FICC area as many of our customers have. I want to hit this head on. First of all
column91: fixed income a good business for us here at Bank of America. It is a business which benefits not only by its core activities but by being coupled with our massive global banking franchise that has leadership positions across the globe. Combined together
column92: they generate a pretty steady billion dollars or so of quarterly investment banking fees. It\u2019s also an important part of our overall Global Markets platform
column93:
the platform which sits on top of the number one global research team for the past five years.

"
column94:
"

In the second quarter
column95: this business did well. Global Markets generated $3.7 billion in sales and trading revenue excluding DVA. Compared to the same period last year
column96: that is up 12%. This year-over-year improvement is driven by FICC sales and trading
column97:
which is up 22%. Now think about that. Sales and trading revenue including DVA for this quarter is the highest second quarter we have experienced in five years and it led to one of the most profitable quarters for Global Markets we have seen in the past five years.

"
column98:
"

Also the team served clients well during a period of difficult volatility. So clearly it remains a profitable important business for us to serve clients. We\u2019re proud of how the team supported their clients through the Brexit both in the periods of volatility related there too.

"
column99:
"

Another question is getting clarity on how we\u2019re transforming the business on the fee lines. Noninterest revenue was $11.2 billion this quarter. Although modestly down from second quarter 2015
column100: it was up nicely from the first quarter. There are a lot of the items that one through the various lines of fees. First with regard to consumer fees
column101: we are largely done with the big card portfolio divestitures and branch divestitures. Both those impacted both card fees and banking service charges and you can see them coming off the bottom as you look at the linked quarters. Fees now will grow with the volume of cards and accounts that are now net growing in our company. Our mortgage business is now sized appropriately for our franchise and the fee line there Paul will talk about later
column102:
but will be as that near where it\u2019s going to be in the future.

"
column103:
"

With regard to revenue more closely tied to markets business
column104: the ups and downs in volumes of activity in sales and trading in investment banking and brokerage will move back and forth with the market. But the important thing is we have strong businesses
column105:
strong client-facing businesses in these areas and we\u2019re getting our share of these revenue streams even while the markets ebbs and flows.

"
column106:
"

So if we look about move from the fee line to the expense line
column107: many of you give us credit for having managed expenses from $70 billion five years ago to the mid-$50 billion today. But the question is can we do more? And if you look at this quarter we continue to manage expenses well. Noninterest expense this quarter was $13.5 billion
column108: improving more than 3.5% or 3% from 2015 second quarter. This continues a trend of performance that has shown expense declining significantly on a quarterly basis quarter-after-quarter over the past several years. This is the lowest level that we have reported since the fourth quarter of 2008
column109:
and that\u2019s prior to the Merrill Lynch merger.

"
column110:
"

If you look at our efficiency ratio and normalize it for the NII adjustment stated above
column111: it would be about 62% this quarter. That\u2019s an improvement 200 basis points from last year\u2019s second quarter. Cost control and cost effectiveness is a focus for our management team here at Bank of America. So the question is how much more can we do on expenses? So if you think about this
column112: let\u2019s start by looking at the costs of the most recent four quarters. In the trailing four quarters the total expense base was $56.3 billion. As we look out from the second \u2013 the third quarter of 2016 through the next six quarters into 2018
column113: we believe that with our SIM efforts and the continued work we\u2019re doing across the board on expenses
column114:
we\u2019re targeting an annual expense number of around $53 billion in total expenses for the year 2018.

"
column115:
"

So over six quarters we continue to absorb investment
column116: merit increases
column117: rising healthcare costs
column118: and bring the expenses down a nominal amount. Our continued work in driving down costs to service delinquent loans will help with this
column119: but the other reductions are generally coming from the core work and simplified improved. The work we continue to do to simplify those work processes but also the core work we do to allow us to self-fund our growth initiatives
column120:
are continuing investments in technology and salespeople.

"

"

While I\u2019m on the topic of expenses
column122: I want to point out another important milestone for our company in quarter. This quarter we changed our reporting to eliminate the legacy assets in the servicing segment. This completes transformation. This segment was last place for product orientation was reported
column123: not customer orientation. And more importantly
column124:
it also reflects the last of legacy is really behind us from an operational basis. We added a couple slides in the appendix today to go along with our 8-K we filed a few days ago. They explain the methodology of the realignment of LAS and the highlights that impacts the segment with those loans and associated P&L are reported now.

"
column125:
"

But what I want to get to across to you is LAS as an operational segment successfully did what it was tasked to do: to clean up one of the largest mortgage servicing businesses in the U.S. Consider that progress. From 1.4 million delinquent mortgage loans we\u2019re down to 80
column126: 000 a day. At one point we had 58
column127: 000 teammates and 20
column128: 000 contractors working on this task
column129: and now we\u2019re down to 10
column130: 000 teammates. From one peak a quarter of $3 billion plus in expenses
column131:
we\u2019re down to $600 million this quarter. That phase of the work is complete and we need to move that operating business in with the rest of the company to do the further consolidation and further work to improve our servicing cost. We are pleased with the accomplishments of this group but there is still more to be done.

And that brings us to our provision. Simply put

column136:

And that brings us to our returns. In this operating environment

but you can see the improvement coming through.

column144:
they grew earnings as costs declined more than revenue while we continue to invest in this business. Revenue is impacted by AUM valuations from market variability.

column340: sales and trading revenue of $3.7 billion excluding net DVA was up 12% from Q2 2015 driven by FICC. In terms of revenue
column341: this was the best second quarter we have had in the past five years. Excluding DVA and versus Q2 2015
column342: FICC sales and trading of $2.6 billion increased 22% as the improvement which began in late Q1 continued through Q2 as global concerns abated and central banks took further monetary policy actions. Improvement was across both macro and credit products driven by stronger rates and currency
column343:
client activity as well as improved credit market conditions.

"
column344:
"

Tighter spreads benefited mortgage
column345: trading and municipal bonds outperformed treasuries with strong retail demand. Equity sales and trading was $1.1 billion
column346:
declining 8% versus Q2 2015 which saw significant client activity in Asia driven by stock market rallies in the region.

"
column347:
"

On slide 21
column348:
we show all other which reported a loss of $815 billion. This loss was driven by the current quarter\u2019s $974 million market related NII adjustment. The loss is lower than Q1 due to both a lower market related NII adjustment as well as the absence of retirement-eligible incentive costs.

"
column349:
"

Compared to Q2 2015
column350: the difference is driven by a number of factors. First
column351: the negative NII market-related adjustment in this quarter versus a large positive adjustment in Q2 2015. Second
column352: we had reps and warranty recoveries in Q2 2015 related to a court ruling and gains on the sale of consumer real estate loans. Third
column353:
provision expense declined from Q2 2015 driven by continued portfolio improvement.

"
column354:
"

The effective tax rate for the quarter was about 29%
column355: which is in-line with what we expect for the remainder of the year
column356: absent any unusual items. And as a reminder
column357: we still expect to record a tax charge of about $350 million
column358:
most likely in 3Q that reduces the carrying value of our U.K. DTAs as a result of the U.K. tax reform announced last year. The vast majority of this charge will not impact regulatory capital.

"
column359:
"

Okay. So let me offer a few takeaways as I finish. Q2 was another quarter of solid progress in a challenging global environment. While growth concerns persist in many countries
column360: the U.S. economy continues to steadily improve
column361: albeit at a less than optimum pace. The diversity and strength of our franchise makes us more relevant to clients and customers during times such as these
column362:
and you can see that in our results.

"
column363:
"

Clearly
column364: interest rates affected our financial performance this quarter. Still
column365: while we cannot control interest rates
column366: we are not waiting for them to rise. We grew in this environment by focusing on the things that we can control and drive. We grew deposits
column367: we grew loans
column369: reflected in reduced charge-offs. We delivered for customer clients in another challenging quarter
column370:
especially around the U.K. referendum. We invested in our future by adding sales professionals and continuing to deploy technology that improves customer satisfaction. We returned capital to shareholders and we announced plans to return increasing amounts. And we did all of this while we lowered expenses and drove operating leverage

"
column371:
"

Thank you. And with that

let\u2019s open it up for questions.

Richard Bove

column843:
okay. That\u2019d be great.

Okay. Next we\u2019ll go to Jim Mitchell with Buckingham Research.

No

Yeah

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
IR

"
column9:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chairman and CEO

"
column25:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column27:
"

Marty Mosby - Vining Sparks

"
column29:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl - KBW

"
column31:
"

Good day
column32: everyone
column33:
and welcome to today\u2019s program. At this time all participants are in listen-only mode. Later you will have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded.

"
column34:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead.

"
column35:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column36:
"

Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone as well as the webcast for joining us this morning for the Third Quarter 2016 Results. Hopefully everybody\u2019s had a chance to review the earnings release documents that were available on the website.

"
column37:
"

Before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul
column39: we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those
column40: please refer to either our earnings release documents
column41:
our website or our SEC filings.

"
column42:
"

One thing before Brian and Paul get into the results
column43: I just want to remind you we file an 8-K on October 4
column44:
giving notification the company changed our method of accounting for the amortization of premium and accretion of discounts related to certain debt securities known by the investment community as FAS 91. Our change to the contractual method which is used by the just majority of our peers will provide better comparability of our results.

"
column45:
"

As a result to the change
column46: we restated our historical results
column47:
and provided the historically restated information in the 8-K and our earnings materials today naturally reflect those restatements.

"
column48:
"

With that
column49: let me turn it over to Brian Moynihan
column50: our Chairman and CEO
column51: for some opening comments; before Paul Donofrio
column52: our CFO
column53:
goes through the details. Brian?

"
column54:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column55:
"

Thank you
column56: Lee. Good morning
column57: everyone
column58: and thank you for joining us today to review our third quarter results. Our results this quarter continue our progress on our long term strategy. We continue to drive responsible growth and deliver more of the company\u2019s capabilities to our clients and customers. This progress is becoming clear with each successive quarter
column59:
and you can see the highlights of that on slide 2.

"
column60:
"

We reported earnings of $5 billion or $0.41 per diluted share and EPS improvement of 8% from the year ago quarter. We improved operating leverage across the businesses
column61:
utilizing technology to lower costs and improve our processes. Our pretax earnings improved 17% compared to the third quarter of 2015. This pretax earnings comparison is important as it eliminates the unusual movements in the tax line like this quarters\u2019 tax charge and the UK corporate tax rate change.

"
column62:
"

Like last quarter
column63: I thought I\u2019d address a few topics before hearing from all of you. To do that
column64: let\u2019s look at slide 3 and 4 of the earnings material. The first question is
column65: are we making progress driving our responsible growth strategy? Yes
column66: we continue to show progress throughout all the businesses. Our revenue growth has more clarity as we move past the periods of significant impacts from implementing regulations
column67: running off non-core portfolios
column68:
and divesting non-core businesses.

"
column69:
"

Revenue grew 3% over the third quarter of last year. Behind that improvement is our continued investment in this great franchise
column70: in our sales teams
column71:
in our technology across the board. These sales teams and the buildup we\u2019ve been doing there help us to increase our capacity to serve our customers and clients.

"
column72:
"

An example of that is in our consumer business
column73: they are focused on being the core bank to all our households. This has resulted in fewer checking accounts than we had years ago
column74: but the average balance of the checking accounts we have has doubled and they are now roughly $65 to $100 per account. You can also see this in the growth of our Merrill Edge brokerage balances
column75: which now total over $138 billion
column76:
adding investment relationships to the mass market customer base.

"
column77:
"

In general
column78: consumers are deepening their relationships with us
column79: as they use our straight forward investing tools to get them started on a path to investing. For affluent and wealthy customers
column80: our customer progress also continues. Our global wealth and investment management teams
column81: US Trust and Merrill Lynch not only manage $2 trillion plus in investment balances
column82: but also manage nearly $150 billion in loans and more than $250 billion in deposits
column83:
and we continue to see net flows of core assets in that business.

"
column84:
"

On the commercial side
column85: clients continue to respond to our universal banking model for a simplified stuff for financing
column86: investing
column87:
and advisory services. We will continue to operate within in our established risk framework in defined customer groups and we aren\u2019t reaching for growth. This would drive more sustainable results over a longer period of time for our shareholders.

"
column88:
"

And then with our global peers restructuring
column89: including in the markets business
column90: I think this quarter is another great example of how global markets business is important to our investing and issuing clients. We better client activity driving the best third quarter results we\u2019ve had in the five years in investment banking and in sales and trading
column91: and we are doing that with a smaller balance sheet
column92: fewer people
column93:
and lower value at risk or VAR.

"
column94:
"

So growth in deepening
column95: all consistent with our responsible growth strategy continues across all the customer bases. Paul will talk to you more about the statistics and its successes. Another question that we get asked is can credit remain this strong? Well many of you asked that last quarter and the quarter before that and the quarter before that. And in this quarter
column96:
it\u2019s still got better again with our charge-off ratio decline to 40 basis points this quarter at an historic low.

"
column97:
"

This is driven by changes we made right after the crisis
column98: thinking 2008 and 2009 and the long term benefits of that effort continue to come through. And by the way
column99: sticking to our responsible growth strategy
column100:
even as times have been relatively better.

"
column101:
"

US consumer health is generally good. Over the past few quarters
column102: exposures in our oil and gas that were causing industry concerns for commercial losses have improved
column103:
and charge-offs have receded. Other commercial credit remains very strong and Paul will touch on these topics later.

"
column104:
"

Another question we get asked is
column105: what can we do to drive earnings even if we stay in this low rate
column106: low growth environment? We aren\u2019t waiting for interest rates to rise here at Bank of America. We are driving our earnings growth now. We work on the things that we can control
column107: expenses
column108: loan and deposit growth
column109:
and fee growth.

"
column110:
"

Long-term rates are down compared to last year
column111: yet earnings have grown. Despite that
column112: net interest income is up 3% from third quarter \u201915
column113: while net interest yield has been stable because we grew core loans and deposits. Paul will take you through the loan growth details later
column114:
but I want to pause a moment and talk about our deposit growth.

"
column115:
"

Deposits are core part of what drives our franchise earnings. We have 1.2 trillion of deposits that\u2019s proof the customers entrust us to safeguard their money. We are heavily weighted and mix those deposits towards consumers
column116:
whether they are general consumers or wealthy consumers. This in turn provides a very stable base of funding for the company and allows us to be less relied on the markets we are funding.

"
column117:
"

Nearly $450 billion or 36% of our deposits are non-interest bearing
column118: a very strong mix. Deposits on average grew $68 billion year-over-year or 6%. The teams have done tremendous work here
column119:
and this quarter wasn\u2019t an anomaly. This is the fourth quarter consecutive quarter where we have grown deposits more than $50 billion over the previous year.

"
column120:
"

Our commercial teams remain focused on growing deposits also. They\u2019re growing deposits that are LCR friendly and doing great work with our industry leading cash management capabilities. As a result
column121:
year-over-year global banking grew their deposits 3% to 300 billion.

"
column122:
"

Our consumer and wealth management teams combine have $860 billion in deposits. They grew this large base by 8% in the past 12 months. For the first time
column123: consumer tops $600 billion in deposits. These deposits are growing because our capabilities in the business are the best in the industry and our customers and clients see that. Whether it\u2019s our 21 million plus mobile banking customers
column124: our 34 million plus online customers
column125:
or the more than 5 million customers that come in to our financial centers every week. These customers show that they appreciate the capabilities and integration of our network.

"
column126:
"

So when we look at what else we can do to control and drive earnings in a low growth environment
column127:
we get asked a lot about expenses and can those expenses keep being driven down and go lower. Well the answer is yes. Last quarter we gave you a 2018 expense target and we continue to make progress towards that.

"
column128:
"

Our expenses declined 3% from the third quarter of 2015 to 2016. Our efficiency ratio improved 60% to 62% this quarter that is a 400 basis points improvement from last year\u2019s third quarter. We continue to deliver expense reductions while continuing to invest in technology and sales teams and other matters are important for the futures franchise.

"
column129:
"

After taking in to account the addition of large bank FDIC assessment at the start of this quarter
column130: expenses are also down on linked quarter basis
column131: even as we continue to invest and absorb all the severance
column132: regulatory
column133:
resolution planning and other repositioning cost to continue to reduce our operating cost.

"
column134:
"

We have been innovating in technology and will continue to do so to improve processes and eliminate the need for paper and humans handling that paper. Our simplified and improved initiatives continue to help drive those costs down
column135:
and that leads to the question we also get asked. Can we deliver and sustain returns above our cost of capital?

"
column136:
"

As Lee talked about earlier
column137:
we restate our results to change under FAS 91 and reduce the variability and make us more comparable to peers. As you can see that makes a little easier to see the longer term return on tangible common equity trends. This quarter we reported 10.3% and it is now stabilized above the cost of capital even given our larger and larger capital base.

"
column138:
"

We still have work to do here to drive to our ultimate goals
