"
column1066:
"

I think the pragmatic answer is that we are - 90% of our consumer checking accounts are core transaction accounts
column1067: the primary checking account. Those balances are touching $250 billion plus. They\u2019ve been doubled over the last seven or eight years. Those balances are the data cash flow of household and I don\u2019t think they are going to change much
column1068: but until you\u2019ve got experience the model has to sort of look backwards as we say and so we\u2019ll see what happens. But so far those of us that take the side
column1069:
this will be less sensitive if [won] let\u2019s just say that.

"
column1072: just a strategic utilization of capital
column1073: if you look at your allocation of capital and returns by business segment
column1074: you kind of do a weighted average
column1075:
you come up with close to an 18% return. As profitability is getting higher that\u2019s getting further away from the overall return which is still around 10%. How do you envision trying to clean up either the capital positions or the overhang from overhead expenses that brings those two numbers maybe a little bit closer together?

"
column1078: moving expenses down we talked about that earlier
column1079: that helps the returns. But we always have to remember that there is basically leave aside how the allocation works for the business
column1080: it works differently. But when you think about the 10% capital requirements for us 300 basis points or 3 percentage points of that cannot be put to use
column1082:
"

And so we\u2019re earning all our money on the 7% and so when you think about the weighted average of that
column1083: it comes out over 10 and that means that you\u2019re in a lot more on the seven even across the whole company
column1084: and so that\u2019s one of the difficulties. So how do we optimize that
column1085:
we make that 10% less dollar volume if we can keep dollar volume down and keep increasing earnings you get. That\u2019s by all the discussion Paul had in response to the questions about optimizing the balance sheet.

"
column1086:
"

Will we get expenses down
column1087: will we grow less risky earnings that generate an income
column1089:
but the basic principal of people that we sometimes forget is that when you think about 10% only 30% of capital can take no risk and so basically you\u2019re in to cost of debt.

"
column1091:
"

We\u2019ll take our next question from Gerard Cassidy with RBC. Please go ahead.

"
column1093:
"

A question on your digital sales
column1094:
obviously you\u2019ve had 18% of total sales coming through digital channels and 25% through the mobile. Can you share with us what products you are having the most success with selling through these channels and which products proved to be more challenging?

"
column1096:
"

Well generally you should think that the products which are more straight forward like a card application
column1097: we build a nice auto loan execution that\u2019s kind of unique and because those things are fairly straight forward applications. Mortgage and things like that it really takes a lot more process around them. So
column1098:
I\u2019d say cards and autos are the [downward] part.

"
column1100:
"

Is there any target of where you can get these sales to as a percentage of total sales? Can eventually 50% of sales come through the digital channel?

"
column1102:
"

I think it will continue to rise in terms of dollar amount
column1103: probably rise in terms of percentage. But remember as sales grow overall in the company
column1104: getting in to 50 means they have to win next race in the growth overall
column1105:
but we are becoming more and more capable in delivering this and that\u2019s why you\u2019re seeing a nice growth and so we\u2019re applying deeply where it can really be the primary method and things like cards and auto are the easier place.

"
column1109: sticking with digital; is there any application in the digital channel
column1110:
where you can have success like you are having in the consumer bank in the Merrill Lynch brokerage channel?

"
column1113: Merrill Edge is obviously across-the-board execution; their clients utilize that in Merrill and in US Trust and the broad consumer business. So
column1114:
it\u2019s a broad execution and well recognized as being one of the leaders by the various authorities.

"
column1115:
"

We believe and one of the things Jerry [Lockwood] and Keith Banks and Andy Sieg and John and other are working on is to increase our capabilities for both the advisor and the customer and the digital more or less stated in the (inaudible) business and so we think there is upside for us.

"
column1116:
"

Again less customers so the leverage is not quite the same and that\u2019s why we spend a lot of our time around the consumer
column1117: and there\u2019s just less leverage and the advisor you have to think about that business because the advisors are core strength that we have to the customer that we have to have an execution which is universal between the advisors and the customers
column1118: they can all see the same thing. So we\u2019ve got some great capabilities now My Merrill things like that. But we plan to continue and enhance them and continue to integrate them. So when they get to loans and deposits and things like that they are much more integrated over time. You can still see it all
column1119:
but it\u2019s not where we want to be.

"
column1121:
"

And we\u2019ll take our next question from Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW. Please go ahead.

"
column1123:
"

I just had one quick question
column1124: and it\u2019s on the $52 billion expense target. If we got into an environment where you saw revenues come back more robustly near-term
column1125: could you still commit to that $53 billion target
column1126:
meaning you have enough levers to pull or would you see yourself switching to maybe an efficiency ratio target if all of a sudden these revenues came back stronger? Thanks.

"
column1129: if you remember when we made that target it was in the context of 1.5%
column1130: 2% GDP growth economy much like we have now in the rate environment
column1131:
incremental from where we have now. So I think the shareholders and this management team would be happy if we are having a discussion about revenue related incentives going up faster than that that would be good news for the company.

"
column1133:
"

And it appears we have no further questions at this time. I\u2019ll return the floor to our presenters for closing remarks.

"
column1135:
"

Thank you very much and we look forward to speaking to you next quarter.

"
column1137:
"

And this will conclude today\u2019s program. Thanks for your participation

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q4 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column8:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

"
column9:
"

Paul Donofrio - Chief Financial Officer

"
column20:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets

"
column26: everyone and welcome to the Bank of America Earnings Announcement Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead
column27:
sir.

"
column29:
"

Good morning. Thanks everybody for joining us. I know it\u2019s a busy morning for all of you for the fourth quarter 2016 results. Hopefully
column30: everybody has got a chance to review the earnings release documents that are available on our website. Before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul
column31: let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those
column32: please refer to our earnings release documents
column33:
our website or SEC filings.

"
column34:
"

With that
column35: let me turn it over to Brian Moynihan
column36: our Chairman and CEO for some opening comments before Paul Donofrio
column37:
our CFO goes through the details. Brian?

"
column40: Lee and thank all of you for joining us to review our results today. Results this year in the fourth quarter complete a solid year of execution in driving our responsible growth strategy. We have produced earnings of $17.9 billion in 2016
column41: that\u2019s a 13% growth over 2015. In a year in which we had a series of unexpected and sizable events around the world and a rough start in the capital markets
column42: we are able to achieve 1% growth in revenue against the backdrop of a slow growth U.S. economy. Importantly focused on driving what we could control
column43: cost
column44:
production and risk.

"
column45:
"

So
column46: how do we do on all that? We lowered our costs to improve productivity
column47: with result in reduction expenses by almost 5% compared to 2015. That\u2019s nearly $3 billion in expense reductions continuing a long-term trend. From their peak in 2011 at $77 billion
column48: expenses are now down $22 billion at 29%. And reductions coupled with the revenue growth drove 6% in operating leverage. In improving economy
column49:
a relentless focus on client selection and growth through responsible lending combined to result in a historical low charge-off rate of 39 basis points for our company this quarter. We also returned more capital to shareholders through higher dividends and more share repurchases during 2016.

"
column50:
"

As you may have seen in the news release this morning
column51: we announced an additional $1.8 billion expansion to our share buyback program. So adding the $1.8 billion to the $2.5 billion left
column52: that brings us to $4.3 billion for the first 6 months of 2017. Our approach has resulted in a 2% reduction in share count at the end of 2016
column53: which adds to the earnings growth to produce a 15% growth in earnings per share. For the year
column54: our return on tangible common equity was 9.5%
column55:
while return on assets was 82 basis points. And the efficiency ratio improved from 70% to 66%.

"
column56:
"

From a balance sheet perspective
column57: let me mention a few things that are noteworthy as items continued to grow with the business
column58: while optimizing the balance sheet at the same time. Our average deposits grew $64 billion or 5% compared to fourth quarter of \u201815. Our average loans grew $22 billion or 3%
column59: as the lending segments outgrew the legacy runoff and Paul will show you that later on. On regulatory capital
column60: we ended the year at 10.8% on a fully phased-in CET 1 advanced basis. Importantly
column61: after reviewing our year end calculation and through the hard work of our teams
column62: we are pleased to report that our method 2 G-SIB capital ratio requirement has dropped 50 basis points. So
column63: our total 2019 CET 1 requirement is now 9.5%
column64:
instead of 10%.

"
column65:
"

Turning to Slide 3
column66: on these charts

column492: return on \u2013 advanced approach

column908: could you just talk a little bit about your deposit market share

column929:

The answer would be yes because\u2026

column933:
"

Yes. Let\u2019s think about it. I think Paul said earlier that mobile sales are 20-odd \u2013 20-ish percent
column934: but that means 80% are not mobile therefore they are coming through other \u2013 call centers and branches
column935: so it\u2019s an integrated business system. And Thong and Dean and the team have done a great job of optimizing that. If you look at the chart and watch the cost per deposit
column936: deposit continues to work its way down while there is growth and additional salespeople. So it\u2019s coming. The year-over-year rise in mobile sales is actually faster
column938:
but it\u2019s still only 20% of the contribution.

"
column942: we are using a statistic I really like is we are using \u2013 we have digital appointments
column943: so people come into the branch
column944: but they don\u2019t just on walk in. Now
column945: they are coming in for an appointment that they have made with over their smartphones. So that really helps us from an efficiency standpoint as well if we can get people to do that it\u2019s better for them
column949: yes. My follow-up question is this
column950: I mean we have experienced or we experienced on November 8 sort of a sea change in the thinking about bank regulation going forward and everybody that I have talked to seems to think even if there are not significant changes in what\u2019s on the books
column951: that there will be a \u201clighter touch\u201d in regulation and I guess I would ask if you are thinking in those terms and if so
column953: that will have an impact on your expense figure
column955: number of people you need to add and compliance
column962: there are a couple of dimensions obviously. That dimension is well spoken about out there. You saw yesterday
column963: I think the House passed a couple cost benefit analysis type requirements for the SEC and the commodity things
column964: so I think there will be a body of work that will go on to sort of balance
column965: let\u2019s make sure we understand the pluses and minuses a lot of stuff. But the reality
column966: if you think about our company
column967: we have maintained \u2013 we invest a lot of talent and capabilities in people
column971: but the company has shrunk around it
column972: so it\u2019s become a higher percentage
column973: but it\u2019s not \u2013 we are able to now start to optimize that
column974: make it better. And so I think if we get that
column976: that will help us even do more potentially. But even if we don\u2019t
column977: there is optimization to come now. We kind of crested all the different things have gone on in the industry. So first
column978: it was the work of just collecting the bad mortgage and stuff
column979: but now you are optimizing more the way we manage risk in a systems environment and stuff like that
column980:
so I look forward \u2013 that\u2019s what helps us to get confidence of the future path on costs overall.

column985:
"

And we will take our last question from Gerard Cassidy with RBC. Please go ahead.

"
column990: how are you. I have got a question for Paul

column994: I know Brian referenced already some pickup in middle markets and commercial real estate
column995:
but can you give any further color of that commercial activity that you saw in the lending side at the end of the quarter?

"
column999: the earnings prep talk into ahead of our middle markets business
column1000: our DCB business and our small business banking. They are telling me that they are definitely seeing more interest from CEOs to have meetings. A lot of engagement around \u201817 and what the environment might be
column1001: things are feeling a lot more optimistic to those bankers. And it\u2019s not just talk. Late in the quarter
column1002: we actually did see an increase in loan balances that was a little \u2013 I wouldn\u2019t call it a spike
column1003:
but there was definitely an acceleration late in the quarter in \u2013 particularly in middle market and to a lesser extent us in business banking.

"
column1005:
"

Great. And another question actually Paul
column1006: obviously the banking industry has to live by a number of regulations that are dictated by the regulators on capital
column1009: coming back to that operational risk capital number you gave us for businesses that you have exited and no longer are operating in
column1010: is that an opinion that the Fed has just laid upon all the banks or is that actually in statutes where \u2013 to change it would require a lot of work versus if it\u2019s just the Fed wants to do that to make it extra conservative
column1011:
maybe a new change in the Fed could maybe give you guys some relief there?

"
column1013:
"

Yes. So we have $500 billion of operational is RWA. I think our closest competitor has $400 billion. And then I think Citi is probably at $300 billion something. So we were given more by the regulators based upon the history of the bank
column1015: the losses that were historical. But as you know
column1016: we have exited a lot of those products. We \u2013 Bank of America never had a risk profile. It was more the companies that we acquired
column1017: so it\u2019s a little bit arbitrary. There are models out there for calculating operational risk capital. Those models
column1018:
there is lot of debate if you follow the Basel Committee process. So we are focused on trying to get that number down. But it\u2019s going to take a little while and we are going to need more clarity from the regulators on how they want to calculate a company\u2019s operational risk capital. But that\u2019s something that would be very helpful to us if new models were approved that were a little bit more rational in terms of looking at historical losses versus the current operations of a company.

"
column1020:
"

And then just finally. I think in your K
column1021: you put your DTA from last year
column1022: it might have been around $25 billion for the deferred tax asset
column1023:
do you have an estimate yet for where it will stand at the end of \u201816?

"
column1028: but I think it will be $19 billion. But let me give you the number that kind of matters probably is what you are \u2013 if you are thinking about the future. I mean we are not here sitting predicting any tax change
column1029: but what really matters if there is to U.S. tax change in the U.S. is
column1031: we had over $20 billion of U.S. profits
column1033: that\u2019s an important number. And then the other number that\u2019s important is
column1035:
our DTAs that would be re-priced if the tax rate changed equaled approximately $7 billion.

"
column1039:
"

Thank you. Alright. So that was the last question. Let me close by closing up \u201816. We had 13% increase in net income for the year
column1040: 15% EPS. We had a good operating leverage
column1041: with 1% revenue growth and 5% expense growth. And we announced today that we increased our stock repurchase program another $1.8 billion. So that closes off a good year. As we look forward to 2017
column1042: we will just continue to do what we told you we are doing: focus responsible growth and we look forward to the benefits of a faster growing economy potentially and the increasing rates. So
column1043:
thank you for your time and we forward to next time.

"
column1045:
"

This will conclude today\u2019s program. Thanks for your participation. You may now disconnect. Have a great weekend.

{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q2 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan \u2013 President and CEO

"
column8:
"

Bruce Thompson \u2013 CFO

"
column18:
"

Paul Miller \u2013 FBR Capital Markets

"
column27: everyone
column28:
and welcome to today\u2019s program. (Operator instructions) It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead sir.

"
column29:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column31:
"

Good morning
column32: thanks everybody on the phone as well as the webcast for joining us this morning for our second quarter results. Before I turn the call over to Brian and Bruce
column33: let me just remind you we may make some forward-looking statements today. For further information on those
column34: please refer to either our earnings release documents
column35:
our website or the other SEC filings.

"
column36:
"

So with that I\u2019ll turn it over to Brian Moynihan our CEO for some opening comments before he goes to Bruce.

"
column37:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column40: Lee
column41: and good morning everyone
column42: and thank you for joining us. As you look at our results
column43: you can see the storyline for this quarter is much the same as it was for last quarter. You can see that the revenue is showing stability in most of the core businesses. You can see the good core expense control
column44: continued credit improvements
column45:
and solid business activity throughout the franchise.

"
column46:
"

You can also see obviously the litigation expense from our legacy mortgage issues continued to affect our earnings this quarter. And you can also see we\u2019ve continued to build our strong balance sheet position and capital and liquidity. So in a minute
column47:
Bruce will take you through the details of the results.

"
column48:
"

But I thought it would be good if we spend a couple of minutes at the outset here talking about what our customer and client data is telling us about the economy and what we see in our franchise.

"
column49:
"

As we all know the economy is off to a little bit of a slow start this year
column50:
but growth has picked up recently. Most recent jobs data shows nearly 1.4 million are created in the first half of this year.

"
column51:
"

As we have strong positions
column52: leadership positions across consumer and commercial companies in the Americas
column53: we have a view into the key indicators of an improving economy which shows signs everywhere of improvement. Even in advance with the short-term interest rate is changing which would help our rich consumer \u2013 our deposit rich consumer and business banking segments
column54:
our consumer business had another good quarter. It performed well growing earnings 29% from last year included solid origination activities across the various products.

"
column55:
"

In addition
column56: as we look at our underlying consumers
column57:
they have increased their spending. We can see in our data that the retail volumes on debit and credit cards were up 4% from last year\u2019s second quarter but more importantly up 8% from the first quarter of this year showing increased momentum in spending among our card customers.

"
column58:
"

Consumers are growing card balances also
column59: they\u2019re borrowing a little bit more and they continue to add to their deposit balances. As you know
column60: home sales continue to improve across the industry and we can see on our own results
column61: as our originations and mortgages increased from first to second quarter
column62:
but importantly our purchase mortgage origination continue to grow. Our home equity originations also were up almost 30% for the quarter.

"
column63:
"

When you look at the underlying transactional activity and volume activity in our stores
column64: 7 to 8 million visitors come in each week showing continuous strong activity. We can also see that in our online activity where 30 million online customers continue to grow their overall volumes and importantly in our mobile activity where 15.5 million mobile customers continue to increase the use of technology including depositing 10% of all the checks
column65:
retail checks in our company through their mobile phones and other devices.

"
column66:
"

The health of the consumer is also evident in our asset quality. Delinquencies continue to improve. Our consumer card loss rate ended the quarter at less than 3%. We see on the wealth management side
column67: the consumer
column68:
the market\u2019s growth has added to consumer wealth. We have nearly $2.5 trillion in client balances in our global wealth and investment management business including a $100 billion in the brokerage assets for their retail and preferred customer base in our consumer business.

"
column69:
"

We also see encouraging signs throughout our commercial customers. Commercial construction has improved and manufacturing activity in our clients has accelerated. The borrowing by our commercial customers remains healthy across the industry and credit quality is very strong.

"
column70:
"

Encouraging is that middle-market utilization rates are moving forward again this quarter ever so slightly. Industry sales and trading activity among our trading counterparties has been low as many of our peers have talked about in this low volatility environment.

"
column71:
"

However
column72:
our business \u2013 underlying business performed well. Tom Montag and his team had - our global markets business posted $1 billion - $1.1 billion in earnings for the quarter. Our investment banking pipeline remains strong and the back half of 2014 looks healthy.

"
column73:
"

While the economy still faces challenges
column74: progress is being made throughout the economy but also throughout our company. We are seeing good business activity and a strengthening as we go through 2014. We are seeing improved financial health for our consumers
column75:
our customers and our corporate customers.

"
column76:
"

But the most important thing to think about is the signs of a gradually improving economy
column77:
is how our businesses is continually positioned to take advantage of the activity and deliver for you our shareholders.

"
column78:
"

With that I\u2019ll turn it over to Bruce.

"
column79:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column80:
"

"
column81:
"

Great
column82: thanks
column83: Brian
column84:
and good morning everyone. Let\u2019s start on slide 2 and work through the second quarter results. We recorded earnings of $2.3 billion or $0.19 per diluted share this quarter which included pretax litigation expense of $4 billion which equated to roughly $0.22 a share after-tax. $3.8 billion of the litigation expense is associated with the build in reserves for previously disclosed legacy mortgage related matters which also included the AIG settlement that we announced this morning.

"
column85:
"

We are very pleased to have reached the definitive agreement with AIG which resolves all outstanding RMBS litigations between the parties for a settlement amount of $650 million. This agreement is important for two primary reasons.

"
column86:
"

First
column87:
we have now resolved 95% of the unpaid balance of all RMBS as to which securities litigation has either been filed or threatened for all Bank of America related entities. It also includes AIG\u2019s agreement to withdraw as an objector to the Bank of New York Mellon private label securities settlement referred to as the Article 77 proceeding.

"
column88:
"

Revenues this quarter
column89: on an FTE basis were $22 billion
column90: relative to the second quarter of 2013 revenue was down $990 million driven by lower net interest income and mortgage banking income. Relative to the first quarter of 2014
column91: it was approximately $800 million lower as higher investment banking fees
column92: higher mortgage banking revenue was more than offset by seasonally lower sales and trading revenue
column93:
as well as lower equity investment income.

"
column94:
"

Total non-interest expense for the quarter was $18.5 billion
column95: but included $4 billion of litigation expense. If we back out that litigation expense and compare it to Q2 2013\u2019s expenses
column96: expenses improved by $1 billion or 6%
column97: which was driven by lower LAS non-litigation expenses and to a lesser extent
column98:
our new BAC savings.

"
column99:
"

If we back out the $1 billion of retirement-eligible incentive comp from our first quarter results as well
column100: you can see expenses declined roughly $700 million from the first quarter as a result of lower revenue-related compensation within our global markets business
column101: lower LAS expenses ex litigation and to a lesser degree
column102:
our new BAC savings.

"
column103:
"

Provision for credit losses was $411 million with net charge-offs of $1.1 billion and a reserve release of $662 million during the quarter. Our results from the quarter also benefited from the sale of $2.1 billion in non-performing residential loans.

"
column104:
"

The income statement benefit from that sale was approximately $350 million of pre-tax or $0.02 a share after-tax and you saw roughly a $150 million of that benefit flows through other income and the balance through the recovery of net charge-offs.

"
column105:
"

And lastly
column106: the aggregate amount of a few other items including debt securities gains
column107: equity investment income
column108: net DVA
column109:
as well as FAS 91 resulted in a benefit to EPS of approximately $0.04 a share.

"
column110:
"

If we move to Slide 3 and look at our balance sheet highlights
column111:
you can see the balance sheet increased $21 billion from the first quarter of 2014. Our debt securities increased as a result of valuations and increases to highly liquid securities in our primary banking subsidiaries. Our Repo match book increased as well.

"
column112:
"

If we look at ending loans
column113: they were down $4.3 billion
column114: primarily due to lower residential mortgages
column115:
principally within our discretionary portfolios and that also included the $2.1 billion bulk sale that I just mentioned.

"
column116:
"

If we exclude residential mortgage loans

our consumer loans rose slightly as our US card balances grew $1.3 billion and our securities-based lending with our wealth management clients increased $1.8 billion. This was partially offset by pay-downs within our home equity book.

column120:
as well as a focus on overall relationship returns.

column121:

Period end deposits were over $1.1 trillion and reached record levels. Our tangible common equity ratio improved 14 basis points from the first quarter of 2014 to 7.14%. Tangible book value per share was $14.24
column122: a 3% improvement from the first quarter and it was driven by both our earnings during the quarter
column123:
as well as a $2.3 billion increase in the value of our debt securities which you saw flow through OCI.

"
column124:
"

Lastly
column125: to further enhance our Tier-1 capital structure
column126: during the second quarter
column127: we received shareholder approval and amended the Series T preferred shares
column128: which increased our Tier-1 capital by $2.9 billion
column129:
and we issued $1.5 billion in preferred stock during the quarter at a favorable rate.

"

"

On Slide 4

column132: our CET1 capital was $153.6 billion
column133: risk weighted assets $1.28 trillion
column134: and that resulted in a ratio of 12%. If we look at our Basel 3 regulatory capital ratios on a fully phased-in basis

column136: OCI improvement
column137:
as well as well as lower threshold deductions.

column138:
"

The numbers in the chart reflects risk weighted assets under the standardized approach with our CET1 ratio improving from 9% to 9.5%
column139: well above our 8.5%
column140: 2019 proposed minimum requirement. Under the advanced approach
column141: our CET 1 ratio improved from 9.6% at the end of the first quarter of 2014 to 9.9%. That was driven by the improvement in our capital
column142:
partially offset by an increase in risk-weighted assets.

"
column143:
"

If we turn to the supplementary leverage ratios
column144: we estimate that at the end of the second quarter of 2014
column145:
we exceeded the updated US rules that are applicable beginning in 2018.

"
column146:
"

Our bank holding company exceeds the 5% minimum and our primary bank subsidiaries
column147:
BANA and FIA are both in excess of the 6% minimum.

"
column148:
"

If we turn to Slide 5 on funding and liquidity
column149: our long-term debt of $257 billion was up modestly during the quarter as our debt issuances were larger than maturities during the period. As we look forward at our debt issuance during the balance of the year
column150:
we\u2019ll continue to be opportunistic but we do expect our parent issuance to be below the $13 billion of contractual maturities in the second half of 2014.

"
column151:
"

We\u2019ll also likely to continue to issue term debt out of our primary bank subsidiaries. Our second quarter 2014 long-term debt yields improved 12 basis points from the first quarter of 2014 2.29%. We realized significant improvements given only two years ago this yield was over 3% and our average debt balances were nearly $75 billion higher.

"
column152:
"

Our total global excess liquidity sources during the quarter increased to a record $431 billion as bank liquidity continue to grow in the second quarter and our time to required funding remained strong at 38 months.

"
column153:
"

If we turn to Slide 6
column154: our net interest income on a reported FTE basis was $10.2 billion
column155: consistent with the first quarter of 2014 is a less negative impact from market-related adjustments was offset by an anticipated decline in the core net interest income. Negatively impacting our reported net interest income during the quarter were market-related adjustments of $175 million and that compares to $273 million negative in the first quarter of 2014
column156: as you all know
column157:
long-term rates declined again during the quarter.

"
column158:
"

Our net interest income
column159: if we exclude the market-related adjustments declined as previously expected and communicated
column160:
due to seasonally lower average consumer loan balances and yields offset by an extra day of interest and all of that resulted in net interest income of $10.4 billion.

"
column161:
"

As a result of the increased liquidity in the first half of the year
column162: as well as lower loan balances and loan yields
column163:
the net interest yield excluding market-related adjustments declined 10 basis points to 2.26%.

"
column164:
"

We continue to thoughtfully manage our OCI sensitivity and are very mindful of the liquidity and leverage rules as this quarter we invested more into shorter duration treasury securities. We continue to remain positioned to benefit if interest rates move higher
column165:
particularly from the shorter end of the curve.

"
column166:
"

And as we head into the back half of 2014
column167: we still expect modest improvement off of the second quarter of 2014 level of net interest income
column168: which was $10.4 billion
column169:
excluding market-related adjustments.

"
column170:
"

Non-interest expense on Slide 7 was $18.5 billion during the second quarter and once again included $4 billion of litigation expense. As we mentioned
column171: $3.8 billion of the litigation expense relate to a build in reserves associated with previously disclosed legacy mortgage related matters including the AIG agreement. If we exclude litigation
column172:
total expenses were $14.6 billion this quarter.

"
column173:
"

If we compare those to the first quarter of 2014 and exclude retirement eligible costs that we saw during the first quarter of 2014
column174: our expenses declined $700 million on the lower incentives related to sales and trading revenue
column175:
reduced LAS non-litigation expense and to a lesser extent New BAC savings.

"
column176:
"

Our legacy assets and servicing expenses during the quarter ex litigation were $1.4 billion and declined approximately $150 million from the first quarter of 2014. As we look forward with respect to our two expense programs
column177: New BAC as well as our LAS expenses ex litigation
column178:
we have modified our expectations slightly.

"
column179:
"

Our New BAC expense program is ahead of schedule and we now expect to reach a quarterly level of $2 billion in expense savings in the fourth quarter of 2014 as opposed to mid 2015. This means on an annualized basis
column180: we will have fully achieved the $8 billion target that we announced in 2011. In the second quarter of 2014
column181:
our quarterly savings rate that was achieved on New BAC was $1.8 billion plus.

"
column182:
"

Moving to our LAS expenses ex litigation
column183: we continue to make very good progress
column184:
but our compliance with applicable mortgage programs as well as governance guidelines may delay the expected timing of achieving our $1.1 billion goal by one quarter.

"
column185:
"

If we turn to asset quality on Slide 8
column186:
you can see credit quality once again improved on all fronts. Net charge-offs declined $315 million from the first quarter of 2014 to $1.1 billion or a 48 basis points net loss ratio.

"
column187:
"

As I mentioned earlier
column188: this quarter did include a $2.1 billion sales of bulk non-performing loans
column189: which included recoveries of $185 million on previously recorded net charge-offs. If we exclude the effect of the bulk sale net charge-offs
column190:
they\u2019ve declined a $130 million or 9% and the net loss ratio would have been at 56 basis points. These are decade level loans.

"
column191:
"

Delinquencies
column192: a leading indicator of net charge-offs also showed improvement during the second quarter. Provision expense during the quarter was $411 and we released $662 million of reserves. We would expect net charge-offs going forward to continue to show modest improvement from the second quarter of 2014 levels of $1.3 billion
column193:
which excluded the recoveries that we received on the non-performing loan sales. We would also expect reserve releases to decline modestly through the balance of 2014.

"
column194:
"

Let\u2019s walk through the business segment results now starting on Slide 9 with consumer and business banking. We continue to make solid progress on the strategy in this business through deepening relationships and reducing our costs by optimizing the delivery network. We are simplifying the product set as we reduce the number of offers
column195:
offerings and focus the smaller product sets on customer feedback and offer greater rewards to customers who bring us more of their relationships.

"
column196:
"

Some of the more significant operational activity during the quarter included the rollout of an advanced platform for mobile banking that had added functionality
column197: rolling out the safe balance checking account
column198:
as well as an enhanced preferred rewards program that we launched after a successful pilot program. We are pleased with the results again this quarter as our earnings of $1.8 billion grew $29% from the second quarter of 2013 and were up 7% from the first quarter of 2014.

"
column199:
"

This business generated a 24% return on allocated capital during the quarter. Our revenue was relatively stable across the periods as lower net interest income was partially offset by higher service charges. Our expenses are down 4% from the second quarter of 2013 and lower operating
column200:
litigation and personnel costs. Our network delivery optimization benefit continued as we reduced another 72 banking centers through both sales as well as consolidations.

"
column201:
"

Our credit quality remains strong as net charge-offs decline versus both periods. Our U.S. credit card business exited the quarter with less than a 3% loss rate in June. Second quarter provision expense was $534 million
column202:
our net charge-offs improved $313 million from the second quarter of 2013 and $36 million from the first quarter of 2014.

"
column203:
"

We released $120 million more in reserves this quarter than the second quarter of 2013 and $242 million more than the first quarter of 2014. From a customer activity perspective this quarter
column204:
we saw continued growth in our mobile banking customers which reached 15.5 million customers and our customer deposit transactions using mobile devices represented 10% of all transactions.

"
column205:
"

Our average deposits of $544 billion are up organically almost $11 billion or 2% compared to the first quarter of 2014 and up 5% or nearly $25 billion compared to the second quarter of 2013 and we did that as our rates paid on our deposits reached a new low of 6 basis points.

"
column206:
"

Our brokerage assets surpassed $105 billion and are up 26% year-over-year based on both improved market valuations as well as customer flows. Our card issuance remained strong at 1.1 million new accounts in the second quarter of 2014 with approximately two-thirds of those cards going to existing customers.

"
column207:
"

We saw growth in ending U.S. credit card balances this period with ending balances up $1.3 billion relative to the first quarter of 2014 and our risk-adjusted margin remains strong at approximately 9%. If you move to consumer real estate services
column208:
the loss in the quarter was driven by $3.8 billion of litigation expense.

"
column209:
"

Overall
column210: we saw higher originations
column211: improved mortgage banking revenues
column212:
and lower cost in both the fulfillment as well as the servicing sides of the business. Let\u2019s focus first on the reported sub-segments of home loans where we record the origination of consumer real estates.

"
column213:
"

Our home loans saw better leverage versus the first quarter of 2014 as both revenues and expenses improved. Our first mortgage retail origination were $11.1 billion and were up 25% from the first quarter of 2015 leading to higher core production revenues. As Brian mentioned
column214:
our mix of originations continued to shift to purchase as we are now at 47% purchased versus 17% in the year ago quarter.

"
column215:
"

At the end of the quarter

column217:
but our applications per day are slowing a bit. Our home equity originations were $2.6 billion and increased 31% from the first quarter of 2014. We continued to reduce production staffing levels and the savings from several quarters of these reductions are beginning to show in our expense levels.

column218:

If we move to the legacy assets and servicing sub-segment

column221: 000 units to 263
column222:
000 units or down 5% from the end of the first quarter of 2014.

"
column223:
"

The primary revenue component in our LAS sub-segment servicing fees declined $40 million versus the first quarter as the size of our servicing portfolios declined. This was offset by a better net hedge performance on our MSRs. Also during the quarter
column224:
we did benefit from lower rep and warrant provisions which was $87 million or down nearly $100 million from the first quarter of 2014.

"
column225:
"

If we turn to Slide 11
column226: global wealth and investment management
column227: this business turned in another record revenue quarter
column228:

"
column229:
"

Record asset management fees offset the softness in transactional activity. Net income
column230: $724 million was slightly lower than both comparative periods

column233:

column234:
"

Relative to the first quarter of 2014
column235: expenses were driven by higher revenue-related costs
column236:
litigation-related expenses as well as marketing. Our return on allocated capital during the quarter was 24%. The momentum we are seeing in flows continued and was quite strong during the quarter.

column237:

Client balances were up $72 billion from the end of the first quarter of 2014 to a record $2.5 trillion. Our ending client loan balances were up $3.9 billion to a record $123 billion
column238:
which is up 3% from the first quarter of 2014 as we saw growth in both our securities-based lending as well as our residential mortgage lending.

column241:
"

column242: our global banking earnings for the quarter were $1.4 billion
column243:
up 4% from the second quarter of 2013 and up 9% over the first quarter of 2014. Our return on allocated capital was very strong at 18%.

column244:
"

Compared to the second quarter of 2013
column245: our revenue showed modest improvement while expenses increased and credit cost declined. Within the revenue category

column247: company-wide this quarter were $1.6 billion
column248:
up 5% from the second quarter of 2013 and up 6% on a linked quarter basis. We maintained a solid leadership position in investment banking fees and we had particularly strong equity underwriting results during the quarter.

"
column249:

Our provision was $132 million during the quarter and included a $156 million reserve build. Our provision costs were favorable to both comparative periods as we added less reserves in the first quarter of 2014 and had less charge-offs compared to the second quarter of 2013.

column250:

Expenses increased $50 million versus the second quarter of 2013 on higher litigation

column254: up 6% compared to the second quarter of 2013

column256: but I\u2019d like to make the first is
column257:
we saw sizable pay-downs during the quarter as our customers accessed the capital markets. We had approximately $2 billion of such pay-downs where our customers chose access to markets and refinanced existing bank loans.

column258:
"

Within commercial real estate
column259: we continued to optimize the mix with several small portfolio sales that took those balances down
column260:

"

And lastly within the global banking segment
column262:

If we move to global markets on Slide 13
column264: we earned $1.1 billion in the second quarter of 2014
column265:
that\u2019s up 14% from the year ago period and down seasonally 16% from the seasonally strong period of the first quarter. Net DVAs during the quarter was a gain of $69 million versus gains of $49 million in the second quarter of 2013 and a $112 million in the first quarter of 2014.

column266:

Despite the slowdown in FICC across the industry group

column268:
but down 9% from the seasonally high first quarter of 2014. Our second quarter of 2014 revenue did include an equity gain of roughly $240 million on the modernization of an equity investment. That is not reflected as part of our sales and trading revenues. Our sales and trading revenue net of DVA was $3.4 billion which was 1% lower than the second quarter of 2013 and 17% lower than the first quarter of 2014. Our FICC sales and trading revenue during the quarter increased 5% compared to the second quarter of 2013 and was down 20% from the seasonally higher first quarter of 2014 levels.

"
column269:
"

Driving the year-over-year improvement within fixed were results in our mortgage business
column270: our munis business
column271:
as trading conditions and our performance improved in both areas. Those improvements were partially offset by weaker financial performance in foreign exchange as well as commodities.

"
column272:
"

On the equity sales and trading side
column273: we were down 14% from the second quarter of 2013 and 11% from the first quarter of 2014 as lower market volatility depressed overall secondary market client activity. Expenses were up from the second quarter of 2013 on higher technology and staff support investments and to a lesser degree incentives
column274:
but down from the first quarter of 2014 in line with the seasonal revenue decline that we saw.

"
column275:
"

Trading-related assets on average increased $23 billion to $460 billion during the quarter and our return on allocated capital was 13% during the second quarter.

"
column276:
"

On Slide 14
column277:
we show all other; revenue was down $463 million from the first quarter of 2014 and lower equity investment gains of $618 million which were partially offset by lower negative market-related adjustments to net interest income during the quarter.

"
column278:
"

Our second quarter 2014 expense and all other is down $1.3 billion from the first quarter as it included retirement eligible incentive costs and some litigation expense. The second quarter of 2014 provision benefit of $246 million was $111 better than the first quarter of 2014 and $67 million better than the second quarter of 2013.

"
column279:
"

Net charge-offs of $11 million improved $195 million from the first quarter of 2014 driven by the recoveries that I had mentioned associated with our bulk NPL sales.

"
column280:
"

During the quarter
column281: our effective tax rate was relatively low
column282: primarily as a result of the impact of tax preference items on a lower earnings base. For the back half of 2014
column283:
we would expect to see an effective tax rate of approximately 31% ex any unusual items.

"
column284:
"

I am going to wrap up before we take questions with a couple closing comments. We feel like we made very strong progress during the quarter. We saw good business activity across the customer base. We experienced year-over-year revenue growth in our global banking
column285:
global markets and global wealth management businesses.

"
column286:
"

Our consumer business profitability grew 29% from last year and in the mortgage business we are taking cost out of the fulfillment side as well as the cost to service our delinquent loans. We reported $0.19 of earnings and absorbed cost allowing us to resolve all outstanding RMBS issues with AIG and build substantial reserves for our remaining legacy mortgage issues.

"
column287:
"

We did this while adding to our already strong Basel 3 capital ratios and improving our liquidity measures to record levels and our asset quality improved to decade low loss ratios. And with that

we\u2019ll go ahead and open it up for questions.

column1248: we can\u2019t discuss that and you get a rendition of all the different criteria that people written about. I think this quarter we are able to put away the AIG case
column1249:
which if you remember was back in 2011 lot of the people said it was worth a lot more money for $650 million. So we will continue to figure out where we get behind us a reasonable cost for our shareholders. We just can\u2019t talk about details on this.

"
column1254: good job with the AIG. I was one of those people who thought it was going to be more
column1255:
and it wasn't. But that's fine. I will take any guidance I can get on the legal costs ahead. Thanks a lot.

"
column1262:
"

And we\u2019ll take our last question from David Hilder with Drexel Hamilton
column1266:
"

Thanks. Most of my questions have been answered. Just on the AIG settlement
column1267: I actually thought AIG was the only remaining objector
column1271:
"

There are several other objectors that had not been as vocal and as I said
column1272:
we\u2019ll have to see where it goes with that dropping out.

"
column1275:
"

And AIG has agreed to dismiss all its claims or its objections
column1281:
it\u2019s part of the settlement agreement.

"
column1289:
I think we are through all the questions. So thanks a lot for joining us and we look forward to talking next quarter.

"
column1295:
"

This does conclude today\u2019s conference. You may now disconnect and have a wonderful day.

"
column1296:

column1:
{"Bank of America's (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Q3 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC)

"
column2:
"

Q3 2014 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column7:
"

Brian Moynihan - Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

Bruce Thompson - Chief Financial Officer

"
column21:
"

Paul Miller - FBR Capital Markets

"
column27:
"

Good day
column28: everyone. And welcome to today\u2019s program. At this time
column29:
all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later you\u2019ll have the opportunity to ask questions during the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions). Please note this call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance.

"
column30:
"

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Lee McEntire. Please go ahead
column31:
sir.

"
column32:
"

Lee McEntire

"
column33:
"

Good morning. Thanks everybody on the phone as well as the webcast for joining us this morning for our third quarter results. Hopefully you\u2019ve had a chance to review the earnings release documents available on our website.

"
column34:
"

Before I turn the call over to Brian and Bruce
column35: let me just remind you
column36: we may make some forward-looking statements today. For further information on those
column37: please refer to either our earnings release documents
column38:
our website or our other SEC filings.

"
column40: let me turn it over to Brian Moynihan
column41:
our CEO for some opening comments before Bruce goes through the details.

"
column42:
"

Brian Moynihan

"
column43:
"

Thanks
column44: Lee
column45: and good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us to review our third quarter results. As you know
column46: our bottom-line results were heavily impacted by previously announced settlement with Department of Justice. But given that
column47:
I\u2019m still encouraged by what we accomplished this quarter. Our business has generated enough earnings to absorb the $5.3 billion charge and still reported positive net income before preferred dividends.

"
column48:
"

Now
column49:
the themes that we see are consistent with the past several quarters. You can see in our numbers a prudent balance sheet management; you can see in the numbers good core expense control; you can see in the numbers continued credit improvement and you can see in the numbers solid business activity.

"
column50:
"

Before Bruce takes you through the detail of the quarter
column51: I thought I\u2019d focus quickly on the profitability of our business segments and some of the key statistics that give rise thereto. If you look
column52: we\u2019ve included in the appendix the materials on pages 18 and 20 some information about net income
column53:
PPNR and business statistics.

"
column54:
"

So you step back and look
column55: you can see from our release
column56:
the company reported $2.9 billion in year-to-date pretax net income that includes and overcomes 15.6 billion in pretax litigation costs to resolve primarily legacy mortgage issues.

"
column57:
"

Now we\u2019re not suggesting that we want to incur litigation cost going forward but what this demonstrates is how much progress we\u2019ve made behind the noise of significant legal settlements. So you step back and think about the businesses
column58:
you can see on appendix slide 18 a graphic showing year-to-date net income comparative performance by the businesses.

"
column59:
"

Let\u2019s first focus on our Consumer and Business Banking segment. Year-to-date net income was $5.3 billion in 2014. That compares to $4.6 billion after tax in 2013. The return on average allocated capital in Consumer & Business Banking was 24%. It is our largest business and it\u2019s had a good year. Our Global Wealth and Investment Management business had net income of year-to-date of $2.3 billion in 2014 that\u2019s up 3% from 2013. Now this business
column60:
our GWIM business has a pretax margin of 26% and has returns on allocated capital of 25%.

"
column61:
"

As we move to our Global Banking business
column62: that\u2019s the business provides lending
column63: treasury services
column64: investment banking activities to middle markets and large corporate clients around the world. That business earned $4 billion after tax so far this year
column65:
up 8% from 2013 and generated returns on allocated capital of 17%. Those three businesses together have great annuity streams and hold us in good state as we look forward.

"
column66:
"

Our Global Markets business which obviously is more affected by what\u2019s going on in the market on the given quarter has earned $2.9 billion after tax this year and for the first nine months versus $2.7 billion in 2013 when you adjust for DVA and in 2013 you exclude the UK tax changes.

"
column67:
"

So in total
column68: these four businesses generated $14.5 billion net income after-tax for the first nine months of 2014. That $14.5 billion is up 10% from last year. You can look on slide 19 and you can see on a pretax pre-provision basis which some of you also focus on
column69:
we are 4% year-over-year. And you can see on pages 20 and 21 the business statistics over the last couple of years which give rise to these results.

"
column70:
"

We\u2019ve made real progress in the four businesses and we continue to work on the Consumer Real Estate segment and losses therein. But that real progress shows in the operating leverage profitability of these businesses and we expect that momentum to continue as we move the other side of the mortgage issues.

"
column71:
"

With that
column72:
I'll turn it over to Bruce.

"
column73:
"

Bruce Thompson

"
column74:
"

Thanks Brian and good morning everyone. This quarter does reflect what we believe is very solid execution and a lot of what we\u2019ve been consistently talking with all of you about. We maintained a strong balance sheet as a foundation to operate from. We continued to rationalize our balance sheet for liquidity
column75: profitability as well as evolving regulatory changes. Our revenue has shown relative stability and our non-litigation expenses continue to be reduced. Charge-offs have continued to come down
column76:
and we resolved significant legacy mortgage exposures during the quarter.

"
column77:
"

Let's start on slide two and go through the details. We recorded a $168 million of earnings in the third quarter and after preferred dividends that resulted in a loss of a penny per share. Earnings included the $5.3 billion pretax income -- or pretax impact
column78: excuse me of the settlement with the Department of Justice in various state attorneys general that we announced in August. On an EPS basis
column79: the impact was $0.43 a share
column80:
as a portion this charge was not tax deductable.

"
column81:
"

As you can see on the right hand side of slide two
column82:
the $5.3 billion impact was split between $4.9 billion in litigation expense and $400 million in provision expense that relate to additional reserves that are associated with a consumer relief portion of this settlement.

"
column83:
"

Revenue during the quarter on an FTE basis was $21.4 billion versus $21.7 billion in the year ago quarter. If we exclude the DVA impact from both periods as well as the $1.2 billion of equity investment income that we recorded during the third quarter of \u201813 that was driven by gains from our CCB investment
column84:
adjusted revenue of $21.2 billion was up slightly from the third quarter of 2013.

"
column85:
"

On a segment view
column86: revenue was stable to modestly up in four of our five businesses from last year with CRES being the exception. Relative to the second quarter of 2014
column87: revenue was 3% lower driven by the lack of equity investment gains
column88:
seasonally lower investment banking fees and lower mortgage banking revenue.

"
column89:
"

Total non-interest expense was $19.7 billion which included $5.6 billion in total litigation expense. We back out litigation expense; compared to the second quarter of 2014
column90: expenses declined roughly $400 million from both our New BAC and our ALS cost initiatives as well as lower revenue related incentives. On the same basis
column91: looking back to the third quarter of 2013
column92:
expenses improved by $1.1 billion or 7% which were driven by reduced LAS costs and to a lesser degree our New BAC cost savings.

"
column93:
"

Provision for credit losses during the quarter was $636 million and included $400 million
column94: as I mentioned for the DoJ Settlement
column95: while our net charge-offs were $1 billion. Our results during the quarter did benefit from roughly $200 million in DVA or about a penny per share as our debt spread widened during the end of the quarter. There was also approximately $0.04 of benefit to earnings that relate to certain discrete tax items. Lastly
column96:
the quarter also benefited by about a penny as our weighted average share count excluded the impact of diluted shares given the financial performance.

"
column97:
"

On slide three
column98: we show you all the usual balance sheet highlights that we do each quarter but we did want to focus you specifically on our efforts to rationalize the balance sheet as our actions led to a $47 billion decrease from the second quarter of 2014. We took prudent actions to increase liquidity as well as to reduce both credit and market risk. We shifted the mix of some of our discretionary assets out of less liquid loans into more liquid debt securities. For example
column99:
we converted 6.5 billion of residential mortgage loans that benefited from standby insurance agreements into agency securities. We also sold $2.5 billion of non-performing and delinquent loans during the quarter and had $4 billion of net pay downs in our legacy consumer real estate loans. We reduced our global markets balance sheet and associated funding by $11.7 billion from the second quarter of \u201814 and that included low margin prime brokerage loans of approximately $3.3 billion.

"
column100:
"

Our decline in quarter end deposits was primarily driven by optimization efforts that included the reduction of approximately 15 billion of deposits that had little to no benefit to our LCR ratio. From a capital perspective
column101: I'll remind you that we did issue 3.1 billion of preferred stock during the quarter that improved our Basel III Tier 1 regulatory capital ratio. And lastly as a reminder
column102:
we increased our quarterly common dividend to $0.05 a share during the quarter.

"
column103:
"

We move to slide four where we show our capital ratios under Basel III. Under the transition rules
column104: our CET1 ratio was stable at 12%. If we look at our Basel III regulatory capital ratios on a fully phased-in basis
column105:
you can see CET1 capital declined 1.6 billion that was driven by a $1 billion decline in OCI.

"
column106:
"

Our operational risk weighted assets did increase that negatively impacted our advanced levels but not the standard levels. Other RWA balance sheet improvements benefited both approaches and that partially offset the increase in RWA under the advanced approach. If we look at the ratios under the standardized approach
column107: CET1 improved slightly to 9.6% during the third quarter of \u201814 and under the advanced approach
column108: the CET1 ratio was also at 9.6%
column109: both well above our 8.5% 2019 proposed minimum requirements. If you look at our operational risk
column110:
risk weighted assets under the advanced approach; they now represent approximately 30% of our overall risk weighted assets.

"
column111:
"

We move to supplementary leverage. This is the first quarter that we've actually disclosed the actual ratios from a supplementary leverage perspective. The bank holding company during the third quarter was at 5.5%. And if we look at our primary banking subsidiary BANA
column112: its ratio was 6.8% which is pro forma for September 30th as we merged FIA
column113:
our card services unit into BANA on October 1st. We\u2019re obviously very pleased with the capital and supplementary leverage ratios in the context of the resolution of the DoJ matter during the quarter.

"
column114:
"

We turn to slide five
column115: feel very good about the work that the funding team did during the quarter. In addition to the $3.1 million of preferred stock issuance
column116: we issued 3 billion of Tier 2 subordinated debt
column117:
which also adds to our total capital metrics.

"
column118:
"

Lastly
column119: we issued $4.5 billion of straight debt at the parent. Our goal is not only to build the Basel III non-CET1 component of the capital stack that we thought or levels that were appropriate
column120:
but also to build liquidity in advance of the payments that we\u2019ll make during the month of October for the DoJ and state AG settlement.

"
column121:
"

Total long-term debt for the quarter ended at $250 billion
column122:
which was down $7 billion from the end of the second quarter 2014. We look at the cost of our debt; our long-term debt yields improved 10 basis points from the second quarter of \u201814 due primarily to maturities of higher yielding debt as well as issuances at more favorable levels. Global access liquidity sources remained very strong at 429 billion and our time to required funding was stable at 38 months.

"
column123:
"

We turn to slide six; net interest income on a reported FTE basis was 10.4 billion
column124:
up from the second quarter of \u201814 as we had a less negative impact from market related adjustments and that was coupled with modest improvement in our adjusted net interest income.

"
column125:
"

The market related adjustments during the quarter were a negative $55 million in the third quarter of \u201814 that compares to a negative $175 million in the second quarter of \u201814.

"
column126:
"

Net interest income of $10.5 billion excluding the market related adjustment
column127:
improved modestly as lower long-term debt balances and yield as well as an extra day of interest accruals were partially offset by lower loan balances as well as lower loan yields.

"
column128:
"

The net interest yield improved 4 basis points on an adjusted basis and 7 basis points on an actual basis. We continue to remain positioned to benefit as interest rates move higher
column129:
particularly from the short end of the curve.

"
column130:
"

Since we\u2019re largely done at this point with our debt footprint reductions
column131:
the direction as well as the trajectory of our net interest income and net interest yield will be more dependent on rates as well as balance sheet movements going forward.

"
column132:
"

And given the volatility of the rates
column133: should the opportunity present itself
column134:
we could decide to take actions to reduce OCI risk in preparation for what we will be in an eventual rising rate environment. Those actions could have a relatively small near term impact to net interest income but reduced our duration risk as well as to provide additional liquidity to reinvest in a higher rate environment.

"
column135:
"

Non-interest expense on slide seven was $19.7 billion in the third quarter of \u201814 and included $5.6 billion of litigation expense. As I previously mentioned
column136: $4.9 million of the expense related to the DoJ Settlement while the remainder was associated with the number of smaller pre-existing cases
column137:
one of which caused us to book approximately $200 million in our Global Markets business.

"
column138:
"

We exclude litigation; total expenses were $14.2 billion this quarter which declined $400 million from the second quarter of 2014 on both
column139: our New BAC as well as our LAS initiatives as well as lower revenue related incentive cost. Compared to the third quarter of \u201813
column140: expenses are $1.1 billion lower
column141:
driven by LAS cost savings. Our legacy assets and servicing cost once again ex-litigation reduced by approximately a $100 million in the quarter and remained on track to hit $1.1 billion in the first quarter of 2015.

"
column142:
"

In the third quarter
column143: we\u2019ve now reached our new BAC savings initiatives with the targeted goal of $2 billion a quarter or $8 billion on an annualized basis. So
column144: as we move forward
column145:
we believe that expenses apart from litigation as well as the continued reductions in legacy assets and servicing expenses should move more directionally with the revenue streams that we see in the businesses.

"
column146:
"

Asset quality on slide eight
column147: you can see credit quality continued to improve. Net charge-offs declined slightly from the second quarter of \u201814 to $1 million or a 46 basis-point net loss ratio
column148: a new decade low. NPL sales which I mentioned produced modest recovery in both the second quarter of \u201814 as well as the third quarter of \u201814. And if we normalize for those benefits
column149:
net charge-offs would have been $1.3 billion in the second quarter of '14 and $1.2 billion in the third quarter of '14 with the third quarter being about 8% lower.

"
column150:
"

Delinquencies
column151: a leading indicator of net charge-offs remained very low. Our third quarter provision expense was 636 million and we released 407 million of reserves
column152: given the continued pace of asset quality improvement. If we exclude the reserve that was associated with the DOJ Settlement
column153:
we released 807 million from our reserves.

"
column154:
"

Let's now focus on the businesses
column155: starting on slide nine with Consumer & Business Banking. Results again this quarter showed year-over-year improvement as our net income grew 4% to 1.9 billion and increased 3% from the second quarter of 2014. This business generated 25% return on allocated capital during the third quarter. Revenue was relatively stable at 7.5 billion compared to the third quarter of '13 and up from the second quarter of '14
column156:
led by higher card income and service charges for both comparative periods.

"
column157:
"

As you can see on the slide
column158:
Q3 provision expense was lower than the third quarter of \u201813 as net charge-offs improved and we also released less reserves. Expenses of 4 billion were stable compared to both periods as the benefits from our net book delivery optimization were offset by investments that we made in our special sales force.

"
column159:
"

With regard to the special sales force
column160: over the course of the last year
column161: we've added nearly 500 financial solutions advisors and small business bankers. Growth in mobile as well as other self-service customer touch points has allowed us to continue to reduce our banking centers where we went below 5
column162: 000 units during the quarter
column163: while at the same time
column164:
our customer satisfaction scores continued to improve and customer activity continues to build.

"
column165:
"

We look at customer activity during the quarter. We had good deposit growth and our rates paid remained very low. We experienced modest improvement in average loans on a linked quarter basis driven by activities that we saw within the U.S. consumer credit card business. Brokerage assets were up 21% year-over-year as we benefited from both improved account flows and market valuation.

"
column166:
"

Our mobile banking customers reached over 16 million during the quarter and 11% of all of our customer deposit transactions are now done through mobile devices. Card issuance remained strong at 1.2 million new accounts in the third quarter of \u201814 with 64% of those cards going to existing customers of our company. And lastly
column167:
credit quality continued to improve as our U.S. credit card loss rate fell below 3% and where we continue to see north of a 9% risk adjusted margin.

"
column168:
"

If we moved to consumer real estate services; as I mentioned
column169: the loss in the quarter was driven by the DOJ settlement
column170: which impacted expense
column171: provision
column172:
as well as income tax. Revenue was down about $300 million from the second quarter of 2014. The servicing income component of revenue was driven by an approximate $100 million charge to adjust our MSR for cost of service assumptions. And a smaller amount in our level of servicing assets did decline.

"
column173:
"

Our production revenue decline was driven by approximate $80 million increase in rep and warrant expense. First mortgage retail origination of $11.7 billion
column174: were up 6% from the second quarter of 2014. If we look at the pipeline at the end of the quarter
column175:
our first-lien origination pipeline was down 12% from the second quarter of 2014.

"
column176:
"

On the home equity front
column177: we continue to see very good demand where originations during the quarter were $3.2 million
column178:
which were up nicely on both the linked quarter and a year-over-year basis.

"
column179:
"

Expenses once again included $5.3 billion of litigation costs during the quarter versus $3.8 billion in the second quarter of 2014. If we exclude that $1.5 billion increase in litigation cost
column180:
expenses declined a $117 million.

"
column181:
"

Our LAS expense for the quarter was just over $1.3 billion and once again remains on track to hit $1.1 billion in the first quarter of 2015. Our number of 60 plus day delinquent loans of $221
column182: 000 that are serviced by LAS dropped $42
column183: 000 or 16% from the end of the second quarter of \u201814. In addition
column184:
we continue to reduce our production staffing levels in line with the market opportunity as we continue to lower our fulfillment cost.

"
column185:
"

On slide 11
column186: global wealth and investment management delivered another strong quarter
column187: where we saw both record revenues
column188: as well as record earnings. Pre-tax margins remained strong
column189:
north of 25% for the 7th consecutive quarter.

"
column190:
"

Record asset management fees drove revenue higher
column191: but were offset by some softness in transactional activity
column192:
although I do want to mention that we did see transactional activity pickup during the month of September.

"
column193:
"

Net income of $830 million was up 12% on a linked quarter basis as the business continues to focus on operating leverage and drop the revenue growth to the bottom-line. We increased the number of financial advisors and year-to-date the retention of our more experienced advisors remains at record levels.

"
column194:
"

Client balances were nearly $2.5 trillion with negative market valuation mostly offset by positive flows that we saw during the quarter. Long-term AUM flows were $11.2 billion during the quarter
column195:
the 21st consecutive quarter of positive flows. Ending client loan balances also increased to a record level from the second quarter of \u201814 as we see good activity in both securities-based and residential mortgage lending. And return on allocated capital in this segment was 27% during the quarter.

"
column196:
"

If you turn to slide 12
column197: global banking earnings were $1.4 billion
column198: which is up 24% from the third quarter of \u201813 on both on lower credit cost and to a lesser degree higher revenue. Compared to the second quarter of \u201814
column199: earnings were up on lower credit costs
column200:
which were slightly offset by seasonally lower investment banking fees.

"
column201:
"

Return on allocated capital during the quarter was strong at 18%. Within the revenue line item
column202: investment banking fees for the company this quarter were $1.4 billion
column203: which is up 4% from the year ago quarter
column204: but down seasonally from the second quarter of 2014. Our overall investment banking pipeline does remained very strong
column205: but I do want to note that our fourth quarter of \u201813 was a record quarter from an investment banking fee perspective. Provision during the quarter was a slight benefit
column206:
which reflected continued low loss rates and a small reserve release.

"
column207:
"

If we look at the balance sheet
column208: average loans were $267 billion
column209: which is up 3% compared to the year ago period
column210:
but which has slowed over the past couple of quarters as we continue to focus on client profitability. We've also seen some significant prepayments from some of our larger corporate banking clients during the last couple of quarters.

"
column211:
"

Although our average deposits during the quarter did increase
column212: our end of period balances declined. And that's due as I mentioned earlier
column213:
that we intentionally managed down certain deposits which have a little LCR benefit.

"
column214:
"

If we move to Global Markets on slide 13
column215: we earned $769 million during the third quarter of 2014. To put the third quarter of \u201814 on a like basis to the third quarter of \u201813
column216: you should exclude a $1.1 billion impact from the UK tax rate change that we saw in the third quarter of \u201813
column217: as well as the impact of DVA for both periods. Once again DVA this quarter was a benefit of $205 million versus a decrement of $444 million last year. If we make those adjustments
column218:
we saw very strong growth in earnings of 21% on a year-over-year basis.

"
column219:
"

Earnings are down from the second quarter of \u201814 as a result of the typical seasonal declines in sales and trading
column220:
as well as higher litigation expense during the third quarter of \u201814 within this segment.

"
column221:
"

If we back out DVA
column222: revenue is up 7% from the year ago period driven by strong sales and trading results. We're pleased to report both FICC and equity sales and trading revenues were up versus the year ago period. FICC revenues were up 11%. The improvement was driven by results and currencies given the increased volatility that we saw during the month of September
column223:
as well as improved performance in both our mortgages and our commodities areas.

"
column224:
"

Equity sales and trading was up as well
column225: up 6% from the third quarter of \u201813 driven by a higher client financing revenues. On the expense front
column226: they were up 2% year-over-year driven by higher revenue-related incentives. Relative to the second quarter
column227: expenses were up $70 million from the second quarter due to higher litigation expense. If we back out the $200 million litigation expense during the quarter
column228:
expenses declined by about $130 million in line with the lower revenue levels on a linked quarter basis.

"
column229:
"

Average trading-related assets were down about $13 billion from the second quarter of \u201814 and our overall bar remains very low. Return on allocated capital during the quarter was 9%.

"
column230:
"

On slide 14
column231: we show all other. Our non-interest revenue during the quarter was down on a year-over-year basis as we had $1.1 billion of equity investment gains in the third quarter of \u201813 and during the third quarter of \u201814
column232:
we had a $300 million charge for UK payment protection insurance.

"
column233:
"

Expenses on a year-over-year basis are down about $400 million due to lower litigation expense and all other
column234:
as well as lower personnel costs. Income tax expense is included within all other is the benefit related to discrete items that I mentioned earlier are largely reflected in this segment.

"
column235:
"

As we look at the fourth quarter of this year
column236: we'd expect the tax rate to be roughly 31%
column237:
absent any unusual items during the quarter.

"
column238:
"

So before we open it up for questions
column239: I'd like to summarize the quarter. We feel we made once again very good progress during the quarter. We saw good business activity across the customer footprint. This led to year-over-year earnings improvements in four out of the five businesses. And then in our mortgage business
column240:
we're taking cost out of the legacy assets and servicing side and have taken cost out of the fulfillment side as well.

"
column241:
"

We generated enough earnings during the quarter from the businesses to offset a significant charge to settle our RMBS issues with the DOJ and RMBS working group. And at the same time maintain a very strong capital position. Asset quality continued its trend of improvement. And we did take some delivered balance sheet actions to improve liquidity
column242:
manage OCI risk and reduce both credit and market risk.

"
